HEADLINE: Unlikely Union Arises To Press Family Issues

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
An unusual alliance of conservative Republicans and liberal and moderate Democrats is pressing the Federal Government to adopt policies that members say will reverse the decline and breakup of American families.
On the one hand, the coalition includes lawmakers like Representative Patricia Schroeder, a Colorado Democrat who is one of the more liberal members of Congress, and groups like the Progressive Policy Institute, a centrist Democratic public policy research organization. 
 On the other are conservatives like Phyllis Schlafly, a staunch opponent of sex education in public schools and a prime force behind the defeat of the Federal equal rights amendment, and the Family Research Council, a group opposing abortion and gay rights.
The coalition is loose, united by similar views on specific issues rather than by a formal organization. Mrs. Schlafly and Ms. Schroeder, for example, have never met to plot strategies.
"Liberals and conservatives in this room would disagee on everything, including the time of day, but not on this issue," Gary L. Bauer, president of the Family Research Council, recently told a Congressional hearing on financial constraints and the family. "I am convinced that the politics of saving the family will be the politics of the 90's."
In a series of position papers, reports and political remarks, both sides of the coalition agree that strengthening the family is the best way to make progress on a number of domestic ills from drug abuse to poor achievements in education.
"The family is under great cultural and fiscal attack today," said Representative Frank R. Wolf, Republican of Virginia. "Nearly every statistic on family well-being, from teen suicide rates to teen pregnancy, indicates that the family is in a downward spiral. Yet while children are more at risk, parents are pushed by financial pressures to spend less time with their children."
It is improving the financial situation of families that the coalition addresses first, pressing a bill that would raise the income tax deduction for parents with children under the age of 18.
The emphasis on the family is a bit of a rhetorical shift for Democrats. In the past, it was rare for the party, especially the liberal wing, to be linked with calls for strengthening "pro-family, moral values" that the Republican Party has championed in recent decades. Instead, Democrats tended to espouse ideals of individual liberty, privacy and tolerance of diverse ideas and life styles. If they talked at all about helping families, they tended to concentrate on the poor.
But now, Democrats like Ms. Schroeder, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia and Representative Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma talk of families as the main engine for teaching moral values to children and of the need for the Government to strengthen families so they can carry out that job.
Referring to the values that have dominated the party since the mid-1960's, Mr. McCurdy said: "It was the agenda of narrow and special interests. You had the formation of women's groups, and organizations like the Gay and Lesbian Alliance, and the pro-abortion and anti-abortion debate. The interests got so narrow, and the agenda got dictated by those narrow interests, and we lost sight of the broader principals and objectives."
In an article for the Progressive Policy Institute last fall, William A. Galston explained the shift. "The baby boom generation is aging," he wrote, "and they are starting to have kids in record numbers. With parenting comes a change of perspective and a change of responsibility and second thoughts about a value system oriented toward individual freedom."
In addition, Mr. Galston said, there is a growing body of research documenting the financial and emotional hardship on children arising from divorce.
 
Ripples From Tax Policy
 The current tax relief bill for families, sponsored by Mr. Wolf and 88 other House lawmakers, would raise the personal exemption for each dependent under the age of 18 to $3,500 or $4,000, from the current $2,150. Supporters note that in 1948 the exemption, $600, was 42 percent of the national per capita income but that last year, when the exemption was $2,050, it was only about 11 percent.
If the exemption had been steadily indexed for inflation and growth in real personal income, it would be $7,800 today, C. Eugene Steurle, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, a public policy research organization, told the House Select Committee on Children, Youth and Families on April 15.
In addition to simply giving families more money, a higher exemption could send positive side-effects rippling though society, supporters of the bill say. It could lead to a decrease in divorce, they say, because financial stress is a prime factor in the breakup of marriages, and it could permit more parents, generally mothers, to spend more time at home with their children rather than having to work full time.
"By reducing the family's tax burden," Mrs. Schlafly said in support of the bill, "the Federal Government would recognize the value of children and the costs of raising them. Then the choice of having two incomes in a family would become a personal preference, not economic necessity."
But advocates of the bill acknowledge having a difficult time gaining the support of Congressional leaders, probably because of the bill's cost, which some experts put at $8 billion to $12 billion in lost tax revenue annually.
"Increasing the personal exemption is a classic example of a great idea that is running headlong into the practical and immediate Washington constraints, to wit the budget," said a Bush Administration official who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
 
Constraints on Divorce
 But the tax change is only one item on the coalition's agenda. Members are also talking about encouraging the states to revise divorce laws to discourage couples with young children from separating.
In his paper for the Progressive Policy Institute, Mr. Galston, who was issues director for Walter F. Mondale's Presidential campaign in 1984, argued for a "braking mechanism in the divorce law." A waiting period of nine months for a divorce to become final "seems enough time to sober people up," he said, "but not too much time to constitute a form of indentured marriage."
And Ms. Schroeder said in an interview: "You need a waiting period in a lot of states before you get married. Where there are children involved, you shouldn't be able to just check out and not even think about it."
An additional brake on divorce, Mr. Galston said, would be to have child support payments automatically deducted from the pay check of the non-custodial parent. Such a policy, which he said the Federal Government should oversee, would make divorce less financially attractive to a parent who might otherwise plan to leave his family and then ignore child support payments.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Phyllis Schlafly, left, a staunch conservative Republican, and Representative Pat Schroeder, a liberal Democrat, are members of an alliance to press the Federal Government to adopt policies that they believe will reverse the decline and breakup of American families. (Paul Conklin; Associated Press)

HEADLINE: United Technologies' Bumpy Ride

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
These should be heady days for the United Technologies Corporation.
Last week, the Air Force chose an engine made by its Pratt & Whitney division to power a new fighter plane. Three weeks ago, the Army tapped the company's Sikorsky division to help build a new light helicopter. And just yesterday, Malaysian Airlines said it had selected Pratt & Whitney engines to go on the airline's new Boeing 747 wide-body jets. That order could be worth as much as $266 million. 
 The three contracts, good for more than $20 billion, and stretching well beyond the year 2000, are a badly needed tonic for a company battered by the recession. But United Technologies executives at the company's headquarters in Hartford are relatively mute and sober. For one thing, the work from the contracts at Pratt & Whitney, the company's largest unit, and Sikorsky will not even begin for several years.
And in the meantime, the giant producer of jet engines, air-conditioning equipment, helicopters, elevators and automotive parts, is enduring one of its toughest periods ever.
The company enjoyed steady growth in the late 80's, fueled by its diversified business strategy. But cuts in military spending, coupled with the downturn in the automotive industry and slackened demand for commercial airline parts, have thrown the company painfully off track.
To dampen the blow, United Technologies has stepped up companywide cost-cutting measures. Pratt & Whitney has laid off 1,500 workers since January, about 3.5 percent of its work force. Capital expenditures, which have risen steadily in the last few years, are now being re-examined with an eye toward delaying some projects. The company has also imposed a three-month delay in merit raises for United Technologies' tens of thousands of salaried employees. The effects of the downturn became clear two weeks ago, when United Technologies reported first-quarter earnings of $40.2 million, a drop of 70 percent from the comparable period a year earlier.
At the same time, the company's stock, which traded in the low 60's last spring, has also slipped. Shares closed at $46 yesterday, up 25 cents in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Robert F. Daniell, the company's straight-talking chairman and chief executive, conceded that it was the first time that the company's three core businesses -- supplying parts to the aerospace, building and automotive industries -- "simultaneously have been at the bottom of their industry cycles."
And even Mr. Daniell is not betting on a rebound any time soon. "We are not running our businesses on the assumption that the recession is nearing an end," he said. "The first half will be down. As far as the second half, it depends on how quickly things recover. And we haven't seen many signs of improvement in housing starts, in large building construction or in other areas."
 
Eroding Airline Ridership
 Much of the quarterly decline came from the downturn in the market for spare airline engine parts, normally a highly lucrative business. But eroding airline ridership has led to canceled flights. That translates into lower airline profits and lower spending on spare parts.
Still, many analysts see the company's problems as merely short-term ones tied directly to a sour economy. These analysts contend that United Technologies has worked diligently to shave operating costs and to bolster its dominant positions in many industries. Thus, they say, the company will vigorously rebound when the economy improves.
"Their sales of spare parts are down 25 percent and that's consistent with what's going on with other companies that sell spare parts," said Judith L. Bollinger, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company. "But that's not a surprise because air traffic is weak. When the economy recovers, airline ridership will recover and spare parts will recover."
United Technologies certainly does have many things working in its favor. For one, its main divisions have names that are among the most venerable in their industries. More important, most are in strong positions to take advantage of a recovery.
Pratt & Whitney, for example, is the nation's second-largest jet engine builder, behind the General Electric Company. Although Pratt has seen strong growth in its commercial jet business, that success has been tempered by tough times for its military business. And while the company has a large backlog of orders for commercial jet engines, those orders are spread over the coming decade and cannot compensate for the immediate Pentagon budget cuts.
But Pratt & Whitney may be in line for more new business. Analysts contend that the company's engines so dominate new airline orders, that many customers will opt for Pratt rather than having to adopt the new maintenance procedures that would come with the products of another manufacturer.
The Carrier Corporation, the United Technologies division that makes heating and refrigeration systems for homes and industry, has been hurt by the sharp decline in housing starts.
In fact, profits at the company's building systems division, which consists of Carrier and the Otis Elevator Company, the world's largest elevator manufacturer, fell by two-thirds in the first quarter, primarily because of the drop in housing starts.
Mr. Daniell said that his strategy for Carrier was to follow the growth of Otis, which has a vast global reach and a dominant market position in nearly every country in which it operates.
"It is inexcusable for Carrier not to be pre-eminent, when you consider the technical ability that exists with this company," Mr. Daniell said. "We have a long way to go to have Carrier attain the international infrastructure that Otis has. With that international infrastructure, you're not quite as concerned about the building starts in North America being back to the 1982 level."
Carrier's global growth will be achieved, he said, by a series of small acquisitions and partnerships "in every country you can think of."
 
Expansion Into Eastern Europe
 Analysts agree that Otis will benefit from expansion into Eastern Europe and that Carrier will expand its sales as it begins obtaining a foothold outside of North America.
The company's automotive division makes automobile products ranging from electrical systems and motors for power windows to the wiring harnesses in cars and switching equipment used to power windshield wipers. The big drop in American car sales has caused losses in that division. The prospects of continued sluggish sales by auto makers will mean even deeper deficits than the the $5 million loss United Technologies reported for its industrial segment in the first quarter.
Despite those problems, many analyts say that United Technologies is in a relatively strong competitive position.
"I feel positive about the company's prospects," said Wolfgang H. Demisch, an analyst with UBS Securities Inc. "This is a painful period for them, but it's merely short term. They're doing precisely what they should be doing: You have to cut costs and grin and bear the current hard times and keep the research and development going."
Mr. Daniell, while clearly happy about winning two major long-term contracts, remains cautious.
"Airline executives have told me that ridership has increased, but that hasn't filtered down to us yet," he said.
"I am not optimistic that there is going to be a quick end to this recession. I think it's going to be slow, steady progress for the economy as opposed to anything more dramatic. And I expect the same for our company."

HEADLINE: 2 Health Plans With Payments Tied to Income

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
In Germany and Japan, employers and employees contribute to health care, but in a radically different system that holds down society's total costs and treats workers more equally, guaranteeing insurance coverage for all with payment levels linked to incomes.
The German system developed over decades, while Japan adopted its health care system after World War II, modeling it on the German program. 
 A young German, starting his first job, enrolls in one of the nation's "sickness funds" and stays in that fund all his life, no matter how many times he changes employers. During his working years, the employee and his various bosses each pay into the fund a tax of 12.8 percent of the worker's pay. Unlike American health benefits, which companies offer at their discretion, this is mandatory for everyone. And since the tax is a proportion of pay, the burdens are spread more equitably, with high-income workers paying more, low income workers less. The tax revenue also helps cover the health care costs of retirees, who remain enrolled.
In Japan, large companies operate their own insurance funds, but the fee schedules are set by a central authority for all workers, regardless of which fund insures them.
In both nations, government plays an aggressive role in keeping down overall medical spending. In Germany, the Parliament places ceilings on total outlays. In Japan, on the other hand, there are fixed fees, applied nationwide, for a hospital visit, drugs or hospital care, but no limits on total spending.
A German worker can choose his doctors and hospitals, but the fees they charge have been negotiated with the funds and are subject to various federal guidelines. Germans go to doctors twice as often as Americans and the doctors charge for each visit, says John K. Iglehart, editor of Health Affairs, a policy journal, who has studied the German system. But if all the fees threaten to exceed a fund's annual budget for office visits, then the doctors are reimbursed proportionately less as they bill more.
Germany spent 8 percent of its national income on health in 1989, the same share as in 1975, while Japan spent 7 percent of its income on health in 1989, a slight increase over the 1970's. In contrast, American health spending climbed from 8 percent of the gross national product in 1975 to 12 percent in 1989.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Sharply Higher

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Interest rates plunged yesterday as prices of Treasury and other fixed-income securities soared in response to two moves by the Federal Reserve to reduce borrowing costs. The first was to cut the discount rate, which the Fed charges member commercial banks, to 5 1/2 percent from 6 percent.
The Fed's second and more important action was to flood the banking system with $3 billion of reserves. This caused the Federal funds rate, which banks charge one another for temporary loans, to drop to 5 3/4 percent from 6 percent. The funds rate is considered the basic cost of credit because most other interest rates are scaled upward from it. The rate is so termed because it is the interest rate most easily controlled by the Federal Reserve. 
 The discount rate has become more symbolic in recent years because commercial banks now have access to a much wider variety of sources for capital here and abroad.
One measure of the credit market's response was the price of the Treasury's bellwether long bonds, the 7 7/8 percent issue maturing in 2021.
 
Bouts of Profit Taking
 After overcoming several bouts of profit taking, late dealings found the long bonds offered at 96 20/32, up 16/ 32, or a half-point, which is equivalent to $5 for each $1,000 of face value. As a result, the long bond's yield sank to 8.17 percent, from 8.22 the day before. The 7 3/4 percent long notes of 2001 jumped 10/32, to 98 9/32, as the yield dropped to 8 percent, from 8.06 percent the day before. The shorter note maturities posted smaller gains.
Some Treasury securities dealers said the market's somewhat cautious reaction to the Fed's moves was not surprising. On Feb. 1, the last time the Fed simultaneously lowered the discount and funds rate, the moves did not set off a wave of interest rate reductions, which always benefits holders of existing fixed-income securities.
Then as now, commercial or other banks contended they had to regain their financial health before cutting loan rates, citing heavy loan losses.
"Although there was plenty of dismal economic data to warrant action by the Fed, it still came as something of a surprise," said Jeremy J. Siegel, professor of finance at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. "For one thing, the Fed's Open Market Committee normally decides changes in the funds rate, which is far, far more important than the largely symbolic discount rate, as well as monetary policy generally. But the policy-setting Open Market Committee doesn't meet again until May 14.
"We think the Fed's board of governors, which controls the discount rate, responded to pressure from the White House and Congress to do something to revive the economy."
 
Poor Economic News
 Michael J. Moran, chief economist at Daiwa America Securities Inc., agreed that the Fed's action was motivated by the steady flow of poor economic news. As for the Fed's timing, Mr. Moran said "it was undoubtedly influenced by the meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations that met last Sunday."
At the Washington meeting, the United States pleaded for lower interest rates worldwide to stimulate economic growth.
As for the Fed's decision to add reserves to the banking system indirectly through customers, Mr. Moran said that "if the Federal Reserve System added the reserves, the amount involved would have probably led the credit market to believe it wanted to knock the funds rate down by a half- point and not a more limited reduction."
Although the Fed never discloses the dollar amounts involved when it engages in systemwide operations to either add or drain reserves from the banking system, the sums are believed to be far greater than the $3 billion injection of funds. Even so, when the Fed adds reserves by buying Treasury securities from dealers for brief periods "on behalf of customers," usually foreign central banks, it normally involves much less than $3 billion.
As expected, Treasury bill rates, which are the most sensitive to any change in the funds rate, responded immediately with soaring prices and plunging discount rates. After some late profit taking, the 90-day bill rate dropped 7 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.53 percent; six-month bills lost 11 basis points, to 5.57 percent, and the one-year bills also fell 11 basis points, to 5.71 percent.
The funds rate, meanwhile, closed at 5 15/16 percent after trading at 5 13/16 most of the day. But today is the end of the two-week bank statement period, when the funds rate normally firms. Ironically, the Fed had struggled to push up the funds rate to 6 percent in recent weeks with little outward success.

HEADLINE: Americans Teaching English in Czechoslovakia Learn About Themselves

 BODY:
Missy Darwin teaches English at a parachuting club in Prague. She never trained to be a teacher and has no textbooks. For St. Patrick's Day, she asked students to wear green and bring whatever green food they could find in the drab wintertime stalls of Czechoslovakia's markets.
"I sort of improvised from there," said Ms. Darwin, a former legislative aide to Senator David Pryor of Arkansas. "Every day is an adventure. My students are very enthusiastic." 
 As a volunteer for Education for Democracy/U.S.A., Ms. Darwin is getting by in much the same way as the grass-roots program that sent her -- with a mixture of ingenuity, persistence and a desire to help Czechoslovakia reinvent itself after four decades of Communist rule.
Founded in Mobile, Ala., in the heady months after Czechoslovakia's "velvet revolution" in 1989, Education for Democracy has sent more than 600 Americans to Czechoslovakia to teach English in schools, factories, government agencies and, as in Ms. Darwin's case, private organizations.
"The Czechoslovaks are looking to the West, especially the United States, for many answers," said Ann Gardner, the organization's founder. "To learn Western know-how they feel they have to learn English."
The program, modeled on one founded by Czechoslovak expatriates in Canada, grew out of Ms. Gardner's friendship with Pavel Demes, a Czechoslovak doctor who in 1987 worked at the medical center at the University of South Alabama, where Ms. Gardner's husband, William, heads the pathology department.
After the revolution, Dr. Demes joined the new Government as director of foreign relations for the Ministry of Education in the Slovak Republic and asked Ms. Gardner if she would organize volunteers in the United States.
Working in the dining room of her Mobile home, Ms. Gardner quickly improvised volunteers and arrangements. "Grass roots is really the appropriate term," she said.
 
The Volunteers Enlist
 The first two volunteers, both from Mobile, left in March 1990, followed the next month by about 40 more, most of them students from universities in Alabama.
Since then, Education for Democracy has had a steady stream of volunteer teachers, ranging in age from 19 to 72 and coming from 37 states. The organization is being run from a two-room office lent by the medical center at the University of South Alabama, and Ms. Gardner has applied for a grant from the United States Information Agency so that she can broaden the program's scope.
Volunteers pay their own air fare to Czechoslovakia and bring their own teaching materials -- newspapers, travel brochures, restaurant menus. Through the Ministry of Education, the Prague and Bratislava offices of Education for Democracy in assign them to schools or businesses.
The volunteers typically hold class about 20 hours a week, teaching beginning and advanced speakers of English. They are paid about 2,000 korunas a month, or $65, slightly below the average for a Czechoslovak worker, and they live with families or in state-owned apartments.
Paula Ross, a television journalist from Pensacola, Fla., who spent four months in Prague last summer, lived with a working mother "in one of those giant Communist concrete complexes that goes on forever."
For many volunteers, living in a foreign culture has been at once adventurous and frustrating. Workaday life is complicated by what Ms. Darwin called "Czech management," a sometimes bewildering and seemingly irrational way of running things.
Corrine Palmer, a real estate agent from Myrtle Beach, S.C., who recently returned after four months in Nizna, a small village near the Polish border, said she was astounded by the Czechoslovak standard of living. "Their lives are very, very hard compared to ours," said Ms. Palmer. "They were not even aware there was such a thing as a clothes dryer."
For other volunteers, this overseas teaching assignment has been a personal revelation. "Before I came here, I was doing the whole yuppie thing," said Christopher Kingery, a lumber salesman in Portland, Ore., before volunteering to teach and then to run the program's office in Bratislava. "My life felt so empty. So here I am. I don't know what we're really going to accomplish in the end, but I know we're going to do something."
In a telephone interview from Bratislava, where she was checking on the program's operations, Ms. Gardner said she hopes to expand the program's focus, supplying not only English teachers but business executives, engineers and other professionals who could help ease Czechoslovakia's transition to a market economy.
Ms. Gardner has recently reached agreement with officials in Poland to begin sending volunteers there in September.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "The Czechoslovaks are looking to the West, especially the United States, for many answers," said Ann Gardner, founder of Education for Democracy/U.S.A., which has sent more than 600 Americans to Czechoslovakia to teah. She is shows in her Mobile, Ala., office. (Dave Hamby for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Drop in U.S. Interest Rates Sends the Dollar Tumbling

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
A surprise cut in American interest rates sent the dollar tumbling on world currency markets yesterday.
Gold prices staged a strong advance. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $355.90 an ounce, up $3.80 from Monday. The Republic National Bank said gold rose $4.15 an ounce, to a late bid of $356.25. 
 The dollar opened on a weak note and then moved sharply lower after the Federal Reserve announced it was cutting the discount rate half a percentage point, to 5 1/2 percent, the lowest level since late 1977, in an effort to pull the economy out of recession.
A cut in the discount rate, which the Fed charges on loans to commercial banks, generally leads to widespread cuts in interest rates, a move that is negative for the dollar because it makes dollar-denominated securities less valuable for investors.
"The timing was somewhat of a surprise," said Michael Malpede, a senior analyst at the Refco Group in Chicago. He added that relatively high interest rates in both Japan and Germany had served as a kind of "double whammy," taking the dollar lower.
Another negative factor for the dollar, Mr. Malpede said, is that traders had anticipated a rebound in the American economy, but "so far that recovery has not materialized." Indeed, the Commerce Department reported yesterday that orders to United States factories for manufactured goods fell 2.8 percent in March, the fifth consecutive monthly drop.
Still, some bullish sentiment continues to surround the dollar. "Everyone's loaded with dollars because they all feel our economy is going to turn first," said John Marchese, chief economist at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. There was no "mass dumping" of the dollar, he said, adding that the currency decline "wasn't that bad" considering the Fed cut was not anticipated.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 137.42 Japanese yen, from 137.83 yen on Friday. Japanese markets were closed for a holiday on Monday. In London, it fell to 136.30 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 136.15 yen, down from 136.50 yen on Monday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7235, from $1.6765. In New York it cost $1.7325 to buy one pound, more expensive than Monday's $1.6980.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.7067 German marks, down from 1.7510; 1.4410 Swiss francs, down from 1.4730; 5.7760 French francs, down from 5.9100; 1,262.50 Italian lire, down from 1,294.00, and 1.1529 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1533.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Monday, included: 1.7180 German marks, down from 1.7685; 1.4495 Swiss francs, down from 1.4845; 5.8085 French francs, down from 5.9660; 1.9355 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9920; 1,272.00 Italian lire, down from 1,305.25, and 1.1512 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1534.

HEADLINE: Bush Offers Trade-Pact Concessions

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
The Bush Administration, facing a critical vote in Congress next month over its authority to negotiate with other countries on trade, will make significant environmental and job-security commitments to accompany a trade pact with Mexico, Administration and Congressional aides said today.
The commitments are intended to sway votes in a battle that has pitted the Administration and proponents of free trade against organized labor, textile interests and others who fear that greater trade with Mexico will result in the loss of jobs and a weakening of environmental and labor standards. 
 The initiatives, to be announced on Wednesday, include programs to be jointly operated with Mexico to curb pollution on the border and strengthen environmental enforcement, the naming of environmentalists for the first time to official trade-advisory bodies and beefed-up efforts to asist workers who may lose their jobs because of imports.
They will be detailed in a letter from President Bush to the chairmen of the House and Senate committees responsible for trade policy -- Lloyd Bentsen of Texas at the Senate Finance Committee, and Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois at the House Ways and Means Committee.
At a meeting with a bipartisan group of Congressional leaders called today to discuss international trade, President Bush injected himself energetically into the fight.
"This is a priority, and we are going all out," he said, terming the negotiating authority crucial because of the growing importance of exports to economic growth.
"We need this fast-track authority to negotiate trade agreements that will open markets, keep our exports strong, and create jobs, and frankly, sustain our leadership in the world economy," the President said.
 
Making Concessions
 The current debate is part of a process that has marked allpostwar trade agreements. Because the Constitution gives Congress power to "regulate foreign commerce," the President's ability to negotiate trade agreements derives from a delegation of authority from Congress.
But the lawmakers, traditionally sensitive to domestic interests, have always demanded a price for going along in terms of increased safeguards for industry and workers.
This time, the Administration is making concessions in connection with its request for a two-year extension of the "fast-track" procedure, a measure that makes trade agreements non-amendable and subject only to up-or-down votes.
Foreign countries have served notice that they will not negotiate with the United States if what they finally agree to is then subject to Congressional amendment.
Extension of the fast-track authority would permit the Administration to negotiate not only a special accord with Mexico but also a sweeping trade liberalization agreement with 107 countries, known as the Uruguay Round, which has been in the works for five years and could be concluded within 12 months.
Initial reaction to the Administration plan was favorable. "The Administration has demonstrated sensitivity to Congressional concerns," said Max Baucus of Montana, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee's Trade Subcommittee, adding, "A vote against fast-track extension is now clearly a vote for protectionism."
Kathryn S. Fuller, president of the World Wildlife Fund, one organization expected to sit on the trade advisory panels, said, "If we can play a useful role we will."
She noted that environmentalists and conservationists until now have had practically no impact on trade policy.
One result of the Administration's plan may be to split the environmental lobby. Some groups, like Greenpeace and the Natural Resource Defense Council, have taken a hard line against the fast track.
 
Response to a Letter
 One criticism by Congressional aides who have seen the letter is that while the commitments are in strong language, nothing is said about what Washington would do if Mexico does not live up its promises.
The initiatives are in response to a March 7 letter from Representative Rostenkowski and Senator Bentsen asking for reassurance that the Administration will address issues related to the environment, labor standards and worker displacement in seeking the fast-track extension.
The environmental commitments are the most specific. The letter pledges the two Governments to a comprehensive review of environmental laws to see where they need improvement, promises no weakening of American laws in the process and stresses that the United States will retain the right to limit imports that contain hazardous pesticides or other products harmful to health.
Mexico has acted in recent years to orient policies toward standards set by the United States. The letter, according to those who have seen it, says Mexico is strengthening its enforcement budget and expanding from 6 to 100 the number of enforcement agents. It is also said to point out that Mexico has closed 900 plants for environmental reasons, 70 in the last three weeks.

HEADLINE: State Makes Winning Bid In New York On City Notes

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
In an odd twist to the city and state's intertwined fiscal mess, the State of New York submitted a winning bid on $50 million in short-term city notes auctioned yesterday, effectively lending the city money that it needed because the state has failed to give the city aid that it owes.
The city had been forced to sell $1.2 billion worth of notes only because the state, unable to pass a budget, had not paid the city money that would have come to the city under the new state budget. Now the city finds itself paying interest to the state to borrow money it should have already received. 
 "In a way the state is creating a problem and profiting from it," said City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman.
To add insult to injury, said a spokesman for State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, the main reason the state bid on the notes was not to help the city but to take advantage of its worsening credit picture -- caused in part by the state budget delay. Yields on the city's notes exceeded the return on alternatives available to the state.
 
'Paramount Concern'
 "Our first, paramount concern is to maximize the return on our investment," said Bob Hinckley, Mr. Regan's spokesman.
The state's winning bid was for only a fraction of the $1.2 billion in short-term notes the city auctioned yesterday. The auction was suspenseful because the city's rating for revenue notes was lowered by Standard & Poor's on Monday because of the city and state's overlapping problems.
But all the notes sold easily -- with the city getting $3 in bids for each $1 of notes up for sale -- and Mayor David N. Dinkins asked reporters to take note that he was commenting on the sale "with glee."
 
The Cost Is High
 But the cost to the city was high. It paid 6.74 percent in interest at a time when a parallel issue by the State of California was trading to yield 4.60 percent. Selling the notes -- which, unlike bonds, typically mature in months, rather than up to 30 years -- will cost the city a total of $11.9 million that it would not have had to spend if it had received state money on time.
However, the Standard & Poor's downgrading -- which precluded many money market funds from bidding because their rules allow them to bid only on higher-rated notes -- hurt the city less than expected because most interest rates dropped sharply yesterday anyway after the Federal Reserve lowered two of its key interest rates and because the investment banks that un derwrite city bonds decided to buy and hold large blocks of the notes.
One city official recalled a Wall Street adage: "It is better to be lucky than smart."
At 11 A.M., when a deputy city comptroller opened a green metal box in a conference room filled with Wall Street executives at the Municipal Building in lower Manhattan, there were gasps when the state's bid for $100 million in city notes was read.
 
'Good and Sound'
 The state was allowed to buy $50 million at an interest rate of 6.95 percent, or a return of $492,291 when the notes come due at the end of June. The chairman of the City Council's Finance Committee, Herbert E. Berman, who observed the auction, joked that perhaps the state should be investigated to see if it manipulated the market in city notes for its own gain.
At a City Hall news conference, Mayor Dinkins praised the state for demonstrating that the city "remains a good and sound investment" and suggested -- in jest, he said -- that the state waive its right to the interest payments.
The state's investment comes from its short-term investment pool, a pool of about $2 billion from state and local tax collections, fees and other funds.
Mr. Hinckley, the State Comptroller's spokesman, said the state decided to buy city notes, which are tax-free, for the pool after discovering that they gave a better return than taxable investments with similar maturities. Treasury bills paid around 5.45 percent, he said, while corporate paper yielded about 6 percent.
In downgrading the city's notes from SP-1 to SP-2, the lowest rate currently held by any notes, Standard & Poor's said it worried that the city would face cash problems if the state failed to adopt a budget as the end of the city's fiscal year approached.
Yesterday, city officials said dire warnings by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo about the possibility of an impasse might have contributed to the downgrading decision.
 
Questioned About Warning
 Sally Hernandez-Pinero, Deputy Mayor for Finance, said the rating agency sharply questioned city officials about the Governor's warning that the state impasse could continue until July.
Most of the notes were purchased by the underwriters of the city's bonds, who said that they were not pressured by the city to bid but understood that they were expected to do so.
But they pointed out that the interest rates for the issue were so high that they would not lose money.

HEADLINE: Recycling to Expand to Businesses in New York

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
New York City's mandatory recycling program, limited so far to residences, will soon be expanded to include the five boroughs' 200,000 businesses.
The city's goal is the same as it is for residences: to reduce the amount of garbage buried in landfills or burned. 
 Regulations describing the recycling obligations of businesses and private garbage haulers, who collect commercially generated trash, were published yesterday in The City Record. They take effect in 30 days.
 
Two-Year Phase-In Planned
 The program will be phased in over two years. Within six months, businesses must begin separating recyclable materials, including high-grade office paper, corrugated cardboard, metal containers and construction debris. After a year, glass containers, newspapers and magazines must be added to the list, and in 18 months separation of plastic containers must begin.
In the process, some businesses may save money by reducing the trash they pay to dispose of, but big savings are not expected because recycling itself is expensive. Like the participants in the residential program, businesses and private garbage companies can be penalized for failing to carry out their recycling responsibilities.
City officials are hoping mandatory commercial recycling gets better results than its residential counterpart. The two-year-old residential curbside program has suffered from lagging participation in many neighborhoods and high collection costs.
At the moment, budget problems have put the future of the entire curbside collection in doubt. But commercial recycling will go forward because the city's responsibilities are largely in enforcement, not collection.
 
Private Haulers Unhappy
 Few big American cities require businesses to recycle, and it is not clear how many New York City businesses currently recycle. Government and private specialists say the number is relatively small but growing rapidly.
Of 1,000 large Manhattan office buildings, only about 50 have full-scale recycling programs, said Richard Fuller, president of Great Forest Inc., a New York recycling consultant.
Over time, mandatory commercial recycling will prompt "major changes in how waste is handled" in New York City, said Sanitation Commissioner Steven M. Polan. Much more responsibility will fall on private haulers, who collect at least 10,000 tons of commercially generated waste daily, and private concerns known as transfer stations, where trash is taken for separation into recyclable components. Private pickups account for more than 40 percent of all trash collected in the city.
The haulers are not happy about their new burden. They say they will face higher costs at a time when the city is trying to cut their rates. City officials say that if the haulers can show their costs are higher, a rate increase will be considered.
Of even bigger concern is the economics of the recyclables markets. If markets are not vibrant enough to absorb the materials, recycling could become prohibitively expensive. Haulers, transfer stations and businesses may have to pay to get their materials taken away. Material designated recyclable under the regulations cannot be dumped in a landfill, even if there is no market for it.
City officials acknowledge that markets may be a problem and hope that the phase-in period will afford the necessary slack.
 
Delays in Drafting Rules
 The recycling law, approved by the City Council in April 1989, called for the commercial regulations to be completed a year ago, but there have been many delays. The law calls for the regulations to designate recyclable materials that in total constitute at least half of all the trash private haulers collect.
The Sanitation Department collects about 17,000 tons of residential garbage daily. Exactly how much private haulers pick up is unclear, but the department estimate is at least 10,000 tons a day. That is the amount haulers dumped at the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island until about two years ago, when the city raised the dumping fee sharply and the haulers took their business to landfills out of the city.
In addition private haulers are collecting 12,000 tons of paper a day for recycling, said Anthony Lomangino, an owner of Allied Sanitation, one of the city's biggest private refuse haulers, and Star Recycling, a big transfer station.
Residential recycling is in place in 29 of the 59 city areas supervised by community boards, or nearly two million of three million households. About 6 percent of residential waste is being recycled, the Sanitation Department says. The department failed to reach its tonnage goal for the second year of the program, mainly because of cost-cutting measures. The recycling law calls for 25 percent recycling by April 1994.
 
Choices for Businesses
 Commercial recycling will differ markedly from residential recycling in how the materials are handled. The Sanitation Department collects garbage generated by households and is also responsible for picking up recyclable material separated by residences. In contrast, businesses hire private haulers to pick up their refuse.
Under the city's recycling law, businesses must decide whether they will do their own separation of recyclables from trash and arrange for its collection or whether they will let their private garbage haulers do the work.
Many smaller businesses, like delicatessens, are expected to rely on haulers to pick up unseparated trash and take it to sorting areas. Multi-tenant office buildings will likely do their own separation.
 
Recycling in Offices Praised
 Dozens of big buildings already have introduced office-paper recycling programs to take advantage of strong markets for such products. Smaller businesses, like greengrocers, routinely separate corrugated cardboard.
Office buildings in New York City that have introduced recycling have generally received good cooperation from tenants and their employees, recycling specialists say. The programs usually involve setting out recycling containers, changing cleaning staff practices and educating employees about what to separate.
At 520 Madison Avenue, a 43-story office building owned and managed by Tishman Speyer Properties, about four tons, or 20 percent, of its paper waste is being recycled a week, said David J. Arena, the building manager. About 300 to 400 deposit cans and bottles are separated and donated every two weeks to We Can, a nonprofit organization that redeems containers collected by the poor.
Of 47 tenants, only one balked when asked to begin separating office paper last summer, Mr. Arena said. That tenant "didn't want their executives to walk four feet to a pail," he said. "In an environmental sense, they were living in the Stone Age."
Mr. Fuller, the consultant who helped set up the 520 Madison Avenue recycling program, said most buildings could reduce disposable trash by 10 to 20 percent. The 520 Madison program cost $10,000 to $15,000 to put in place, Mr. Arena said.

HEADLINE: Labor Secretary Proposes Revamping Pension Laws

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
Secretary of Labor Lynn Martin proposed changing the nation's pension laws today to encourage employers to create retirement programs for about 42 million workers who are currently not covered.
In general, the Administration proposes simplifying the rules and reducing the administrative burden for employers, particularly small businesses. But critics, including groups representing retirees, say the changes would do little to encourage employers to make more generous pension contributions and would mainly benefit highly paid employees who can afford to contribute to tax-deferred retirement saving plans. 
 "They are purporting to increase pension coverage, but they're not," said Karen Ferguson, director of Pension Rights Center, a public interest group in Washington. "What they're doing is increasing the availability of tax-sheltered savings plans. Tax-sheltered savings plans are great for yuppies, but they don't work for most American workers."
Ms. Martin said she was not proposing a specific bill to Congress, but was instead trying to start a dialogue on the basic features of a plan.
The proposals come after recent efforts in Congress to deal with growing concern that 45 percent of all full-time employees in the United States have no pension plan, according to Labor Department statistics.
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, and Senator David Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas, made similar proposals last year, and consequently Ms. Martin's overall plan is thought to have a good chance of gaining the bipartisan support needed for enactment.
Business groups generally support the proposals, contending that they would eliminate paperwork that now discourages many small companies from offering retirement programs for workers. But business lobbyists also noted that the biggest obstacle for many employers was the cost.
"Generally speaking, this is a very positive step, but I'm not sure how much change it will create in the marketplace," said John Satagaj, president of the Small Business Legislative Council, which represents dozens of trade associations that lobby for small companies. "In the end, the biggest issue is whether a small business has the money."
 
Plan for Small Businesses
 The central proposal is a new, simplified retirement plan for small businesses, which in recent years have accounted for most of the nation's new jobs. The National Federation of Independent Business, a trade association, estimates that as many as three-quarters of all small companies currently provide no retirement benefits for their employees.
Under the Administration plan, small employers would not have to follow complex rules that prevent companies from discriminating in favor of highly compensated employees -- often including the owners -- when they offer a qualified plan, or one that receives favorable tax treatment. Some small companies simply cover the owners with a nonqualified plan, forgoing the tax benefits, but do not offer a qualified plan for everyone.
Another proposal would expand the availability of the retirement savings plans known as 401(k) plans to employees of nonprofit organizations and state and local governments. A third provision would allow employers to transfer money in a retirement plan to an individual retirement account when a worker changes jobs. A fourth measure would let more workers keep accumulated retirement benefits after five years.
 
'Security and Dignity'
 "The goal of this proposal is to add as many individuals to the list of those with pension coverage as we can," Ms. Martin said. "An enlightened and caring society insures that its senior citizens are protected. And the best way to protect them is seeing they have the economic power, the means, the pension coverage, to live out their retirement years with security and dignity."
Ms. Martin said the proposals would not increase the deficit, because measures that are likely to cost the Treasury tax revenues would be offset by not allowing retirees who take lump-sum pension payments to average their tax liability over 5 or 10 years, as they now can. The Labor Department provided no revenue estimates, and some Congressional experts were skeptical of the Administration's assertions.
The new retirement plan for companies with fewer than 100 workers is intended to eliminate as much paperwork as possible. Small employers complain the nondiscrimination requirement entails too much paperwork to make such plans practical.
Under the proposed rule, employers with fewer than 100 workers would be free of the nondiscrimination requirements, as long as the employer contributes 2 percent of each employee's salary to their retirement accounts.
But groups representing retirees said the move would make it too easy for employers to ignore the needs of low-paid workers. "All this does is give a tax break to workers who would be saving for their retirement anyway," said Ms. Ferguson of the Pension Rights Center.
Another key feature in the plan would require the multiemployer pension programs established by trade unions to cover members at different companies to give workers full access to their retirement funds after five years. Under current rules, union members sacrifice their accrued benefits if they take a job outside the union in less than 10 years.

HEADLINE: New Jersey to Add Trains to Midtown

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY

 BODY:
Thanks to almost $100 million in new money from the Port Authority, New Jersey plans to start work next year on a long-delayed railroad connection that will give four counties a direct train link with Penn Station in Manhattan.
The project is designed to link N.J. Transit's Morris and Essex Lines with Amtrak's main New York-Philadelphia line where the two cross in a desolate stretch of Kearny near the New Jersey Turnpike, a few miles northeast of Newark. 
 The new system, to be completed in 1995, would allow the Morris and Essex Lines' 14,000 daily passengers from cities and suburbs in Essex, Morris, Union and Somerset Counties to bypass the Hoboken train station and its link, via PATH trains, to lower Manhattan and midtown.
Railroad old-timers say the idea for the link-up, called the Kearny Connection, originated after World War II. Over the years, major preliminary work has been done. Some designs are finished. The Morris and Essex Lines' electrical system was modernized and made compatible with Amtrak's in the early 1980's. And Amtrak and N.J. Transit, which operates the Morris and Essex, have worked out scheduling to accommodate more commuter trains on Amtrak's line.
Despite all this groundwork, construction never started because New Jersey said it lacked money. N.J. Transit says it now has enough -- about $125.5 million in all -- for all necessary work in and around Kearny. The only financing still missing is for a new concourse at Penn Station in New York and escalators linking it to train platforms to handle an anticipated 8,000 extra passengers expected to take the new direct line. But officials say the new concourse-escalator system, expected to cost up to $50 million, is not critical and lack of money for it now will not mean more delay for the Kearny Connection.
"Our preference is to have the new concourse because it will facilitate movement of people, but we can do without it for now," said Jeff Lamm, a spokesman for N.J. Transit.
The money that finally assured construction of the Kearny Connection is coming, indirectly, from the $1 toll increase that took effect April 7 on the Port Authority's tunnels and bridges on the Hudson River. Before Gov. Jim Florio and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo approved the increase, the Port Authority agreed to give each state $200 million over five years for economic development and transportation improvements. The toll increase is expected to generate $117 million in new revenue each year.
Between now and 1994, New Jersey's $200 million share is to be deposited into a state economic development fund. Of the total, $98.5 million in Port Authority money is to be transferred by 1994 to the state's transportation trust fund, which finances improvements to mass transit, highways and bridges.
The Port Authority's infusion into the trust fund will free $98.5 million in state funds committed to other projects to be used, instead, on the Kearny Connection through 1995, said Barbara Richardson, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Transportation Department.
Of the $98.5 million, $71.5 million is earmarked for construction, new tracks and switching equipment, and a storage yard. Another $27 million will be spent upgrading signals on the Amtrak tracks.
In addition, $27 million in state and Federal funds will be spent to increase electrical power on the Amtrak tracks to accommodate the additional trains.
 
A Sense of Relief
 The Port Authority is restricted, through convenants in its bonds, from subsidizing operating railroads, except for the PATH system, which it owns. Richard Kelly, head of the agency's interstate transportation department, said he planned to meet with New Jersey officials this week to review if their use of Port Authority money to free state money for a railroad construction project poses any problems with the bond restrictions.
"I don't anticipate any," Mr. Kelly said.
Commuters in the four counties have agitated for the Kearny Connection for years. And N.J. Transit's vote last week to start construction in 1992 brought a sense of relief and joy.
"It's long overdue," said John Hyde, who represents Summit on the Lackawanna Coalition, a commuter group serving 15 towns on the Morris and Essex Lines.
"It'll be a big improvement, we couldn't be happier," said James Laurie, a retired railroad consultant and Millburn's representative on the coalition. "It'll save anywhere from 15 to 20 minutes to Manhattan."
A direct train to Manhattan will make midtown's theaters, stores and other attractions more accessible, and thus more enticing, to residents of the four counties, suburban officials believe. An easier commute to Manhattan will also make communities along the lines more attractive to newcomers.
The Morris and Essex Lines have three parts, vestiges of the Erie Lackawanna Railroad. The main one is the Morristown Line, which runs from Hoboken to Newark, through the Oranges, and on to Morristown. The Montclair branch veers off it outside Newark and serves Bloomfield, Glen Ridge and Montclair. And the Gladstone branch veers off the Morristown Line in Summit and serves towns in Union and Somerset Counties, including New Providence, Berkeley Heights, Basking Ridge, Bernardsville and Far Hills.
At least 10 trains will run on the direct line during morning and evening rush hours, said Rick Richmond, N.J. Transit's assistant executive director for engineering and construction. Off-peak service will be similar to current scheduling.
He said officials expected that 3,000 riders who now reach midtown via Hoboken and PATH would switch to the direct trains. In addition, he said, the new line is expected to lure 5,000 new riders who now drive or take buses to Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Weicker, to Block Indian Casino, Seeks Repeal of Charity Gambling

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, April 30

 BODY:
In senior centers, church basements and high school gymnasiums across the state, nonprofit groups are allowed to go crazy once or twice a year and pretend that old Connecticut is really wild Las Vegas. With play money and small prizes, "Las Vegas nights" are a way to raise money.
But now, hoping to prevent an Indian tribe from using the state's charity-gambling laws as a legal basis to build a casino on its reservation, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. wants to repeal those laws. 
 In a letter sent today to legislative leaders, he asked for emergency legislation repealing nonprofit-gambling statutes that he said had been interpreted by the tribe and the courts in a way that was never intended.
Mr. Weicker has consistently argued that allowing the Indians to open a casino would create pressure for other casinos, and could lead to a host of social problems like compulsive gambling, prostitution and organized crime.
Federal law says that if a state permits gambling, federally recognized Indian tribes within its borders have the right to conduct gambling, too.
Under a court order, Connecticut reached an agreement last year with the 200-member Mashantucket Pequot tribe of Ledyard to permit a profit-making casino that could operate blackjack, poker, roulette and other games at whatever stakes the tribe chose. The state still opposes the plan, but its last appeal was rejected last week by the United States Supreme Court, and the agreement now requires only the approval of the Federal Interior Secretary, Manuel Lujan Jr.
But Connecticut's Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, said he believed that if the Weicker measures were passed and signed within the next two weeks and forwarded to Washington, the agreement could not be approved.
Tribal spokesmen said that trying to change the law now, after ground has already been broken for a multimillion-dollar casino, hotel and restaurant complex that could open as early as this fall, is duplicity of the same stripe that American Indians have endured for centuries.
"Indian people have faced a long and tragic history of broken treaties," Tribal Chairman Richard Hayward said in a statement. "It would be very sad if Connecticut added another chapter to that history. We cannot believe the state would do this to us now."
A lawyer for the tribe, Barry A. Margolin, said he did not believe that Federal law would allow the state to unilaterally change the terms of the compact after the fact. He also contended that Connecticut could not block the tribe's casino plan unless the state was willing to dismantle all its gambling enterprises, including dog tracks, jai alai, and the state lottery -- and thus forgo the hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue that those games contribute to the state budget.
But Mr. Weicker, in a news conference, said that no compact was final until it left Mr. Lujan's desk in Washington, and that there was still an opportunity "to protect Connecticut's right to determine its destiny in this critical matter."
He said that if a law were passed by the General Assembly and signed before the period for public comment on the compact expires on May 17, Mr. Lujan would have to consider the state's new public policy.
And regardless of what Federal officials do, changing the law would inevitably throw the question back into the courts, lawyers on both sides said, thus possibly delaying the casino for months, if not years.
But lawmakers, Interior Department officials and tribal spokesmen also said that Mr. Weicker had launched the state onto an uncharted course. Currently five states -- California, Minnesota, Nevada, South Dakota and Nebraska -- have formal compacts with tribes in their borders under the Indian gaming law signed by President Reagan in 1988. Nowhere has a state tried to turn the tables in the middle of the game.
 
'It's Very Curious'
 "It sounds like an overnight change of heart," said Carl Shaw, a spokesman for the Interior Department's Bureau of Indian Affairs.
"It's very curious," he added, "that they would only be in opposition to this when the courts have ruled that the tribes can participate in it. I don't know what will happen."
In the legislature, which is already wrestling with a huge tax-revenue shortfall and a statewide recession, some lawmakers said that Mr. Weicker's proposal could face problems. It would deprive nonprofit groups of a proven way of raising money, and also pass up what the tribe promised would be 1,900 or more new jobs -- all in the southeast corner of the state, which has been hard hit by the recession and by cuts in defense spending.
Groton, less than 10 miles from the proposed site of the casino, is home to the state's largest concentration of defense contractors, led by Electric Boat, a division of General Dynamics that makes submarines for the Navy.
"I'm caught in a bind," said State Representative Glenn N. Arthur, a Republican who represents Ledyard in the legislature. Mr. Arthur said he was opposed to the casino, but did not want to hurt nonprofit groups and had doubts about whether changing the law now would be constitutional.
 
Potential for Jobs
 The Speaker of the House of Representatives, Richard J. Balducci, a Democrat from Newington, noted at a news conference that he had participated in Las Vegas nights himself to raise money for a football team in his town. He said he was not convinced that repealing the charity-gambling laws was desirable.
Because Indians lands are not subject to state taxes, the state would not derive any tax revenues from casino profits.
But the president of the Chamber of Commerce of Southeastern Connecticut, William D. Moore, said the casino would make the Pequots the fourth-largest employer in the county. In just the week since the Supreme Court said it would not hear the state's appeals, Mr. Moore said, he has received calls from four developers who wanted to talk about building hotels.
"There is considerable amount of business support for the casino -- considerable," Mr. Moore said.
At the senior center in the town of Manchester, a Las Vegas night scheduled for May 15 could face cancellation if the charity-gambling laws are repealed. The director, Jeanette Cave, said that while the center did not depend on the occasion for fund-raising, the cancellation would deprive elderly members of "a night of fun" and the chance to win hundreds of dollars in donated prizes.
"We even make the play money ourselves," she said.

HEADLINE: FEDERAL RESERVE TRIMS LOAN COSTS TO SPUR ECONOMY

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
Trying to end the recession, the Federal Reserve cut interest rates today, noting as it acted that the latest data showed the economy to be still quite weak.
In an early-morning announcement, the Federal Reserve said it had lowered the discount rate, the rate it charges on loans to banks, to 5 1/2 percent from 6 percent. A few hours later, the central bank pushed down the important Federal funds rate, which is what banks charge each other on loans, to 5 3/4 percent from 6 percent. 
 Both rates affect what banks pay for deposits and other funds, and what they can then charge when they lend out this money for mortgages, home equity loans, car loans and the like.
 
Benchmark Rate at 9%
 With their cost of funds lower, banks are now under pressure to reduce their prime lending rate, currently at 9 percent, but no large bank moved immediately. This rate is the benchmark for many commercial and other loans.
The Federal Reserve's move came after Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady had failed to persuade Germany and the other major industrial nations to lower their interest rates to help give the American economy a lift. The timing suggested to some economists that the Federal Reserve had acted today at least partly in response to the Bush Administration's call for lower rates.
"All signs point to the Fed trying to bail out the Brady position after the unsuccessful meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations on Sunday," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston, a Wall Street investment firm. "This is arm-twisting by the Administration, successfully."
 
A Different Explanation
 But the Federal Reserve offered a much different explanation. The announcement accompanying the discount rate cut said the Fed had acted because data released in the last few days, including some figures published today, showed "continued weakness in economic activity." Industrial production and factory orders have declined, spending for new machinery and other equipment has fallen more than expected, employment costs have edged down and consumer confidence -- a measure of the willingness of Americans to spend -- fell in April.
"I am reasonably confident the economy will turn up," said Lyle Gramley, chief economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association and a former Federal Reserve governor, reflecting a view held not only in the Bush Administration and the Federal Reserve, but also among many private economists. "Still," he said, "you have to make adjustments, and the latest numbers are softer than I and others would have expected."
The credit markets seemed to agree that the economy was quite weak, and interest rates on bonds fell today.
The Federal Reserve's action -- praised by the President -- did not come without opposition among its policy makers. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, and the four other sitting governors control the discount rate, and they voted 4 to 1 to lower it by half a percentage point, the third such reduction since last December. Although it is the least important of the two rates, since banks borrow very little directly from the Fed, changes in the discount rate serve as a very public signal of the central bank's latest concerns about the economy.
 
One Negative Vote
 The negative vote came from Wayne Angell, a governor who has said that he believes a recovery is imminent and that lowering rates now might make the recovery too robust in the initial months, risking inflation.
A similar view among some of the Federal Reserve's other policy makers -- the chairman, the 4 governors and the 12 regional bank presidents -- has led to debate over whether the Federal funds rate should have declined as sharply as it has since last December, when it was more than 7 1/2 percent. As the rate that banks charge each other on very short-term loans, the Federal funds rate more than anything else helps to determine what banks pay for funds that are then lent to consumers and businessmen. All 17 policy makers play a role in determining its level.
Mr. Greenspan agreed in late March to consult in advance by telephone with the other policy makers when he wanted to move the Federal funds rate at the same time that the Federal Reserve changed the discount rate, officials said. This new procedure, called "enhanced consultation," was used this morning. The Fed policy makers spoke on a conference call, before the discount rate announcement.
Rate Lowest Since 1987
Some policy makers asked questions, but none reportedly objected to the Fed funds rate cut. Some objections could come to the surface, however, at the policy makers' next meeting, on May 14, if the economy turns out to be stronger than it appears today, Federal Reserve officials said. The discount rate is now at its lowest level since 1987
The discount rate announcement came just as Horst Kohler, Under Secretary of Finance for the German Government, was winding up a news conference at the conclusion of the International Monetary Fund's spring meeting here, and he greeted the news enthusiastically. "Wonderful," he said. "We gave them the advice to lower their own rates. That is what we thought they should do."
The German official had argued that the German economy, unlike the American, was still robust and that a cut in German rates would, therefore, only result in too much demand and lead to higher inflation, despite Mr. Brady's arguments to the contrary at the Sunday Group of Seven meeting. Besides, he said, lower German interest rates would result in "a free fall" in the German mark. "That is not in anyone's interests," he said.
The mark jumped in value in trading today, as the dollar weakened on the cut in American interest rates.
Mr. Brady had sought lower European rates -- and in particular lower rates in Germany, which dominates Europe's economy -- to encourage more growth and with it more purchases of American goods to help the United States out of recovery. But Germany argued that while European economies were weakening this year, they were still too strong to justify rate cuts. Nevertheless, he said that the Group of Seven nations -- the United States, Germany, Britain, France, Japan, Canada and Italy -- would consider a coordinated rate cut in the future to help the United States, if there was evidence that the American recession was deepening.
 
Signs of Some Recovery
 "We have not heard an estimate that there is a cumulative spiral downward in the United States," Mr. Kohler said. "We heard from Mr. Brady and Mr. Greenspan that there were signs of some recovery."
Mr. Greenspan and David W. Mullins Jr., vice chairman-designate of the Federal Reserve Board, have taken the lead in pushing for lower interest rates in recent months, and some of their actions were challenged on procedural grounds by other policy makers, particularly those who disagreed on strategy. The disagreement is not over whether a recovery is imminent -- nearly all the policy makers agree this is the case -- but whether some insurance is called for in the form of more rate cuts to guarantee the recovery.
With Mr. Greenspan, Mr. Mullins and a few others believing additional rate cuts were necessary, according to all accounts, the Fed lowered the discount rate and the Federal funds rate half a percentage point on Feb. 1. Mr. Greenspan advised the other policy makers, by telephone, of this action just before he put it into effect and no one objected, Federal Reserve officials said. But some objections were reportedly raised when the policy makers held one of their regular meetings five days later.
 
Set Stage for Agreement
 Then Mr. Greenspan, acting without telephone consultation with other policy makers, lowered the Federal funds rate on March 8 by a quarter of a percentage point. The Labor Department had just announced a sharp rise in the unemployment rate. The two actions reportedly set the stage for the agreement on "enhanced consultation" that was reached at the policy makers' March 26 meeting.
With the discount rate and Federal funds rate both at 6 percent, Mr. Greenspan seemed locked into consultation before today's action, if only because the Fed rarely moves the funds rate below the discount rate.
Procedurally, Mr. Greenspan and the four other governors vote on a discount rate change when regional banks submit requests for one. Today's reduction was requested by the banks in Boston, New York, Atlanta and Dallas. Later, the other banks joined the request, except for those in St. Louis and Cleveland, whose presidents have lately been reluctant to reduce rates.

HEADLINE: Dow Edges Upward 10.89, to 2,887.87

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
After stock traders waited a month for the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates, the Fed finally came through with a surprise cut, but stock prices did not respond much.
The Dow Jones industrial average edged 10.89 points higher, to 2,887.87, while the Standard & Poor's 500 moved ahead a bit more. The Nasdaq composite, though, home of many of the stronger small stocks, edged lower, along with the American Stock Exchange's market-value index. 
 Traders, economists and market strategists have been arguing for weeks that what the market needed to give it a shot in the arm was a strong dose of Fed easing.
Yesterday, with professional short- sellers overwhelmingly convinced that the market was headed lower, many had sold the market short, selling borrowed stock in the hope of profiting by buying it back later for less.
But on the opening bell, with the Fed cutting the discount rate to 5 1/2 percent from 6 percent, stocks took off.
 
Buying by Short-Sellers
 Within a few minutes it was ahead sharply. Short-sellers, scared that prices would move still higher, rushed in to buy, driving the market ahead 30 points well before 10 A.M. Then it started dropping.
By 10:30 the Dow had given up 21 points. It tried several times to recover but failed. By 11:46 and for the next 13 minutes waves of program selling lopped 11 points off the Dow.
Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said that in spite of the selling, heavy computerized buying lifted the blue-chip index 16 points.
Trading soared to 204.9 million shares, the heaviest in almost two weeks. Monday, by comparison, activity slumped to 149.9 million, barely enough to keep stockbrokers awake.
Advances led declines by 843 to 757. Still, 59 reached new highs. One was FMC, maker of chemicals and machinery, which rose 1 3/4, to 44 3/8, after a new high of 44 1/2.
Jack Solomon, market technician for Bear, Stearns & Company, said that the lukewarm response means that the market "will probably still go lower because this is the news everybody waited a month for and there was no big fanfare."
Still, he said, "It did arrest the decline of the last few days."
Analyzing the Fed rate cut, he argued that while the response at first was favorable, "so far, there's been no beneficial net effect."
He blamed fears of a recession and concerns over disappointing earnings and European interest rates, particularly high rates in Germany that siphon off money that might otherwise flow into the American market.
"The rate cut," he said, "thus may be a little bit late to have an effect to lift us out of recession."
Among the casualties yesterday, Apple Computer tumbled 3 1/4, to 55, and Quantum, a maker of computer disk drives, sank 3 5/8, to 19 7/8, both in exceptionally heavy trading after Andrew Neff, computer analyst for Bear, Stearns, eliminated his "buy" rating on the stocks.
I.B.M., which told stockholders on Monday that it felt uncertain about 1991, slid 1 7/8 in heavy trading, to 103. It also dropped to a new low for the year of 102 1/8.
Other high-tech stocks, normally leaders in an up market, were down. Digital Equipment fell 1, to 67 1/2; Intel 1 1/8, to 49 1/4; Compaq Computer 1 3/8, to 49 1/2; Borland 3 1/4, to 51 1/2, and Storage Technology, 2 7/8, to 35 7/8.
U.S. Surgical and Amgen, two medical stocks, dropped sharply after Stan Weinstein, editor of the Professional Tape Reader in Hollywood, Fla., recommended their sale because of heavy gains. U.S. Surgical slid 7 1/4, to 104, and Amgen 5, to 126 3/4, both in heavy trading.
In a quiet bank group, Wells Fargo lost 4 1/8, to 83 1/2, although there was no news to account for the drop. Mellon Bank, which will offer 5 million shares, fell 2 1/2, to 27.
UAL, which is planning a $1 billion shelf offering of notes, fell 3 7/8, to 153 3/8.

 TOKYO, Wednesday, May 1 (Reuters) -- Japanese stock prices rose today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 377.75 points, or 1.45 percent, to 26,489.00.
