HEADLINE: Insurance as a Job Benefit Shows Signs of Overwork

SERIES: The Price of Health - Fourth of five articles.

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
World War II was only a few months old. The nation was mobilizing. With millions of young men in uniform, civilian workers were in short supply and the War Labor Board, to avoid inflation, put a ceiling on wages.
So the trade unions proposed "hidden" raises. Money earmarked for raises would pay for health insurance instead. And the board gave its approval. 
 Thus was born, accidentally, the job-linked health insurance system that dominates medical care in the United States today, providing coverage for nearly 150 million people. Businesses soon became enthusiastic supporters, viewing company health plans as a recruiting lure and a "comfort factor" for employees. And the unions saw health care as a rich benefit to be won in collective bargaining.
 
System Once Worked Well
 For a time the system worked well for most companies and most workers, although since it was voluntary, many small companies never participated. Now, as medical costs climb and companies and insurers seek ways to limit their obligations, the insurance system is in turmoil and new questions are being raised about its economic and social costs.
"Corporate America thought that health care was a cost they would not see, and for many years this was the case" said Eli Ginzberg, an economist at a Columbia University. "As health care expanded, companies passed on the expenses in higher prices for their products. Now they can't pass them on very easily and they are larmed."
Arguing that health costs are putting them at a competitive disadvantage, a few big companies like the Chrysler Corporation and Caterpillar Inc. have even suggested that national health insurance might be a less expensive and more efficient alternative. Many economists say that if the country were starting from scratch, they would not choose to tie health insurance to employment. But the system is deeply entrenched and seems likely to survive, if only because a majority of the nation's largest companies still want it to.
"Companies take a lot of pride in being able to offer health benefits; it is something they have done traditionally and some of them have made big investments in systems that try to manage costs," said Sharon Canner, director of employee benefits for the National Association of Manufacturers. "It would be very hard to just dump out job-based health care."
Most of the proposals for change now being debated try to build on the system rather than scrap it, seeking ways to counter its adverse effects on the economy and people. Among other problems, the current system depresses take-home pay; gives large companies an advantage over small ones, which have to pay higher premiums for health insurance; provides some workers with better health care than others, and leaves tens of millions of Americans, some of them jobholders and some unemployed, with no insurance.
Intensifying all of these effects, economists note, is the rapid rise in health care costs. They contend that the job-linked insurance system, as it has been run in the past, has fueled that inflation by offering open-ended coverage. Employers, insurance companies and government are all now experimenting with ways to slow the rising costs, in effect trying to place ceilings on what Americans spend for health care.
 
Big Companies' Problems
Older Workers, Global Markets
Among American companies, the push for change is led mostly by big, long-established manufacturing companies, like the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, Chrysler, Caterpillar and others. They say soaring health expenses make them uncompetitive in world markets, or will once they run out of ways to offset rising bills.
The outspoken companies tend to share three characteristics: their work forces are mostly people in their 40's and 50's who require more health care than younger workers; their health plans cover a much larger number of retired workers than do those of newer companies like computer or airline concerns, and they make products that must compete on world markets.
"Our cars are not priced higher than others; you have to stay competitive," said Walter Maher, Chrysler's director of government relations. While Chrysler offsets most of the increases in health costs by reducing wage increases, this cannot go on indefinitely, Mr. Maher said. Moreover, profits are being squeezed, which might eventually dampen investment, he said.
The biggest concern of companies like Chrysler or Bethlehem is that of retirees. Chrysler has one retiree for every active worker. At Bethlehem the ratio is two retiress to each worker.
 
New Bookkeeping on Retirees
 Until now, companies with coverage for retirees paid the retirees' health care bills as they were incurred and listed the outlays as a corporate expense. But under new accounting rules set by the Financial Accounting Standards Board, a private institution whose rulings are accepted by industry and Government as if they were law, companies must estimate health care costs for present and future retirees and enter these on their books. The ruling takes effect in 1992.
I.B.M. entered the entire amount, $2.26 billion, in this year's first quarter, which cut sharply into profits. Chrysler and others are likely to spread the entry over 20 years. Whatever the method, the requirement means damage to profits, a point that Walter F. William, Bethlehem's chairman, emphasized in a recent statement to Congress.
But so far it is the workers more than the corporations who are largely footing the mounting health care bills, data show. Corporations subtract the cost increases from the money available to pay salaries. "Such cost-shifting has been showing up as slower wage growth, and not as higher labor costs for employers," said Alan Krueger, a Princeton labor economist who has studied the phenomenon.
A consequence is that while health insurance payments and Social Security taxes, adjusted for inflation, rose by 1.9 percent last year for most of the work force, wages fell by 2 percent, the Labor Department reports. Such offsets have kept total employment costs, combining wages and benefits, from rising since 1985.
 
Differing View of Implications
 But this process cannot continue, Mr. Maher says, echoing the views of many executives and their trade associations. Corporate officials express their alarm by noting that the health care costs in 1989 equalled 56 percent of pretax company profits, as against 8 percent in 1965. Or they point out that health care spending consumed 7 percent of total compensation for employees in 1989, as against 2 percent in 1965.
But economists charge that such comparisons are often misleading. Uwe E. Reinhardt of Princeton says that in Germany, health care is financed through a payroll tax that is 12.8 percent of a company's total employment costs. "I tell executives, 'You should be in Germany or Japan, where health care spending is a higher percentage of total compensation," he said.
And Mark Pauly, a health economist at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, says the real competitiveness issue is not health care costs but productivity. If a German worker can turn out, say, 100 calculators a day and an American only 80, then the revenue from selling the 20 additional calculators finances more compensation for the German. "The true competitiveness issue is whether our companies are productive enough to support a high level of compensation," Mr. Pauly said. "How the compensation is split between health care and take-home pay isn't relevant."
 
Problems of Uninsured
Government Role Favored by Many
The preference of business leaders for retaining health insurance that is tied to employment, and their recognition of the system's inadequacies, emerged in a recent poll of chairmen and chief executives at 1,000 of the nation's largest companies. Seventy-five percent of the executives said they wanted to keep employers, not the Government, as the chief brokers in funneling money into health care.
But 67 percent said that while they did not want national health insurance, they did want the Government to pay for the growing number of Americans who lack any coverage.
"These executives are saying, 'We want to keep the employer areas,' " said Randolph Desonia, program officer for the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, a New Jersey philanthropy on health issues that sponsored the survey by the Gallup organization. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points.
For the companies, the burden of runaway health costs is compounded by the bills for society's uninsured. When a patient cannot pay for medical care, doctors and hospitals can make up some of their loss by adding to the fees they charge patients who do have insurance. Since insured patients are mostly covered by company policies, the companies pay higher insurance premiums.
Similarly, as payments from Medicaid and to a lesser degree Medicare have failed to cover the costs incurred by their poor and elderly clients, uncovered hospital costs have been shifted to private insurers.
 
Major Cause of Labor Strife
 The battle between corporate owners and workers over who will pay the mounting bills has made health care a major issue in collective bargaining. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. estimates that three-fourths of the days lost to strikes in 1989 involved disputes over health care. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and several steel companies, for example, agreed last year, after strikes, to maintain health benefits. But the extra expense curtailed wage increases, which in each case were fixed to rise by less than 3 percent a year, or less than the expected inflation rate.
To help save the system, and hold down their own health costs, the major employer organizations want the Government to fill the gaps in the current system. Groups like the Business Roundtable, the National Association of Manufacturers, the National Federation of Independent Business and the United States Chamber of Commerce propose that the Government provide better coverage for the elderly, the poor and those who are now uninsured. Since many of the uninsured work for smaller businesses, there is also wide support for new regulations aimed at providing cheaper policies to small groups.
"There is always the notion in the United States that government is encroaching on the private sector," Dr. Reinhardt said. "But the government is also being asked to be a shovel brigade, bailing out employers in health care."
 
Small Companies' Problems
As Costs Go Up, Pay Is Squeezed
The current system produces inequities that have increasingly given some Americans more health care than others. Generally, workers at large companies do better than employees of small ones and unionized workers fare better than nonunion.
Among small companies, there is a growing third tier. As health insurance premiums rise, the many companies that want to pay roughly $8 an hour or less to cover both the pay and benefits for most employees discover that they cannot divert more money to health care without reducing wages below $5 or $6 an hour, a level frequently unacceptable to workers. So such companies, including, for example, many restaurants and other service concerns, often do not provide medical insurance.
Three-fourths of the 33 million Americans without health insurance are workers or their dependents, Federal data show, and the number is rising. Most of these work for small operations of fewer than 25 people. But some low-wage workers at fast-food chains and other big retail operations also lack health insurance.
 
Further Economic Distortions
 "There is just so much money to pay employees, and at some level of pay, you can't take money out of the pay package anymore to put it into health insurance," said William Dennis, research director of the National Federation of Independent Business, representing 550,000 companies, most of which employ fewer than 20 people and pay, on average, less than $10 an hour.
The federation favors the Government's paying medical bills for households with annual incomes below $15,000.
The job-based insurance system distorts the economy in additional ways. One is the uneven pattern of insurance premiums, with small companies forced to pay much more for each employee than, say, General Motors, General Electric or International Business Machines.
The national average is $2,300 a year, but a company the size of I.B.M., with tens of thousands of workers, can come in below average by spreading the cost more easily than a company with fewer than 500 employees. I.B.M. has enough healthy, young workers who do not require much medical care that their payments subsidize the older employees, who might require more medical attention than their payments can finance.
As a result, smaller companies, particularly the vast number with fewer than 50 employees, often have to pay more than $3,000 a person for an annual health insurance policy, said Karen Davis, chairman of the health policy and management department at Johns Hopkins University. That forces the companies to either charge higher prices to cover health costs or offer employees less pay, economists say. Both alternatives can make a company less competitive.
Various schemes have been proposed to reduce insurance premiums for these smaller companies, which employ more than half of the nation's work force. One frequent proposal, put forth by the insurance companies themselves, would set up an insurance pool, privately operated, offering back-up coverage to insurers, who would then feel more secure about providing coverage for thousands of workers in small companies.
The goal would be to simulate the sort of broadly based insurance that large companies with thousands of employees can provide, said Carl J. Schramm, president of the Health Insurance Association of America. Ten small companies might have 10 different health insurance carriers, but each of the 10 carriers would in effect sell part of the risk to a "reinsurer." The reinsurer, forming a pool that covered many employees, would spread the risk and thus lower rates.
 
Some Inequity Likely to Remain
 As part of the plan, the insurance companies would not be allowed to deny insurance to a small company's employees, a restriction that is likely to prod insurance companies into trying to negotiate fee ceilings with doctors and hospitals, Mr. Schramm says.
But whatever the rule changes, some inequity in premiums is likely to remain. For one thing, low-income workers, concentrated in small companies, are less healthy than higher-income workers in larger companies. For another, the costs of administering a small company's health insurnance eat up 30 percent to 40 percent of the premiums, as against 10 percent or less for plans covering many more employees, Dr. Davis estimates.
The system favors big over small companies in another way. Corporations are allowed to deduct their contributions to health care from profits, a deduction that saves them billions of dollars in taxes. Small, unincorporated companies do not qualify for this tax break.
"The small company market, no matter how you cut the cards, will end up with rates that are higher than those paid by larger employers," Mr. Schramm said.
Another drag on the economy in the current insurance system is its tendency to limit an insured worker's ability to switch jobs and still have health insurance on the new job. Economists consider such "portability" vital to the efficiency of a free-enterprise system, with workers free to seek better pay and companies more produtive workers. But switching jobs and insurance is becoming harder for workers who have chronic medical conditions or histories of ailments like cancer. Proposed changes in insurance regulation would address the problem.
Such built-in inequities and inefficiencies have led some conservative theorists, as well as liberals who want national health insurance, to propose scrapping the current system. The conservative Heritage Foundation, for example, has urged eliminating the tax break for corporate policies, instead giving personal tax credits so that people can buy their health insurance directly.
 
Problem-Solving Efforts
Leverage Has Limits
While most companies have so far managed to remain competitive by shifting most of the rising health care costs to employees rather than into higher prices, this approach tended until recently to make companies lazy about cost control, Dr. Reinhardt and others say.
"When I talk to business, I say, 'Look, you're not using your money; you're using employees' money,' " Dr. Reinhardt said. "I've asked, 'Did you stop to think that you might be taking such and such a percentage of your employees' money and blowing it wastefully on health care?' "
The money "wasted" by generous, open-ended health plans that encouraged overuse, in this argument could be used more productively by society to support education, public works, the environment and high-tech machinery or could allow higher pay, which would eventually show up in more consumer spending.
Companies and their insurers are now trying to hold down costs with strategies like making workers pay higher deductibles and urging more workers into health maintenance organizations or other "managed care" plans.
And while they wait for better solutions, some companies are trying to negotiate cost controls on their own.
Some have tried to improve their bargaining power through service contracts with networks of doctors and hospitals. The doctors and hospitals are offered thousands of insured employees as patients, if they agree to ceilings on their fees and other controls. The Hewlett-Packard Company, the computer giant that has 20,000 workers in the San Francisco area, has such an arrangement with El Camino Hospital there.
But even that big a worker pool provides El Camino with only 2 percent of its patients. "We picked that hospital because it was already a low-cost, quality provider," said Robert Hungate, director of government affairs and health care at Hewlett-Packard. "But we can't leverage the hospital much. We are not trying to force discounts."
The General Electric Company, with an aircraft engine plant in Cincinnati and 18,000 workers there, teamed up with the Procter & Gamble Company, which is headquartered there, to increase their leverage with a network of doctors and hospitals that have contracted to care for thousands of employes of the two companies.
But with all their size, General Electric and Procter & Gamble fail to provide most of the network's patients. "The group practice we are attempting is in an early stage and there is still a fair amount of uncertainty about how much it will have to evolve to be effective in controlling costs," said Charles Buck, G.E.'s director of health care management.

HEADLINE: Wages Show a More Moderate Advance

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
Wages, salaries and benefits paid to American workers rose 4.6 percent over the last 12 months, a much slower advance than the year before, the Government said today in a report viewed as evidence that wage inflation was abating.
Analysts said the more moderate rise in the Labor Department's employment cost index, considered one of the best gauges of wage inflation pressures, probably played a part in the Federal Reserve's move to lower the discount rate. 
 The 4.6 percent increase in overall compensation costs for the year ending March 1991 marked a sharp decline from a year ago, when those costs had soared 5.5 percent for a similar 12-month period.
Also today, the Labor Department said that workers covered by collective bargaining agreements settled so far this year won annual wage gains averaging 3.4 percent over the life of the pact. Previously, those contracts had provided 2 percent annual gains.
The employment cost report showed that both wages and salaries and benefit costs appeared to be moving downward. Wages and salaries increased 4.2 percent for the year ended in March, compared with a 4.4 percent increase a year ago.
For the last year, too, there was a substantial slowdown in benefit cost increases, which rose 5.9 percent for 12 months ended in March, down from the 7.4 percent spurt for the year ended in December.
In the first quarter of 1991, benefit costs rose 1.4 percent, well below the 2 percent increase for the corresponding three-month period a year ago.

HEADLINE: Brooklyn Tells Tourists, Yo! Don't Overlook Us

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
The bedroom's lace curtains rustle in a cool spring breeze, filtering dots of sunlight onto a four-poster bed. Like hundreds of other bed-and-breakfasts throughout America, the appeal of Donald Kurz-Fiedeke's small hostelry is its 19th-century charm, its whiff of romance.
But just beyond the curtains and a well-tended garden, laundry hangs from red-brick tenements; a block from the front door are decaying East River piers, and a short stroll away is the Pulaski Bridge, which connects southwestern Queens with Greenpoint in Brooklyn, the setting for Mr. Kurz-Fiedeke's Brooklyn Bed and Breakfast. 
 The presence of a bed-and-breakfast amid the industrial grit of Greenpoint tells the story of Brooklyn's quixotic but resurgent aspirations to become a tourist mecca.
The hearts of Brooklyn boosters have been stirred in recent weeks by a combination of optimistic, if unlikely sounding, developments: the publication of a full-fledged Brooklyn guidebook, the first of its kind in 50 years, its publishers say; the reawakening of plans for a Downtown Brooklyn Hilton Hotel, and the designation of Brooklyn, by the New York State Department of Economic Development, as its official "I Love New York" destination for next spring.
But the very idea of attracting out-of-town visitors to the borough whose most famous landmarks -- Coney Island, the Navy Yard, Ebbets Field -- are dead or dying, and whose international image lies somewhere between Beirut and Podunk, has the inevitable flavor of a routine by a Brooklyn-born comedian like Henny Youngman: "They dropped a bomb on Brooklyn," he said the other day. "It did a million dollars' improvement."
 
'In the Shadow of Manhattan'
 "I won't say that Brooklyn is a hard sell," said Borough President Howard Golden, who tirelessly touts his turf and whose words of welcome greet drivers on the Brooklyn, Manhattan and Williamsburg Bridges. "But our No. 1 problem is that we sit in the shadow of Manhattan. And the only time you see Brooklyn in the news is if there's some violent act."
Whereas 25 million out-of-town visitors come to pump more than $12 billion a year into New York City every year, pumping more than $12 billion into its 's economy, only an comparatively infinitesimal trickle find their way to Brooklyn. De spite a wealth of cultural institutions like the Brooklyn Museum and theBrooklyn Botanic Garden, landmarked buildings, historic neighborhoods, and a world-famous beach and a wealth of cultural institutions like the Brooklyn Museum and the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, Brooklyn faces several seemingly insoluble problems in attracting out-of-towners.
At the New York Aquarium on Coney Island, for example, only 5 to 10 percent of its 775,000 annual visitors are non-New Yorkers, said a spokesman, Rick Miller. And at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, barely 2 percent of its 250,000 ticket buyers are from out of town, said Doug Allan, the academy's vice president for marketing.
With Brooklyn a low priority for state and city tourism officials, the job of promoting Brooklyn to tourists has fallens to poorly financed private hands. One organization, the Fund for the Borough of Brooklyn, prints attractive booklets on picturesque neighborhoods, famous Brooklynites and noteworthy poets and restaurateurs. Robert Ohlerking, a freelance promoter, has a project called Destination Brooklyn, but the effort it has stalled, and he is now seeking to unite local institutions behind the cause.
 
New York's 'Soul'
 In general, their Brooklyn is an antidote to the showiness across the bridge, a place where an out-of-towner can experience the real New York. "Brooklyn is an ideal destination for visitors who've been to New York before, seen all the Manhattan sites, and want to discover the rest of the city," Mr. Ohlerking said.
Ellen Freudenheim -- whose new guidebook, "Brooklyn: Where to Go, What to Do, How to Get There," is being promoted as Brooklyn's first in a half century, calls Brooklyn New York's "elusive soul" to Manhattan's "thumping heart."
"Brooklyn's got personality because it's so ethnically diverse and human-scaled," says the guidebook by Ms. Freudenheim and her husband, Daniel P. Wiener. "And it's a treasure chest of history, culture and family fun."
Judy Deutsch, who came with her husband, Harry, from St. Louis last week to visit New York, heard of Liana Paolella's Victorian on the Park bed-and-breakfast in Park Slope, and decided to opt for something different from the high-priced, high-glitz, high-density midtown hotels.
"I've come to New York many times, but I wanted to be out of the Manhattan rat race," she said, sitting in her $135-a-night garden-floor suite, replete with Oriental rugs, antique furniture and a fireplace. "The first night, I felt I was imposing on someone else's house, but then it felt wonderfully homey, quiet and relaxed. It's a nice respite after a day in Manhattan."
 
Where Whitman Edited
 Despite such testimonials, even the boosters acknowledge that Brooklyn is widely perceived as a place whose glory days have long passed. Baseball pilgrims in search of Ebbets Field will find a housing project.; d Dreamers may prowl the Coney Island Boardwalk in search of the ghosts of fabled turn-of-the-century amusement parks like Dreamland and Luna Park, only to find the crumbling Parachute Jump., And the printing plant for the daily newspaper that Walt Whitman once edited, The Brooklyn Eagle, is now a heavily guarded luxury condominium.
Some 800 murders were committed in the borough last year, the police say -- a rate no higher or lower than the city as a whole. Yet to legions of out-of-towners, Brooklyn is little more than a famous bridge and the a grisly setting for the grisly crime du jour.
Beyond its image of decline, Brooklyn seems either unable to capitalize on its resources or hellbent on cultivating attractions that may not exert magnetic appeal on to the occasional visitor.
 
Not for Everybody
 At the Transit Museum, for example, one can pay more than the cost of a token to descend into one of New York's typically cheery subway stations and get on a train and go nowhere. The Harbor Defense Museum, hidden on the Fort Hamilton aArmy base near the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, beckons to those with an interest in 19th-century coastal fortifications. For tourists in search of panoramic views, a platform atop the Grand Army Plaza Arch is open 28 days a year. But the pinnacle of the borough's tallest building, the 512-foot-tall Williamsburg Savings Bank, is off-limits to all visitors except those with bad teeth. It is a dentist's office.
Less quirky attractions like the borough's Dutch colonial and Victorian homes are unknown; its Russian and West Indian nightclubs are frequented largely by people who live in the area; imaginative small museums like the Brooklyn Children's Museum and the Brooklyn Historical Society are often bereft of visitors, and potentially attractive recreation areas languish -- places like Floyd Bennett Field and Marine Park, both in the Gateway National Recreation Area, and even Coney Island.
 
Where to Stay
 Brooklyn's once-great hotels like the St. George, where Brooklyn Dodgers cavorted in the hallways; the Brooklyn Arms, and the Half Moon on Coney Island and the St. George, the city's largest in 1929 with more than 2,600 rooms, are now either apartments, welfare hotels or homes for the elderly.
Now the borough's has only two sizable overnight accommodations. One is now are the Gregory Hotel, a recently refurbished 66-room establishment in the Bay Ridge section that rivals Manhattan hotels at least in with its rates -- of $115 to $245 a night. (It also has and a Sinatra suite for honeymooners.), The other is and the 150-room Golden Gate, a 1960's-vintage, Interstate-style motel built for the 1964-65 World's Fair. Less enticing to out-of-towners are a strip of motels along the Shore Parkway distinguished mainly by their advertisements for mirrored ceilings and short-stay rates.
About 50 times a year, half-filled Gray Line buses take tourists from Manhattan to 12 of the borough's "key points of interest," including a view of lower Manhattan's skyline. These money-losing tours are subsidized by the city and state.
The city's Convention and Visitors Bureau has increased its efforts to promote Brooklyn and its attractions, yet the borough has been all but invisible in travel magazines and New York City guidebooks.
 
A Seed Grows in Brooklyn
 "It's not that it's not worth covering, but it's a hard sell to readers," said Ila Stanger, the editor of Travel & Leisure magazine. "It's hard enough to get Manhattanites to cross a bridge to Brooklyn, so it's hard to expect an out-of-towner to come there."
The borough's brightest glimmer of hope for tourism is now an empty downtown lot behind the State Supreme Court. As soon as the city approves a leasing agreement for what is optimistically called Renaissance Plaza, ground will be broken on a 31-story office building that is to include a 380-room Brooklyn Hilton. Alas, even the builder, the Muss Development Company, sees the Hilton as "mainly a business hotel, and clearly not the first choice for tourists coming to New York," said a spokesman, Lloyd Kaplan.
A more fundamental problem is that the hotel is likely to share the building with the Brooklyn District Attorney's Office. So, as guests search for the health club or conference rooms, they may be confronted with a steady stream of lawyers, police officers and felons.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
The Fed cut interest rates, noting that the latest data showed the economy to still be quite weak. It cut the discount rate to 5 1/2 percent and the Federal funds rate to 5 3/4 percent. [Page A1.]
Four regulators urged lawmakers to adopt a Treasury proposal for a banking overhaul, setting the stage for a showdown between the Administration and Congressional Democrats. [D1.] 
 Labor Secretary Martin proposed changing the nation's pension laws to encourage the creation of retirement programs for some 42 million workers in America who are not covered now. [D1.]
Orders for factory goods fell 2.8 percent in March, the fifth straight decline, the Government said. [D5.]
Prices that farmers get for raw products were unchanged from March to April, the Agriculture Department said. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Fire Damages a Nuclear Plant in Maine

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Me., April 30

 BODY:
A nuclear power plant in Maine was crippled by explosions and a fire Monday night, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today, but it said no radiation was released into the air.
The commission and officials of the Maine Yankee nuclear power plant in Wiscasset said the flames, heat and firefighting efforts did no damage to the reactor or other nuclear parts of the plant. Automatic firefighting equipment in the nuclear part was not needed, they said. 
 The fire began at 6:32 P.M. in the non-nuclear part of the plant, plant officials and the commission said. Its cause has not been determined, but employees told Federal investigators they heard what appeared to be explosions before the fire broke out near the plant's main electrical transformer and beneath the turbine generator.
The fire occurred 100 feet to 200 feet from the containment building that encases the plant's nuclear reactor within a 4 1/2-foot-thick wall of concrete reinforced with steel.
Plant officials said the fire burned for four hours and was fed by hydrogen used to cool the generator. It was hot enough to cause the main electrical transformer to buckle, rupturing seals, and allowing thousands of gallons of lubricating oil to spill into a catchment area outside the plant. At least 200 gallons of oil leaked into the Back River, plant officials said.
No one was injured, plant officials said today in a prepared statement.
 
System Worked, Officials Say
 Richard H. Wessman, project director in the Office of Nuclear Reactor Regulation for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, stressed that although the fire appeared to be severe such accidents have occurred before in nuclear and conventionally powered electrical generating plants. The automatic shutdown system, as intended, shut down the reactor without incident immediately after the fire broke out, he said.
At a news conference this afternoon, Maine Yankee's president, Charles Frizzle, also said the fire could have happened at any power plant.
"I don't want to downgrade the seriousness of the event," Mr. Frizzle said, "but it's not a nuclear event. From my perspective, this should not reflect negatively on the use of nuclear power. It has nothing to do with nuclear power."
 
Crucial Time for Industry
 The accident occurred during a politically sensitive period for the American nuclear power industry. On Thursday, the regulatory commission is to rule on a staff recommendation to restart a reactor at Browns Ferry, a troubled nuclear plant near Athens, Ala., that has been shut for safety reasons since March 1985. John Moulton, a spokesman for the Tennessee Valley Authority in Knoxville, Tenn., the plant's owner, said the accident in Maine should not effect the decision to restart Browns Ferry.
Next week, the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee is scheduled to vote on a measure that would streamline the licensing procedures for nuclear power plants. The changes, proposed by the committee's chairman, Senator J. Bennett Johnston, Democrat of Louisiana, would make licensing a one-step process and eliminate almost every stage that enables the public to make comments.
The Bush Administration has also staked a sizeable portion of its national energy strategy on reviving nuclear power. It says the 110 American nuclear power plants are safe and are far less polluting than electric power plants fueled by coal or oil. The Administration has also financed studies through the Department of Energy to design a new generation of nuclear reactors that would be largely incapable of melting down.
But critics of the technology say that splitting atoms to gain energy is inherently dangerous and insist that the mining, milling, and processing of uranium for nuclear fuel is one of the dirtiest and most dangerous industries in the United States. Moreover, they say, the Administration has yet to find a permanent solution for safe disposal of radioactive wastes from nuclear power plants.
The regulatory commission reported today that unplanned incidents occurred Monday and last week at two other nuclear plants in New England, forcing their shutdown.
A leak of hot water in the nuclear containment vessel at the Pilgrim nuclear plant in Plymouth, Mass. prompted its shutdown on Monday, the commission said, but no radiation was released. The plant's owner, the Boston Edison Company, had been aware of the leak for weeks before the shutdown and planned to repair it during a planned shutdown beginning May 4. A worsening of the leak caused the utility to take the reactor out of service early.
The other incident occurred April 24, when the Vermont Yankee nuclear plant five miles south of Brattleboro suddenly lost its primary source of power. The interruption of power prompted the plant to turn on its independent electrical generators and led to an unplanned shutdown of the reactor. The incident may have caused when an employee mistakenly tripped a switch that caused all power into the plant to be cut off, the regulatory commission said. Its investigators are studying the incident.
For more than a decade Maine Yankee, which sits along the coast about 40 miles northeast of Portland, has been at the center of a struggle between environmentalists and the nuclear power industry. Critics tried three times from 1980 to 1987 to shut it down with voter referendums on statewide ballots; each time about 60 percent of voters favored keeping the plant open.
Leaders of the Maine Nuclear Referendum Committee, an antinuclear group based in Portland that has led the campaign to close Maine Yankee, said today that since last July the plant has been shut down nine times because of unexpected problems. "We feel very strongly that what we're dealing with is an aging nuclear reactor that is beginning to show its age," Thomas Coffin, a spokesman for the group, said.
Residents of Wiscasset say the plant has been a good neighbor, a good employer and a supplier of about 90 percent of the local tax base. Of the plant's 420 employees, many come from Wiscasset, which has a population of about 3,400.
"Until they come up with a better alternative, I support its being here," said Robert Rogers, who lives less than a mile from the plant. "It does pump quite a lot of money into the economy here, and they've had a real good safety record."
The regulatory commission said that in the last several years the owners of Maine Yankee have received the Government's highest rating for operating the plant.
Maine Yankee, which began operating commercially in 1972, is owned by 10 utility companies in New England, with the Central Maine Power Company having the largest share. The 825-megawatt plant was designed Combustion Engineering Inc., a nationally known engineering company in Stamford, Conn. It provides low-cost electric power to about one-fourth of the homes and businesses in Maine.
Plant executives said today it was too early to determine when Maine Yankee would return to service. The generator and transformers sustained extensive damage, and the plant could be shut down for weeks if not months. But the shutdown will not cause a shortage in power, they said, because hydroelectric power is plentiful this time of year.
The regulatory commission sent a team of experts Monday night to investigate the causes of the explosion and fire and determine how well the plant's operators and its automatic systems responded.

HEADLINE: Courts' Role as Land Manager Grows

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, April 30

 BODY:
A zoologist who tracks nocturnal birds in the forest was in court here today, trying to explain the breeding habits of an owl to a Federal judge. One floor below, another Federal judge was going over maps prepared by the Government to determine how much land the owl needed to avoid extinction.
The cases are likely to result in the most sweeping land protection measures ever taken on behalf of wildlife, restrictions on millions of acres. The cases also illustrate that, more than ever, many of the nation's most important natural resource decisions are being made by Federal judges. 
 Whether the dispute is over bison in Yellowstone National Park, salmon on the Columbia River or wolves in the high Rockies, questions that were usually left up to scientists have moved into the courtroom.
Last year 540 legal challenges were made to the Forest Service's timber-selling program nationwide -- a record, more than doubling the previous year's 234 appeals. Federal timber policy is essentially paralyzed, with most logging on national forests in the Pacific Northwest halted by injunction or similiar legal threat.
 
Restraining Order on Bison
 The story is much the same in some national parks. A plan, years in the making, to shoot 25 bison in Yellowstone National Park as part of a test on disease was halted earlier this month after a judge in Washington, D.C., issued a restraining order.
Under possible threat of judicial order, Federal dams on the Columbia River are drawing down their water this spring to help save endangered salmon, which need a strong current to help them migrate.
Environmentalists say there are more than enough laws to protect land and wildlife; what is lacking, they say, is enforcement of those laws. The higher the economic cost, the more likely it is that the cases will end up in court. The plan to save owls, for example, could result in more than 20,000 lost logging jobs; bringing wolves back to the Rocky Mountains is said to pose a threat to the cattle industry.
"The laws are there, but the Administration is just not following them," said Representative Norm Dicks, Democrat of Washington. "If they would simply follow the law, we wouldn't be in this mess."
In the absence of clear direction from the top, some wildlife managers and forest supervisors say they are now as likely to get their management instructions from a judge as they are from agency heads.
 
Concern About Court Role
 "When you have a judge interpreting the Endangered Species Act the way some of them are doing it now, in essence the judge is acting as the Secretary of Interior," said Steven Goldstein, a spokesman for Manuel Lujan Jr., the Interior Secretary. "Obviously that is a major concern to us."
Until the mid-1980's the Government would decide how much Federal timber from national forests it would sell, then move ahead with minimal delays. But in recent years, court injunctions on behalf of owls, grizzly bears, fish or other creatures protected by law have tied up the program.
"I look at court action now as the basic cost of doing business," said John Butruille, the Regional Forester for the Pacific Northwest.
Administration officials say they are trying to strike a balance with laws designed to protect animals that can also require a huge human sacrifice.
"For many years it was as easy to support the Endangered Species Act as it was motherhood or apple pie," said Mr. Goldstein. "But that's not the case anymore."
 
The Owl and the Secretary
 One lawsuit, now before Federal District Judge Thomas Zilly in Seattle, is entitled: Northern Spotted Owl v. Manuel Lujan. After the owl was listed as a threatened species, imperiled by logging of its forest home in Washington, Oregon and Northern California, the Administration and Congress failed to agree on a long-term plan on how much land to set aside for the owl.
Environmentalists stepped in, asking the the United States District Court to force the Government to come up with a plan. Last Friday, two days before the court deadline, the Fish and Wildlife Service announced that logging might have to be restricted on 11.6 million acres. The plan, which timber industry officials say could cost $600 million a year in lost jobs and income, is now before Judge Zilly.
A second owl lawsuit, before Federal District Judge William L. Dwyer of Seattle, targets another Federal agency, the Forest Service, for failing to sufficiently curb logging in national forests. Judge Dwyer today convened an extraordinary 10-day hearing on the fate of the nation's last big sections of old-growth forests. Loggers, biologists, timber managers and others will testify. At the end of the hearing, the Judge Dwyer will act on a request to shut down logging for up to 15 months in the most productive timber-producing region in the country. Such an injunction would cost more than 20,000 jobs, Government officials said.
 
Plea for Law Enforcement
 "Again and again, environmentalists are going to court to simply ask judges that they enforce the laws that are on the books," said Todd True, the lead lawyer for the group of environmentists before Judge Dwyer.
Bill Pickell, general manager of the Washington Contract Loggers Association, said, "I think foresters should be making these decisions, not Federal judges."
The foresters, who often live in the same community where jobs may be curbed to save an animal, are not immune to the views of their neighbors.
"There was a tremendous amount of political pressure put on the Forest Service last year to not follow their own scientific report," said Representative Dicks. "As a result, things are much worse than ever before."
On rare occasions, Congress has tried to exempt some land and wildlife decisions from judicial review. But those Congressional actions have also wound up in court.
"We're dealing with the system, checks and balances, the way it's always been, " said Mr. Butruille. "It's just that more people are using it than ever before. I've never seen such a level of public interest in natural resource decisions."

HEADLINE: New Orders At Factories Drop by 2.8%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
Orders for factory goods fell 2.8 percent in March, the fifth straight decline, the Government said today in a report showing widespread weakness persisting in the industrial sector.
Laurence H. Meyer, head of the St. Louis economic forecasting firm of Laurence H. Meyer & Associates, said the Commerce Department report "convinced us the economy is still sliding" and would post a third quarter of negative growth from April through June. 
 Falling orders for both durable and nondurable goods contributed to the decline, with orders for durable goods at their lowest level in three and a half years.
The Federal Reserve cited the continuing weakness in the industrial and capital goods areas today when it announced that it was lowering its discount rate to 5 1/2 percent from 6 percent.
It was the third such move in four months and was intended to drive down interest rates on other loans and thus stimulate the economy.
The Commerce Department report said new orders for both durable and nondurable goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $226.6 billion, down from $233.1 billion in February. New orders have fallen every month since October.
Orders for durable goods -- items from trucks to turbines expected to last more than three years -- fell a revised 4.9 percent, to $111.8 billion. It was the lowest level since September 1987, when orders had fallen to $111.7 billion.
Although the decline in durables orders was less than the 6.2 percent estimate reported last week, it was the fourth drop in the last five months.
The key category of nonmilitary capital goods fell 5 percent, to $32.1 billion, its third consecutive monthly loss. This category is often a barometer of industry plans to expand and modernize.
"At first, I thought we would see the bottom in the first quarter," said Evalina Tainer, an economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. "But the fact that it continued in the first quarter means capital spending will be pretty anemic for three to six more months."
Transportation orders tumbled 5 percent, to $28.3 billion, for the third consecutive drop. Excluding this category, however, orders still fell 2.5 percent.
Orders for electronic and other electrical equipment plunged 13.5 percent, to $15.6 billion, wiping out an 11.2 percent gain a month earlier. Primary metals were down 1 percent, to $9.7 billion, after posting a 2.8 percent advance in February.
Orders for nondurable goods declined six-tenths of a percent, to $114.9 billion, in part because of a large drop for chemicals and petroleum products. Nondurable goods orders have fallen every month since October.
Unfilled orders, an indication of how busy factories will be in coming months, slipped four-tenths of a percent, to $524.9 billion.

HEADLINE: For A Lot of Mainers, Lobstering Life Is Losing Allure

BYLINE: By DENA KLEIMAN

DATELINE: SPRUCE HEAD, Me.

 BODY:
IT was more than 100 years ago that Maynard Post first put down lobster traps in the icy waters off this isolated fishing village on the craggy Maine coastline.
Both of his sons became lobstermen. So did four of his grandsons, as well as three of his great-grandsons, in what has been far less a job than a proud heritage passed from one generation to the next. 
 But a kind of malaise has settled over the lobster industry in Maine, a state known more for its salt-of-the-earth common sense than for introspection and self-analysis.
As the state prepares for its busy summer lobster season, which unofficially begins today, the Posts along with many other Maine lobstermen, wholesalers, biologists and others are worried about where Maine's $180 million lobster business -- the largest in the world after Canada's, and a major tourist attraction -- is headed.
"No question we're at a turning point," said Dave Dow, director of the Lobster Institute, an industry-supported education and research group at the University of Maine in Orono. "All of us are scrambling around trying to figure out how we can put the king of seafood back on its throne."
The problem is that last year the supply of Maine lobster was at an all-time high and its dock-side price was the lowest since 1981. In 1988 the average price lobstermen received from wholesalers was close to $3 a pound, an all-time high, but last year the average dipped to $2.13, according to the National Marine Fisheries Service in Portland, Me., and retail prices fell as well.
"We've got to fish twice as hard to earn the same amount of money," said Darren Post, 25 years old. Like his father, grandfather and great-grandfather before him he is a lobsterman in Spruce Head, which is just south of Rockland and about 90 miles northeast of Portland. And like many, he worries about the industry's future.
Industry analysts say the decrease in the price of lobster is due in part to today's lean economic times, to the general decline in sales of luxury items and to competition from other species of seafood around the world that are being marketed more aggressively.
But clearly a chief reason for the 1990 price decline was the record catch, estimated at more than 28 million pounds. More lobster were caught in Maine last year than ever before; the second-largest catch was 101 years ago, in 1889, when 24 million pounds were caught.
Part of the uncertainty brewing in Maine is just what to do about the oversupply at a time when new technology has made it easier to catch a lobster than ever before and when the state has sought to regulate the lobster industry out of fear that overfishing would lead to the species' decline.
"Lobster continues to be an overfished resource," said Jay Krouse, chairman of the lobster and crab fisheries division of the Maine Department of Marine Resources in Booth Bay Harbor. "And without lobster there is no industry."
Currently, lobstermen must throw back "chicken lobsters," those that measure less than 3 1/4 inches from the eye socket to the tail, a restriction begun in 1988.
Lobstermen oppose this measure because these smaller lobsters, which weigh about a pound each, are highly desired by Japanese consumers and provide a lucrative export market for Canada, which does not have such size restrictions.
But biologists argue that last year's record catch may mask serious losses in the lobster population. They note, for example, that the average lobster caught in the mid-1960's weighed five pounds, but the average today weighs just over two.
Over the heated objections of lobstermen, a number of bills have recently been introduced into the Maine Legislature to further restrict lobstering. These include proposals to limit the number of traps lobstermen may set as well as putting a limit on the lobstering season, which currently extends all year long.
"It will soon get to the point where it won't pay anymore for many to fish," said Gilbert Post, 51, who has been fishing for lobster off Spruce Head since he was 10.
Mr. Post and his family, who all live within a few blocks of each other, have been busy these past few weeks painting buoys and repairing traps for the new season. Speaking to them provides a window into the frustrations, joys and uncertainties that surround lobstering in Maine.
"To us lobstering is all that we know," said Richard Post, 48, who is Gilbert's younger brother and who remembers catching his first lobster when he was 3. "It is all I ever wanted to be as a child. I knew I wanted to become a lobsterman when I was 2. But these days it's gotten almost to the point where it no longer pays. The price of bait keeps going up but the price of lobster keeps going down. Everyone's got ideas but no one really knows what to do."
At this season the haunting sound of a fog horn often pierces the quiet of this modest but immaculately kept village. The dock overlooking the Atlantic is crowded with mountains of wire traps and ruddy-faced men.
Like 85 percent of Maine's lobstermen, the Posts fish from May through October when the frigid waters warm and lobsters become more mobile. During these warmer months lobsters typically migrate from the deeper ocean floor to shallower waters nearer land, where they shed their shells so they can grow.
The Posts set lobster traps in the same spots that Maynard ("Grampy") Post used more than a century ago in what is an unofficial but firmly enforced inheritance in Maine. (Lobstermen are known to come to blows over fishing spots.)
But the difference is that when Maynard Post fished for lobsters all he had to guide him were his compass and a watch, whereas his great-grandsons would not think of looking for lobster without a computer.
Indeed most lobster boats today are equipped not only with devices that can tell the precise location of where the lobsterman caught lobsters before but also instruments that register the depth and composition of the ocean floor. The best place to catch a lobster is on a ledge leading from shallow to deep water, and the only way Maynard Post could determine that was with a piece of rope and a weight. Old lobster hands like David Post, 73 years old, who is one of Maynard's sons, feels that the art of lobstering has disappeared.
"Today anyone can catch a lobster," said Mr. Post, who is the father of Gilbert and Richard. He is convinced that the new technology aboard lobster boats is to blame for many of industry's current woes. Because it is so easy to catch a lobster, he says, so many more lobsters are being caught by so many more inexperienced people that there is far more supply than there is demand.
Years ago all a lobsterman needed to do to make a living was to set 100 traps; today each of the Posts sets between 800 and 1,000 traps. It is cold, hard work that requires hauling some 300 wire traps on board each day to retrieve the catch and replace bait. (But an energetic lobsterman can earn as much as $80,000 a year.)
"There are only so many hours in a day," said Ashley Post, 44, another of Maynard's grandchildren living here in Spruce Head.
Like most of his relatives, Ashley Post rarely thinks of eating lobster because of all the effort involved in the catch. In recent years, he said, he has often put in 12-hour days. "Before, it was fun. Now it's just work."
Despite these difficult times, lobstering appears to be in the Post family's blood. Just talking of a new season seems to give them a tangible spirit of renewal. "The fever," they call it in Spruce Head, when men awake at 5 A.M. and rush to the sea to check the tide.
"Once you get in a boat and you get a little salt water in your face, that's what happens to you," said David Post, now retired, who desperately misses his days at sea.
"It's the cold; it's the wind; it's the freedom of it," said Gilbert Post, David's son, who still loves what he does.
"I love it too," said Duwayne Post, Gilbert's 29-year-old son, adding that from the time he was a child, becoming a lobsterman was the only thing he ever wanted to do. He gave his boat the name Skylark -- the same as his great-grandfather Maynard's -- and says he is proud of his heritage. He has a son, Dennis, who is 4.
"But it's not something I want anymore for my son," he said. "No one knows where all of this is going to lead."

HEADLINE: Unresolved Questions

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
Although the draft agreement reached in Madrid appeared to satisfy environmental groups as well as the nations that had sought to keep open the option of mining in Antarctica, many questions remain unresolved.
For one, it remains to be seen whether the draft will be approved by the governments whose representative met in Madrid. Robert Ford, a spokesman of the State Department's Bureau of Oceans and Environment, said that the department had not yet had time to study the draft. Meanwhile, he said, it would be premature to guess whether the United States would ratify it or not. 
 A spokesman for the National Science Foundation said that in any case the United States would not agree to any provision that would interfere with the free conduct of scientific research in Antarctica.
Still, the support of the United States delegation of at least a temporary ban on Antarctic mineral exploitation represented a significant shift in the State Department policy that prevailed until last autumn, when Congress voted to ban American mineral exploitation of Antarctica.
 
Agreement Falls Apart
 Earlier, the State Department had supported the kind of agreement by which mining could be conducted in Antarctica only under international regulation and with the agreement of the parties to the Antarctic Treaty. This approach was incorporated in the Convention for the Regulation of Antarctic Resources tentatively adopted by the Antarctic Treaty nations in 1988 at a meeting in Wellington, New Zealand.
The New Zealand agreement began to fall apart the following year when Australia decided to withdraw. Soon afterward, France joined Australia in repudiating the agreement, also calling for a complete ban on Antarctic mineral exploitation. Since then, the convention has been effectively abandoned.
Although the 39 nations party to the Antarctic Treaty may finally agree to ban the exploitation of Antarctic mineral resources for 50 years, there is no legal mechanism to prevent any of the hundred-odd nations remaining outside the pact from moving in on Antarctica with oil drill rigs and mining machinery. Some third world nations, led by Malaysia, have accused the Antarctic Treaty signers of "economic imperialism" that denies the poorer nations their fair share of Antarctica's supposed mineral wealth.
In fact, most geologists and other experts doubt that Antarctica's resources, such as they are, could ever be exploited economically. There is some chance that oil reserves may exist under the ocean floor off West Antarctica's coast. But experts say that only a supergiant oilfield, the existence of which has been virtually ruled out, would warrant the gigantic expense of drilling under water covered with thick drifting ice during much of the year.
The Madrid draft agreement also leaves unresolved the issue of fishing and biological resources in Antarctic waters.

HEADLINE: More City Business, for Less Money

 BODY:
Mayor David Dinkins of New York has taken a small but firm step in the right direction by consolidating six city agencies concerned with economic development into two agencies: a new Department of Business Services and the New York City Development Corporation. This will eliminate 71 jobs, saving $5 million over 18 months.
Given the size of the city's growing budget deficit for the coming fiscal year, which could reach $3.5 billion, the saving is small. But that's not the main point. The consolidation sends a healthy message to business that the administration is prepared to overcome squeamishness about cutting the bureaucracy. It's also an example of the fundamental streamlining that can help the city provide services more efficiently. 
 Government experts, including Mr. Dinkins's own blue-ribbon management advisory committee, have been recommending this sort of merger for many years, and for good reason. The agencies shared too many overlapping functions, aimed mainly at helping businesses thread their way through a confounding maze of regulatory rules and tax concessions.
New York State's tax policies invite complex case-by-case negotiations on issues like tax abatement. But even if the State Legislature some day summons the courage to modify these rules, New York City will still need an agency to stimulate new investment while encouraging existing businesses to stay.
But the city plainly did not need the separate bureaucracies that have now been consolidated. Mayor Dinkins and his Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, Sally Hernandez-Pinero, deserve praise for taking this difficult, if overdue, step.

HEADLINE: The Great Game Of 'Gai-atsu'

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis ;Flora Lewis is Senior Columnist of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
The word for it in Japanese is "gai-atsu," literally "foreign pressure," but in effect "Japan-bashing." It covers all those things like extracting billions of dollars to help pay for the gulf crisis, pushing on the sacrosanct ban against rice imports, trying to set market quotas on semiconductor chips.
But new undertones have been added, with new candor, as the Japanese struggle to define their relations with a world in which they have become a huge and proud economic power yet still feel virtuously weak. There are admissions now that "gai-atsu" has been exploited to serve a neat political trick, "a strong, face-saving device to which [domestic] vested interest groups were persuaded to give in" by a Government pretending to be their champion. 
 These were the words of a leading Japanese economist to a recent meeting of the Trilateral Commission. They were echoed by a number of others who admit they are getting frustrated by their country's dithering passivity on all but trade.
They reflect the shock of Japan's political and moral quandary when it was confronted by the gulf crisis and sought reasons for avoiding responsibility. There is a gradually spreading awareness that Japan is a global power, but incapable of initiative, in a sense immature, avoiding asking itself what it should do but asking what others, perhaps unfairly, expect of it.
But what kind of power does it want to be? The phrase "no taxation without representation" became a fashionable argument in Japan in response to American demands for more and more money to support the gulf coalition. But it was clear that the last thing they wanted was to have to face a decision.
Talk of a permanent Japanese seat on the U.N. Security Council arouses excited interest. Japan is the world's second largest contributor to the U.N., and recognition of its status matters to people. But apart from the trouble that opening the U.N. Charter to amendment would provoke, the same people admit Japan really isn't prepared to take a stand on the tangled issues that come before the council. Helping to keep the peace involves more than pacifism.
Whenever the argument goes deeper, the complaint comes quickly that Japan now has an unusually weak Government. Nobody has a good word to say about Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. Yet he is likely to be chosen to succeed himself when his term expires this fall. Nor is there the slightest sign of an alternative to the ruling Liberal Democrat Party.
The subtlety of relying on "gai-atsu" is that it helps keep the existing political structure in place, blaming somebody outside for uncomfortable accommodations that are needed without having to examine Japan's internal power relations. And as the journalist Yoichi Funabashi points out, "It shifts debate away from the issue of what Japan should do in its own best interest and toward what other countries want Japan to do. For this very reason, it often arouses nationalistic feelings and emotionalizes the issues."
He is one of relatively few who see a problem in Japan's failure to come to terms with its militaristic past. Mr. Funabashi's ambition for Japan's role is that of "a global civilian power" with a "value-oriented diplomacy." He is against a military buildup or projection of force, as some Americans misguidedly urge, but he is also against perpetuating Japan's "patron-protege relation" with the U.S. and their "love-hate emotions."
The U.S. should not fear this Japanese self-assertion and search for self-reliance. It prolongs the gai-atsu game by accepting the role of stern tutor and protector, instead of insisting that Japan become a partner in its own self-interest. Time to tell the Japanese: when you need bashing, do it yourselves. You'll feel better.

HEADLINE: So Call It a 'Victory Dividend'

BYLINE: By Barney Frank; Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, is a member of the House Budget Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
What's in a name? Sometimes, hundreds of billions of dollars.
In 1989, with the Russian empire crumbling, some of us in Washington argued that the time had come to begin a shift of America's resources from the worldwide military competition, which we are winning decisively, to the global civilian area where we are lagging. It make no sense, we said, to spend two to six times as much of our gross national product on the military as do our wealthy allies while they outsell America. It is poor policy, we argued, to spend more than $100 billion a year defending Western Europe from the defunct Warsaw Pact while our deficit expands and our infrastructure decays. 
 Our mistake was calling this a "peace dividend." The phrase suggested that its advocates were naive about the world, apologetic about America's role in it, or both.
Consequently, when repression persisted in Russia, and America went to war in the gulf, the peace dividend was pronounced dead. Had the case for it depended on Mikhail Gorbachev becoming head of Amnesty International and Saddam Hussein being as reasonable as the Bush Administration thought he was before Aug. 2, it would deserve its demise.
But it didn't. And doesn't. Given the drastic weakening of the Communist military, the great increase in industrial strength of our allies and America's proven military superiority over any likely adversary, a military budget that is less than two-thirds of our current expenditure would more than suffice to keep us the strongest power in the world.
What taxpayers are entitled to after 45 years of carrying a grossly disproportionate share of the non-Communist world's military burden is a "victory dividend." It is a dividend, because it is more than $100 billion a year that we can use for health care, deficit reduction, education or any other purpose. It is a victory dividend because it has been made possible by our success in the cold war and the increased self-defense capacity of our allies.
It is not a call to disarm. We should retain the ability to deter nuclear war, to deploy air, sea and land power rapidly around the globe when our vital interests are at stake, and to reassure weak nations threatened by belligerent neighbors. The consensus to keep such a force is overwhelming in Congress and the country.
In fact, the weapons used by the U.S. in the gulf were not the controversial ones of the 80's. The MX and Midgetman missiles, the B-1 and B-2 bombers, anti-satellite weapons, and Strategic Defense Initiative were irrelevant to victory in Iraq and will be to future conflicts of this sort. (The effort to claim the Patriot for the S.D.I. program is one of the great acts of intellectual piracy of our time.)
We demonstrably do not need a huge land force in Europe and a $5 billion a year subsidy for Japan in the form of American forces stationed there. Nor do we need to add tens of billions of dollars to a nuclear deterrent already more than sufficient to its task.
The victory dividend can also be used for foreign policy objectives not achievable through military strength. If we took a small part of the money we spend on NATO and applied it to debt reduction in Latin America, we would be better off morally and from the standpoint of national security.
There will be debate over how much of our victory dividend should be used to reduce the deficit, how much should go to meet social needs, and how much should be spent to avoid war. But properly understood -- as a recognition of West's great success, rather than as a declaration that the world is now safe for pacifism -- the case for a phased-in reduction of military spending should not be controversial.
In fact, the choice of reducing our deficit, inoculating our children against disease, and repairing our bridges and roads versus sending large sums to subsidize Japan and Europe should be an easy one.

HEADLINE: Burdens of Keeping New York City Going Must Be Shared

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Public Servants: Public Spirited?" (editorial, April 21), calling on New York City's municipal unions to be "social statesmen" as in the 1970's and to agree to furloughs of city employees, misrepresents the situation. 
 For months, municipal union leaders have advocated actions to share the pain, to have all parts of the community absorb some costs to keep the city going. The policy of furloughs or layoffs, unfortunately, would land disproportionately hard on the employees of the city and lower- and middle-income residents who rely on the city for health care, education, parks and recreation.
Union leaders have strongly advocated for months that the city downsize its structural costs with a management-controlled attrition plan and an early retirement program. These alone would reduce the city payroll by many thousands of employees -- without the pain (and added unemployment insurance and welfare costs) of layoffs or forced furloughs.
Further, we have maintained for years that the city could save hundreds of millions by control of a contracting-out process that costs more than $10 billion a year. A moratorium on outside contracts or an agency-by-agency program to reduce even 5 percent of the total spent on them would significantly reduce the city's budget costs.
We too would like to see more of the spirit of the 1970's that you recall, in which all New Yorkers work and share together.
 
STANLEY HILL
Exec. Director, District Council 37
American Federation of State,
County & Municipal Employees
New York, April 22, 1991

HEADLINE: Don't Make Greece Europe's Black Sheep

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Club of Europe Is Seething About Greece" (The Week in Review, April 7), your report from Athens about alleged gossip in Brussels attacking Greece, claims that Greece has ignored European Community regulations and has used the Community "as a cash register." 
 The most recent report from the European Community Court indicates that in 1989 the number of cases brought before it involving Italy, for example, was almost double that for Greece. Moreover, the history of farmers misusing Community funds predates Greek membership, for instance, the infamous case of olive growers in Italy claiming to have far more trees than they actually had, to claim bigger grants.
Nor are northern Europeans beyond reproach: last year the Community Court of Auditors uncovered a $50 million sting involving British, Danish and French farmers re-exporting wheat from Germany to Eastern Europe to qualify for grants.
European Community aid is too little to have much impact. Greece and Portugal are the two poorest Community members, and in 1989, the Court of Auditors reports, they received nearly equal grants from the regional and social funds. However, Portugal lost out under the common agricultural policy, a Communitywide system, because of the commodities covered. Greek farmers received more from its price-support mechanism, but the money went to individual farmers, not public infrastructure projects.
You compare Greece with Portugal. The Portuguese economy has recently grown faster than Greece's. However, Portuguese inflation rates fell significantly below those of Greece only in the late 1980's. Athens has introduced austerity measures, so that the rate of money supply is lower in Greece than in Portugal. Moreover, economic growth is higher in Greece than in Britain, Denmark or the United States. The Greek economy is thus showing some signs of promise.
 
KEVIN FEATHERSTONE
Visiting Professor in Politics
New York University
New York, April 15, 1991

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Big Losses For Ford And G.M.

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 30

 BODY:
The nation's two biggest auto makers announced huge first-quarter losses today.
The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest car maker, reported a net loss of $377 million. It would have reported a $1.1 billion loss except for one-time gains from an accounting change and the sale of the G.M. Building in New York. 
 The Ford Motor Company posted a quarterly loss of $884 million.
Although the companies' failure to make money was unsurprising, given the slumping economy, the size of the losses underscored the vulnerability of the nation's biggest manufacturing industry to worldwide competition.
 
Ford Sees Improvement
 Ford's vehicle production and sales to dealers are expected to improve sharply in this quarter, but Ford said it would probably not be profitable because of competitive pressure in the American market caused by a glut of worldwide production capacity. Moreover, Ford said it would be "difficult" to make a profit for 1991.
Robert C. Stempel, the chairman and chief executive of G.M., said the company was facing "the toughest and most competitive North American automotive market in the corporation's history."
Both auto makers have been slashing expenses and laying off salaried workers, but the collective bargaining agreement reached last fall with the United Automobile Workers union, which guaranteed income for all hourly workers regardless of layoffs, has prevented the companies from reducing their labor expense as production has dropped. In addition, the cost of discounting remains about $900 for each Ford car and truck, and $1,100 for each G.M. vehicle.
 
Chrysler Loss Also Expected
 "The gross profit margins at G.M. and Ford were up slightly from the fourth quarter, but those were so bad as to be off the scale," said Ronald A. Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco. "In the case of both companies, the profit margins are significantly worse than in the past."
The Chrysler Corporation, the No. 3 domestic auto maker, is scheduled to release its results on Wednesday, and automotive analysts are forecasting a large loss.
G.M.'s shares rose $1.75 each today, to $35.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. Ford's stock gained 62.5 cents, to $32.50.
G.M.'s $377 million net loss compared with a $710 million profit in the first quarter of last year. Sales declined 3.1 percent, to $29.2 billion.
G.M.'s loss attributable to its common stock was $461 million, in contrast to a profit last year of $619 million, or $1.02 a common share. The latest results included a gain of $403 million, or 66 cents a share, on the G.M. Building sale and $303 million, or 50 cents a share, as a result of G.M.'s decision to account for the expense of spare parts in the year they are used, rather than immediately.
Ford's $884 million loss compared with a profit of $506 million, or $1.10 a share, a year earlier. Ford's revenue dropped nearly 10 percent, to $21.3 billion.
Ford's heaviest losses came in North America, but the overseas operations were also unprofitable. Ford's American automotive operations lost $947 million, in contrast to a profit of $160 million a year earlier. Overseas automotive operations lost $208 million, in contrast to a profit of $155 million last year.
Ford's factory sales of vehicles to dealers, on which the company books revenue and profit, dropped almost 25 percent, to 590,000, in the quarter. Overseas factory sales were down 1.1 percent, to 651,000 cars and trucks.
Ford was particularly hard hit by losses in Britain, its most important overseas market. David N. McCammon, vice president-finance, said the British car market was "worse than in the United States."
One bright spot was Ford's financial services group, which earned a record $271 million, up 42 percent from a year earlier. The increase reflected strong results of the Ford Credit Company and the Associates.
Ford's First Nationwide savings and loan unit, which added $66 million to its reserves to cover bad loans, lost $20.9 million, in contrast to a profit of $35.9 million a year earlier. On April 1, First Nationwide signed an agreement with Federal regulators to overhaul its management practices.
G.M. said many of its worldwide businesses, including vehicle sales overseas, performed well. European profits were at a record, but they were overwhelmed by the losses of the North American automotive business. On Monday, G.M.'s E.D.S. unit reported higher profits while its General Motors Acceptance Corporation and GM Hughes units posted lower earnings.
The single most important factor in the North American losses was lower volume. G.M. said North American factory sales were down 13.9 percent in the quarter, to just over a million cars and trucks, while worldwide factory sales were down 8.8 percent, to 1.65 million.
In addition, G.M. was building more lower-priced models with fewer options than a year earlier, a spokesman said, and it was still paying rebates averaging $1,100 a vehicle.
About 37 percent of G.M.'s cars were sold to fleets, including daily-rental fleets, a business that is less profitable than the normal retail business. A year earlier, about 26 percent of G.M.'s cars were sold to fleets.
Ford's sales to rental fleets are projected to average about 26 percent of all car sales for 1991, up from 22 percent last year.
Both companies expressed optimism, supported by recent consumer confidence surveys, that retail sales will improve this year. They conceded that the timing and magnitude of the recovery were uncertain.
But Mr. McCammon warned that personal income levels remained low and unemployment was high -- and that both factors directly affected vehicle sales. He applauded the Federal Reserve's decision today to lower the discount rate, which he predicted would make it easier for consumers to get auto loans.
After two progressively stronger months of vehicle sales in February and March, sales were down in the first 20 days of April. Ford said it thought the downturn might be temporary, caused by the expiration of several incentive programs in March.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 3, 1991, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the quarterly reports of the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company misstated Ford's first-quarter revenue in some editions. It was $21.3 billion, down 9.7 percent from $23.6 billion in the comparable quarter last year. The article also misstated the first-quarter performance of two of G.M.'s non-automotive units in some editions. The General Motors Acceptance Corporation had lower, not higher, profits; the GM Hughes Electronics Corporation had lower profits, not a loss.
