HEADLINE: William Paton, 101, Pioneer Accountant, Theorist and Scholar

BYLINE: By ALFONSO A. NARVAEZ

 BODY:
William A. Paton, a certified public accountant who was a pioneer in modern accounting theory, died Friday at the Whitehall Convalescent Home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 101 years old and lived in Ann Arbor.
Dr. Paton, who received a Ph.D. in economics in 1917 from the University of Michigan, taught accounting at his alma mater for 45 years. He started as an instructor in 1914, was named a full professor in 1921 and at his retirement in 1959 was named the Edwin Francis Gay Distinguished University Professor Emeritus of Accounting and of Economics by the university. 
 In 1987 he was named "Educator of the Century" by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants.
In the 1920's Dr. Paton was one of the first accounting theorists to argue that economic factors, like inflation and interest rates, should be considered when presenting a company's financial picture, rather than just a listing of the assets and liabilities of the owners.
In his years as a teacher, he had contact with more than 20,000 students. Many became corporate leaders, including Roger Smith, former chief executive of the General Motors Corporation, and Lynn A. Townsend, former chairman of the Chrysler Corporation.
Dr. Paton wrote dozens of books and hundreds of articles. His many awards and honors included the naming of the accounting center at the University of Michigan in his honor. He was the editor of "Accountants' Handbook," a widely used source book for certified public accountants. He was also a founder of the American Accounting Association and in 1926 began Accounting Review, the oldest scholarly journal in accounting.
He is survived by a son, William Jr., of Saline, Mich.; a daughter, Margaret Buttrell of Denver, and nine grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Tsongas Is First Entrant In '92 Presidential Race

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., April 30

 BODY:
Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts began a long-shot campaign for the Presidency today with a scornful indictment of "Washington mediocrity" and a plea for "a different path" toward economic and political renewal.
With a quietly reflective speech here and in his hometown of Lowell, Mass., Mr. Tsongas became the first official candidate of the 1992 Presidential campaign. 
 "Today I begin a journey of purpose," he said at an outdoor rally in Lowell, where hundreds of supporters listened stoically through a driving rain. "I ask you to come with me."
Mr. Tsongas (the name is pronounced SONG-guss) enters a race for the Democratic Presidential nomination that seems frozen by the war in the Persian Gulf, the remarkable popularity of President Bush and the fear among many Democrats that the President is all but unbeatable. Democrats from the Rev. Jesse Jackson to Senator Al Gore of Tennessee have been considering a race, but only Mr. Tsongas, who left the Senate six years ago because he had cancer, has taken the plunge.
 
'Values of Our Ancestors'
 The 50-year-old Massachusetts Democrat, who underwent a successful bone marrow transplant five years ago, seemed untroubled today by the conventional wisdom, which holds that his chances for the nomination are slim. Indeed, he offered his candidacy as an antidote to politics-as-usual, seeming to play to the same restless mood among voters that showed up in numerous public opinion polls and some elections last year.
He talked of returning to "the values of our ancestors" and of recognizing the nation's responsibility to future generations by refusing to burden them with a spoiled environment and a bloated Federal debt. "In the Apache tongue the word for grandfather and grandson is the same," said Mr. Tsongas, surrounded by his wife and three daughters. "They understood linkage. They understood honor. They understood mutual obligation.
"In Washington there is no such wisdom. It is all here and now. It is all polling data. The vision extends only to the next election."
This failure of political leadership, Mr. Tsongas said, has left the nation drifting, falling far short of its destiny. "We were never meant to be the world's greatest debtor nation," he said. "We were never meant to have American workers rank ninth in the world in wages. We were never meant to have dysfunctional schools or imploding cities or racial disharmony or an evironment at risk."
 
A Harder, Steeper Path
 In contrast to the made-for-television messages of most political speeches, Mr. Tsongas's announcement speech had an almost mystical tone. "I offer a different path," he said, "harder but more hopeful, longer but more compelling, steeper but more worthy."
He compared the political journey facing the nation to his own journey past cancer. "Born out of that adversity was a commitment to devote myself to those people and to those issues that truly matter to me," he said.
So far, Mr. Tsongas's campaign has revolved around what he sees as the nation's serious economic decline, and he says this demands new thinking and new policies, like a more aggressive Federal role in helping businesses develop new technologies. He presents himself as a pro-business liberal who is committed to an "economic renaissance," and he breaks with fellow Democrats on several issues.
 
A Loyal Audience in Lowell
 Mr. Tsongas supports a carefully targeted cut in the tax on capital gains to encourage investment. He backs nuclear power as a means of easing the nation's dependence on fossil fuels, a stance he did not mention here in New Hampshire, where the issue has long been controversial. And he backs a free trade pact with Mexico, an issue that has caused bitter debate among Democrats.
His announcement in Lowell this morning drew a loyal audience that came packing umbrellas and determined enthusiasm. "He's a hometown guy, what do you think?" said David Gannon, when asked where he stood on Mr. Tsongas.
The new candidate delivered his speech against a backdrop of renovated textile mills, intended to reflect the economic development projects that Mr. Tsongas pushed for during much of his political career. Still, the "Massachusetts miracle" that Michael S. Dukakis rode to the Democratic nomination three years ago has long since faded.
From Lowell, Mr. Tsongas drove to New Hampshire, where the nation's first Presidential primary will be held early next year, then flew on to Iowa, which holds the first caucuses. In New Hampshire he spoke on the Manchester campus of the University of New Hampshire, where some Democratic politicians shied away from assessing his chances but noted that he certainly had an opportunity to fill a void.
"It seems there's few other Democrts with the courage or the wherewithal to jump into the field," said Joseph Grandmaison, former state Democratic chairman. "That gives him an opportunity."
Peggy Connolly, spokeswoman for the campaign, said the response of much of the Democratic establishment was "cordial but not enthusiastic." She said Mr. Tsongas, whose campaign at the moment has a full-time paid staff of three, would obviously not be "the Democratic Party establishment candidate."
Still, he plans several trips to Iowa, including a two-week stay there in July. And his announcement tour this week will also take him to Denver, Los Angeles, Seattle, San Francisco, San Jose, Calif., and Tampa, Fla.
The campaign is clearly sensitive to the issue of Mr. Tsongas's health, making the candidate's physician, Dr. Tak Takvorian, generally available. Dr. Takvorian, who treated Mr. Tsongas for lymphoma, said the former Senator has shown no sign of the disease since he underwent the bone marrow transplant in 1986.
Regardless of Mr. Tsongas's chances for the nomination, there was the reassuring air today of the old rituals of Presidential campaigns grinding forward once again: the bus motorcades from Manchester to Logan International Airport in Boston, the New Hampshire pols sizing up a candidate, the audiences willing and eager for applause lines. "Let's go!" Mr. Tsongas exclaimed at Lowell today -- and with a lurch, the campaign began anew.
 
Paul Efthemios Tsongas
 
Current Job: Of Counsel, Foley, Hoag & Eliot; Chairman, Massachusetts Board of Regents of Higher Education.
 
Date of Birth: Feb. 14, 1941; Lowell, Mass.
 
Education: Dartmouth College, B.A., 1962; Yale Law School, LL.B., 1967.
 
Religion: Greek Orthodox.
 
Military Service: None.
 
Married: To Nicola (Niki) Sauvage, Dec. 21, 1969.
 
Children: Ashley, 17; Katina, 13; and Molly, 9.

Other Major Positions: Private law practice, 1971-74; Partner, Foley, Hoag & Eliot, 1985-89.

HEADLINE: At This Circus, The Sideshow Is in the Kitchen

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
"I NEVER had sushi before I joined the circus," David Lebel, an acrobat, was saying the other day between numbers at the Cirque du Soleil, the French Canadian circus that is appearing at Battery Park City in New York through May 19.
When people think of a circus, they usually picture tumblers, contortionists and clowns. Ah, but here the real theater is in the kitchen. 
 In a small yellow-striped tent tucked behind the big top and no more than a back flip or two from the Hudson River, a kitchen manager, two chefs, a pastry chef and two or three assistants ply the 105 cast and crew with food that could make just about anyone want to run away and join the circus.
"The food is as good as the show," Mr. Lebel said. "At a lot of circuses, you're pretty much on your own. Here, it's like having a gourmet restaurant under a tent."
The impresario behind this smaller scale but equally ambitious production is Laurent Comeau, a 47-year-old former restaurant chef who has been the Cirque's kitchen manager for three years. Mr. Comeau, a thick-waisted Acadian with spiky reddish hair, darts about constantly inside the three trailers that form the nucleus of the mobile kitchen, pantry and dining area.
With black rubber bracelets dangling from his wrist and one pierced ear, a rakish reminder of the 10 years he was the chief steward on a cargo ship, Mr. Comeau is passionate about his latest moving kitchen. He can see the poetry in puff pastry and takes pleasure in cosseting the performers, technicians and family members in his care.
He knows their favorite foods and routinely puts heaping plates aside for performers who like to put off supper until after the last show. He also keeps plastic cups of ice in the freezer for bruised knees, and a blender on standby in case someone's infant needs "these little concoctions," as he puts it.
From 7 A.M., when the kichen opens, until 2 A.M., when it closes, anywhere from 300 to 500 meals are turned out every day of the week except Monday, when the performers are off.
Mealtime never officially ends. Breakfast flows into lunch and lunch into dinner as the chefs refill the steam tables in a shifting kaleidoscope of tastes and smells. The espresso, a dark roast shipped in from Seattle, is served Quebec style in two-handled bowls. And except for wine, beer and soft drinks, all the provisions are free.
It is all a far cry from the way of life at other circuses. At the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, for instance, cast members can buy sandwiches and snacks from the pie cars on the trains that house and transport them. The Big Apple Circus, whose performers live in trailers, has a mobile cookhouse featuring mostly Southern fare, where the crew members eat free and the performers pay a small fee.
Yet many performers in both shows -- for reasons of health, economy and convenience -- tend to fend for themselves. Either they find restaurants where they can grab a healthful bite between shows, or they make do in small kitchens with limited pantries.
"It's not really my type of food," David Dimitri, a tightrope walker with the Big Apple Circus and self-taught cook, said of the fare at the cookhouse. But he perked up when the conversation turned to the Cirque, where he once ate as a guest. "They have a real cookhouse," he said. "It's more like a restaurant."
Mr. Comeau is aware that other circus performers are a bit envious of the Cirque's pampering. Not only are the meals paid for, but the Cirque's cast and crew are put up in hotels like the Marriott in lower Manhattan.
"The other circuses, they call this the Cadillac tour," Mr. Comeau said. The perks do add up, of course, and the show's owner, Groupe du Soleil of Montreal, charges slightly more to cover its costs. As a result, in some cities, the Cirque's cheapest seats cost more than Ringling Brothers' most expensive ones.
To be sure, Mr. Comeau grapples with constraints that few kitchen managers face. One trailer serves as his refrigerator and freezer. The other day, it was packed with melons, salmon pate, cheeses and a shipment of quail for Sunday night's supper. "I'd rather have pigeon," he said, "but good pigeon is so hard to find."
Another trailer doubles as the bakery and the library. A well-worn copy of Larousse Gastronomique is one of dozens of references and cookbooks, most in French, stuffed inside the cubbyholes. All the cooking takes place in a third trailer, 38 feet long by 6 feet wide.
Meat, fish and dry goods are delivered once or twice a week. But Mr. Comeau must find new sources for many perishable or hard-to-stock items like fresh bread, croissants and cheese each time the circus picks up tent. He often resorts to specialty stores like Dean & DeLuca in New York. "There's no real supermarket in Manhattan," he muttered.
The search for fresh, tasty ingredients is harder than one might imagine, he said, even in a metropolis like New York. New York bagels? Don't ask. "They look like doughnuts," Mr. Comeau said contemptuously. What about the smoked meats? Forget it. "The closest thing you have is pastrami," he said.
Where he has no problem with a local product, his charges often do. For instance, he scrambles to find Canadian maple syrup for the Quebecers in the troupe, who expect it on or in everything from pancakes to maple mousse pie. Mr. Comeau thinks Vermont maple syrup is just as good, "but try explaining it to them," he said. "The contortionists, it's like wine to them. They'll taste it and know right away if it's not from Quebec."
Lack of counter space also forces Mr. Comeau to make compromises. For instance, he would prefer to do his own butchering, but he buys his meat precut.
His biggest challenge is a clientele that never changes, one reason he hired Emile Poulier, one of his two chefs, away from a Montreal restaurant. Mr. Comeau said Mr. Poulier impressed him in his job interview because Mr. Poulier said he was bored cooking the same menu night after night. "I knew he would experiment," Mr. Comeau said.
Last Saturday, lunch featured five different selections of Indian cuisine, including curried lamb and apricot chutney with cranberries. There were also two vegetarian dishes, in addition to cheese souffle and vegetable-corn soup. For nibbling, there were platters of croissants, mounds of cranberry muffins and loaves of French bread. Dessert was a sugar pie that tasted like pure butterscotch. Mr. Comeau also keeps cereals on hand, and a salad bar is always open, piled high with huge artichokes, slices of cantaloupe and bunches of grapes.
On special occasions, the kitchen goes all out. It prepares an opening dinner in each city, complete with Champagne, escargots, sushi and other delicacies. It also does weddings, in one case a rabbit dinner for 125 people and a wedding cake -- or more precisely, a croquembouche, a pyramid-shaped confection doused with caramelized sugar.
On Saturday, Mr. Comeau was behaving like a bombardier on a precision raid, plopping lemon-poppy seed drops on an outdoor patio table, where some performers were gathered, and vanishing before anyone could protest. "See, this is what happens," said Julie Dewhurst, whose husband and son are the show's tightrope walkers.
"Well, you can't be rude, can you?" her husband, Brian, said, popping one of the warm cookies into his mouth. Unlike his wife, he never frets about his weight. "Most of the acrobats are training during the day and working at night, so they need a lot of calories," he said.
Other performers find Mr. Comeau's kitchen a tough test since it doubles as the town hall, the place to drop by to exchange gossip, play backgammon and check out any new romances. "What's hard is not eating something each time you come in, when you come in 10 times a day," said 12-year-old Laurence Racine, a contortionist.
Still, no one is a fanatic calorie-counter. "They're athletes, but they're not Olympic athletes," Mr. Comeau said. He gets occasional complaints, he said, "about too much butter in the vegetables, and you see them eat three pieces of cake."
For all this, Mr. Comeau is paid about $300 a week less than what he made on the ship, but he couldn't care less. "I'm having more fun than I ever had in my life," he said. "I'm finally managing a kitchen that has respect for food. It's priceless."
 
Two Treats From the Yellow-Striped Tent
 
Lemon-Poppy Seed Drops
Total time: 40 minutes
 
1 1/2 cups flour
 1/4 cup poppy seeds
 1/4 teaspoon salt
16 tablespoons butter, softened
 3/4 cup sugar
2 large egg yolks
2 teaspoons vanilla extract
Zest of 3 large lemons.
1. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees.
2. In a small bowl, combine the flour, poppy seeds and salt. Set aside. In a large bowl, cream together the butter and the sugar until fluffy. Add the egg yolks, vanilla extract and lemon zest. Stir until well mixed. Add the dry ingredients, and stir only until they are incorporated and dough pulls together into a ball. Do not overmix.
3. Drop the dough from a teaspoon onto ungreased cookie sheets, leaving an inch between the cookies. Bake for 15 minutes, or until the cookies are lightly browned around the edges.
Yield: 2 1/2 dozen.
 
Sugar Pie
Total time: 1 hour, plus 1 hour for resting
 
For the pie crust:
 
2 3/4 cups flour
 1/2 teaspoon salt
 1/2pound lard, cut into small pieces and chilled
 1/2 cup ice water
1 1/2 tablespoons butter, cut into small pieces and chilled
 
For the filling:
 
2 cups brown sugar
14 ounces sweetened condensed milk
1 tablespoon flour
1 tablespoon butter, softened.
 1. To make the crust, combine the flour and salt in a large bowl. Add the lard, and with a pastry cutter or two forks, cut the lard into the flour until the mixture resembles small peas. Add the ice water, 2 tablespoons at a time, and mix with two knives. Add just enough water so that all the flour is incorporated and the dough pulls together into a rough ball.
2. Turn out onto a lightly floured board, and with a rolling pin flatten the dough into a 6-inch square. Scatter the butter pieces all over the dough, then fold the dough in half. Roll the dough back out into a 6-inch square, then fold and roll out again. Repeat once more, then cover the dough with plastic wrap, and refrigerate for an hour.
3. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees.
4. Remove the dough from the refrigerator, and allow to soften.
5. To make the filling, combine the sugar, condensed milk, flour and butter in a medium-size bowl. Stir until smooth.
6. On a lightly floured board roll out the dough until it is 1/4 inch thick. Gently lift the dough, and put it in a 9-inch pie pan. Trim the edges, then pour in the filling. Bake for 15 minutes, then reduce the heat to 325 degrees, and continue baking for another 25 minutes. The filling will look cracked and bumpy. Do not overbake.
Yield: 6 to 8 servings.

HEADLINE: Japanese in U.S. Aiding Charities As Volunteers

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
If Toshio Matsunami's countrymen in Tokyo could have seen him and several of his co-workers, they would not have believed it. There he was, the executive vice president of the Fuji Bank and Trust Company, carrying rubbish out of a building on the Lower East Side of Manhattan that is being turned into a residence for the homeless. Nearby, two bank managers were painting a ceiling in the building.
In Japan such activity is virtually unheard of: helping the needy is considered the government's duty. But exposure to American customs and a desire not to be seen as interested only in making money has led Japanese executives and their employees to rethink their relationship with the United States, its people and its problems. 
 "We don't want Americans to see us as Godzillas," said Akiko Mitsui, a 26-year-old Fuji assistant vice president, twisting her face to imitate the fire-breathing monster of Japanese films. Miss Mitsui said she had worked on five renovations on the Lower East Side "for personal satisfaction."
 
A Shift in Style
 Charitable work by Japanese executives and professionals living in America is becoming more common as a tiny but growing number of them plunge into philanthropic ventures.
And with that surge of activity has come occasional questioning about whether the Japanese initiatives are goodwill gestures or calculated public relations. Nonetheless, the Japanese are serving on fund-raising boards like the United Way, teaching language classes, counseling students, joining charity marathons and finding jobs for teen-agers.
Tadashi Yamamoto, president of the Japan Center for International Exchange, with offices in New York City and Tokyo, said there was a clear shift in style: until recently most Japanese companies "simply wrote checks to big universities and cultural centers."
"Now they are working in depressed neighborhoods and developing real human contacts instead of being locked up in a bank or boardroom," he said, adding that the companies and their employees realized that they needed to become "good corporate citizens."
"These days the term 'stakeholder' has entered their business jargon," he said, "and corporate leaders understand that unless they help protect the environment and improve schools, they will suffer."
That sentiment, Japanese executives say, is reflected around the country.
 
Involvement in Communities
 In New York City, for example, Japanese executives are not only working to create shelters for the homeless, but are also joining their American counterparts in trying to help the city develop strategies to ease its budget gap and improve the economy.
The Bank of California, owned by Mitsubishi Bank, has encouraged its 3,700 employees to volunteer in the community, including working at shelters for the homeless and residences for battered women or abused children. It also donates money to organizations where its employees serve.
In Seattle, the Japan-American Society got the wives of some Japanese executives to work in day-care centers in the inner city, pairing them with the wives of American businessmen.
After building a plant in rural Georgetown, Ky., Toyota Motor Manufacturing, U.S.A., voluntarily donated $15 million to county schools because the plant was financed in part with tax-free bonds.
Some Japanese executives say their philanthropy helps counter anti-Japanese sentiment, while others argue that companies that demonstrate a social conscience attract more customers.
 
Likened to Investments
 Osamu Yamada, chairman of the Bank of California, says Japanese companies should apply the same care to giving and volunteering as they do to business investments. "We will not make progress if Japanese goods are no longer thought of as cheap, but Japanese companies are," he said.
Jiro Ishizaka, chairman of the Union Bank in California, who helped raise $1.85 million from 300 Japanese companies for the United Way, said he had done so because "I wanted to improve the image of Japanese companies, and I also wished to have Japanese enterprises recognize the importance of corporate citizenship."
Whatever the motive, Japanese involvement in charities in the United States is spreading. And nowhere does it seem more ventursome than with the Fuji bankers in Manhattan.
 
Involvement 'Very Natural'
 "When did anyone see a dozen Japanese officials walking along Avenue D at 9:30 on a Saturday morning?" asked Gabriel D. Boratgis, an administrator of the Lower East Side Catholic Conference Area, an association that is developing the shelter for the homeless.
"It's tremendous that the Japanese are coming into our neighborhood and trying to help with a problem that troubles all of us."
Mr. Matsumani said that when he worked for Fuji in San Francisco he was not impelled to volunteer. But after moving to New York City, he saw "that it is very natural for concerned people to be involved, to do whatever they could to help."
With at least 3,000 Japanese companies in the United States, 70 formal philanthropic programs and 23 company foundations, the Japanese are becoming more visible and more influential. Six hundred of the Japanese companies are in the New York area.
 
Variety of Efforts
 A survey of Japanese companies in the United States conducted for the Japan Society underscores the evolution of Japanese corporate thinking.
"An increasing number of companies see being a good corporate citizen involves nondiscriminatory hiring and promotion practices, encouraging employees to volunteer, lending the corporation's prestige to support commmunity goals and puchasing supplies from local firms," said Daniel E. Bob, an assistant director of the society, which got in touch with nearly 3,000 Japanese companies and received responses from 585.
A few Japanese leaders have goaded companies to act. One such leader is Sadahei Kusumoto, president of the Minolta Corporation. Mr. Kusumoto spends five hours a week campaigning for United Way of Bergen County, N.J. Recently he proposed that Japanese companies contribute one-tenth of 1 percent of all American sales to philanthropy.
Tsuneo Tanaka, who is leaving after five years as president of Hitachi America, an electronics company, decided to give $10,000 checks to the volunteer ambulance corps and the Fire Department in Tarrytown, N.Y., where Hitachi has its headquarters, instead of having a farewell party.
But expansion of Japanese giving and volunteering has its negative side.
 
Some American Skepticism
 Some American foundations have voiced skepticism and concern about the independence of the Global Partnership Center, which the Japanese Government has established with a $375 million endowment. The organization will have offices in Tokyo and New York and is supposed to help the United States and Japan look together at issues like urban poverty, aging, the environment and crime. The critics maintain it could be just a device for polishing Japan's image.
And Dr. Delwin A. Roy, president of the Hitachi Foundation, cited lingering suspicions that the Japanese were using philanthropy to gain access to American technology or to influence American education.
"Such comments continue to crop up in Congress, the media and within the philanthropy community," he said, adding: "Given the decline in funds for social needs, one would expect Japanese giving to be encouraged, not discouraged."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in U.S. Trading And Gold Prices Are Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished higher yesterday against most key currencies after falling overseas.
Gold prices were mixed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $356 a troy ounce, up 10 cents from late Tuesday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $355.75 an ounce, off 50 cents. 
 The dollar started out lower in Asian and European markets on concern about the sagging United States economy, but rallied later in domestic trading.
Dealers said traders snapped up dollars because they were attracted to the currency's lower rates, which stemmed in part from a drop in two key interest rates by the Federal Reserve on Tuesday.
The Fed cut the discount rate and the Federal funds rate to help bring the nation out of the recession, and banks followed suit yesterday by trimming the prime lending rate half a percentage point, to 8 1/2 percent.
Earl Johnson, a vice president for Harris Trust and Company in Chicago, said United States traders shrugged off the prime cut because they had been anticipating one for days.
Also helping the dollar, Mr. Johnson said, was a survey released yesterday by the nation's purchasing managers, which said that while the manufacturing economy declined in April, it showed some modest signs of recovery.
In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar fell to a closing 136.64 Japanese yen, from 137.42 yen Tuesday. It stood at 137.60 yen in London, and at 138.15 yen in New York, up from 136.15 yen Tuesday.
Against the German currency, the dollar moved up in New York to 1.7100 marks, from 1.7067, after tumbling more than 4 pfennigs on Tuesday after the United States interest rate cut.
Against the British pound, the dollar was mixed compared with Tuesday. Sterling fetched $1.7265 in London, up from $1.7235, and $1.7225 in New York, down from $1.7325.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's late quotes, included: 1.4480 Swiss francs, up from 1.4410; 5.7885 French francs, up from 5.7760; 1,266.00 Italian lire, up from 1,263.00, and 1.15175 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15285.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $357 an ounce, from $357.60 late Tuesday. The Zurich market was closed yesterday for the May Day holiday.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.70 an ounce to close at $357.01.
Silver prices were lower. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $3.95 a troy ounce, down 1.9 cents from Tuesday. Silver fell in London to $3.98 an ounce from $3.99.

HEADLINE: Therapists Say a Single Session May Be Enough

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

 BODY:
In keeping with the mood of the times to economize in all things, some therapists are saying that a single session of psychotherapy is enough for most people.
The approach capitalizes on the fact that on average about a third of the people who consult a therapist never return for a second session, making one session the most frequent length of therapy.
The advocates of single-session therapy argue that what is so often a person's only therapeutic encounter should be used to maximize its effect. 
 But they also contend that for many, if not most, people, one therapy session can leave them with the tools and the encouragement to handle their problems on their own. For example, a single session may be all that is required to give a person the resolve to end a destructive relationship.
 
Idea Seems Absurd to Some
 "It's not hard to be helpful to somebody in a single session," said Dr. Bernard Bloom, a psychologist at the University of Colorado who is an originator of the approach.
For most psychoanalysts and other psychotherapists who routinely do therapy lasting months or years, the idea seems absurd. And even some therapists who have milder reactions are skeptical.
Typical was the reaction of Dr. Robert Michels, dean at the Cornell Medical School who is a former chairman of the psychiatry department."In my clinical experience," he said, "a single session of therapy is unlikely to be enough for most patients."
Even so, Dr. Simon Budman, a psychologist at the Harvard Community Health Plan in Boston, said: "There is more single-session therapy going on than many therapists realize. I find that 10 to 15 percent of my clients only need a single session."
 
Panic About the Future
 Recently, Dr. Budman treated a college senior who had been suffering from panic attacks. The first occurred in the initial meeting of a second-semester course, when the instructor asked students to introduce themselves and tell their plans for the future.
"He got so panicked, he had to walk out," Dr. Budman said, after which the student became increasingly anxious because of the fear he would have more attacks.
In talking to the student, Dr. Budman discovered that he was worried about his future. "Here it was, the end of his senior year and he was unsure about what he would do next," Dr. Budman said. "I pointed out that it was entirely appropriate for him to be anxious in his situation."
Sometimes, Dr. Budman said, all a person needs to hear is that his or her reaction is normal given the circumstances. Four months after their single meeting, Dr. Budman called the student and found that he had not had any more panic attacks.
Normally, therapists use the first session, or several, to gather information about a client, delaying therapeutic intervention until later. But single-session advocates argue that, in addition, therapists should use the initial session to make interventions and suggestions that can have therapeutic effect.
"You can say from the outset, let's see what I can do to be helpful to you in an hour or so," Dr. Bloom said. "When the hour is over, the person can have gotten enough to make a change in his life."
Dr. Bloom's book, "Planned Short-term Psychotherapy," which describes methods for brief therapy, including single sessions, will be published in August by Allyn & Bacon.
To be sure, even the most enthusiastic supporters of single-session therapy admit limitations. Perhaps the most important is how long a person expects the therapy to last.
"If a client comes in the door expecting long-term therapy, single-session therapy can't work," said Dr. Moshe Talmon, a psychologist at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in Hayward, Calif., a leading advocate of the approach. But he said that most first-time patients in community clinics and prepaid medical plans do not expect therapy to last long.
People who need more than a single session, Dr. Talmon said, include those with problems so severe, like psychosis or suicidal feelings, that they require hospital treatment, or with conditions like manic-depression, which require a longer period to find the proper medication.
Still, Dr. Talmon said, most people who go to therapists are appropriate candidates for a single session, especially those have a specific problem, like family conflicts.
"At the beginning I thought single-session therapy would be most helpful for less severe and acute problems," Dr. Talmon said. "But when a problem is very urgent and painful, people are motivated to change quickly."
Data supporting the single-session treatment has come from a variety of studies, often unexpectedly. For example, one of the earliest was a follow-up of 141 people who had consulted therapists on only one occasion in community clinics in New York City. Done in the 1950's, the study found that two-thirds said they had been helped, though their therapists thought of them as "dropouts."
Indirect evidence of benefit came from a 1979 study of 304 patients in a prepaid medical plan in California. The study found that people who consulted a psychotherapist for a single session had a 60 percent decline in their use of all other medical services over the next five years.
And in recent research, 200 patients who had consulted a therapist just once at a California prepaid medical plan were called several months later; 78 percent said they had got what they wanted out of that single session and felt better about the problem. The research is reported in Dr. Talmon's book "Single Session Therapy," published last year by Jossey-Bass.
One of the first to suggest that a single session could be therapeutic was David Malan, a British psychoanalyst who was one of the developers of short-term psychotherapy, which usually lasts from 8 to 20 sessions. Dr. Malan, writing in the 1970's, said that there could be a "powerful potential therapeutic effect both of telling a patient that he must take the responsibility for his own life, and of reassuring him that he can manage without therapeutic help."
Those principles are at the heart of the method Dr. Talmon has developed for single-session therapy. Right from the start of the session, Dr. Talmon recommends, therapists should suggest that the single meeting may be sufficient, while leaving open the possibility that more therapy may be necessary. The session should be scheduled for two hours rather than the usual one, he advises.
From the patient's early description of the problem, the therapist must find a focus that seems to be the main issue, and identify strengths in the patient that might be used to deal constructively with the situation.
 
Break for Final Thoughts
 Then the therapist suggests a step the patient could take toward a solution and helps the patient rehearse that step. For example, with a woman who came to Dr. Talmon because she was full of anger and guilt over her father's forced sex with her in childhood, Dr. Talmon recommended a ritual in which she burned her father's picture along with her written account of the sexual abuse and her feelings of outrage. He said she required no further therapy.
In general, just before the end of one session, Dr. Talmon takes a brief break from the room while the client thinks about any issues that have not been aired. In his closing remarks, Dr. Talmon acknowledges the client's emotional upset, reviews what positive qualities the patient has to deal with the problem on the client's own, and suggests a simple task that will be a step toward its solution.
He also says that the patient can come back for more any time. Most, Dr. Talmon says, do not.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Moshe Talmon of Kaiser Permanete Medical Center, Hayward, Calif., advocates single-session thearapy in some cases. (Terrence McCarthy for The New York Times)
 
Drawing
 
Chart: "Who May Benefit From Single-Session Therapy?
 
MOST LIKELY CANDIDATES
 
Patients who want to deal with a specific problem.
Patients who mostly need reassurance that their reaction to a troubling situation is normal.
Patients who have dealt successfully with life problems in the past or who have managed the current one for some time on thier own.
Patients who are tired of feeling "stuck" in a strong reaction to past events.
 
INAPPROPRIATE CANDIDATES
 
Patients who need immediate hospitalization, including suicidal, psychotic or intoxicated patients.
Patients suffering from conditions requiring medication, like manic depression and schizophrenia.
Patients who request long-term therapy.
Patients who are seeking self-understanding rather just a solution.
 
Source: Moshe Talmon, Ph.D.

HEADLINE: 161 Hospitals Found With High Death Rates

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
Federal health officials today listed 161 hospitals with higher-than-expected death rates for Medicare patients, including 15 that have had high rates for four years in a row. Six of the 15 were in Puerto Rico.
In all, about 3 percent of the nation's more than 5,600 hospitals were found to have death rates significantly higher than expected, about the same proportion as in earlier years. 
 The information, included in the government's fourth annual report compiling data in 25 volumes, is intended to give consumers a yardstick for choosing a hospital.
 Medicare is the government health care program for the elderly and disabled. It has 34 million beneficiaries, and in 1989 about 6.4 million of them were hospitalized at least once.
This year's report covers 1987, 1988 and 1989. It differs from previous reports in that it includes deaths that occurred within 30, 90 and 180 days after hospital admission. The earlier studies reported deaths within 30 days. The new report also includes data on surgical procedures for the first time.
Though hospitals with repeatedly high mortality rates may have quality problems, some of them may actually be "fine institutions with unusually sick patients," the report said.
"In general, hospitals in this country, given the kinds of measurements we are using, appear to be performing well," said Gail Wilensky, head of the Health Care Financing Administration, which runs the Medicare program.
"We are, of course, concerned about hospitals that are repeatedly showing on the list" of hospitals with higher-than-expected death rates of Medicare patients, she said.
But she emphasized that "mortality is not the only measure of quality." On further review, she said, "we have found that as many as one-third of the cases that appear to be problems may be, in fact, special characteristics of the patients that we are not able to adjust for."
The main factor that the calculations are unable to account for is the severity of illness of a hospital's patients.
The information is used by peer review organizations that conduct certification reviews of hospitals, Ms. Wilensky said.
The 161 hospitals that were identified were found to have significantly higher-than-expected death rates for Medicare patients at both 30 days and 180 days after admission in 1989.
Last year, 32 hospitals were reported to have exceeded the upper limit of the range of predicted mortality for 1986, 1987 and 1988. Fifteen of those hospitals were on this year's list of 161. Sixty-five hospitals were found to have higher-than-expected rates at 30 days after admission in 1987, 1988 and 1989.
In predicting a hospital's mortality rate, the agency considers age, gender, hospital admissions within the previous six months and reason for admission.
The agency's study of mortality rates has been criticized by researchers at New York University Medical Center. In the April 10 edition of the Journal of the American Medical Association, they contended that the agency's assessment of mortality rates was flawed because it does not properly consider the patient characteristics.
Officials at two Puerto Rican hospitals on the list of four-year repeaters, the Ponce District Hospital and the Dr. Ramon Ruiz Arnau Hospital, said the survey did not give enough weight to economic and other factors.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money-Fund Yields Mixed, But Analysts Expect Decline

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The yields on money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report remained mixed for the second straight seven-day period, which ended yesterday.
Analysts at IBC/Donoghue's said investors should see more declines in yields in the coming weeks as a result of the Federal Reserve's reduction Tuesday in its discount rate, the rate the Fed charges on loans to banks, to 5 1/2 percent from 6 percent. 
 "This move was a surprise to the market," said Walter S. Frank, chief economist at IBC/Donoghue's, "and we can't rule out another move by the central bank at a later date. We always live with one more move, whether it's up or down."
 
Tax-Exempt Yields Rise
 Analysts said they did not expect yields on money market funds to decline by more than about a quarter of a percentage point.
Yields on tax-exempt money funds increased for the second consecutive week, as supplies of new issues continue to overwhelm investor demand. The average number of days to maturity of securities held in portfolios declined by a day, to 45, while their total assets fell by $1.6 billion, to a total of $87.6 billion.
For the period ended yesterday, the average seven-day compounded yield rose 16 basis points, to 4.44 percent, while the seven-day simple yield increased 15 basis points, to 4.34 percent. The 30-day compounded average yield fell one basis point, to 4.29 percent, and the 30-day simple yield dropped four basis points, to 4.20 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
The taxable equivalent of the current seven-day tax-exempt compunded yield is 6.16 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket and 6.62 percent in the 33 percent tax bracket.
 
Taxable Fund Assets Drop
 Among the tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million that are monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the General California Municipal money market fund, distributed by the Dreyfus Service Corporation of Garden City, L.I., had the best return for the week at 5.32 percent.
The assets of taxable money market funds declined $4.5 billion, to a total of $456.9 billion, with the assets of consumer funds down by $2.9 billion, to $342.8 billion. The assets of institutional funds fell by $1.6 billion, to $114.1 billion.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield fell six basis points, to 5.90 percent, while the 30-day yield fell seven basis points, to 6 percent.
For the fourth consecutive week ended yesterday, the taxable fund with the best return on investment was the Olde Premium Money Market Series with a yield of 6.84 percent. The distributor is the Olde Discount Corporation of Detroit.
By comparison, the average yield on money market accounts at banks, which compete with money market funds, fell one basis point, to 5.43 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.

HEADLINE: Indicators Are Up 0.5% In 2d Consecutive Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
Sending an ambiguous message about the economy, the Government's principal forecasting index rose for the second straight month in March although most of its components fell.
The index of leading indicators rose five-tenths of 1 percent, after a 1.2 percent gain in February. The March increase was entirely caused by a surge in consumer expectations after the Persian Gulf war, but subsequent surveys have shown that that jump in confidence is ebbing. 
 Analysts generally regarded the results as mildly favorable but they said even a third straight increase, which is thought likely, would not indicate an imminent economic upturn.
 
Calculating Probabilities
 Michael P. Niemira, an economist at Mitsubishi Bank, called the March result an "encouraging sign but by no means convincing evidence of the end of the recession." He calculated from the March data that the chance of economic recovery within the next six months is only 30 percent -- "far below the important 90 percent threshold used as confirmation of a business cycle turning point."
In a separate report today, a monthly survey by the National Association of Purchasing Managers showed the industrial sector of the economy declining at a slower pace in April for the third straight month. And the Federal Reserve said today that its survey of business conditions by district through April 21 found activity "remained weak in much of the nation, but there were some indications that the decline may be bottoming out."
Only 4 of the 11 components of the index contributed to the March advance, with the jump in consumer expectations, as compiled by the University of Michigan, adding more than three times as much as the second-biggest positive factor, which was an increase in the money supply.
The other pluses were increases in stock prices, as measured by the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, and a rise in permits to construct buildings.
The four components that moved up in March -- three of them financial or psychological -- were the same four that paced the February increase.
The seven negative March factors, ranked by their importance, were a decline in factories' orders for consumer goods and materials, a rise in average weekly new claims for state unemployment insurance, a decline in the length of the workweek, lower contracts and orders for plant and equipment, a fall in unfilled factory orders, a decline in the price of materials particularly sensitive to the business cycle and speedier deliveries by corporate suppliers.
"We're still declining, but at a slower rate," said Richard B. Berner, an economist at Salomon Brothers. "The issue is not whether we get a recovery but how strong and how soon." He predicted that an upturn would begin in late summer.
 
Two Other Indexes
 The leading index is intended to predict economic turns but failed to do so for this recession, which began in July. As complements to the index, the Commerce Department compiles indexes of indicators that tend to move at the same time as the economy and of indicators that trail behind it.
The index of coincident indicators fell five-tenths of 1 percent in March, the same as in February, its ninth straight decline. The latest two months, however, showed the smallest declines since August.
The index of lagging indicators rose three-tenths of 1 percent in March, continuing the zigzag pattern of the last 18 months.
The ratio of the coincident to the lagging index, which is considered a long lead-time predictor, fell for the seventh straight month.
Reflecting a longer average workweek than initially estimated, the department revised upward to 1.2 percent, from 1.1 percent, the advance in the leading index for February.
The leading index now stands at 141.1, with the first-quarter average 3.4 percent below its level a year earlier, today's report showed.

HEADLINE: Door Opens a Crack for Colombia's Indians

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia

 BODY:
With his brown bowler hat, striped poncho and blue wraparound dress, Lorenzo Muelas Hurtado causes more than a sartorial clash as he moves among the delegates in business suits at Colombia's constitutional convention.
In politics, Indian tribal elders like Mr. Muelas have rarely found open doors among the capital's elite. 
 "We Indians were always called anti-social, delinquent, anti-Christian," Mr. Muelas, traditional leader of the Guambia tribal group, said between sessions of rewriting Colombia's Constitution, which dates from 1886. "Now, if I want to see the President of the Republic, I can see him tomorrow."
To the dismay of Colombia's political elite, the process of revising the oldest Constitution in Latin America has been thrown open to a host of new voices.
In a nation where Roman Catholicism has long enjoyed the advantages of an official religion, two delegates are Evangelical Protestants. In a political system restricted for decades to members of the Liberal or Conservative Parties, almost a third of the 73 delegates come from recently disarmed guerrilla groups.
And in a nation that in 1890 passed a law setting a 50-year target to "civilize the savages," three delegates speak for Colombia's 600,000 Indians.
"Our arrival at the convention is a historical event: it means a break in our marginality," said Francisco Rojas Birry, an Embera Indian elected on Dec. 9 in a nationwide poll for convention delegates. With pluralism now a hallmark of Colombian politics, the Indian delegates are challenging the nation to grapple with a new concept: cultural pluralism.
Here as in the rest of the continent, the fight for Indian rights has accelerated with the impending 500th anniversary of the arrival of Columbus in the Americas. One poster seen on streets here shows an international stop symbol superimposed in red on a cartoon of the explorer's face. The caption reads, in Spanish, "500 Years -- No."
"We, Indians of Colombia, reject with all the anger we have built up over hundreds of years the 'celebration' that the West wants to make in 1992 of the great ethnocidal saga," Mr. Rojas Birry, a 31-year-old lawyer, said last February in his opening speech to the assembly here.
Representing 80 indigenous ethnic groups -- from the Amazon rain forest to the Andean mountains -- the three Indian delegates propose that Colombia's new constitution accord Indians rights to bilingual education and to political and economic control over recognized homelands.
The Indians also want to be judged by Indian courts and to have seats set aside for Indians in Colombia's congress. The Indians seek to end work by missionaries like the Summer Institute of Linguistics, a United States group that encourages Indians to abandon traditional religious beliefs and medical practices in favor of Evangelical Protestantism and Western medicine.
 
'Right to Be Different'
 "The Right to Be Different," Colombia's largest-selling newspaper summarized in a headline over a list of Indian demands. As never before in Colombian history, the constitutional convention has provided a national pulpit for Indian demands. With his distinctive felt hat and knit shoulder bag, the 53-year-old Muelas is an instant celebrity who is often greeted by applause when he walks down the streets of this somber mountain city.
Grumbling about "theatrics," conservative delegates complain that Mr. Muelas converses with them in fluent Spanish, but adopts an artificially broken "Indian Spanish" when television cameras are rolling. Mr. Muelas, who has escaped from three attempts on his life since he left a local landowner's debt peonage system 35 years ago, knows that in Colombia, instant celebrity is not a bulletproof jacket.
Last Dec. 13, four days after the Indian delegates were elected, members of the Arhuaco tribe recovered the mutilated bodies of their three most senior traditional leaders. The Arhuaco, who live in Colombia's northern Sierra Nevada range, say an army detachment kidnapped and killed the leaders after leftist guerrillas kidnapped a local rancher.

HEADLINE: Fed Sees Signs That Slump May Be Close to Low Point

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
Despite the ending of the Persian Gulf war, economic activity remained weak in much of the nation during the early spring, the Federal Reserve said today. But the central bank said its latest survey of the economy found scattered signs that the recession may be nearing its low point.
The survey, compiled from information supplied by the 12 regional Fed banks, was prepared for top Fed officials to use at their May 14 session to map interest rate policy. 
 The central bank on Tuesday pushed two key interest rates lower; it is believed that the signs of weakness noted in the survey played a role in that decision.
The regional banks reported that retail sales were sluggish, nonresidential construction remained in the doldrums and demand for bank loans was essentially flat.
Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of overall economic activity, remained sluggish in most regions. Weaker sales were reported by Philadelphia, Chicago and Dallas, although Cleveland reported a pickup in activity in areas not affected by auto layoffs.
Increased sales of autos were reported by Kansas City, Cleveland and Atlanta, but most other districts found little improvement in this sector, and Dallas reported a sharp drop in car sales.
In manufacturing, the Fed survey found that the steep slump over the last two years might be bottoming out. Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Cleveland, Richmond, Atlanta, Chicago and Kansas City all noted stable or slightly improving conditions for manufacturing companies.
St. Louis said manufacturing conditions were continuing to worsen, and attributed the weakness to further layoffs in the auto sector and an expected plant shutdown in May.
Kansas City, Dallas and San Francisco reported stronger foreign demand for products, which they credited to contracts to rebuild Kuwait.
One of the few bright spots, the Fed said, was a significant pickup in the housing industry, with most parts of the nation reporting improved sales of both new and existing homes.
But the survey said conditions in nonresidential real estate remained severely depressed. The Boston district reported that construction of new commercial space had nearly halted as vacancy rates continued to rise "due to further contraction in the financial services industry."
The New York Fed reported that office leasing in midtown Manhattan had dropped to its lowest level in three years. High vacancy rates were also reported in Los Angeles and Minneapolis-St. Paul.
The demand for bank loans was reported to be flat or only slightly improved around the country. Some strength was noted in mortgage lending and mortgage refinancing, but Atlanta and Boston said tight lending conditions continued to restrict loan growth.
Kansas City reported that warm weather had helped the winter wheat crop, but California said a late December freeze had halved fruit production and exports and destroyed many fruit and nut trees.

HEADLINE: Seattle Showpiece of Health Care by Democracy

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, May 1

 BODY:
For a single monthly fee, most members of Group Health Cooperative have access to nearly unlimited medical care. If they live well, without smoking, drinking heavily or becoming overweight, they can pay even less. If they do not like the way their local clinic is being run, they can change it by voting out the management.
Group Health, medical care by democracy, is the nation's largest consumer-governed health care organization, with 470,0000 members. One of every eight residents of the Puget Sound area belongs to the cooperative, which is based in Seattle. 
 As other health maintenance organizations have floundered, or run into financial trouble, Group Health turned a $19 million surplus last year.
 
'Model of the Future'
 With its healthy balance sheet and growing membership, Group Health is attracting national attention. "It's my model of the future," said Dr. Arnold Relman, the former editor of The New England Journal of Medicine.
"With patients right on the board of directors monitoring them, doctors are committed to the highest quality of care," he said. "There's no incentive for doing more tests than indicated, but every incentive to do all that is indicated."
It has taken the cooperative more than 40 years to work out its kinks. The mid-1980's, as health care costs soared far beyond the rate of inflation, were particularly rough.
Group Health keeps costs down by eliminating unnecessary surgery and procedures and by stressing preventive care. "We have tried to get away from the idea that the more surgery you do, the more money you make," said Dr. Phillip M. Nudelman, the president and chief executive of Group Health.
 
Avoiding Unneeded Surgery
 About 30 percent of all surgery in the United States is not needed, Dr. Nudelman contends. On average, he said, the cooperative performs about 40 percent fewer cardiac operations on patients with heart disease than are done in other health systems.
Twice as many Group Health members receive flu immunization shots as the national average. There is an aggressive screening program to detect colon, skin and breast cancer at early stages. The cooperative's program for smokers who want to quit succeeds at a rate twice the national average. Consulting nurses are available 24 hours day by telephone to answer questions.
 
Complaints About Waiting
 Doctors here insist that they do not shortchange their patients. Dr. Nudelman says any procedure that is available, including costly operations like bone marrow and organ transplants, can be had at Group Health, which has 29 medical centers and 2 hospitals in the Northwest. Cosmetic surgergy is excluded.
"On a technical and service level, Group Health is as good as anybody," said Dr. Douglas Conrad, an economist at the University of Washington.
Complaints have to do with waiting periods for certain doctors and certain procedures. Group Health has more than 700 staff physicians. Members choose their own doctor, but the more popular ones can be hard to see.
The doctors are paid anywhere from $60,000 to $220,000 a year, said Dr. Nudelman, and the turnover rate is about 3 percent a year, well below the industry average.
Almost all the cooperative's revenue, which totaled $577 million last year, comes from premiums paid by consumers. In the early years most members were self-employed, jobless or could not find afford medical insurance. Now, about 85 percent of members are on company payrolls, including large corporations like Boeing, with premiums paid by the employer.
Membership in Group Health is slightly more expensive than the local average. A 40-year-old with full coverage will pay about $100 a month, but most members pay no deductibles.
 
Threat of Rising Cost
 The rising price of medical technology and services, though, poses a threat to Group Health's ability to provide top care at low cost. Officers wonder whether the group will always be able to afford the best and newest. But without staying on the cutting edge, it may have trouble attracting new members.
The concept of Group Health may not be easily transplanted. Group Health grew out of a Scandinavian tradition of pooling costs and talent. For this to work elsewhere, said Dr. Nudelman, "there has to be a culture willing to accept something that goes against the grain of most American health care."

HEADLINE: Apple Warns of an Earnings Dip

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 1

 BODY:
Although its sales are growing rapidly after it cut prices on its popular Macintosh machines, Apple Computer Inc. said today that its earnings for the third quarter of its fiscal year might be lower than for the corresponding period a year earlier.
Apple executives said the dollar's resurgence on currency exchanges and the company's shift toward lower-priced products would hurt profit margins for the quarter ending June 30. 
 The news seemed to catch many analysts and investors by surprise, and Apple shares plummeted $7.75, to $47.25, in over-the-counter trading today.
 
Pressure on Profit Margins
 The pressure on Apple's profit margins was well known, but many analysts had anticipated that a big jump in sales volume would offset the lower profits on each computer. While Apple's move to gain market share makes sense in the long term, it is likely to create short-term earnings disappointments, analysts said.
In its third quarter last year, Apple earned $119.8 million, or 96 cents a share.
Apple's announcement followed a report on Tuesday by the Quantum Corporation, a major supplier of disk drives to Apple. Quantum said that it expected slower growth in orders from Apple in the next few quarters. Apple, however, said it expected shipment growth to continue in the third quarter at about the same rate as it had in the second quarter.
The announcement today led some analysts to cut their earnings estimates for the company, which is based in Cupertino, Calif. Last month, Apple shares fell after the company announced lower than expected earnings for its second quarter, ended March 31.
Apple can point to some signs of success in its transition from a low-volume producer of high-profit computers to a company seeking higher market share by lowering prices and profit margins. Macintosh shipments have increased 85 percent in an economic downturn, indicating Apple is succeeding in gaining market share.
But Joseph A. Graziano, Apple's chief financial officer, said the company had not been able to reduce costs rapidly enough to accommodate the lower profits on each sale.
"Clearly, we are succeeding at our overriding business objectives," he said. "We are attracting new users to the Macintosh platform and increasing our share of the personal computer market. At the same time, our gross margins have declined faster than we had originally expected, challenging our ability to achieve the levels of profitability we had targeted at the start of the fiscal year."
Speaking to analysts today at a technology conference here sponsored by Hambrecht & Quist, a brokerage firm, Mr. Graziano said the company would cut sales and marketing expenses to improve its operating margin, which fell to 11.8 percent in the March quarter, from 14.8 percent a year earlier. He said that the company would continue to increase its research and development spending, and that he did not anticipate any layoffs.
In the past, Apple made so much profit from its computers that it could afford to be profligate, leading to high operating costs relative to competitors.
Apple does have reasons to hope for improved future earnings. They include the introduction later this month of System 7.0, an updated version of the basic operating system software that controls the Macintosh. It is expected to be accompanied by major new programs from several software companies.
Apple also has "a whole slew of new products coming out in the fall," Mr. Graziano said. These are expected to include new high-end Macintosh models and a notebook computer to be developed in conjunction with the Sony Corporation.
So far, the bulk of the growth has been from Apple's new entry-level product, the Macintosh Classic, which is less profitable than the company's higher-priced models. The shift in product mix toward the low end, coupled with a higher dollar, which lowers the value of overseas sales made in foreign currencies, has cut margins faster than Apple had anticipated.
"We are going through a transformation, but I think we're on track, and we are sticking to our strategy," Mr. Graziano said.
That transformation is one that other personal computer makers may also experience. The Compaq Computer Corporation last month slashed prices across the board in an effort to increase market share, and the International Business Machines Corporation is expected to cut prices soon. The maturing of the personal computer market, and the entry of many low-cost clones, has made such plays for market share necessary.
 
'Period of Transition'
 "I think the industry overall is going through a very real period of transition," said Bruce Lupatkin, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist. The rapidly changing market will distort many companies' profit and loss projections throughout 1991, he said.
When Apple introduced the lower-priced models in October, it answered critics' charges that its machines were too expensive, but the move raised concerns among analysts about what these low-profit items would do to Apple's profitablity.
Analysts also fretted that the new models were too good, and would cannibalize sales of Apple's middle-range and high-end machines. Apple lowered prices on those models in March.
"While our mid-range and high-end products are up, they are still not up as much as we would expect," Mr. Graziano said. But he added that it was not clear whether this was a result of cannibalization or of the general economic downturn, since those models are primarily sold to business users.

HEADLINE: Bush Trade Concessions Pick Up Some Support

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
The Bush Administration got a favorable reception in Congress today to its commitments to insulate American workers and the environment from the effects of a free trade agreement with Mexico.
But while several key interest groups were swayed in favor of the President, it was still uncertain whether the 150-page "action plan" sent to Capitol Hill today would be enough to win a critical vote later this month on extending Mr. Bush's trade-negotiating authority for two years. 
 Organized labor, textile interests and others who fear that greater trade with Mexico will result in a loss of jobs and a weakening of environmental and labor standards have been lobbying against an extension.
"This response contains some significant concessions by the Administration," said Lloyd Bentsen, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, who was among Congressional leaders warning Mr. Bush that the extension could fail without reassurances on the environmental and labor fronts.
 
Some See Mushiness
 The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee's Trade Subcommittee, Sam Gibbons, a Florida Democrat, said the program came out "better than expected."
Among the commitments are special provisions that would restore tariffs on fruits and vegetables to earlier levels if protection was needed. The tariffs would probably be cut in the trade pact, and the fruit and vegetable industry in Texas and Florida fears low-price, low-tariff Mexican competition.
But other lawmakers, such as Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat, and William D. Ford, the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, remained steadfast in their opposition.
"It would be hard to be vaguer and mushier than this Administration has been in these so-called commitments," Mr. Wyden said.
Mr. Ford, who comes from an automaking area, said, "I think the Mexican free trade agreement would make the Great Depression look like a Sunday school picnic in my Congressional district."
These were the key pledges by the Administration:
*To work with Congress to fashion an "adequately funded" program of assistance for workers dislocated as a result of increased foreign competition.
*To exclude changes in immigration policy from the trade pact.
*To prevent Mexican products that do not meet United States health or safety requirements from entering this country.
*To put in place an integrated environmental plan for the border between the United States and Mexico and appoint representatives of environmental organizations to official trade advisory bodies.
Howard F. Rosen, an economist at the Institute for International Economics, said of the commitment on workers: "They are reversing a Reagan Administration policy against special adjustment programs."
As the documents were released, President Bush told a conference of business editors that President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico and the Mexican people "have no interest in allowing their country to become a pollution haven for U.S. companies."
The National Council of La Raza, a Hispanic civil rights organization that has expressed concerns about pollution and labor standards, today endorsed an extension of the Adminstration's negotiating authority, according to its chief executive, Raul Yzaguirre.
Among the interest groups that significantly softened its opposition to the extension was the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental organization.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
U.S. Wants Iraq to Finance Kurdish Relief Operations

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
The United States wants Iraq to pay for the American-led effort to help Kurdish refugees in the northern part of the country, senior Bush Administration officials said today.
Although the Administration is uncertain exactly how to require the Baghdad Government to finance the operation, which is expected to cost more than $500 million over six months, one option under consideration would link such payment to approval of Iraqi resumption of oil exports. Linkage would require the approval of the sanctions committee of the United Nations Security Council, which is setting the terms for lifting economic sanctions against Iraq. 
 The idea of collecting payment from Iraq, initially floated by Britain, reflects the Administration's overall strategy to keep President Saddam Hussein politically and militarily weak, while also searching for new ways to strangle his economy.
Resigned to the prospect that Mr. Hussein may remain President of Iraq for some time and determined that the country not be allowed to rebuild as long as he remains in power, the Administration is preparing a proposal under which Iraq would have to contribute 40 to 50 percent of its oil revenue for reparations from its invasion of Kuwait last August, senior Administration officials said.
But there is considerable skepticism in the Administration that the United States will succeed in convincing the sanctions committee, which includes all 15 members of the Security Council, to require Iraqi financing of the relief effort or to extract such a high percentage of its oil revenue for reparations for damage done to Kuwait during the war.
India, Cuba and Yemen, members of the Security Council, have urged that Iraq pay no more than 10 percent, while Britain proposes that Iraq pay the same amount for reparations as it did for the purchase of weapons over the last decade, a figure equivalent to about 25 to 30 percent of its prewar oil revenue. Under the British plan, these payments would be phased in as Iraqi oil exports come back on line.
The Security Council will begin this week to grapple with the reparations issue. Under the cease-fire resolution adopted by the Council on April 3, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar must submit an initial report by Friday with the structure for a fund generated by oil sales. This fund will be tapped for reparations.
Administration officials acknowledge that the American demand for Iraq to pay for the relief effort goes beyond two Security Council resolutions that dictate Iraq's conduct: a cease-fire resolution that sets a series of demands and deadlines that must be met before economic sanctions are lifted, and a resolution giving the Security Council sweeping authority to provide relief to Iraq's refugees. But they argue that these resolutions are flexible enough to take changing circumstances into account.
The United States and Britain take a strict interpretation of the cease-fire resolution in opposing Iraq's requests to sell close to $1 billion of its oil and to gain access to $1 billion of its assets frozen in foreign banks. Baghdad says it needs this money to buy food and medical supplies.
"Everyone in the Council is inclined to be more flexible than us and Britain," a White House official said. "We're motiviated not only by the fact that Saddam is still in power but also that if we open the door a little, he'll find ways to circumvent the sanctions and undermine the coalition aligned against him."
Administration officials argue, for example, that Iraq still has considerable assets in its central bank and sizable gold reserves that it should spend first. Other Security Council members, such as China, are leaning toward aiding Iraq's economy, but the United States remains suspicious of its appeals that its civilian population is in desperate need of food.
The hard line was reflected by Under Secretary of Defense Paul D. Wolfowitz, who said on the "McNeil-Lehrer News Hour" on Monday: "As far as we can tell, some large share of the trucks bringing food in from Jordan get diverted to Iraqi military camps, and as far as we know, the Iraqis still have plenty of assets with which to buy food. So these claims are greeted with considerable skepticism."
 
U.S. Approach Unavailing
 Administration officials acknowledged that their hard line thus far has had no success in dislodging Mr. Hussein. In fact, they said, he is stronger now than he was at the end of the war because he has successfully put down civil insurrections and because the presence of foreign troops on his soil gives him the chance to argue that Iraqi sovereignty is being violated.
These officials acknowledge that there is increasing sympathy in the Security Council for Iraq's economic plight and that the United States may be swimming against the tide.
"There's a new mood that Iraq should be able to get on with their own affairs and recover after the war," an official said. "There's a lot of feeling that 'you destroyed their infrastructutre and they've suffered enough.' "
Former United Nations officials question the wisdom of continuing sanctions that might backfire.
"There is a limit beyond which you may not be able to get much out of the Iraqis," said Sir Brian Urquhart, a former Under Secretary General. "If the object of the exercise is to get Saddam to leave, I can't believe this is going to work. There's the danger that you will revive undeserved sympathy and support for the guy."
