HEADLINE: The Interest-Rate Battle;
U.S. Wants to Grow Out of the Recession, But Its Partners Fear Rekindled Inflation

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady's efforts this week to bring down worldwide interest rates are being portrayed in the Bush Administration as the opening round in a battle between a rather pessimistic American view of the world's economy and a more buoyant German approach.
To European finance ministers, Mr. Brady's actions seem quixotic at best. Perhaps that reaction is inevitable for an Administration that is trying to argue simultaneously that the recession in the United States is about to end and is also in danger of getting worse, along with many other national economies. 
 Whatever the contradictions, the Administration argument -- with Mr. Brady as the spokesman -- is that the other industrial nations must understand they are more deeply mired in slow growth and recession than they realize. And, incidentally, the Administration seems to say that if the industrial nations do not change their ways, the United States may remain in recession.
The American concern is that if the other nations -- Britain, Japan, Germany, Canada, France and Italy -- do not adopt pro-growth policies, then American exports will level off or fall, particularly the 30 percent that go to Europe. If that happens, the United States recession could endure. The nation's exports to Europe in fact have leveled off this year.
The Brady solution is to campaign for lower interest rates, despite the failure of that approach this week. Lower rates mean cheaper loans, which in theory, at least, lead to more spending and investment and eventually stronger growth abroad. The danger, the Germans and others argue, is that lower rates and the greater demand can also mean rising inflation -- and that concern, for the moment, is uppermost in their minds, they say.
Mr. Brady's office says he is planning to continue his campaign for lower interest rates abroad, and the Administration seems to be endorsing his efforts, despite the initial failure.
As Michael Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, put it carefully today: "Secretary Brady is clearly right to point out to those other countries that we have a worldwide growth slowdown, several countries in recession and the need for all countries to renew their commitment to growth-oriented policies."
Mr. Brady got into trouble last weekend when he tried to lean on Germany to reduce its interest rates, although the Germans had warned him in advance that they would not respond to his plea. The other nations lined up with the Germans, who dominate Europe's economy.
Then the Federal Reserve Board reduced American interest rates on Tuesday, in effect doing just what the Germans had said the Americans should have done in the first place.
 
Performance Is Criticized
 Mr. Brady's performance, played out at a meeting here of the world's seven largest industrial nations, known as the Group of Seven, brought forth derisive criticism. The Financial Times of London, in the opening words of an editorial, declared, "Rarely can a great power have come to an important international meeting with arguments as feeble as those advanced by the U.S."
And Horst Kohler, an Under Secretary in Germany's Finance Ministry, told reporters that Mr. Brady and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, could not appeal for help by implying that they needed it to avoid a potentially more severe American recession while arguing at the meeting that "there are signs of recovery."
Back home, there is speculation about what Bush Administration officials might be up to. Robert Giordano, chief economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said he thought the Administration was becoming "increasingly concerned that the recovery won't be strong enough" -- a concern that various economic statistics this week seems to support. "The Administration wants a real recovery for the 1992 election year, not a half-hearted one," he said.
Others, like C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, contend that while the Administration tries to maintain a confident aura -- adhering to a forecast that the recession will end by summer -- it is reaching out for solutions to a recession that in fact may turn out to be worse than anyone had figured.
 
'Pounding on Foreigners'
 "The pounding on the foreigners plus the Fed's cutting of interest rates can only be explained by the concern that the Government feels about the economy," Mr. Bergsten said.
And then there is the view that Mr. Brady's performance seemed inept, whatever its merits, because the United States failed to carry the day against Germany.
"It is desirable to try to get the others to lower interest rates," said Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, who is chairman of Congress's Joint Economic Committee and who endorsed the Brady strategy. "But I think it is a commentary on the times that the United States muscle was not sufficient for us to be listened to."
Indeed, German concerns were much different, and they won the day. As the Germans saw it, lowering interest rates would weaken the mark at a time when it has fallen in value anyway since early this year. That would create huge difficulties for Germany, encouraging holders of German marks to sell them for other currencies at a time when the Germans need all the capital they can get to revive eastern Germany.
 
Looking to Eastern Germany
 The Germans in attendance this week -- Theo Waigel, the Finance Minister, Karl Otto Pohl, president of the Bundesbank, and Mr. Kohler -- also argued that eastern Germany's economy, while in deep trouble now, would rebound before long and the new demand would help to revive national growth.
Reducing interest rates in this context, the Germans argued, would only result in a rising inflation rate -- a concern that other finance ministers also raised. German short-term rates, adjusted for inflation, are four to five percentage points higher than similar American rates.
Most important, Germany's overpowering role in the European economy constrains other nations from lowering rates if Germany does not, although the weakening economies of France and Italy make them natural allies of the Brady approach, American officials argue.
"Japan also might be wavering," Mr. Bergsten said. "They are saying that they are concerned about growth and inflation. My suspicion is that they might attempt to reduce rates in two or three weeks."

HEADLINE: Kodak Net Dips to Low End of Forecasts

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
The Eastman Kodak Company reported yesterday that its first-quarter earnings declined 10.6 percent, to $178 million, or 55 cents a share, from $199 million, or 61 cents a share, a year earlier.
The results were at the low end of analysts' expectations. Most had forecast that the company would report earnings of more than 60 cents a share. Kodak's stock closed yesterday down 87.5 cents, to $40.75. 
 The company attributed the earnings decline to advertising and promotion costs needed to stimulate sales in a recession. Kodak's sales increased 7.3 percent, to $4.4 billion in the period from $4.1 billion in last year's first quarter.
"Continued recession in the U.S. economy, the dampening effect of the Mideast war -- particularly in travel and tourism, a dollar that was stronger than expected and signs of weakness in other world economies made the first quarter a difficult period for Kodak," said Kay R. Whitmore, chairman.
 
Gains Are Forecast
 Mr. Whitmore forecast "continued gains in sales and margin recovery later in the year, assuming improvement in the tone and pace of the U.S. economy."
Earnings in the company's imaging segment, Kodak's basic photographic film business, declined 18.7 percent, to $178 million from $219 million, although worldwide sales increased to $1.4 billion from last year's $1.3 billion.
Profits in the information segment, which includes copiers and printers, plunged to $1 million, from $28 million. The company attributed the falloff to "general softness in the U.S. economy," which contributed to lower sales of equipment and supplies.
However, earnings of the chemical segment increased 19.2 percent, to $155 million from $130 million. Higher prices in the United States and "excellent sales increases" overseas were cited.
Earnings in the health segment, largely from its Sterling Drug unit, increased slightly, to $122 million from $121 million.
The company, based in Rochester, said its research and development spending totaled $352 million in the period, compared with $317 million in the period last year. Capital spending totaled $511 million, up from $308 million.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Gun Measure Is Lesson in Geography

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
The Brady bill is the first tough domestic issue the House will face this year, and the whole issue of gun control has stirred intense ideological passions. But next week's vote will not be an occasion for rounding up the usual stereotypes of the 101st Congress.
The fight over the Brady bill, which would impose a seven-day waiting period on handgun purchases, is not really a fight between liberals and conservatives or Republicans and Democrats. Neither party's leadership is demanding, or even counting, votes. This issue is intensely individual and representative. 
 There are divisions that offer a better clue to how the roll-calls will break than the traditional political analyses; they are geographical. Like the major battles of the last century, over railroads and banks, this one pits the East against the South and the West and, most of all, divides the House on rural-versus-urban lines.
Consider two outspoken Wisconsin Congressmen.
Representative David R. Obey is one of the most dogged liberal Democrats in the House, and he is leaning strongly against the Brady bill.
Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr. is one of the House's most conservative Republicans. National Journal, the Washington weekly of government, found that last year he voted more conservatively than 89 percent of the House on social issues and 98 percent on economic issues. Although rarely found backing any measure that can be attacked as increasing the power of government over the individual, he is a supporter of this bill.
Mr. Obey represents the forests, farms and iron mines of northern Wisconsin, where, he said, "we look at hunting as a normal recreational experience" and where pistols are frequently used on squirrels and "other nuisance animals."
He scoffs at the proposed waiting period, saying it would do nothing but keep vacationers from buying guns from hardware stores or tobacco shops in his district. "If you say you're going to have a seven-day waiting period," he said, "you're sending all of those guys back to Chicago or Milwaukee, just taking away an opportunity for a sale."
Mr. Sensenbrenner's constituents may go fishing in Mr. Obey's district. But a lot of them work in Milwaukee, and they live in the Milwaukee suburbs, where crime is an issue. Mr. Sensenbrenner argues that the bill would help "reclaim our streets and our communities for our families."
His latest newsletter sought to reassure constituents that the bill would protect "the rights of citizens to keep and bear arms," a paraphrase of the Second Amendment, on which the National Rifle Association has based its constitutional objection to anti-gun legislation. And he argued that the waiting period would not only enable the police to check a buyer's background but also offer a "cooling off" period that would reduce "impulsive crimes of passion."
Mr. Obey and Mr. Sensenbrenner are not alone. Conservative Republicans like Representatives Henry J. Hyde of Illinois and Frank R. Wolf of Virginia, both representing suburbs near high-crime cities, back the Brady bill. Liberal Democrats like Bob Carr of Michigan, Mike Espy of Mississippi and Dave Nagle of Iowa support a substitute that would have no waiting period but that would require instantaneous checks of criminal records; the Brady bill's proponents and the Bush Administration call the measure impractical. And Representative Bernard Sanders, the independent socialist from Vermont, opposes the bill because it does not attack the "hopelessness and despair" that cause crime.
But party will still matter in the end. Democrats are more likely to support the bill than Republicans are, if only because they are more likely to represent cities.
And, because they control the House, the Democrats will get much of the credit and blame distributed for next week's result. The Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, has fought the bill in the past, but has pushed it to an early vote this time.
Next week's losers are likely to blame him for not doing more for them, and each has a claim. He reflects those competing constituencies. A party whose strength is in the cities elected Mr. Foley to be Speaker, but a vast rural district whose largest city is Spokane, Wash., with a population of 177,196, elected him to the House.

HEADLINE: Strategy for a Boston Comeback

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
As the nation's banks try to recover from the billions of dollars in bad real estate loans they made during the 1980's, the road back will inevitably lead past places like 89 Broad Street, a 14-story Art Deco office building in this city's financial district.
In 1985, when the New England economy was surging and downtown office space was scarce, the Bank of Boston lent $27 million to Harold Brown, a big local developer, to buy and refurbish the building. Now, after Mr. Brown has sought protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, the bank's enthusiasm looks like a costly mistake, with an $11 million loss from writing down the loan's value to $16 million to better reflect the depressed New England economy. 
 But the bank is not giving up on Mr. Brown and the building just yet. In fact, an agreement to restructure the loan for 89 Broad Street is a prime example of how some lenders throughout the nation are trying to prevent further losses while creating the potential for future profits.
 
Patience for Profits
 In a nutshell, the Bank of Boston has decided that 89 Broad Street will eventually fill with tenants and that Mr. Brown needs both time and concessions to make the project successful. So the bank has agreed to take a number of steps, including reducing the interest rate on the loan, deferring some payments and even lending more money to the developer for renovations.
For its patience, the Bank of Boston stands to be fully repaid over time and possibly earn a share of any profit if the building operates successfully or is later sold.
Restructured loans like that for 89 Broad Street are proliferating. They require close cooperation between a bank and a developer. The bank agrees to extend payments on existing debt and often to arrange new loans for the developer. The building owner gets the financial breathing room necessary to begin the slow, steady work of attracting additional tenants and generating more income.
Guilliaem (Rusty) Aertsen, a bad-loan specialist who worked on Texas real estate problems a few years ago, was named last year to head the Bank of Boston's real estate department. His task now is to try to recover some of the losses. For banks that stay with projects that recover, the rewards for patience can be considerable. And Mr. Aertsen clearly believes that in three to five years, 89 Broad Street will prove a shrewd bet.
"I don't need 'Massachusetts Miracle II -- the Sequel' to have this property recover," Mr. Aertsen said. "All I need is some improvement in the local economy. And the upside potential for the bank for staying with a situation like this is enormous."
Not surprisingly, the real estate "workout" business is becoming one of the few growth fields in banking these days. At the Bank of Boston, the number of real estate and workout professionals has jumped to 170 from 100 in 18 months, a period of austerity for the bank as a whole. And last year, the bank handed the challenge to Mr. Aertsen, a veteran of the Texas real estate slump.
Few banks that have survived have been hit harder by bad real estate loans than the Bank of Boston Corporation, a once-aggressive lender based in the slumping Northeast. In the last two years, the bank has taken losses of $546 million on its commercial real estate business.
"It's a deep hole for the bank," said James Moynihan, senior vice president of Advest Inc., a securities firm in Boston, "but in Rusty Aertsen they've got one of the best workout specialists in the industry,"
 
Fast Response to the Problem
 Banking executives and analysts credit the Bank of Boston with moving more quickly than others to face up to its real estate troubles, taking charges against earnings sooner and thinning out its portfolio of bad loans. "They have their hands around the problem in a way that many banks don't," said Thomas Hanley, an analyst for Salomon Brothers Inc.
The Bank of Boston has cut its commercial real estate loans from $6.38 billion in 1988 to $3.91 billion by the end of 1990, according to the IBCA Inc. credit-rating agency, while such loans increased at most other banks.
And the Bank of Boston's nonperforming loans -- those at least 90 days behind -- and real estate seized from delinquent borrowers both stopped growing by the second half of last year; both are expected to shrink. Yet that pile of bad loans and seized property still amounts to more than $1 billion.
 
Two Kinds of Decisions
 A bank's success in dealing with troubled real estate depends on choosing which owners and developers to work with and which to abandon by foreclosing on their property. The easy decisions, Mr. Aertsen explained, are on loans for speculative projects, built during the boom days in outlying suburbs, that will not attract tenants even after the region's economy revives. "Some are in places where the highest possible economic use is a cornfield or something," he said.
The difficult judgments are on delinquent loans for solid projects where a deteriorating economy has eroded rents, leaving the owner unable to meet payments. The decision to restructure developers' debt and allow them to hold on to their property is a bet on their character and competence.
Mr. Aertsen insists that both 89 Broad Street and Mr. Brown are worth the risk. Mr. Brown made his fortune by buying older buildings just outside the most costly blocks of downtown Boston, then refurbishing and renting them as growth expanded the central business district. He is known for frugality, working out of austere offices and living modestly without yachts, private planes or a distracting social life.
 
How the Project Fell Ill
 Poring over a cash-flow analysis of 89 Broad Street at his office, Mr. Aertsen explained how the project fell ill and how the bank plans to restore its financial health. Mr. Brown originally invested $8 million of his own money along with the $27 million loan from the Bank of Boston, for a total of $35 million. The building is 70 percent occupied -- a respectable figure in a weak market -- but rental rates and the building's value have fallen sharply.
At the going rate of $20 a square foot prevailing in June 1989, the bank and its appraisers calculated that the building had a long-term value of about $140 a square foot, or $38.1 million. But by the end of last year, with rents falling to $14 a square foot, the estimated long-term value of the asset slid to $61 a square foot, or $16.6 million, or less than half its previous estimate.
The bank not only wrote down the amount of the loan on its books to $16 million but also, as part of its agreement, trimmed the interest rate by a percentage point, to 9 percent. The result: Operating income that Mr. Brown needs to service the current debt has been sliced from $3.2 million a year, including interest and fees, to $1.4 million.
 
The New Plan
 Under the new plan, Mr. Brown must make monthly payments and, eventually, pay the full, $27 million amount of the original loan with deferred interest. Mr. Aertsen said that over three to five years, the local economy is likely to revive sufficiently to raise rents and to allow Mr. Brown to meet these terms.
The Bank of Boston stands ready to give Mr. Brown new loans of as much as $8.8 million to complete interior renovation and the restoration of the Art Deco lobby. But the bank will not lend the additional money until Mr. Brown lines up new tenants, generating the income to make payments on the new loans.
In return for its cooperation, the Bank of Boston received not only a pledge of full payment on all its loans, but also what amounts to an equity stake in the building.
Such delicate debt negotiations between banks and hard-pressed developers are typically private. But the plan for 89 Broad Street was filed in a Boston court in early April, the month after Mr. Brown sought bankruptcy protection. The developer hopes the 89 Broad Street pact will serve as a model for refinancing another $640 million in bank loans on more than 300 properties he controls in New England.
 
Stake in Building's Appreciation
 For the next 30 years, the bank will be entitled to 25 percent of any appreciation in the building's worth above the original $27 million loan value. Should 89 Broad Street be sold or refinanced for $45 million, the bank is entitled to one-fourth of the $18 million difference -- a $4.5 million profit.
If Mr. Brown fully repays the original loan of $27 million, the bank would report another $11 million profit over the $16 million loan value the bank now carries on its books.
Mr. Brown, 65, who bought and renovated his first Boston building in 1953, is used to taking the long view. He says he firmly believes that after the Northeast's slump ends, the Bank of Boston's patience will prove profitable.
"All we need from a bank is the vision to restructure the debt and some faith that this down cycle will end," he said. "The Bank of Boston has shown those qualities, and they'll get their money back."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The office building at 89 Broad Street in Boston's financial district. The Bank of Boston is restructuring its loan to the building's developer in hopes that the property will become profitable in a few years. (Jim Bourg for The New York Times) (pg. D6)
 
Chart: "What Happened on Broad Street"
How Bank of Boston's loan was restructured.
 
1.Bank of Boston wrote down the loan to $16 million from $27 million, taking $11million in charges against earnings in the fourth quarter of 1990 and the first quarter of this year.
 
2. The operating income needed to service the debt was reduced to $1.4 million a year, from $3.2 million.
 
3. The interest rate was reduced to 9 percent, from 10 percent, as the developer, Harold Brown, agreed to repay the original loan ($27 million) and all deferred interest.
 
4. In a 30-year agreement, the developer agreed to pay the bank 25 percent of the net cash flow, sale or refinancing proceeds in excess of the debt claim, which includes $27 million of principal, any additional money advanced by the bank and any accrued but unpaid interest. These proceeds would be gains for the Bank of Boston, as are all loans payments above $16 million.

HEADLINE: NASA Says It Is Time to Build Space Station

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
 The space agency, bombarded by conflicting cost estimates for a planned space station and continued disagreement among scientists about its usefulness, said today that it was time to stop studying the proposal and to build it.
Adm. Richard Truly, the administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, told a Congressional hearing that the program finally had a stable configuration and promised funds, and that it was time to move to construction. 
 Responding to suggestions from members of Congress that NASA should have independent auditors review cost estimates and that experts should study whether necessary research could be done elsewhere, Admiral Truly defended the current plan.
"I believe the space station program has had enough reviews," he said at a hearing of the House Government Operations Subcommittee on Government Activities and Transportation. The project "has been reconfigured based on the recommendations of previous reviews and the will of Congress," Admiral Truly continued. "Let's give it to the engineers to build."
NASA officials said the space station, recently scaled back in size and capability at the request of Congress, could be finished in space by 1999 for $30 billion. After the station is permanently occupied by astronauts, agency officials estimated that operating costs would average about $2 billion annually through the year 2027.
Admiral Truly testified that the $84 billion estimate did not include potential additions to the station.
The General Accounting Office, the auditing arm of Congress, said NASA's estimate was too low and put the 30-year cost of the project at $118 billion.
Comptroller General Charles A. Bowsher told the hearing that even the space agency's estimate of $30 billion for the initial phase of the project was about $10 billion too low. NASA figures, he said, did not include the total cost of using the space shuttle to build and service a station, nor did it include money for a space "lifeboat" for station astronauts or the installation of expensive scientific instruments.
"What we actually have is at least a $118 billion program -- about $40 billion to achieve permanent occupancy and about $78 billion to keep the station operational between 2000 and 2027," said Mr. Bowsher, who called NASA's estimates inappropriate.
Representative Barbara Boxer, the California Democrat who heads the subcommittee, said even the G.A.O. figures on the space station might too low.
"I believe that the $30 billion NASA estimate will get us a garage in space with nothing in it and nothing happening around it," she said. "Our subcommittee investigation has estimated that the true cost of this project will be approximately $180 billion, plus inflation, over its lifetime."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
G.M. Outlet In Manhattan Closes Doors

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 1

 BODY:
The last remaining General Motors Corporation dealership in Manhattan, a Cadillac-Buick-Chevrolet franchise belonging to Roger S. Penske and G.M., quietly closed its doors today.
Mr. Penske is a transportation entrepreneur with interests as diverse as truck leasing and Indianapolis 500 racing. A spokesman for Mr. Penske said the decision to close the dealership was based on declining prospects for automobile sales in New York City and the poor state of the Northeast economy. 
 Mr. Penske had previously acknowledged that sales at the dealership had been weak from the day he bought it from Victor Potamkin in the fall of 1987.
Mr. Potamkin, 80 years old, at one time was one of the nation's top Cadillac dealers. He remains active selling other car brands at a dealership near 787 11th Avenue at West 56th Street where Penske Cadillac had operated.
 
Another Dealer Sought
 A G.M. spokesman said the auto maker was searching for another dealer to take over the franchise and had discussed the idea with Mr. Potamkin, among others. He said the dealership would honor "all sales and service commitments" and those owning G.M. cars and trucks could take their vehicles for service to dealerships in other boroughs.
The spokesman, Harold Jackson, said G.M. learned last week that Mr. Penske planned to close the dealership. This morning the sign came down.
Originally, the dealership was known as Penske Cadillac, but G.M. added Buick and Chevrolet franchises in an effort to increase the store's sales volume. Even that was not enough to save the business.
 
Problems in Cities
 The closing of the dealership reflects not just the growing difficulties of selling cars in downtown locations, but the nationwide automotive slump that has put pressure on the profits of all franchised dealers, causing many of them to fail. Last year about 900 of the 25,000 United States dealerships failed.
Increasingly, city dwellers avoid owning cars, while suburban commuters prefer to do business with dealers close to their home.
Mr. Penske's venture in Manhattan seemed star-crossed from the outset. He signed the contract taking over the dealership on the Friday before the stock market crashed in October 1987. He then spent more than $6 million refurbishing the showroom and service bays to offer white-glove pampering of customers. Mr. Potamkin, by contrast, always had attracted customers by aggressive advertising and competitive pricing.
With G.M.'s help, Mr. Penske had been able to open in Manhattan under very favorable terms. G.M. agreed to invest an unspecified amount in the dealership. The No. 1 auto maker also agreed to lease the building from Mr. Potamkin under a 25-year agreement and charge Mr. Penske rent based on the number of cars he sold.
 
Successful Elsewhere
 The skyrocketing price of urban real estate has been an important factor in driving many dealers to the suburbs.
For Mr. Penske, it was an unusual instance of a business venture gone sour. He owns several other successful car dealerships in California, including a Cadillac dealership and the nation's biggest Toyota dealership. He also owns the Detroit Diesel Corporation, which makes engines for trucks, boats and tanks and which he bought from G.M.; Hertz Penske Truck Leasing, and a car racing team that competes on the Indy car circuit.

HEADLINE: Angry Taxpayers Reject 44% of New Jersey School Budgets

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HACKENSACK, N.J., May 1

 BODY:
After a year of angry debate over tax increases and the way New Jersey finances public education, voters on Tuesday rejected 44 percent of the local school budgets submitted to them in one of the most politicized school elections in years.
That percentage, however, was less than the 48 percent rejected last spring, reversing five years of steady increases in the number of school budgets rejected. 
 In the days leading up to the vote, Gov. Jim Florio and Senate President John A. Lynch, themselves targets of taxpayer anger because of sales-tax and income-tax increases and the shifting of some school aid from well-off districts to poorer ones, began openly criticizing education spending.
Many school superintendents, in turn, said Mr. Florio and other Democratic leaders were trying to deflect voters' animosity onto local school boards and undermine the local school budget process. Many in the education field, most notably the statewide teachers' union and an association of school boards, began predicting that upward of 70 percent of the budgets would be rejected.
 
Two Sides Breathe Easier
 After the results were counted today, with the defeat of 245 of 556 budgets, the warring sides expressed relief and a sense of surprise that the damage had not been worse. In the southern half of the state and its relatively rural western counties along the Delaware River, a majority of budgets were approved.
But a broad wave of rejections hit much of northern New Jersey, where schools are the oldest and property taxes and education costs the highest. The pattern spread across wealthy districts, working-class and urban systems, and growing suburbs.
In Mercer County, seven of eight budgets were rejected, including Princeton's. In neighboring Middlesex, 18 of 22 lost and in Monmouth, 34 of 54.
Farther north, in Bergen, 49 of 74 were defeated, including those in Ridgewood, Teaneck and, for the first time, Franklin Lakes, one of the state's wealthiest communities.
 
Newark Budget Approved
 Essex County voters bucked the pattern of rejection in North Jersey and approved 15 of 17 local budgets, including Newark's, the state's largest at $495 million.
In the aftermath of the voting, all sides claimed some measure of victory. Governor Florio said in Trenton that more budg ets would have been rejected if not for the Quality Education Act, his overhaul of the state's school-financing law, which gave districts $832 million in new state aid.
"He felt encouraged that in the midst of a recession, a majority of budgets passed," said Jon Shure, Mr. Florio's spokesman.
 
Union Sees 'Major Victory'
 Betty Kraemer, president of the New Jersey Education Association, the statewide teachers' union, called the returns a "major victory" for children and schools.
In a thinly veiled reference to Mr. Florio's and Senator Lynch's election-eve criticism of local spending, Robert E. Boose, executive director of the New Jersey School Boards Association, said: "We commend the people of New Jersey for cutting through the political rhetoric they have been hearing for the past few weeks and for making their own assessments of proposed school budgets."
Every year the question before the voters is whether they approve of the portion of the school budget to be raised by local property taxes. The budgets defeated in the state must now be reviewed by local government officials.
While the votes are nonbinding on the officials, they have power to recommend, but not order, cuts in education programs and spending. Any disputes between local government and school officials over cuts are mediated by the State Department of Education. The final budgets are not resubmitted to the voters for approval.
 
Growing Tension for Months
 The atmosphere surrounding this year's budget elections had been highly charged for months, starting with the Governor's overhaul of the state's school spending formula and his $2.8 billion increase in income and sales taxes last spring.
The mainfeature of the new formula, the Quality Education Act, shifts millions in state aid, starting in the 1992-93 school year, from the wealthiest suburban districts to urban, rural and middle-income districts.
In addition the State Supreme Court last June ordered the state to provide enough aid to its 30 poorest urban districts so their spending for each pupil matches that in the state's richest districts by mid-decade.
Residents in 21 of those 30 districts vote on their school budgets, as do the vast majority of other districts in the state. School spending in nine of the 30 districts is approved by an appointed board of local officials. In 12 urban districts voters rejected budgets on Tuesday.
 
Rich and Working-Class Defeats
 Towns hit by rejections Tuesday ranged from the wealthy to the working-class. Franklin Lakes, one of Bergen County's richest, suffered its first budget defeat despite efforts by school officials to adhere to a tradition of holding budget increases to 6 percent. Officials attributed rejection of the $8.6 million budget to newly organized groups of elderly citizens who were upset about property taxes.
Twenty-two percent of Franklin Lakes voters turned out, exceeding Tuesday's statewide average turnout of 18.6 percent, itself a record in budget election.
"But our affluent parents did not come out to vote," said Margaret Ann Vrola, secretary of the Franklin Lakes school board.
On the other side of Bergen, in Bogota, the budget lost by 246 to 209, even though the tax levy was cut by $62,000 and state aid increased from $2.3 million to $3.2 million. Bogota's turnout was 12 percent, and Christopher Tarantino, the board secretary, attributed the defeat to voter apathy.
 
First Loss in 15 Years
 In Monmouth County, a hotbed of anti-Florio sentiment where nearly 63 percent of the budgets lost, Holmdel's budget lost for the first time in 15 years. The $16 million plan called for a 5.3 percent increase in school taxes.
In neighboring Middlesex County, where 18 of 22 budgets went down, Woodbridge, the state's 10th largest district, approved its first budget in 27 years. The $103 million document called for no new taxes. To guarantee that, 79 teachers, supervisors and administrators, along with 20 teachers's aides, were dismissed. And art programs, violin and cello intruction, and honors and advanced placement courses for high-achieving high school students were reduced, said Fredric Buonocore,the superintendent.
Dr. Buonocore said he believed the voters did not want to risk more cuts by rejecting the budget. "I think they felt enough was enough and they didn't want a good district to become a poor one," he said.

HEADLINE: Angola Agrees On a Cease-Fire With Guerrillas

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LISBON, May 1

 BODY:
After 16 years of civil war, Angola's leftist Government and United States-backed rebels agreed today to call a cease-fire before the end of this month and to hold the nation's first free elections in the second half of 1992.
The peace agreement was initialed here after a year of complex negotiations in which Portugal, which was Angola's colonial master, and the United States and the Soviet Union, which backed the opposing factions, played a key role in encouraging the two sides to end a war that has taken some 300,000 lives and shattered the Angolan economy. 
 The accord is to be formally signed by Angola's President, Jose Eduardo dos Santos, and the rebel leader, Jonas Savimbi, at a ceremony scheduled to take place here May 29-31.
 
U.N. to Monitor Cease-Fire
 The official cease-fire will go into effect immediately after the agreement is signed, but Portugal's chief negotiator, Jose Manuel Durao Barroso, said the two sides had agreed to respect a de facto cease-fire from May 15, the deadline for confirming acceptance of the peace plan.
A United Nations force of about 600 men will be charged with monitoring the cease-fire, but a joint political and military commission made up of the two Angolan factions and the three mediating governments will have the main responsibility for preparing elections and forming a single army.
The agreement establishes that the elections will be held between September and November 1992, but the mediators strongly recommended that they be held in September before the rainy season complicates campaigning and verification of a fair voting process.
The main contenders will be the governing Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, or M.P.L.A., and the rebel National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or Unita. New political forces are also likely to take part.
Portuguese diplomats warned that despite the details built into today's draft accord, Angola's transition to democracy will nonetheless be difficult because of the deep distrust that still separates the opposing forces.
They said that, more than a sign of true reconciliation, the agreement resulted from recognition by both sides that neither could win an outright military victory.
"There were no winners and no losers today,"' Mr. Durao Barroso said tonight. "The only winners are the Angolan people."
 
Outside Influences
 But the peace process also benefited from changes beyond the country's borders, including new Soviet-American cooperation to settle regional conflicts, South Africa's decision to grant independence to Namibia last year and the agreement that all Cuban troops will leave Angola by July 1 this year.
For Angola's 10 million people, a lasting cease-fire should bring respite from a seemingly endless process of internal warfare that began when nationalist guerrilla groups first started fighting for independence from Portuguese colonial rule more than 30 years ago.
After Portugal's rightist dictatorship was toppled in 1974, in good measure because of the unpopularity of its efforts to hold onto its African colonies, the new Government in Lisbon was so eager to get out of Africa that it granted independence to Angola in 1975 without adequate preparations.
A scramble for power resulted, with the Soviet-backed Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola calling in Cuban troops to help it obtain control of the capital city, Luanda, and much of the coast and oil-producing areas, and Unita, then backed by China, and other armed groups occupying rural areas bordering on Namibia and Zaire.
 
South Africa Joins Conflict
 Cuban troops, which at one point numbered 50,000, insured the survival of the Luanda Government in the growing civil war, but they also drew South Africa into the conflict from Namibia. By the late 1970's, Pretoria was backing Unita. By 1986, American military aid to the rebels was public.
A turning point came when Washington and Moscow began working together to try to end several regional wars. This led to agreement that Cuba start withdrawing from Angola on Jan. 1, 1989, and that South Africa stop arming Unita as well as pull out of Namibia. Simultaneously, both the Luanda Government and Unita began floating their own peace plans.
Finally, in April last year, Portugal, using its influence as the former colonial power, brought the two sides together for the first of what would prove to be seven negotiating sessions ending in today's accord. Since September, Soviet and American observers have also taken part in the talks.
In Luanda, the Government has been preparing for peace by permitting the emergence of new centrist political forces that hope to profit from popular disenchantment with both the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, which has earned a reputation for corruption as well as repression, and Unita, which has been blamed in massacres.
At a special congress last week, the Popular Movement also abandoned its commitment to Marxist-Leninism and declared itself a social democratic force. Addressing the congress, President dos Santos said peace was essential. "In spite of enormous sacrifices," he said. "the country is more devastated than it was in 1975."
With Lopo de Nascimento representing Luanda and Jeremias Chitunda leading the Unita delegation, the negotiations dealt with all aspects of the peace process, including the complex question of insuring that neither side will be in a position to use the army to swing next year's elections.
In the final round of talks, held since April 4 at a hotel school at Bicesse near Estoril on the outskirts of Lisbon, one of the main points of dispute was the date of the elections. The Luanda Government proposed November or December 1992, while Unita insisted on September next year. In the end, a compromise was found.
Earlier today, President dos Santos told a May Day crowd that an accord had been reached but, hinting at problems that may still lie ahead, he warned, "We must be in condition to prevent our adversaries from taking advantage of any distraction on our part to try and achieve by force what they have failed to win up to now."

HEADLINE: Pollution Shrouds Shenandoah Park

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: THORNTON GAP, Va.

 BODY:
In the 1930's, when Shenandoah National Park was established here in the Blue Ridge Mountains and engineers boldly stretched the Skyline Drive from one lofty end of the mountain range to the other, visitors could clamber up Mary's Rock and, on a clear day, make out the tip of the Washington Monument 65 miles to the east.
These days, even on the crispest morning after a hard rain, the view from the rock seldom reaches halfway to the monument, and on most mornings little can be made out more than 15 miles away. 
 Air pollution, most of it blown by winds that carry a high concentration of acids produced from factories and utility plants in the Midwest, is the worst in any national park in the country, according to the National Park Service.
The pollution at Shenandoah National Park, which extends 80 miles along the crest of the Blue Ridge in northern Virginia, not only obscures the striking panoramas once visible from cliff-hugging overlooks, but is also slowly poisoning the park's trout streams and killing its ferns, flowers and forests.
 
On the 'Edge of Disaster'
 The Park Service considers the threat to Shenandoah and other parks so serious that it has recently become one of the Federal Government's most aggressive proponents of antipollution measures. It is opposing two new power plants in southern Virginia, and has suggested other remedies that could slow the pace of economic development in the country.
"Shenandoah National Park is under siege more than any other park in the country," said J. William Wade, the superintendent of the park, where spring is now climbing the mountainsides at nature's rate of 100 feet a day, the buds bursting bright green, white, red and yellow despite the haze.
"We've got fish and trees up here that are slowly but steadily beginning to weaken, and in a few cases die, and we've even had a couple of days up here when we've had to issue pollution health warnings," Mr. Wade said. "We're right on the edge of disaster, poised."
"What we do to correct this problem could set a pattern," he continued. "But in any case we've got to act, and fast. More industrial sites and power plants are on the drawing boards, and that means more pollution will soon be on the way if we don't somehow head it off."
 
Top-Ranked Park in Sulfates
 The Park Service says Shenandoah ranks first among major Federal parks in the amount of sulfates in its air, and second in the amount of ozone. Sulfates are a critical part of acid rain, which contains high concentrations of acid-forming chemicals produced in the burning of coal and other industrial processes and carried aloft by air currents. The acidic deposits kill aquatic life, and ozone damages the leaves and slows the growth of plants and trees.
As a result of its concern for Shenandoah, the Park Service is opposing new industrial plants for the first time in its history.
In findings that are disputed by state and Federal environmental agencies, the Park Service contends that the two new coal-fired electric power plants, proposed for southern Virginia would mean more air pollution in Shenandoah, even though the plants would be equipped with pollution control devices. It has said the construction permits should be denied until a way can be found to put a limit on the amount of pollution flowing into the park.
One suggested solution: allow the new plants to be built if their owners agree to pay for devices to cut pollution from older plants elsewhere in the state. In other words, offset new pollution with a reduction in old pollution.
The Park Service also plans to study new industrial sites and power plants planned near other parks, including Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the Tennessee-North Carolina line and Acadia National Park in Maine.
The agency is also focusing on older plants that affect air quality in Federal parks, particularly Grand Canyon National Park in Arizona, where visibility is often a serious problem.
"Parks are meant to be beautiful and heathful places, by definition," said Molly N. Ross, the Park Service's assistant chief of air quality. "We intend to protect ours. We will report what we find and what we think must be done. If that has a beneficial effect beyond our parks, so much the better."
The Virginia Department of Air Pollution Control acknowledges that air pollution in Shenandoah is a serious problem. Nevertheless, it has approved construction of the new plants. The department says pollution estimates and wind calculations do not indicate that the plants, the first of a dozen or so planned for the rapidly growing state, would add to the park's problems.
The regional office of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, the nation's final nonjudicial arbiter of air pollution cases, also says its calculations and estimates do not indicate that the new plants would cause further damage to the park.
Environmental groups are expected to appeal these findings, and Park Service officials say they will continue to lobby against building the plants unless steps are taken to put a limit on the level of pollution in Virginia.
"This case is much too serious to let such a flawed finding pass unchallenged," said David W. Carr Jr., a lawyer with the Southern Environmental Law Center, a nonprofit group based in Charlottesville, Va., that monitors environmental issues.
"The future of a unique park is at stake, along with the environmental future of a lot of the rest of the state and, for that matter, the future of a lot of other parks," he said. "We'll challenge it, if necessary, if people don't back off and find a better solution. In fact, we'll take it into the courts if necessary."
 
'A Really Major Decision'
 Mr. Carr added: "Sooner or later the E.P.A. will be forced to pass judgment on a fellow Federal agency that has suggested a far-reaching solution to an air quality problem that could affect the pace of industrial growth in a state. That's a really major decision, a precedent, really, and you can bet it will go all the way to the White House before it's over."
On April 18 the Law Center, along with 14 other leading environmental organizations, including the Sierra Club, the Natural Resources Defense Council and Trout Unlimited, called the Virginia and E.P.A. findings inadequate and urged the Federal environmental agency to reassess problems that new power plants might cause in Shenandoah National Park and the rest of Virginia.
While there is a dispute about how much the new power plants would add to Shenandoah's pollution problems, there is little dispute with longstanding statistics indicating that the park is already under serious assault from air pollution, with more than 90 percent of it coming from west of Virginia.
 
Turning Water Into Vinegar
 Studies by the park's scientists and by scientists at the University of Virginia show that air pollutants, particularly the sulfur spewed from coal-fired power plants -- most of them in the industrial Midwest -- are getting into the Shenandoah's streams, mainly in the form of acid rain, raising the acid level in many of them to the point where some fish are dying. A year or so ago, after a particularly heavy assault of foul air, one stream was found to be almost as acidic as vinegar.
Other studies have found that pollutants, especially ozone, are beginning to harm plants and forests, causing some to lose leaves and weakening the disease resistance of others. Twice in recent years, ozone levels have risen so high that park officials have been forced to issue health warnings to hikers, climbers and joggers.
"A lot of national parks are heavily impacted by too many visitors, and some by encroaching development," said David Haskell, chief of the Division of Natural Resources and Science in Shenandoah. "We have some of that, too. But what we have more of than any other park is bad air. It's slowly but surely killing us. When you think about what parks are supposed to be, that's a terrible irony."

HEADLINE: Stricken Nuclear Plant Was at Capacity

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WISCASSET, Me., May 1

 BODY:
The fire that has indefinitely shut the Maine Yankee nuclear power plant occurred while the plant's operators were running the reactor here at record power levels, plant officials said today.
They said equipment installed in the last few years had increased the reactor's capacity to 880 megawatts from its original design capacity of 825 megawatts. In March and through much of April the plant generated record amounts of electricity, most of it sold to utilities outside New England. 
 The Monday explosion and fire that crippled the power plant came in the most troubled year of operation in the plant's 19-year history, the officials said. The accident did not release radiation or damage the nuclear portion of the plant, utility and government officials said. They added that the nuclear reactor was safely shut down today, its heat slowly diminishing through clouds of steam vented into the atmosphere.
Weeks before the accident, an anti-nuclear group here warned that mechanical malfunctions and what it said was an operating philosophy stressing economic returns over safety were pointing to the potential for a major accident.
 
9 Shutdowns in 9 Months
 Among the factors cited by the group, the Maine Nuclear Referendum Committee, was a sudden turn last July in the plant's operating record. After enjoying years of relatively trouble-free operation, the Maine Yankee nuclear plant was shut nine times in nine months because of leaks in the reactor, problems with gauges and monitoring equipment and difficulty in controlling the turbine that generates electricity.
The group also said Maine Yankee officials were planning to replace a deteriorating electrical generator in September, yet were running the reactor at peak power, generating electricity in near-record levels in April.
"I'm sorry it happened, but things were going on out there that we were worried about," said Robert Moldaver, the executive director of the Maine Nuclear Referendum Committee, which is based in Portland, 40 miles south of here. "We get accused of making up wild scenarios, but the way I feel is we were lucky it wasn't worse."
Charles D. Frizzle, the president of the Maine Yankee Atomic Power Company, which operates the plant for 10 utilities that own it, criticized anti-nuclear groups for trying to make the accident a political statement against nuclear power. He sought to characterize the accident as something that could happen at any electrical power plant, and said that in the moments after the explosion the plant's monitoring system identified a malfunction and automatically shut down the nuclear reactor without incident.
"As you can see, there isn't a lot of external damage to the generator and the fire does not look like it was very hot," Mr. Frizzle said in a tour this morning. "This accident had nothing to do with the nuclear operations at this plant and had nothing to do with nuclear power."
Mr. Frizzle said engineers had determined that the accident was probably caused by a short circuit in the transformer outside the plant.
 
Fire Less Intense Than Thought
 The short circuit produced a huge electric current that struck with enormous force. The transformer appears to have sustained an immense internal explosion. Its supporting steel beams are bent, bolts sheared in two, and the sides of the 750,000 pound unit bowed outward.
Monday night, thousands of gallons of mineral oil, used to cool the transformer, poured out of the ruptured transformer, and some of it seeped into the Back River 200 feet away. Workmen scraped seaweed off rocks this morning, finishing the cleanup today.
Inside the plant on Monday, the bolt of electricity split pipes carrying hydrogen gas to the generator, igniting a fire that was controlled within minutes but allowed to burn for nearly four hours for safety reasons, Mr. Frizzle said. The plant's fire brigade shut off the source of the hydrogen, a common coolant for electrical generators, seconds after discovering it.
The fire did not appear to be especially intense, as the Nuclear Regulatory Commission initially reported on Tuesday. Paint near the source of the fire was smeared with soot but had not bubbled as a result of intense heat.
The condition of the generator, however, is not known, Mr. Frizzle said. Workmen have been unable to dismantle the machine to get a closer look. A team of specialists from the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the manufacturers of the generator, are on the way here to assist Maine Yankee technicians, Mr. Frizzle said.
The Maine Yankee Plant will be shut for at least a month to replace the transformer, Mr. Frizzle said. Three years ago, the same transformer malfunctioned and had to be rebuilt.
In the worst case, the plant could be shut until December. Maine Yankee was planning to close the plant in September to replace the generator because it was not large enough. It takes two months to install a new generator, and the replacement may not be ready until September.
Maine Yankee supplies about a quarter of the state's electricity, but because of ample power supplies from hydroelectric dams, a short shutdown would not affect households or businesses, said a spokesman for the Central Maine Power Company, the plant's principal owner.
A long shutdown, however, would cause problems in the summer, when demand for electricity is much higher.
If the shutdown drags on, Central Maine officials said, the company may need to buy power from other sources at a cost of $2 million to $5 million a month in the summer. The company did not estimate today how much extra a typical household might pay as a result.
Thomas Coffin, a spokesman for the Maine Nuclear Referendum Committee, said the extra expense might have been avoided had the nuclear plant's operators paid attention to what he called "unmistakable warning signs."
 
Leaks and Malfunctions
 In the past nine months, the plant was shut down to repair leaks in the reactor steam generator system, malfunctions in gauges and monitors, and a problem in controlling the steam turbine.
The anti-nuclear group said another sign of potential trouble was the boosting of the reactor's generating capacity. They warned the company and the public last week that such power loads might be dangerous because the reactor, the electrical generator and other main components were nearly 20 years old and might not be able to withstand the stress.
"Their song is always 'Don't Worry, Be Happy' " said Mr. Coffin. "But what I say is the potential for a severe accident is always there in a nuclear plant. It didn't happen. I'm glad. What you can also say is it didn't happen this time."
Mr. Frizzle, an electrical engineer who helped to start the reactor in the early 1970's and became the plant's president in 1989, said today that pushing the plant to peak power had nothing to do with the accident.
"There is no relation at all in the events of the last several months that would lead one to have any concern for the safety of the Maine Yankee nuclear power plant," he said.

HEADLINE: BIG BANKS REDUCE PRIME LOAN RATE TO 8 1/2% FROM 9%

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Most of the nation's largest banks reduced their prime lending rate yesterday to 8 1/2 percent from 9 percent, a move that will cut borrowing costs for small businesses and some consumers, and could eventually help stimulate the lagging economy.
The rate cuts were led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company; Citibank, the nation's largest bank, and the First National Bank of Chicago and were joined by a host of others, including the Bank of America late in the day. 
 A cut in the prime lending rate is most important to businesses that have loans on which interest rates are pegged to the prime and to consumers who have mortgages or home-equity, credit-card or other installment loans that are adjusted according to the prime.
 
Hoping for a Revival
 The move came one day after the Federal Reserve signaled its desire for lower interest rates by reducing the discount rate it charges on loans to banks to 5 1/2 percent from 6 percent and by pushing down the important Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for short-term loans, by a quarter-point, to 5 3/4 percent.
Federal Reserve officials hope the lower rates will help an economy still largely mired in a recession that began in July, but some private economists are not sure the rate moves will provide much aid. The continuing weakness was evident yesterday in the release of divergent results of four barometers of economic activity, from the Government's index of leading indicators to an industrial index of corporate purchasing trends.
 
Pace of Decline Slows
 The reports added up to a picture of an economy still losing ground but not so quickly as it was and with a few encouraging signs showing up. Stock traders focused on those signs yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average up 42.33 points.
"The economy is not declining so rapidly as during the winter months, but it is still declining," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Manhattan Bank.
The Government's chief economic forecasting gauge, the index of leading indicators, rose five-tenths of 1 percent in March, its second consecutive monthly advance, the Commerce Department reported, and that followed a revised 1.2 percent gain for February. But the gain came mostly from improved consumer confidence, higher stock prices, and an increase in the nation's money supply.
Analysts said that more recent readings of consumer confidence, taken in April, showed modest declines, and that most parts of the leading-indicators index continued to point toward a weak economy. Furthermore, in another report yesterday, the department said construction spending fell 1.5 percent in March, wiping out a small gain registered in February.
And the Federal Reserve said its latest survey of its 12 regional banks showed that economic activity remained weak in much of the nation during the early spring, but that the recession might be nearing its low point. That assessment was also evident in a report by the National Association of Purchasing Management. The group's monthly survey showed that the economy remained in recession in April, although with slight improvement in new orders, production and deliveries.
The association's index of economic activity rose to 42.1 percent in April from 40 percent in March. But economists said the improvement was virtually insignificant because the economy remained sluggish. A reading below 50 percent indicates that the manufacturing economy is declining, while a reading above 50 indicates expansion.
These economic reports lead some private economists to conclude that declining interest rates alone will not be sufficient to revive the economy. Unlike the economic downturn of 1981 and 1982, when the prime rate rose above 20 percent, the economy's current malaise is attributed to a variety of other factors, rather than to high interest rates.
"A half-point change in interest rates does not do much to stimulate loan demand," said James E. Annable, chief economist at First National Bank of Chicago, one of the first banks to cut its prime rate yesterday. "The major impact of the rate cut is among people who are already borrowing."
Similarly, H. Erich Heinemann, chief economist at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, the securities firm, said, "The latest rate reduction by itself is not likely to stimulate a lot of borrowing or pull the economy out of a recession." But he added that the cumulative effect of the drop in short-term interest rates in the last two years "plus the declines still to come" are key parts of the Federal Reserve's efforts to revive the economy.
The prime rate has little effect on large businesses, particularly the 1,000 largest corporations, because they generally pay interest rates that are linked to conditions in the financial markets. Currently, the highest-quality large companies can borrow at interest rates below 6 percent by selling commercial paper, a kind of i.o.u., or they can borrow at rates below prime from banks.
Lower rates entice some borrowers, economists say, but most borrowers are more concerned with the general economic outlook. Businesses, for example, are most concerned about future demand for their products, while consumers are more concerned about employment conditions and the chances of losing their jobs.
Analysts expect that unemployment will be one of the last measures of the economy to show improvement. The number of jobless is expected to increase in May, and analysts warn that the unemployment rate could rise from its current level of 6.8 percent, which is up sharply from 5.3 percent last summer.
Federal Reserve officials began pushing short-term interest rates lower in early 1989 amid gathering signs of economic weakness. Banks, in turn, have lowered the prime rate from its 11 1/2 percent level of early 1989, but their cuts have been less than the drop in other interest rates. Analysts and bankers say the reason is that the banks need to offset losses from record amounts of defaulted and delinquent loans.
Economists noted that the recent declines in interest rates have already helped some sectors of the economy, particularly housing, where new building permits have been increasing, and mortgage lenders are reporting an increase in sales activity now that mortgage rates are below 10 percent.
 
Sluggish Demand for Loans
 But lower interest rates have not yet caused the widespread rebound in loan demand that would point to a general rise in spending by businesses and consumers. Business loans at large banks across the country, after adjusting for seasonal aberrations, fell at about a 3.3 percent rate in the month ended April 11, the lastest available data, and have fallen at a 6.1 percent rate since mid-December, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis.
Consumers also do not seem much attracted by lower rates, as shown by a decline in consumer credit in March.
At its current level of 8 1/2 percent, the prime rate is the lowest since February 1988. The only time it has been lower in the last 10 years was a 14-month period in 1986 and 1987, when it fell to 7 1/2 percent.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Book Says Powell Had Doubts on Bush's War Plan

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
A new book on the Bush Administration's decisionmaking in the Persian Gulf war says that Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, had serious reservations about the President's push for an offensive military strategy against Iraq's army in Kuwait.
The Washington Post reports in its Thursday editions that "The Commanders," a forthcoming book by a Post editor, Bob Woodward, says that General Powell repeatedly suggested a "containment" strategy of sanctions and pressure to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Mr. Bush was said to have rejected this advice, citing the political costs of waiting for such a strategy to work, The Post reported. 
 The Post account did not say that General Powell opposed the military option, and the general has said publicly that he supported the decision.
Mr. Woodward also writes that a senior Defense Intelligence Agency officer, Walter P. Lang, sent an explicit warning to Pentagon leaders two days before the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait that President Saddam Hussein intended to send his troops across the border.
 
No Alarm Sounded
 Mr. Lang was said to have intended for his warning to generate a "thunderclap" in the Pentagon, but Defense Secretary Dick Cheney rejected a suggestion from General Powell that they sound an alarm at the White House, Mr. Woodward's book reports.
Mr. Woodword's account is likely to reignite the debate over the adequacy of the intelligence warnings and the Administration's response to them.
"The Commanders" covers decision-making surrounding the gulf war and the invasion of Panama in December 1989, protraying the relationship between General Powell and other senior Administration officials, including President Bush.
Excerpts from the book are to begin running in The Post on Friday.
The news article about "The Commanders" in The Post's Thursday editions emphasizes that Mr. Woodward "once again employs a technique that has created controversy for him in the past," by "describing how several key figures thought and acted without saying explicitly whether they provided him with the information."
Mr. Woodward also uses direct quotations in the book without specifying how he obtained such details of conversations, The Post says.
But in an opening note to readers, the author says that "thoughts, beliefs, and conclusions attributed to a participant come from that individual or from a source who gained knowledge of them directly from that person."
Mr. Woodward says in the note that he interviewed more than 400 people over 27 months, The Post said.
Pentagon officials have said that among those who gave interviews to Mr. Woodward were Mr. Cheney; General Powell and other senior members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; the Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams; the Army Chief of Staff, Gen. Carl E. Vuono; and Adm. William J. Crowe, the former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
According to the book, the commander of allied forces in the gulf, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, was "furious" when President Bush began pressing for a plan for an attack on Iraqi forces in October.
Mr. Woodward's account parallels General Schwarzkopf's public statements that he was rushed into offering a plan that was rejected. He maintains that this early plan, for a frontal ground assault against Iraqi forces in Kuwait, was never his recommendation.
The book suggests that the President's inner circle was divided between hawks and doves.
The President and his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, along with Mr. Cheney, were pressing for a military offensive because they were convinced that sanctions would not deliver a timely victory, The Post quoted the book as saying.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, General Powell and perhaps other military chiefs were worried about both the human costs and the political costs of a war, it said.
Though Mr. Woodward draws distinctions between the views of these officials, the Post account of the book gives no indication that these reservations carried forward into January, when the final decision to attack Iraq was reached.
Judging from the Post's account, the magnitude of the book's assertions do not rival those in Mr. Woodward's previous works -- "All the President's Men" and "The Final Days," on Watergate and the Nixon White House, which he wrote with Carl Bernstein; "The Brethren," which examined the inner workings of the Supreme Court, or "Veil," a 1987 expose about the C.I.A.
After President Bush's election in 1988, General Powell reportedly turned down offers to serve as Director of Central Intelligence or take a senior State Department position. He chose instead to return to the Army from his last White House job in the Reagan Administration, where he was national security adviser.
 
Powell's View of Campaign
 Mr. Woodward asserts that General Powell made that decision partly because "he felt uneasy about the man who was about to become President." The general "was troubled by the way the Bush campaign had been run. The race-baiting Willie Horton television commercial especially bothered him," the Post account quotes the book as saying.
It was Mr. Cheney, the book says, who sought out General Powell for the top military job upon the retirement of Admiral Crowe.Mr. Cheney has taken credit for in a number of press accounts.
The book also reports some conflict between Mr. Cheney and the White House Chief of Staff, John H. Sununu, who is said to have denied a request from the Defense Secretary to borrow a Presidential helicopter to fly the military chiefs to Camp David for a meeting after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
 
Baker Said to Back Powell
 The book portrays Mr. Baker as General Powell's chief ally in seeking to urge Mr. Bush to let the sanctions take their toll on Iraq as a means of averting war. Mr. Woodward says that Mr. Baker confided to some of his closest aides that the White House was "speeding, not thinking through what it was doing."

HEADLINE: New York City's Loss Is Albany's Gain

 BODY:
What happened in the State of New York this week sounded like a political satirist's idea of a joke, but it was far from funny.
To summarize: New York City had to raise money by selling $1.2 billion in high-yield notes because the state, more than a month late in passing its budget, hasn't paid money it owes the city. No budget, no state aid. So who bought $50 million worth of the notes? The State of New York -- which in effect profited from the fiscal anguish it had helped cause. 
 The transaction was a good deal for the state because the city is in such poor economic shape it had to pay an unusually high interest rate of 6.74 percent on those tax-free notes. "Our first, paramount concern is to maximize the return on our investment," explained a spokesman for State Comptroller Edward Regan.
It's hard to fault that logic. But it's very easy indeed to fault some of those playing the budget game in Albany.
Gov. Mario Cuomo has at least proposed a plausible if painfully austere budget that deals with the state's growing deficit, and has warned that excessive delay could push the city over the brink. Mr. Cuomo could help matters along by showing an inclination to compromise. But even that might not do it. The process is bogged down. Assembly Speaker Mel Miller waited until the eve of the budget deadline to offer a sketchy alternative to the Governor's proposal, and the Senate majority leader, Ralph Marino, unduly concerned about helping the state's wealthiest school districts, has hardly provided strong leadership. Neither has mobilized the Legislature to act on a budget.
The problem, of course, is that the economy is so tattered and the looming deficit so large -- as high as $6.5 billion -- that nobody can agree on how to mete out the pain. But the budget deadline was April 1. The longer the wait, the more cities, towns, counties and school districts will have to borrow by selling notes and bonds at high interest rates.
A paradoxical twist allowed the State Treasury to benefit from the problems the state visited on an already burdened New York City. But in the long run, the absence of a budget only hurts localities and the state itself, which has to worry about its own bond rating and credibility.

HEADLINE: Hollow Rhetoric From the Unions

BYLINE: By Mario M. Cuomo; Mario M. Cuomo of New York is one of 31 Governors facing budget deficits this year.

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
There are a lot of unhappy people in New York City and throughout the state. The rally on Tuesday in downtown Manhattan arranged by public employees' unions was one of the latest expressions of dissatisfaction with the cold reality of the recession, a recession felt not only by New Yorkers but by nearly every American.
Cold, too, is the reality of New York State's loss of revenue that has led to a nearly $6.5 billion potential deficit in the current fiscal year and the need to take drastic steps to deal with it. 
 Significant truths were obscured in the rhetoric at the rally. The representatives of the city employees said that the spending cuts I have recommended to close the state's budget gap are too deep and that the state should raise taxes instead.
What they called for, in effect, is a $3 billion to $4 billion tax increase. They say Albany can get it all from the "rich." But Albany can't raise that much money without taxing the working poor and middle class as well. One income tax proposal, offered by Mel Miller, the Assembly Speaker, would raise less than one-quarter of what the unions want, and would tax people making as little as $11,000 a year.
Those who ask for a tax on nearly every working poor and middle-class New Yorker under the guise of a "tax the wealthy" slogan are just not telling the truth. The billions in taxes the union leaders ask for would be paid largely by the working people of New York City. And by driving away businesses already thinking of leaving, a $3 billion to $4 billion rise in taxes would result not in coffers filled with revenues to preserve services and jobs but a loss of the work opportunities that our poor and middle class need.
Also lost in the protest rhetoric is the fact that the state already taxes the wealthy heavily. In 1983, on my recommendation, the state imposed a real-property gains tax on the sale of higher-priced real property. In my budget proposal this year, I asked the Legislature for an expansion of the mansion tax, for an increased estate tax on the wealthy and for increased fees on luxury automobiles.
Only Oregon relies more heavily on income taxes -- the most progressive tax a state has at its disposal -- than New York does right now.
Workers represented by the union leaders who demanded higher taxes will receive $1 billion in salary increases over the next two years. While that is a victory for union members, that's $1 billion less that the city has to spend for all the poor and the working class people for whom the union leaders claim to speak.
Even if money were available, it is not sensible for the state to commit additional wealth to the city to finance raises for its unions when I have called for layoffs, payroll deferrals and no raises for state workers.
Despite the protesters' slogans and signs, I am sure that the soundly balanced, while austere, budget I have submitted is the best way to preserve jobs, services and programs. It gives the poor and working people a better chance of making it through these hard times, with a better hope for the future, than would placing a crushing new tax burden on an already terribly weak New York City economy.
The protesters should remember that the state and city share common antagonists. There are conservatives who criticize us for having spent too much on our children, on hospitals, housing and roads and bridges in the prosperous 1980's -- and even in the lean budget I have submitted. It will take strength to resist the efforts of these conservatives to disable our progressive state programs.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
