HEADLINE: Lower East Side and Chinatown Need Distinct Council Districts

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The so-called multiracial plan for a New York City Council district proposed by Lower East Siders for a Multiracial District (letter, April 16) violates every conceivable definition of this community. 
 It takes the area west of Avenue A from Third Street to 14th Street and consigns it to another district with which it has no ties. The portion they would discard is the best known and most traveled part of the neighborhood. If Astor Place, St. Mark's Place, LaMama Theater, the Second Avenue Deli and the Ottendorfer Library are not an integral part of the Lower East Side, what is?
Their plan would also exclude the Polish and Ukrainian communities, two of our oldest immigrant groups. Although they call it multiracial, their plan is both racially and economically segregationist. It would take the primarily Hispanic and low-income Alphabet City and call that the Lower East Side. Such a plan ignores the splendid diversity of ethnic groups and cultural heritages that form the true mosaic of the city's most historic neighborhood.
The Puerto Rican-Hispanic Political Council, of which I am an executive committee member, is a coalition of once-feuding Latinos, now united for political empowerment on the Lower East Side. We want the same things as our neighbors -- affordable housing, clean and safe streets, and hope for our children and elderly. We see the Lower East Side as a neighborhood, not a museum of poverty.
Our plan keeps the Latino community intact and combines with it traditional Lower East Side communities. Our Hispanic-based district was created after consulting leaders of the Polish and Ukrainian neighborhoods. Further, it recognizes the legitimate aspirations of the Asian community.
The Multiracial district proposal would force Latinos and Asians to fight for a single council seat. The vast majority of both populations don't want such a fight, but neither are they willing to put their aspirations on hold. Since neither Latinos nor Asians have the numbers to be a majority in any Lower East Side district, both groups would have to form coalitions to win.
Better to have separate districts, each free to build its own coalitions, each with the opportunity to win a Council seat. It is for this reason that we have excluded Chinatown and Asian areas from our plan.
The Redistricting Commission has a mandate to create districts that preserve historical, racial, cultural and economic ties. That mandate will be violated by any plan that divides the Lower East Side and forces half of it into a shotgun marriage with Chinatown.
 
ANTONINO PAGAN
New York, April 16, 1991

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chrysler's 'Abysmal' Loss of $598 Million

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 1

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation, hurt by slumping automotive demand, posted a first-quarter loss of $598 million today. However, the ailing auto maker said it would build more vehicles in the current quarter than it did in the first quarter, and said it did not plan to draw on backup credit lines for the remainder of the year.
The first-quarter results followed reports of steep losses yesterday by its larger rivals. The General Motors Corporation posted a loss of $377 million and the Ford Motor Company one of $1.1 billion. 
 "The quarter was abysmal," said Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman and chief executive. "Industry volume simply collapsed and, as a result, we suffered our worst car and truck retail sales since the first quarter of 1983."
Looking ahead, Jerome B. York, Chrylser's executive vice president and chief financial officer, said: "Losses should be less in the second quarter than in the first, but it would require optimism to say that we will have a profit in the second quarter. The recovery will be gradual for the next two quarters. Based on everything we've seen, we think the first quarter was the bottom."
The No. 3 auto maker is in a precarious condition as it attempts to ride out a recession that is battering Japanese and European auto makers as well as the stronger American companies. Because its financial resources have dwindled, Chrysler in recent months arranged a $1.75 billion line of backup credit with more than 30 banks.
Chrysler had a profit of $71 million, or 32 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1990. The auto maker's loss in this year's quarter reflected a $257 million one-time charge attributable to a change in the way consumer incentives are accounted for, a $199 million one-time charge to cover the cost of reducing the salaried work force and a $242 million after-tax credit for the reduction of certain costs related to the 1987 acquisition of the American Motors Corporation.
 
24% Drop in Revenue
 Chrysler's first-quarter revenue fell 24 percent, to $5.8 billion, from $7.63 billion in the period last year.
Worldwide factory sales of cars and trucks to dealers, on which revenue and profit are booked, slipped 19.7 percent, to 396,410, during the quarter. Mr. York said Chrysler planned to build approximately 100,000 more cars and trucks this quarter than last.
Earnings at Chrysler's financial subsidiary dipped 13.5 percent, to $77 million, primarily because of the increased cost of borrowed funds, Mr. York said. During the last six months the Chrysler Financial Corporation has been all but shut out of the commercial paper market because of a poor debt rating; instead, the subsidiary has been forced to borrow from banks, which charge higher interest rates.
Meanwhile, Chrysler has had to continue to discount aggressively to hold its share of the market. The average cost of consumer incentives was $1,100 a vehicle in the first quarter, down from about $1,250 in the fourth quarter of last year. Mr. York predicted that incentives costs would remain high in the current quarter, averaging $1,100 to $1,250.
Through the first quarter Chrysler was selling about 35 percent of its vehicles to fleets, including daily-rental companies. That compared with 24 percent during the similar quarter last year and put additional downward pressure on profit margins since fleet sales are far less profitable than retail sales to individual customers.
Mr. York said the average number of cars and trucks ordered by Chrysler dealers rose to 8,900 a day in April, compared with 4,600 a day in January, 5,100 in February and 8,600 in March.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 3, 1991, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the first-quarter loss at the Chrysler Corporation misstated the Ford Motor Company's loss for the quarter. It was $884 million.

HEADLINE: Brooklyn Academy Preparing Festival Despite Money Fears

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

 BODY:
With its customary buoyancy, the Brooklyn Academy of Music yesterday announced details of its next Next Wave Festival, which has become New York City's foremost showcase for the vanguard performing arts.
 Behind the air of enthusiasm, however, lies deep concern about whether the Brooklyn Academy will be able to present the annual fall festival or even sustain its overall operations. Already shaken by fund-raising troubles in the current recession and by arts-support cuts at the city, state and Federal levels, the academy will, its president says, be "absolutely devastated" should Mayor Dinkins's suggested cuts of up to 50 percent be carried out. 
 The academy has received a relatively generous city grant, $2.6 million for this fiscal year. But it was later trimmed by $200,000, or 8 percent, and could be reduced by a further $1.1 million in fiscal 1992 if Mr. Dinkins's full cuts are put into effect. On May 10, the Mayor is to present his proposed budget, which requires approval by the City Council, but in the meantime he is trying to extract concessions from labor unions to soften the worst of the blows.
 
Survival of the Fittest
 Of the 31 arts organizations currently supported by the city, such major institutions as the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic would also be hurt by the cuts, but their existence would not be threatened. Many others, however, whose financial underpinnings are more tenuous, have expressed fears for their very survival. These include the Brooklyn Museum, the Museum of the City of New York and the Museum of the Moving Image in Queens as well as the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
 "This institution was built on the idea of cooperation between the city and the private sector," said Harvey Lichtenstein, the academy's president and executive producer. "We could not have survived without that partnership. If these cuts, or even half these cuts, go through, we will be in serious jeopardy."
 When Mr. Lichtenstein announced last month that he would be unable to import the Hamburg, Germany, production of Robert Wilson's cabaret opera "The Black Rider," which has music by the rock star Tom Waits and had been announced as a centerpiece of this year's New York International Festival of the Arts, there was talk in arts circles that the academy was in a perilous financial condition. The current budgetary proposals only underscore that peril.
 The academy's annual budget has fluctuated in recent years between $10 and $14 million. That is because so much of the budget depends on specific projects, which vary in scope from year to year. The academy's fund-raising, too, is "project driven," in the words of Karen Brooks Hopkins, the executive vice president, who is in charge of finances.
 With "The Black Rider," as with all of the academy's imports, specific fund-raising for that project, along with expected box-office revenues, had to balance costs. The academy has no endowment fund, although there is a contingency fund to cover last-minute emergencies.
 
Final Straw: An Extra $150,000
 Although details of the "Black Rider" disagreement have been obscured by squabbling between Ludwig von Otting of the Thalia Theater in Hamburg and Mr. Lichtenstein, both sides agree that the Thalia insisted late in the negotiations that an extra $150,000 was needed (beyond a total budget of $800,000) to present the production properly. Mr. Lichtenstein couldn't -- and wouldn't -- free up that kind of money, having already committed his contingency fund to the overall budget deficit. By the time compromises were discussed, Martin E. Segal of the International Festival had withdrawn his support.
 A closely related problem has been Mr. Lichtenstein's failure to plan foreign engagements long in advance, as is common in the world of opera. That is in part because he is used to working with more spontaneous dance and theater companies, partly because of his financial limitations and partly because the Metropolitan Opera suddenly withdrew from a planned three-year collaboration, leaving Mr. Lichtenstein to hustle up replacements at short notice. He is, however, working now on a multi-year agreement with the Opera Comique of Paris to present a French Baroque opera annually.
 Despite his disappointment over "Black Rider," one had the impression that Mr. Lichtenstein was a little relieved when the project collapsed, given his broader and deeper problems. For the 1991 fiscal year ending June 30, the academy's expenses will be $11 million, and for the first time in a decade it will show a deficit. (For cultural institutions, the word deficit means an unexpected shortfall between expenses and income from the box office, fund-raising and grants.)
 
A $1.1 Million Shortfall
 Income for the current fiscal year will fall $1.1 million below what Mr. Lichtenstein calls Ms. Hopkins's "conservative" estimate. Some $300,000 of that comes from poor box-office revenues from Martha Clarke's "Endangered Species" and the Berlin Komische Oper's production of Gluck's "Orpheus and Euridice." An additional $400,000 can be attributed to fund-raising falling below its goals, and the remaining $400,000 to cuts in public funds.
 Over the last few years, a significant source of income for the academy has been the sale of prints donated by such well-known artists as David Salle and Roy Lichtenstein. But the decline in the art market in general has seriously undermined such sales. Whereas blue-chip corporations and senior executives support mainstream institutions like Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center, the academy has generally drawn its support from trendier, more youth-oriented industries -- fashion, advertising -- that are more susceptible to economic cycles.
 The academy has been able to make up much of the $1.1 million gap. A 10 percent cut in operating expenses -- through layoffs, furloughs and other cost-cutting measures -- saved $650,000, and the contingency fund of $300,000 was applied to the deficit. That still leaves, depending on final accounting (including next month's importation of three Ingmar Bergman theater productions from Stockholm), between $150,000 and $250,000 that must be made up by after-the-fact fund-raising.
 
Some Lively Items Left
 For fiscal 1992, Ms. Hopkins has projected a budget of only $9.5 million, which includes a cut in this fall's Next Wave Festival from $2.1 million to $1.7 million. The program still includes some lively items -- the Pina Bausch Dance Theater from Wuppertal, Germany; a number of dance and puppet-theater troupes (dance is usually less expensive than opera or theater); a Brooklyn Philharmonic program of premieres with Keith Jarrett and Dennis Russell Davies, and several Brazilian and African-American works reflecting the multi-cultural interests of the new Next Wave director, Liz Thompson.
 Still, all this could be threatened if the academy cannot resolve its financial difficulties, of which the threat of a major reduction in city support is the most extreme and immediate.
 "If these cuts go through," Mr. Lichtenstein said, "and unless somebody bails us out, which is highly unlikely, we may simply have to close our doors."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 3, 1991, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the Brooklyn Academy of Music misstated the circumstances under which the New York International Festival of the Arts canceled its contract to support the import of "The Black Rider," a Hamburg theater production. The contract was canceled at the request of the academy, after its negotiations with the producers of the show had broken down.

HEADLINE: Rescuing Health Care

SERIES: The Price of Health - Last of five articles.

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
Chaotic, costly and even cruel, the nation's health care system may pose the supreme political test of the 1990's.
Never before have so many groups -- including many doctors, large corporations, public officials, economists and worried citizens -- called urgently for sweeping change in American health care. 
 Everyone agrees on the goals: insuring access for all and cutting down runaway costs while preserving high-quality care.
But there is still no consensus on how to restructure the system, a fiendishly tangled thicket of traditions, expectations and special interests that has long defied rational control. Many of the proposed solutions would require new tax dollars and all would mean wrenching change for someone.
And remedies will almost certainly mean new constraints, limits on choice in an area where Americans are accustomed to demanding the best, regardless of price.
"We are inconsistent," said Gail Wilensky, who as head of the Health Care Financing Administration presides over the increasingly costly Federal medical programs for the elderly and the poor. "We want everybody to have everything, and we don't want to wait for it. But we certainly don't want to increase taxes."
 
Push for Overhaul
 Congress is taking up health care with a fervor not seen since the 1960's, when creation of the Medicare and Medicaid programs brought a temporary reprieve. For its part, the Bush Administration says it also is developing proposals for change.
Partial measures to extend health insurance to more people could be adopted in the next year or two, lawmakers predict. Broader measures that guarantee care for everyone, or reorganize the way care is paid for or delivered, seem more distant, though that could change as runaway costs shake up more parts of society.
The United States spends far more on health per person than any other country. And technically the care is often superb, the envy of the world. Yet the United States is the only advanced industrial nation that fails to insure care for everyone, the only nation that leaves families vulnerable to medically induced financial disaster.
In Europe, Canada and Japan, governments not only play bigger roles in financing health care; they also play more powerful roles in setting medical prices and limiting overall spending.
The payment system, a chaotic mix of private and public insurers, encourages overuse and overpricing. Doctors and hospitals are forced to spend ever more energy trying to reap funds from the bewildering array of payers, each with different rules. The mounting paperwork and second-guessing are deflating morale in the medical profession, leading more doctors to retire early and fewer young people to apply to medical school.
"We have a badly organized, improperly motivated delivery system, and an inefficient, wasteful payment system," said Dr. Arnold S. Relman, the former editor of The New England Journal of Medicine who is a leading critic of American health care.
In the current structure, rising payments do not reflect a social choice for better health; costs are eluding anyone's control. There is no leveling in sight.
"We spend 12 percent of our income on health, and 6 percent on education," said Daniel Callahan, a medical ethicist who is director of the Hastings Center in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. "Thirty years ago we spent the same amount on each."
"We really have to ask how much is enough."
 
When the Solutions Create New Problems
 As its failings become more apparent, the system is responding, but with partial steps that often create new problems as they solve old ones.
Free-market mythology aside, government already plays a central role. More than 40 percent of all health spending is paid by Federal, state and local governments through the Medicare program for the elderly and disabled, the Medicaid program that covers some of the poor and the military medical system.
Medicare has made pioneering efforts to contain costs by paying uniform fees for hospital care. But, like a balloon that is squeezed in one spot only to bulge in another, these efforts are undermined by shifting of costs. If beleaguered hospitals receive lower public payments, they charge private payers more; if doctor's fees per service are capped, then the number of services jumps.
While government has led the battle to restrict fees, private insurance companies are trying to slow inflation by encouraging "managed care," including aggressive scrutiny of treatment decisions and more use of health maintenance organizations. The scrutiny saves money, but it also means more bureaucracy.
Already, administrative costs soak up one-fifth of the country's health spending, twice the share as in Canada, said Dr. Steffie Woolhandler of the Harvard Medical School, a co-author of a study on administrative costs published this week in The New England Journal of Medicine.
Dr. Woolhandler is also a leader of some 3,500 physicians who are calling for national health insurance, along Canadian lines. Their position goes well beyond that of the powerful American Medical Association, which supports measures to extend private insurance to all workers and Medicaid for the poor, but opposes national insurance or spending ceilings. In a sign of shifting attitudes, though, other mainstream groups representing tens of thousands of doctors have declared their willingness to consider radical overhaul, even including national health insurance.
 
A Blizzard of Choices For Congress to Sort Out
 For decades there has been talk of closing the gaps in the insurance system. Now, even as concern about access is surging, so is fright about soaring cost, creating new obstacles to change. Many in the debate, including major labor unions that had long stressed the access side of the equation, now oppose major new programs to extend care without cost control. And that is a far more complex and divisive matter.
Congress, according to major legislators, is still sorting out the myriad of possible responses. This year, it will consider proposals to reduce the uninsured by requiring most companies to offer health benefits or else pay into a public insurance pool.
To work, this approach should be accompanied by new regulations to make insurance more accessible to small businesses, said George J. Mitchell, the Senate majority leader. It must also be accompaned by effective cost controls, he added.
Mr. Mitchell, a Democrat from Maine, has made health care a personal crusade. He says measures that "build on the current system" should be tried before the country considers national insurance or the setting of national spending limits.
These deeper changes face the fierce opposition of private insurance companies, manufacturers of drugs and medical equipment and some medical groups, among others that could lose income or influence.
"If you nationalize health insurance, you'll have Americans covered very poorly in 10 years," said Carl J. Schramm, president of the Health Insurance Association of America, the industry's trade group. "Government hasn't kept its promises to either the poor or the aged."
Huge political obstacles confront even the more modest proposals, said Senator Mitchell, who drew a comparison with legislation against acid rain, which he first offered in 1981 but that did not pass for nine years.
Requiring companies to offer health insurance, for example, is opposed by small-business owners, while proposals for new public programs run up against budgetary fears.
Perhaps the most likely legislation to pass in the next year or two will be aimed at insurance rules, trying to reduce the skyrocketing rates for small businesses and individuals. "I think that this year it's feasible to do something by way of small-business insurance reform," said Senator Lloyd Bentsen, a Texas Democrat who is chairman of the crucial Senate Finance Committee.
As for broader change, he said, "I've got senators coming at it from all different directions."
Democrats accuse the President of a lack of leadership. President Bush has passed the issue to Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services.
Dr. Sullivan has described the system's problems in detail in recent speeches and exhorted the public to lead healthier lives. He has not yet announced any proposals for change, though he has made his instincts clear. "We need to build on our achievements by getting an even higher percentage of people covered by insurance," he recently said, "rather than replacing our system with something that Americans do not need and would not tolerate."
 
The Day of Reckoning With a New Life of Limits
 However financing and care are reorganized, Americans are destined to confront unfamiliar limits.
"Medicine is not going to conquer death," said Dr. Callahan, the ethicist. "But it's going to find every more expensive way to stave off mortality."
Agreeing on how and when to limit spending may pose the hardest political test of all.
At a minimum, better ways are needed to judge the merits of costly procedures and actively discourage their overuse.
"All of us are interested in seeing that useful new technology gets out there," said Dr. Wilensky, the Federal official. "But all the pressures in the system are to do more, expect more, want more."
Where procedures are clearly useless, the decision is easy. More often, real medical gains must be weighed against huge increases in cost. Is a thousand-dollar scan with a Magnetic Resonance Imaging device warranted to rule out a small risk of brain disease? Should insurers pay for an antibiotic that is 10 percent more likely to be effective but costs 10 times as much as the alternative?
The Federal Government, as it decides what Medicare will cover, is gingerly entering the slippery arena of cost-effectiveness. It hopes, through studies of medical experience, to promote more cost-conscious guidelines for appropriate treatment. These studies might clarify, for example, which patterns of headache justify using the costly M.R.I. scanner, and which patients with heart disease truly benefit from now-overused bypass surgery.
But it is one thing to issue guidelines, and another to deny payment against a doctor's professional judgment. And in any case, will more prudent practice be enough to contain overall spending? Some experts say society will have to cross the murky zone between urging sensible, cost-effective treatment and overt rationing, refusing to pay for some kinds of care to hold down costs.
Questions are raised especially about huge payments for patients with poor odds of survival -- $100,000 bone-marrow transplants in certain cancer patients who are unlikely to be saved, for example, or $5,000-a-day intensive care for aged, extremely ill patients who are unlikely to regain consciousness.
Many experts insist that at current spending levels, the country should have ample funds to provide all medically useful treatments -- if only the system could be overhauled to get rid of its pervasive waste.
"Maybe 20 or 30 years out, with a more aged population and even better technologies, maybe then we won't be able to do everything we know how to do," said Karen Davis, a health policy expert at Johns Hopkins University. "I don't think we're near that point now."
"Things that work, we should do," Dr. Davis said. "Kidney transplants work, heart transplants work. They are expensive, but we can afford that in a $650 billion budget."
But Dr. Callahan, who believes the country must begin debating health priorities, said: "Efficiency will only stave off the day of reckoning. An aging society and increasingly expensive technology are going to force limits on us sooner or later."
A more politically feasible way to limit care may be the less direct path now followed by Canada and other countries: limit investment in costly machines, medical specialists and intensive-care services.
"Once you're there in the intensive care unit, it's extremely hard to withhold things," said Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton University. "If you wish to ration, I feel the only way to do it is not to put the resources there in the first place."
But first, the country must do something about another kind of rationing, already here and more shameful, that through expense and indignities prevents the poor from getting decent medical treatment.
"Our public hospital system is withholding care in a brutal fashion," Dr. Reinhardt said.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Rethinking the Health System: Choices for Change . . . "
 
Improve Current Coverage
 
* Use tax incentives, new insurance regulations and public programs to promote insurance for those now left out.
 
* Employers would be required to offer insurance or pay into a pool that would offer policies to uninsured workers. Medicaid would be expanded to cover the unemployed poor.
 
* While this approach has gained the widest support so far, it is fiercely opposed by small-business owners and critics say it would only add to the administrative morass. Aid for smaller cmpanies and the poor could require significant new public spending.
 
National Health Insurance
 
* Following the Canadian model, private insurance could be largely scrapped for a universal public insurance program, financed by income, payroll or other taxes. The public payer would set uniform national fees.
 
* National financing has the virtue of simplicity, reducing paperwork and allowing easier control of costs. Universal care could in theory be achieved without major new net spending.
 
* Opponents fear this approach would impose rigid limits on medical decisions and personal choice, and would lead to a shortchanging of healthcare by a fiscally strapped Government.
 
Individual Coverage
 
* Promoted by market-oriented conservatives, tax incentives would support direct purchase of insurance by individuals and households. All households would be required to carry a minimum policy and would receive tax credits, linked to income level, for insurance and medical expenses.
 
* This would allow people to switch jobs without worry and would assure minimal coverage for everyone. But even with tax credits, high out-of-pocket payments could be a hardship for poor people, and the price of insurance for those with risky medical histories could soar, requiring major public subsidies.
 
". . . And Strategies to Control Costs"
 
Several strategies, not mutually exclusive, have been proposed. Most could be used in combination with any of the broad structures described above.
 
* Managed Care: Expand efforts to scrutinize doctors' decisions and encourage more patients to enter health maintenance organizations. In some proposals, major payers like government and large corporations would contract with H.M.O.'s for all care.
 While scrutiny saves money, it involves new layers of bureaucracy and is deeply resented by doctors. Also, many doctors and patients oppose being pushed into H.M.O.'s.
 
* Malpractice limitations: Legal changes to hold down lawsuits and size of settlements could help reduce "defensive medicine" in which procedures are used to rule out slight risks.
 
* Single payer: All medical fees could be paid by a single public entity, giving it enormous bargaining power over fee levels and medical practices. While this would happen automatically with a national health plan, private insurers could also, in some proposals, channel their payments through a single public payer.
 In a half-way approach already emerging in Medicare, national guidelines on appropriate fees and use of technology, could be adopted.
 
* Annual cap on expenditures: In an approach successfully used by other countries, annual health budgets could be set - for the country, for states, for individual hospitals - with all care provided for the preset level of funds. If budgets were reasonable, care could be high quality, with strong incentives to offer only cost-effective treatment.
 Critics say the implicit rationing could mean denial of beneficial care and impede medical progress.
 
* Explicit rationing: As proposed in Oregon for its Medicaid program, insurers could refuse to pay for treatments judged as low in priority. Divisive ethical issues would have to be resolved.

HEADLINE: Lawyer Layoffs: Boon to Temporary Job Agencies

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS

 BODY:
In waves of cost-cutting, law firm associates have been laid off, suffering misery if not calamity. The firms suffer fear of hiring. And this is an opportunity for people like Lesley Friedman, who notes that "some incredible talent" has been set adrift since she started a temporary placement agency for lawyers in 1987.
Back then, her Manhattan agency placed lawyers who really wanted to be writers or dancers or entrepreneurs, or to spend more time with their children. Now, according to Ms. Friedman and others in the business, lawyers who want full-time law jobs are the largest single contingent of applicants for temporary jobs. 
 Ms. Friedman estimates that a third of the resumes she receives are in this category. Elsewhere, the proportion is higher at agencies specializing in temporary jobs for lawyers. At the Lawsmiths in California, Eric Walker, who manages the Los Angeles office, said about three-quarters of his applicants for temporary work had lost their jobs. Robert S. Hamberger, co-owner of D.C. Legal Support Inc. in Washington, estimates that 70 to 80 percent of the lawyers who notify him would prefer permanent work.
But the option that is commonly called "contract work" in the business is taking up some slack.
 
Quick Changeover for Some
 Sometimes, matches are made practically without a hitch. Michelle S. Babbitt, who was laid off along with 20 to 30 other associates from Stroock & Stroock & Lavan in Manhattan, left there on a Tuesday and on Wednesday started a nine-month job with Schulte Roth & Zabel.
When she got the bad news in December, Ms. Babbitt sent out hundreds of resumes, knowing that the market was "very very dire." Although she initially had something permanent in mind, she was swayed by the prospect of working, even on a temporary basis, at a firm with "a reputation of having excellent, excellent litigators."
And after the "assault on the ego" that dismissal inevitably brings, she said, it is refreshing to concentrate on work and dispense with office politics. "You have the luxury of working in a politically free environment," she said. "You're just free to be an attorney."
Placements like this one helped Lesley Friedman's Special Counsel Inc. enjoy a record year. Ms. Friedman said her gross billings were about $4 million last year, twice what they were in 1989. The agencies pay the lawyers in temporary jobs 70 percent to 80 percent of what they they bill a law firm or corporation. Smaller agencies in other cities say they have only recently seen business pick up, but they agree with Ms. Friedman that they are benefitting from law firms' moves to cut back.
"In 90 percent of cases they've overreacted," said Mr. Walker, of Lawsmiths, "and then can't handle the work. The last thing they're going to do a month or two after this bloodletting is turn around and start hiring laterally again. Then is the time when they turn to people like us."
Part of the increase is the result of the growing acceptance of temporary hiring among lawyers. Even in a profession where self-employment has long been respectable, many initially looked askance at the idea of dispatching people to fill in as lawyers at firms, some of which would not even use temporary secretaries.
 
Part of Change in Firms
 The resistance eroded, though, along with some of the traditional practices of big firms. "There used to be tremendous loyalty of firms to associates and vice versa," said Mr. Hamberger in Washington. "These things tend to dissolve mutually. Law practice has changed in a thousand ways. We are a piece of that."
There is less skepticism, too, about lawyers who have lost jobs. Janis Meresman Goldman, owner of Lawyer's Lawyer in Washington, said her law-firm clients no longer ask. "They know why these people have been laid off," she said.
Robert C. Webster, head of the Lawsmiths' San Francisco office, said that from the day the agency opened in 1985 he had consistently received one or two resumes a day; beginning late last year, he said, the number rose to five or six. Now he says he is receiving three times as many resumes as he did a year ago.
This trend insures a financial advantage to employers, who pay agencies about two-thirds, on an hourly basis, of what a permanent associate would cost.
 
Temporaries Making Less
 Ms. Friedman lowered her rates recently, acknowledging that people coming from law firms "realize the salaries they were paid were quite inflated." Associates with a few years' experience are now pleased to make $40 an hour in a temporary job, she said, whereas a year ago they commanded $50 or $60.
And sometimes there is no work, at least in the areas where layoffs have hit lawyers the hardest. For corporate lawyers, temporary employment "is not an answer," said a partner who was recently asked to leave the firm and spoke on condition of anonymity, adding: "People being laid off hope it's an answer, or that a temp job will turn into a permanent job. But what really happens is that out there, there are three jobs and 2,300 people who want each job. That's the problem that the corporate or real estate lawyer is facing."
Temporary agencies have also heard from laid-off partners, and, especially in Washington, from lawyers with years of experience in regulatory specialties. Some highly marketable people, like the former Supreme Court clerk who signed up with Janis Goldman's Washington agency, are in no rush to commit themselves.
Jed S. Rakof, now a partner at Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson in Manhattan, who has worked with about a dozen lawyers in temporary jobs over the years, acknowledged that some people do contract work "because they do not fit into a normal working situation."
"You might well decide," he said, "that you wanted to hire someone who was brilliant but flaky to help draft some motion papers and yet not want to take the person on on a long-term basis."
Lawyers who have been laid off yet still want to be lawyers do not have the luxury of being flaky or pleading artistic interests. They must also dispel fears that they will leave if a permanent job materializes.
As Mr. Hamberger in Washington sees it, a law firm should not worry about a temporary lawyer's life plan. "You can't make a mistake," he said, "because you're not promising anything."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Pressure Mounts On Fed to Do More

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE good news is that the Federal Reserve Board has cut the discount rate and the Federal funds rate, and leading commercial banks have followed with cuts in their prime lending rates. The bad news is that the Fed made the rate cuts because the economy is softer than most economists had expected.
John Robson, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, said in an interview yesterday: "I think this was a smart thing for the Fed to do while the economy is so sluggish. There's further room for reductions. The goal is to see growth restarted, and if it takes further rate cuts, we'll be for it." 
 Indeed, consensus is emerging among economists outside the Administration, as well as inside, that Federal Reserve policy needs to be further relaxed. After looking at the latest batch of economic data, George L. Perry of the Brookings Institution said, "There is need to do more."
In part, this stems from the fear that if the recession continues or worsens, the banking crisis would be aggravated and could lead to a systemic breakdown.
For the Administration there are special anxieties -- that the bank-insurance funds would quickly be wiped out, its banking-reform and trade legislation would be derailed, its already yawning budget deficits for 1991 and 1992 greatly widened and its electoral prospects in 1992 gravely threatened. The bailout from these dangers, economic and political, depends primarily on the Fed.
Consumer confidence indexes leaped upward after the victory in the Persian Gulf war, but consumers have not translated that early postwar euphoria into greater spending.
Business, too, has remained cautious. It is still trimming payrolls and holding down inventories and capital spending. Factory orders slipped again in March -- the fifth straight decline. Manufacturers' expectations for production gains dropped slightly in mid-April, according to a new Dun & Bradstreet survey. "Immediately after the Persian Gulf war, manufacturers' optimism rebounded sharply," said Douglas P. Handler, manager of econometric services for D.& B. "But now that the recession has lasted longer than most manufacturers expected, they are taking a wait-and-see attitude."
Contracts for new construction fell in March to the lowest level since December 1983, according to a survey by F. W. Dodge, the construction industry arm of McGraw-Hill Inc. Housing sales have been edging up, but builders' response to lower interest rates has thus far been extremely sluggish.
Worried lest its predictions of a healthy recovery this summer and on into 1992 prove wrong, the Administration has been pushing the Fed to cut interest rates. And during last weekend's meetings in Washington of the Group of Seven industrialized countries, the Administration leaned on foreign central banks to relax their monetary policies.
While the American pitch for easier money had no apparent effect on the German Bundesbank or the Bank of Japan, it apparently influenced the Federal Reserve, which won applause from President Bush for cutting rates -- applause that the Fed, cherishing its independence, might prefer to have been spared.
Even so, Administration pressure on the Fed has not ceased. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, after congratulating the Fed, said he still believed there was "ample room for lower interest rates." Many private economists share that view.
The large majority contend the risk of worsening inflation by further easing money and credit is well worth taking in view of the continuing recessionary dangers. As Stephen S. Roach, principal senior economist of Morgan Stanley, put it, "Inflation is expected to remain under good control, with the Consumer Price Index projected to rise only 4.2 percent through 1992."
Secretary Brady and his advisers stress that nearly all of the United States economic growth in 1990 resulted from rising exports, and they are concerned that a slowdown in Europe and Asia will jeopardize the American recovery.
The Germans have shown no sign of yielding to American pleas. Horst Kohler, State Secretary of Germany's Finance Ministry, while praising the Fed's cut in interest rates, said the Bundesbank would not move. "For the time being, there's no possibility to say we can lower rates," he said. The German Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, offered the deeper German philosophy with his remark: "Quick fixes to push growth would collapse, as they did in the 1970's."
With the German economy still growing solidly, even officials like Jacques Delors, president of the European Community, who would like to see an easier German monetary policy because it could spur growth and ease strains on their currencies, despair of pressing Karl Otto Pohl, president of the Bundesbank, into relaxing monetary policy. Europeans and Americans alike may simply have to let the Germans and the Deutsche Mark go their own way, and take whatever stimulative measures they can to ward off recession and hasten recovery.

HEADLINE: New Claims by Jobless Again Hit Half a Million

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits hit the half-million mark again in April as the ranks of those seeking help rose for the second straight week, the Government said today.
"This is the recession biting at the personal level," said Peter Radford, chief economist at the National Westminster Bancorp of New York. 
 "It's another half a million people who lost jobs and are filing for unemployment," added Robert Brusca of Nikko Securities. "It's a very high number, and it's very disturbing."
For the week ended April 20, the number of people who filed initial unemployment claims rose by 2,000, pushing the total to 500,000, the Labor Department reported. The gain followed a much steeper increase in initial jobless claims of 47,000 the previous week, the agency said.
While cautioning that the number can be extremely volatile, analysts said today's data showed that the recession did not abate last month.
On Friday, the Labor Department is scheduled to release its overall unemployment figures for April. Many analysts have predicted that the rate will probably rise from 6.8 percent to as high as 7 percent. They have estimated that businesses cut 150,000 to 200,000 more jobs.
"The recession did not end in April," said Elliott Platt, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities. "It is still with us. The decline has slowed, but nonetheless, the economy is still in a decline."
Today's report also showed that the number of people actually receiving unemployment claims posted a huge increase for the week ending April 13, rising by 61,000, to 3.6 million.
Still, that means less than half of the nation's 8.6 million unemployed are receiving benefits.
The weekly ncrease in new claimants reported today was relatively small, but it marked a dramatic increase over levels from last year. For the same week in 1990, there were 373,000 new jobless claims.
In early March, claims remained above the half-million mark for two consecutive weeks -- something that had not happened in more than eight years.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Thin Trading; Gold Is Down in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most key currencies in thin trading yesterday, as the markets awaited the latest United States unemployment data.
Gold prices declined, with gold bullion for current delivery settling at $355 a troy ounce on the New York Commodity Exchange, off $1 from late Wednesday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $354.80 an ounce, off 95 cents. 
 Currency dealers attributed the dollar's increase largely to the German Bundesbank's decision not to raise interest rates at its biweekly policy-making meeting. Higher German rates would have strengthened the mark at the dollar's expense.
Kevin Logan, chief economist for Swiss Bank Corporation in New York, said trading was quiet as many dealers kept a low profile in advance of the Labor Department's April unemployment report, which is due for release today.
Some economists predicted the data would show that unemployment continued to rise last month, nearing the 7 percent level. That could hurt the dollar because it reflects a weakening economy, thereby increasing the likelihood of further cuts in interest rates.
The Labor Department reported yesterday that the number of people filing new claims for unemployment benefits rose by 2,000 in mid-April, to 500,000. For the corresponding week in 1990, there were 373,000 people filing new jobless claims.
In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar closed at 137.68 Japanese yen, up from 136.64 yen on Wednesday. It stood at 138.05 yen in London, and 138.15 yen in New York, unchanged from Wednesday.
The dollar was stronger against the British pound. Sterling bought $1.7170 in London, down from from $1.7265. In New York, the pound closed at $1.7193, down from $1.7225.
Against the German mark, the dollar traded at 1.7240 marks in Europe, up from 1.7055 marks, and at 1.7203 in New York, up from 1.7100 on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's quotes, included: 1.4585 Swiss francs, up from 1.4480; 5.8255 French francs, up from 5.7885; 1,274 Italian lire, up from 1,266, and 1.14955 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15175.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $354.50 an ounce, down from $357 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Panel Backs DNA Tests on Lincoln's Tissue

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
There are no compelling legal or ethical reasons to bar an attempt to clone Abraham Lincoln's genes from tissue samples obtained at the time of the President's assassination, a panel of experts concluded today.
The committee, assembled by the Government museum that holds samples of Lincoln's tissue, said it considered issues of privacy, probable consent, ethics and law, and gave the proposal a "qualified green light." 
 The nine-member panel, headed by Dr. Victor A. McKusick, professor of medical genetics at Johns Hopkins University, concluded that there was merit in the proposal to see if Lincoln suffered from a potentially fatal genetic disease called Marfan's syndrome, which is characterized in part by a tall, gangling appearance.
In February, the National Museum of Health and Medicine, an affiliate of the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology, asked the committee to advise it on whether to examine the samples of Lincoln's hair, bone chips and blood stains in its collection to see if any DNA remains 126 years after the Lincoln's death. Such tests would require the destruction of a small amount of the samples.
 
Building Block of Heredity
 "The panel's conclusion is that exploration of the technical aspects of the Lincoln DNA Marfan study be encouraged to proceed," Dr. McKusick said at a news conference. DNA is the basic building block of heredity that makes up 80,000 to 100,000 genes, which contain the biological essence of a person.
Dr. McKusick and other panel members said there was no urgency in beginning laboratory work on the tissue samples because a definitive genetic test for Marfan's has not yet been developed. In addition, they said, the panel wanted to consider the latest test methods and look for ways that might produce the highest yield of genetic material from the smallest amount of sample. Panel members said it would be at least a year before any DNA cloning could be tried.
After the news conference, Jeremy Rifkin, a frequent critic of genetic research who heads a Washington-based organization called the Foundation on Economic Trends, said he would oppose the project to clone Lincoln's DNA and would ask Congress to investigate the social, ethical and commerical implications of working with the genetic materials of dead people.
"The scientists involved in this study are using the corpse of a revered President of the United States for a public relations stunt to draw attention and research funds for a particular disease," Mr. Rifkin said.
 
'Very, Very Good Chance'
 Dr. McKusick said several research groups are working on isolating the gene and defect that causes Marfan's, and that a test should be available before the end of the year.
Dr. Victor Weedn, a panel member who is chief of the Armed Forces DNA Identification Laboratory, said there was a "very, very good chance" that the Lincoln tissue samples contain DNA, although no one could know how intact it is. "DNA tests have been performed successfully on many old skeletal remains," Dr. Weedn said, adding that it very likely that scientists could get useful DNA from the Lincoln samples, particularly the blood and bone specimen.
Genetic tests could reveal if Lincoln was afflicted with the inherited connective-tissue disease, as some experts suspect. The disease could have taken his life prematurely even if John Wilkes Booth had not fired his fatal shot. Lincoln was 56 years old when he died.
Marfan's syndrome, which the National Marfan Foundation estimates afficts 40,000 Americans and one in 10,000 people worldwide, can result in abnormalities and weakness in bones and joints, eyes, the heart and blood vessels. Sufferers often grow to be tall and gangly with unusually long limbs and fingers. They are at increased risk of death from exertion that causes the aorta, the main artery from the heart, to burst.
Cheryl Williams, president of the Marfan foundation and a member of the Lincoln panel, said that if Lincoln is shown to have had the disease, it would be inspirational to Marfan patients and show everyone that a person with a genetic disease can achieve great things. "It will foster research and increase public awareness of Marfan's syndrome," she said.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Urges Changes by Bankers

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 2

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said yesterday that the banking system of the 1990's was likely to be smaller but stronger.
As banks recover from a record level of troubled loans, Mr. Greenspan said bankers must change their practices as Congress and regulators move to limit the scope of deposit insurance and consider granting banks powers to enter new businesses. 
 One of the most important changes, he said, is that banks must increase their capital -- the difference between assets and liabilities -- and to make make fewer high-risk loans.
But, although he stressed the need for more capital, Mr. Greenspan said now was not the time for regulators to raise minimum capital standards, as banks cope with recession. Previously, Mr. Greenspan had warned bankers that they should expect continued pressure by regulators to increase their capital.
In a talk at a banking conference here sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, Mr. Greenspan argued that a stronger banking system would be in the best interest of bankers and their shareholders, and was not just a demand by regulators trying to protect the deposit insurance fund from further losses.
Mr. Greenspan said the current shortage of credit indicated that banks were becoming more cautious lenders, and were trying to improve their financial strength by reducing their size.
Banks that increased their capital, recent Fed studies show, tend to earn a higher return for shareholders than when they are more weakly capitalized. This finding is contrary to the widespread belief among bankers that the highest returns come by expanding a bank's lending while keeping capital low. In that way, profits of the bigger bank are divided among a smaller group of investors who own the bank's capital.
But as bank problems have become more visibile, the financial markets have looked more critically on the banking industry. The presence of higher capital "appears to be convincing uninsured creditors to lend to these safer institutions at significantly lower rates," Mr. Greenspan said. The benefit of lower interest rates paid for uninsured deposits and other funds is enough, Mr. Greenspan said, to increase bank profits.
The benefit of lower borrowing costs for well-capitalized banks are enough to substantially reduce the cost to banks of major reforms like higher capital standards or deposit insurance premiums adjusted for the riskiness of a bank's business, the chairman said.
A bank should prepare for a future with fewer lending opportunities, Mr. Greenspan said. Besides avoiding risky borrowers -- many of whom were welcomed at banks in the 1980's -- he said banks should expect large corporations to continue to raise funds without using banks.
 
Cost Control Cited
 As a result, "the banking industry of the future is likely to be smaller in relative terms than the banking industry of the present," Mr. Greenspan predicted. While mergers will result in larger banks, he said, the newly created banks are likely to be smaller than the sum of the individual merger partners.
Bankers' traditional reliance on growth to increase profits must be replaced, Mr. Greenspan said, by stricter controls over costs, the skillful use of technology and business loans with interest rates that are high enough to compensate the bank for occasional losses and still produce enough profit to satisfy shareholders.
Banks have learned in the 1980's "that they can make significant monies without taking heavy risks," Mr. Greenspan said, and are not making new loans that will likely sour. While there are no signs yet of an increase in bank lending, he said, the groundwork for a revival is being prepared as what bankers call nonperforming loans are increasing at a rate "somewhat under the average banker's expectation."
 
Forecast of Lending Increase
 When the growth in nonperforming loans, which are loans that are badly delinquent or in serious trouble, slows further, he said bank lending would increase and banks would become more willing to reduce the interest rates they charge on loans.
John Rau, visiting scholar at the Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern University, and former chairman of the La Salle National Bank here, said that the benefits of stronger capital were clearest "at the 40 or so large banks which rely most heavily on uninsured deposits." For other banks, he said market discipline might not be enough and regulators might have to dictate capital levels.
Robert E. Litan, a banking specialist at the Brookings Institution in Washington, said that banks with capital of 6 percent or less of assets earned lower returns for their shareholders than banks whose capital equaled 6 to 8 percent of assets. "But there can be such a thing as too much capital," he said, since banks with capital greater than 8 percent of assets earned a lower return on equity than those in the 6 to 8 percent group.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rates on Treasury Issues Ease

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Rates on long-term Treasury securities continued to ease yesterday, prompting a flood of corporate debt offerings. Most corporate bond and other debt issues are priced relative to comparable Treasury maturities.
Thus when yields on Treasury debt issues decline, many corporate borrowers seize the opportunity to sell bonds and other debt issues. Dealers estimate that roughly $1.5 billion of corporate debt came to market on Wednesday and perhaps as much yesterday. 
 The Treasury's current benchmark long bonds, the 7 7/8 percent issue maturing in February 2021, were offered late in the session at 97 9/32, up 16/32, equivalent to $5 per $1,000 of face value. This caused their yield to drop to 8.11 percent, from 8.16 percent the day before.
 
$11.75 Billion Auction
 Next Thursday, the Treasury plans to auction $11.75 billion of new 30-year bonds as part of its quarterly refunding, and the bonds traded on a when-issued basis to yield 8.10 percent.
The Treasury's long notes, the 7 3/4's of February 2001, gained 12/32, to 98 24/32, while its yield fell to 7.93 percent, from 7.99 percent the day before. Next Wednesday, the Treasury will auction $11.75 billion of new 10-year notes, and they traded to yield 7.92 percent on the same basis. In similar trading, the $13.5 billion of new three-year notes up for sale on Tuesday yielded 7.05 percent.
"The day's most important market news was the rise in initial claims for unemployment insurance, but the increase of 2,000 in the week ended April 26, to 500,000, was widely expected," said Peter D. Mayers, Treasury securities trader at the New York branch of Bank Julius Baer of Zurich, which manages investments for many big European pension funds and other institutions.
What may have surprised some market participants, Mr. Mayers said, "was the absence of any reaction to the larger-than-expected amount of Treasury paper to be offered at next week's refunding. One explanation may be that declining yields are forcing investment managers to try to squeeze as much as they can. For some, this means selling the shorter debt issues and buying longer maturities."
But many investors also sought to lock in short-term rates. As a result, the discount rate on 90-day Treasury bills plunged eight basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.46 percent; six-month bills fell two basis points, to 5.56 percent.
 
Fed Action Watched
 The Treasury auctioned $11.8 billion of new one-year bills at an average discount rate of 5.71 percent, down from 5.88 percent a month ago, and the lowest rate since March 1987, when it was 5.68 percent.
The Federal Reserve, meanwhile, was expected to add some reserves to the banking system because of the heavy Treasury withdrawals for Social Security and other payments. But the Fed did not do so. Mr. Mayers of Bank Juluis Baer said, "Many of us had expected the Fed to add some reserves indirectly through weekend repurchase agreements with its customers."
Few expected the Fed system itself to add reserves, he said, because it would have involved a much larger amount of money and thus could have sent a signal that it wanted the funds rate below its current presumed target of 5.75 percent. As it was, the key funds rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans and from which most other interest rates are scaled upward, traded at 5.75 percent for most of the day and closed at that level.
Following are the details of the Treasury's monthly auction of one-year bills:

HEADLINE: Massachusetts Governor Seeks Sharp Cutbacks in the Budget

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, May 2

 BODY:
Gov. William F. Weld announced a Draconian package of budget cuts today that would sharply curtail the General Relief program for the hard-core unemployed, force state employees to accept salary cuts and reduce scholarships for students at state colleges.
The cuts, which would save $802 million, are part of an effort by Governor Weld to cover the $2 billion deficit he has forecast in the state's $13.7 billion budget for the next fiscal year, beginning July 1. The state has been in a fiscal crisis since Massachusetts's economy began to plummet into recession in 1988, causing widespread layoffs, political paralysis over the budget in the Statehouse and growing public disenchantment with state government. 
 To justify his action today Mr. Weld said, "The overriding imperative is to bring the budget into balance." He noted that Massachusetts already has the lowest bond rating of any state and that Wall Street has threatened to downgrade its securities to junk bond status, making it much more expensive for the state to borrow to cover the budget deficit.
The proposals, part of the Governor's continuing campaign to cut back state government, will not go into effect unless they are cleared by the Legislature, which normally seeks to have a budget approved by the start of the new fiscal year. Both houses of the Legislature are controlled by Democrats, but because their leadership has been in disarray, it is hard to predict the outcome of the budget talks.
"The notion of fiscal stability is not some metaphysical idea," he said at a news conference in the Statehouse. "It's got to be done, or the economy will grind to a halt."
Mr. Weld, the state's first Republican Governor in two decades, said his predecessor, Michael S. Dukakis, had tried to reduce the deficit with cuts of 4, 5 and 6 percent. "We can't continue to nibble away at state problems," he said. "The only way to achieves cuts of this magnitude is to eliminate programs." Mr. Weld has consistently ruled out any tax increases.
The proposed cuts drew an immediate outcry from advocates for the poor. "General Relief is not a program for free-loaders, it is for the extremely poor," said Neil Cronin, a spokesman for the Massachusetts Law Reform Institute, a legal services group. "You have to be incapacitated in order to qualify."
There are 40,000 people on General Relief in Massachusetts, receiving $338-a-month payments. All are unemployed and have assets of less than $250. Many have never been employed and more than half are mentally or physically disabled.
 
Dire Impact on Poor Is Seen
 "General Relief is the bottom of the barrel," Mr. Cronin said. "And once you are not eligible for General Relief, you are homeless, hungry and without health care."
Sue Marsh, the executive director of the Massachusetts Coalition for the Homeless, said: "I think Governor Weld is shooting himself in the foot. If even 10 percent of those families become homeless, he will have wiped out his savings. He will have to pay more far more money to shelter them than he would have if he had provided them with the benefits that would have prevented their homelessness."
Under his proposed cuts, Mr. Weld would eliminate the entire $213 million annual General Relief program, though he would partly replace it with a $98 million plan to provide "emergency aid for the elderly and disabled," which would serve less than half the current recipients.
Mr. Weld has argued that many of the people on General Relief, a program that many other states have, are not truly deserving and would be able to find jobs.
The new emergency replacement program will include strict eligibility requirements and will have a medical board to check people's condition to cut down on fraud and abuse, he said.
In last year's gubernatorial campaign, Mr. Weld repeatedly pledged not to make any cuts that would undermine a "safety net" for the poor. Asked today about that pledge, Mr. Weld said, "The elderly and disabled, who are the most needy, will be protected."
But he acknowledged that another of his cuts, which would chop $20 million from a program established by Mr. Dukakis to train welfare recipients for jobs, "will be a tough hit."
The cuts announced today are in addition to other reductions in state spending Mr. Weld made public in February when he introduced his budget for the fiscal year 1992. One of the major cuts at that time was a plan to change the state's Medicaid program into a managed health care system that would give the government greater control over which doctors and hospitals a patient uses.
The new cuts today have been made necessary because state revenues have continued to fall along with the slumping state economy, Mr. Weld said. Unemployment in Massachusetts, the lowest of any of the major industrialized states in the 1980's, has risen to 9.7 percent.

HEADLINE: U.S., Japan Reach Pact On Exports

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
Export financing agencies of the United States and Japan announced the first cooperative arrangements today between the two Governments, a plan in which Japanese money will be used to help finance American exports to Japan and to third world countries.
The initial objective is to support American exports to the tune of $1 billion. But Japanese and American officials said at a news conference here that they expected more money to be allocated by Tokyo if the program proved successful. 
 "This is a major step by the Japanese Government to improve the trade balance between the two countries," said Eugene K. Lawson, vice president of the Export-Import Bank of the United States.
Yoshio Ichiryu, the senior executive director of the export-import insurance division of Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry, said the arrangements "demonstrate how we can deliver something good to international society," adding, "We need a partner to dance to the tango."
 
Swords Have Been Crossed
 The United States, which is running a trade deficit of nearly $50 billion with Japan, has been counting on export growth to pull the economy out of a recession.
"Anything that promises export growth is desirable," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, a policy research organization in Washington.
The agreement comes at a time when Tokyo and Washington have crossed swords on a number of trade issues. Last week the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, announced plans to impose trade sanctions against Japan's construction industry because of the limited access that American companies have to Japan's huge construction market.
Japan's trade ministry is making the $1 billion available for insurance to cover exporters' risks in shipments to Japan or third world countries. Once a contract is insured by the ministry, companies can borrow against it and use funds to build up their inventories, produce more goods or for a wide variety of other purposes. "This is very nice money to have up front," Mr. Lawson said.
But Mr. Ichiryu stressed that it was up to American companies to get the contracts. "We cannot insure nonexistent contracts," he said.
The Export-Import Bank of the United States and similar agencies in Japan facilitate trade by providing credits, insurance and loan guarantees to buyers of exports. It is unusual for the credit agency of a foreign government to finance American exports.
 
Backlash Risk Cited
 The Japanese may also be financing exports of Japanese subsidiaries in the United States, which have a growing presence here. Japanese investment in the United States reached $78.5 billion last year.
Asked whether the Japanese would be using the program to provide special assistance for their American subsidiaries, Seiji Hagiwara, an associate of Mr. Ichiryu, said that under the rules established by the ministry, "there can be no discrimination."
Bradley R. Larschan, general counsel of the Association for International Investment, said that because of the political tensions with Japan, the program could run the risk of "creating political backlash here if it discriminates in favor of companies owned by Japan."
Under the arrangements announced today, plans were sealed for extensive cooperation between the Export-Import Bank of the United States and the Japanese export finance agencies, which besides the Ministry of International Trade and Industry division, include the Export-Import Bank of Japan and the Japan Development Bank.
The Washington agency is to engage in so-called co-financing arrangements with the Ministry of International Trade and Industry and the Japanese Export-Import Bank. This means that for certain large-scale contracts that may include consortiums of Japanese and American companies, the two Governments will team up to provide financing.
Under another arrangement, the Japan Development Bank will provide long-term financing to American and Japanese companies and their joint ventures, both for increasing imports from the United States and for investments in additional Japanese production operations that may import goods and services from the United States.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Home Fed Posts Loss For Period

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 2

 BODY:
The HomeFed Corporation, the parent company of one of California's largest savings institutions, said today that it lost $173.9 million in the first quarter, leaving it short of the Government's standards for financial strength.
HomeFed, the San Diego-based banking company, said the loss resulted primarily from continued weakness in real estate in California and the East. In the period last year it earned $34.5 million, or $1.48 a share. 
The loss continues an abrupt slide at HomeFed, which until last year seemed to have escaped most of the financial woes that plagued the savings and loan industry in the late 1980's. It also suggested that battered real estate markets in many regions, including California and Florida, had not yet hit bottom.
 
Added Reserves for Bad Loans
 The company added $200 million to its reserves for possible losses on loans and on real estate it owns. The size of the additional loss reserves was far higher than expected, and appeared to reflect the results of an intensive examination of HomeFed's books recently completed by Federal regulators.
The weak results left HomeFed, which has assets of $18 billion, short of capital by one of the three standards imposed by Federal regulators. The company said its risk-based capital ratio stood at 6.09 percent on March 31, or $154.6 million below the required level of 7.2 percent. Capital is the financial buffer an institution maintains to guard against losses and this measure considers the amount of risk in a financial institution's loan portfolio.
 
Federal Requirements

 The company said it barely met a second capital requirement, for what is known as core capital, and expected to fall short of the requirement soon. The company continues to meet the third and most basic measure, known as tangible capital.
HomeFed said it expected the Office of Thrift Supervision, the Federal regulatory agency, to require the company to rebuild its capital to levels higher than the minimums set by the Government two years ago. The company said the regulators had not indicated what the new capital levels might be.
Robert F. Adelizzi, HomeFed's chief executive, said he expected regulators to impose additional operating restrictions on the institution soon, although he could not say what they might be. HomeFed has already been barred from increasing its asset size or attracting new deposits by offering high interest rates through brokerage houses.
HomeFed's stock rose 12.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange to $3.625, but the quarter's results were announced after the close of trading.
Mr. Adelizzi said the increase in loan-loss provisions and the resulting loss for the quarter were "certainly higher than I would have expected." And he said the real estate outlook remained clouded.
"Some markets are stabilizing and improving, and some we're not sure have hit bottom yet," he said.
HomeFed and its primary operating subsidiary, HomeFed Bank, shifted focus over the last decade away from home mortgages and into the far riskier business of making loans to developers of homes, apartments, office buildings and shopping centers. HomeFed also plunged into the development business itself, building single-family homes, for example, in California.
The strategy seemed to be paying off until last year, when the company began posting large losses. The company's problems are spread throughout its portfolio of residential and commercial real estate loans, with particular difficulties in California, Florida, Georgia and Washington, D.C.
Analysts have said for several months that HomeFed has no better than an even chance of avoiding being seized and sold by Federal regulators. Mr. Adelizzi acknowledged in a telephone interview that the job of turning the company around would be made that much harder by the unexpectedly large size of the loss, but he said he remained optimistic that the company could survive.
"This company still has a lot of strengths," he said.
But the loss leaves HomeFed in a serious bind. It will be almost impossible for the company to raise new capital while it is losing money. The only realistic way it can bring itself into compliance with Government standards is to shrink by selling assets, increasing the ratio of its capital to its assets.
Unless the real estate markets turn around, however, the only assets the company will be able to sell at a profit are those it most needs to keep, like loans that are being repaid on time and mortgage-backed securities that have appreciated in value.
As of March 31, the company's nonperforming assets -- primarily loans 90 days or more delinquent and real estate it has foreclosed on -- amounted to $1.47 billion, or 8.2 percent of its total assets.

HEADLINE: Czechoslovakia Clings to Arms Sales

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, May 2

 BODY:
Soon after becoming President of Czechoslovakia, Vaclav Havel expressed his revulsion at the country's large arms exports. But a year and a half after the Communists were forced from power, his Government is having a hard time weaning its feeble economy from such trde.
Faced with growing unemployment and political instability in Slovakia, Prague has authorized the export of tanks to Syria. Slovakia, the eastern third of the country, is where most of the munitions industry is concentrated. 
Much as the peace oriented officials in Prague would like to phase out the production of heavy weapons, they are aware that after four decades of Communist rule, Soviet-designed T72 tanks remain one of the few profitable exports this country produces.
Officials are giving few details of foreign sales of the tanks, but this week a Czech investigative weekly, Respekt, reported that 300 T72 tanks will be sold to Syria.
 
Negotiations With Iran
 The newspaper also said that negotiations were under way on a potentially bigger tank sale to Iran. Officials here say the Government is more reluctant to authorize that deal out of concern that there is a greater chance that tanks sold to Iran could be involved in conflict.
Asked about the reported deals on Monday, President Havel told reporters that the profits from tank sales would be used to help the country's arms industry convert to civilian production. "If it were without political risks, we could export them and invest the earnings in conversion," he said.
On Tuesday, Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier visited Czechoslovakia's two biggest arms factories, both in Slovakia, and told worried plant directors who have run out of orders and have been laying off workers that the exports to Syria would be allowed to go ahead. He also promised $50 million in Government help to convert to civilian production.
On hearing of the negotiations over the exports at the beginning of April, the Bush Administration raised objections. In a telephone call to President Bush, Czechoslovak officials say, Mr. Havel asked him to try to understand the importance to Czechoslovakia of selling the tanks, some of which have already been built. Mr. Havel also pleaded with Mr. Bush for help in the conversion to civilian production. The phone call took place just before Foreign Minister Dienstbier left on a trip to Washington. Mr. Dienstbier brought back a promise that the Administration would try to interest American companies in helping Czechoslovakia develop and market new products.
 
Slovak Tensions on the Rise
 Political tensions in Slovakia have risen since the decision of the regional Parliament last week to dismiss the Prime Minister, Vladimir Meciar, who opposed the rapid transformation to a market economy favored by Prague. Critics accused him of exploiting local fears of unemployment.
Although only about 4 percent of the Slovak work force is out of work, that is double the rate in the large Czech part of the country. This is largely a result of the concentration of now uncompetitive heavy industry in Slovakia.
Czechoslovakia's formerly large military exports have plummeted to only one-eighth of their value just four years ago. Officials say exports to third world countries will total about $1 billion this year, down from $8 billion in 1986. Arms sales to the Warsaw Pact countries, which were even larger -- the figures are not being made public -- have dropped by the same proportion.
