HEADLINE: BANGLADESH REPORTS TOLL FROM STORM IS NEAR 40,000; SAYS IT MAY EXCEED 100,000

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DHAKA, Bangladesh, May 2

 BODY:
Prime Minister Khaleda Zia said today that at least 100,000 people may have died in the devastating cyclone that pounded this low-lying country's densely populated coastal areas on Tuesday, leaving hunger, disease and homelessness in its wake.
With bodies washing ashore in the thousands and the Government pleading for international aid for millions of destitute survivors, the official death toll, based on reports from the hardest-hit regions, crept toward 40,000. But many of the victims were swept into the Bay of Bengal, and their bodies will probably never be recovered. 
 "It is a vast devastation, and the loss of human lives could exceed 100,000," Mrs. Zia said. "The information is incomplete. We fear it could go up much more. I pray to Allah it's not true."
 
Bodies Wash Ashore
 Relief workers and journalists who visited the stricken area in the southeast, dominated by ragged islands and river deltas, said the tides were bringing in thousands of bodies. Survivors searched for relatives among the corpses piled on beaches.
"I saw deaths, devastation, agony and misery of a magnitude I have never seen before," a photographer who went to the area told The Associated Press. The impoverished Government struggled to ferry food, water and medicine to the survivors, but vast areas hit by the cyclone were inaccessible. Helicopters dropped essentials to people huddled on the rooftops of marooned buildings.
[Already burdened by efforts to help Kurdish refugees and famine- stricken Africans, the United States and private relief agencies are beginning to assess how to provide aid to Bangladesh. Page A8.]
Lutfar Rahman Khan, Minister of State for Relief and Rehabilitation, said this evening of the death count: "I would not be surprised if the total exceeds 100,000." The death toll was the highest since 1970, the year before Bangladesh proclaimed its independence, when 500,000 people were killed by a cyclone that hit the same area.
The Government has appealed for international help to buy food, clothing, shelter and at least 20 large helicopters to deliver the relief supplies, the Minister said. About 10 million people out of a population of 115 million have been uprooted by the storm, which roared across the region with winds of 145 miles an hour.
The most devastated stretch of shoreline was around the seaside town of Cox's Bazar and on nearby islands, where 95 percent of the houses were destroyed. All along the southeast coast, brackish water has ruined drinking supplies. Roads have been severely damaged and telephone communications are cut off.
 
Rice Crops Destroyed
 A tempestuous sea has destroyed thousands of acres of rice crops that were almost ready for harvest. Experts said that land flooded with salt water might be unworkable for two or three years, a severe blow to the predominantly agricultural economy.
Shrimp farms, salt pans and fishing fleets, all vital sources of employment, have been blown apart. Damage to fledgling industries, including an oil refinery, has not been assessed.
In the port of Chittagong, eight ships, at least one belonging to the small Bangladesh Navy, have sunk, blocking the only harbor that the country can use for berthing large vessels bringing in relief supplies. Mr. Rahman Khan said Bangladesh "desperately" needed foreign expertise in clearing the port.
He said hospitals and schools were destroyed, leaving no place to shelter and treat the homeless. More than 100,000 people have no cover at all, not even tents or lean-tos. Health hazards are considered potentially disastrous in this intensely hot, humid climate.
 
6 Functioning Helicopters
 Three C-130 cargo planes were expected to arrive in the capital with relief supplies from Saudi Arabia, a large donor of aid to predominantly Muslim Bangladesh. But this country has only six functioning helicopters, most of them too small to ferry much equipment to the neediest areas.
Two light fixed-wing planes have dropped some dry food and clothing -- 40,000 saris for women and 20,000 sarongs for men -- in plastic bags from low altitudes. No planes can land on the estuary islands, which are still knee- to chest-deep in water, officials say.
Relief workers will try on Friday to use small boats to deliver food and water to offshore islands.
Hundreds of thousands of Bangladeshis have been living on relatively new silt islands in the estuaries of rivers in defiance of the law. They have fled there over the years in desperation, for land is in short supply in this extremely poor and densely populated country.
Many Bangladeshis on the islands were tending the cattle or crops of landlords who live safely on the mainland. Although they were advised to leave 48 hours before the cyclone struck, many could not think of a place to go -- or chose not to abandon the herds or their own subsistence crops, local journalists say.
Officials listed coastal areas or islands where the devastation has exceeded that of any recent disaster: Moiscali, Chakori, Sandwip, Kutubdia, Hatiya, Manpura, Charfashion, Bhola, Banshkhali, Patharghata, Sitakundu, Cox's Bazar, Patenga and Urirchor.
On Moiscali Island, the local authorities said today, at least 11,000 people died. At Chakori, near Cox's Bazar, the official death toll was 10,000. On Sandwip Island, at least 5,022 people perished.
 
The Leap in the Death Toll
 When the typhoon struck, there was immediate alarm that the death toll could soar into the tens of thousands. The Government initially put the official death toll at 1,000, and then at 3,000, as reports from stricken regions filtered in.
After new reports from remote areas and ravaged provinces, the official toll leaped early today to 35,000. The Government put the number at 37,543 late in the day, but did not say how it had arrived at such a precise figure.
The cyclone is the first crisis for Mrs. Zia's Government, which came to power just weeks ago. Prime Minister Zia, the widow of an assassinated President, Ziaur Rahman, led the Bangladesh Nationalist Party to victory in an election at the end of February.
Bangladesh's previous leader, Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, abruptly resigned last December under pressure from democracy campaigners. Their unexpected success gave the country a huge psychological boost. President Ershad is under arrest on charges of corruption.

Map/Chart: Map depicts Bangladesh and the path of the storm and its intensity.
 
"Four Kinds of Destruction"
 
Waves stirred up by high winds as cyclone approached land caused coastal flooding.
Storm surge near cyclone's center came ashore as wall of water 15 to 20 feet high, especially to right of storm's path.
Heavy rain near storm center added to floods.
Mountain rains fed rivers below, for delayed floods.
 
Source: Pennsylvania State University (pg. A8)

HEADLINE: Wage Accord Ends 12-Day Strike by New York Apartment Workers

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The 12-day strike by building service workers that had disrupted life for several hundred thousand New Yorkers ended last night after union leaders and representatives of apartment building owners announced a tentative settlement.
Some of the striking doormen, porters, elevator operators and handymen began returning to work even before the tentative agreement was announced at 7 P.M. in a statement from the owners' bargaining unit, the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations. 
 Tony Roman, a doorman at 165 West 66th Street, was back in uniform by 6 P.M., after learning about the settlement from union officials.
"Strike's over?" Constance Mensch, a resident, asked as she entered the building about an hour later. Mr. Roman nodded. "Hallelujah!" Ms. Mensch said.
The rest of the workers in the 2,800 affected buildings are to return to work today, said James F. Berg, the executive vice president of the owners' group.
The tentative settlement -- a three-year contract with annual increases averaging about 4 percent -- essentially split the difference on wages, the chief issue in the strike.
The accord was reached at about 4:30 A.M. yesterday after protracted bargaining on Tuesday and Wednesday, according to a management representative. The negotiating committee for the union, Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union, and the full board of the owners' group ratified the proposed contract yesterday afternoon and evening.
Individual building owners do not have to vote on the tentative agreement. It could not be learned whether the union membership must ratify the pact. Gus Bevona, the president of the union who did not speak publicly during the strike, did not return a telephone call last night seeking comment.
The union communicated quickly with its 30,000 members, and many had shifted enthusiastically from picketing to working by early evening. Richard Koch was back as the doorman at 465 West End Avenue, at 82nd Street, working his regular 4 P.M.-to-midnight shift.
"Everybody's happy, even the tenants, even if they have to pay a couple of dollars more," Mr. Koch said. "They like the full service, and why not? They pay for that."
Under the agreement, doormen, elevator operators and porters would get a raise of $16 a week, or 3.46 percent, in the first year. They would get another raise of $19 a week, or 3.97 percent, in the second year, and $21 a week, or 4.22 percent, in the third year. They received $462.73 a week under the contract that expired on April 21, when the strike began.
 
Part of Cost Is Offset
 Before the strike, the union had proposed a wage increase of 5 percent a year, and the owners' representatives had offered an increase of 2 percent a year. The cost of the first year's raise will be offset for the owners because they did not have to pay their employees during the 12 days of the strike.
The Realty Advisory Board said the union members' health and pension benefits would remain basically the same, with the building owners agreeing to contribute more to maintain the current benefit levels.
But the union, in a statement released last night, emphasized several small increases in benefits, from a $50-a-month rise in the maximum pension to additional college scholarships.
"It was unfortunate that a strike had to be called," Mr. Bevona said in the statement, "but under the circumstances it was necessary."
Mr. Bevona also said he was delighted that the workers would receive a "badly needed and much deserved" raise.
Irwin Gumley, the chairman of the realty board's negotiating committee, described the agreement as "a fair settlement after difficult negotiations."
 
Some Complaints
 "We're delighted that the employees who have suffered during the strike are back at work, and we know that the residents will be pleased by the return to normalcy," Mr. Gumley said in a statement.
Some union members complained yesterday before the settlement had been ratified that they had already paid a great economic price for their new raises, whatever they turned out to be. After 12 days on the picket lines, the strikers had lost nearly $1,000 in pay. The raise of $16 a week will give them $832 more in their paychecks over the next year. But the increase will also be built into all future raises.
Management had sought a number of concessions that the union found unacceptable. Among them was a proposal to create a lower wage scale for new workers and the right to switch some full-time positions to part time.
From the beginning, the two sides fought a mild war of attrition. The union ordered its members in about 1,400 Manhattan apartment buildings to go on strike first, although it left the impression in news releases that union members employed in apartment buildings in Queens, Staten Island and Brooklyn had also gone on strike. The workers in those boroughs walked off their jobs on Tuesday, the 10th day of the strike.
Building service workers in the Bronx are represented by a different union local.
The union tried to divide the building owners' group by inducing individual apartment buildings to sign separate labor agreements. These called for a 5 percent wage increase and promised that, if the eventual citywide settlement was less favorable to the union, the citywide terms would prevail in buildings that settled early.Most building owners remained allied with the Realty Advisory Board.
Some owners no doubt benefited from the strike financially because they did not have to pay their employees for its duration. But they were under pressure from residents, many of whom were inconvenienced considerably by the strike.

HEADLINE: Alaska House Rejects Settlement for Exxon Spill

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
The Alaska House of Representative tonight rejected the $1 billion civil settlement of the Exxon Valdez oil spill, a move that puts the agreement closer to collapse.
By a vote of 27 to 13, the House decided to scuttle the agreement, saying it neither penalized the Exxon Corporation sufficiently nor provided enough money to help Prince William Sound recover from the nation's largest oil spill. 
 The House's decision comes little more than a week after a Federal District Judge in Alaska rejected the agreement the Government and Exxon had negotiated to settle the criminal portion of the overall $1.1 billion pact. Judge H. Russel Holland said the $100 million fine proposed by the Government was too small.
But the agreement, which stems from the grounding of the Exxon Valdez on March 24, 1989, is still alive, at least until Friday when the state Senate is scheduled to decide on it and Governor Walter J. Hickel will sign it or reject it.
 
Pledge to Legislature

On March 13, a day after the $1 billion agreement was signed in Washington, Governor Hickel pledged to the Legislature that he would abide by its decision to approve or disapprove the pact. Sentiment in favor of approving the agreement is running much stronger in the state Senate, which is expected to ratify it tommorrow.
Mr. Hickel apparently feels that a split decision in the Legislature gives him the political room to make his own decision.
"The bottom line is the Governor gave the Legislature the opportunity to approve or disapprove," said Eric Rehman, the Governor's spokesman. "He would like the Legislature to act responsibly and give us a clear signal one way or the other. If they do not do so, there is a possibility this decision is open to the Governor's interpretation. If the Legislature ends up split, the Governor may decide to go forward with it."
The civil agreement between Exxon, Alaska and the Federal Government called on the nation's largest oil company to pay up to $1 billion over the next 14 years for scientific studies, environmental restoration work and other activities related to the recovery of Prince William Sound.
 
Initial Satisfaction
 Signed at the Department of Commerce here before midnight on March 12, the pact was applauded by the Bush Administration, environmental groups and many Alaskans as a pathbreaking effort to hold polluters responsible for environmental destruction.
But in the last few weeks, support for the agreement began to erode as its provisions came under more scrutiny. A Congressional study estimated that after inflation, the real value of the settlement was less than $400 million and Exxon could write every penny off on its state and Federal taxes. In no year was Exxon required to pay more than $150 million, the equivalent to a company taking in over $100 billion annually of a $30 traffic ticket to a family earning $30,000.
Many of Alaska's political leaders began to criticize the agreement as a good deal for Exxon and a bad deal for the state.
Mr. Hickel insists that the agreement provides Alaska with enough money to pay for the restoration of Prince William Sound, and years of litigation would be unlikely to gain more money from Exxon.
 
Ready for a New Pact

In rejecting the civil agreement, the House said it was seeking changes and was prepared to approve any agreement that included its members, said a spokesman for Representative Max Gruenberg, the House majority leader.
The House said it wanted Exxon to pay much more immediately; $100 million within 90 days after a new agreement is signed and $600 million more a year after that. The House also wants to increase Exxon's criminal fine to at least $500 million, of which Alaska would be paid $100 million.
Exxon should be prohibited from deducting the cost of the settlement from its state taxes, the House said. And lawmakers asked that a wealth of scientific and economic data about the spill be made public. That information, which was paid for by Alaskans, is currently secret.
Joe Tucker, an Exxon spokesman in Anchorage, said the company would have no immediate comment on the House vote. Exxon's sales totaled more than $107 billion last year and it reported earnings of more than $5.1 billion.

HEADLINE: COLLEGES;
Educators Examine Standards for Athletes

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

 BODY:
College administrators, who have been challenged to bring athletes into the mainstream of campus life, are also being faced with this thorny question: Should athletes recruited by big-time sports programs receive special treatment in admissions?
A survey published this week in The Chronicle of Higher Education shows the extent of special admissions. According to the survey, athletes admitted at Division I-A universities for the 1989-90 school year were four times as likely to receive special consideration in admissions. Football and basketball players were six times as likely as regular students to receive special treatment. 
 Over all, the survey, to which 96 of the 106 Division I-A schools responded, found that 17.5 percent of all athletes and 27.2 percent of football and basketball players were characterized as "special admits" by the universities.
A special admit is generally defined as someone who falls outside the normal profile of students admitted to the university but who is admitted because of some talent in a specific area like sports, art or music.
While the notion that athletes receive special consideration is not new, some educators said they felt the figures proved the system was not overly biased toward athletes.
 
Surprising Figures
 "Frankly, I think a number of people are surprised that the percentage of special admissions for athletes is not higher," said R. Gerald Turner, chancellor of the University of Mississippi and chairman of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's President's Commission.
"What you see is that most student athletes are being admitted on a basis other than special admissions," he said. "That flies in the face of the jock stereotype."
Among other things The Chronicle reported was that while many schools said they did not have a special policy for athletes, many of their football and basketball players had lower academic profiles than the general student body.
For example, the survey points out that the University of Michigan does not have special policies for athletes. But football and men's basketball players entered college in 1989 with an average Scholastic Aptitude Test score of 957, 200 points below the average for all Michigan freshmen that year.
"My own sense is that whether it's a Michigan or a U.S.C. or Notre Dame or Harvard or Yale, if you were to look at the average quantitative statistics characterizing intercollegiate athletes -- S.A.T., A.C.T., class ranks -- you would find those probably on the average somewhat lower than the mean characterizing the institution," said James Duderstadt, the Michigan president. The A.C.T. is the American College Test.
"From my own experience at Yale, I know that characterizes the Ivys just as it does the Big Ten, just as it does most conferences," said Duderstadt, who played football at Yale.
Duderstadt said that 90 percent of Michigan's athletes were "indistinguishable from the normal students we admit."
"Probably 10 percent are at the lower end, and those are sometimes associated with the big-time sports," he said. "But in no case do we admit students who we do not believe have a capacity to graduate."
 
Moving Into Mainstream
 The question of admissions standards sharpens the debate among educators over bringing athletes into the mainstream of college life by eliminating, among other things, athletic dormitories and training tables. Some critics would add to that list eliminating special admission standards for athletes.
Others who argue for equal access to education contend that if special considerations are removed in one area they should be removed entirely.
"Universities have been making special considerations in a number of categories for years," said Reginald Wilson, senior scholar at the American Council on Education. "Athletics is just another category. If they're going to make a special case for eliminating special admissions for athletes, and leave all the others in place, it seems to me that's discriminatory."
 
Disparity for Minority Students
 Another issue raised by special admissions for athletes is the disparity that frequently exists between the energy and resources expended to bring in black athletes and black students who are not athletes.
William Davis, the chancellor at Louisiana State University, said that the university would bring 150 students from economically disadvantaged backgrounds on campus this summer and provide them with four months of intensive course work and academic counseling. The students will enroll at L.S.U. in the fall. Davis said the program, which will cost L.S.U. between $60,000 and $100,000 and is being financed by the athletic department, is an attempt to correct an imbalance.
According to The Chronicle's survey of 24 basketball and football players enrolled at L.S.U. in 1989, 15 were special admissions.
"What we were doing wasn't bad," Davis said. "We just need to do the same things for more people."

HEADLINE: Horses, Taxes And You

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
THE barns used to buzz with dentists at play, jolly men with gold chains and open hands. They loved to get their Guccis dirty and play Owner. If the trainer said that Doc's horse -- call it Perio Dough or LuvWendy -- needed special X-rays or a Calvin Klein blanket or a Florida trip so she could run with her own class, Doc would say, No problem, I'll make it up in gold crowns.
But those were the days when we all helped subsidize thoroughbred racing. The tax reforms of 1986 made it more difficult to deduct the routine expenses of horse racing -- perhaps $60-$100 per day for LuvWendy -- from other income. Since most horses don't turn a profit, a lot of dentists took up sculpture instead. I missed their energy and their capacity to fall in love with horses who, like them, were not considered well bred enough for the Big Events. 
 The breeders who supplied them with horses missed them even more than I did.
 "Two tax stories you can count on every April," says Lou DeFichy, a longtime handicapper and jockey agent. "The I.R.S. tries to scare us by floating one on how they're nailing cheaters, and the breeders try to scare us by putting out the story that the sport is going under."
It's julep time and we've been scared. If you have any money left over from taxes, it is your sentimental duty to bet tomorrow's Kentucky Derby, even if only with the family in front of the TV while some sportscaster actually says that there isn't a dry eye at Churchill Downs while they sing "My Old Kentucky Home." I always thought it was the juleps or taxes.
The big money, once in breeding, is now in parimutuel gambling, and most of the gamblers seem to be hanging around the Offtrack Betting shops in my neighborhood. I frequently go to OTB for intellectual inspiration; where else is everybody in the room either reading or writing? But they are not friendly people. For the past two days, I've tried to poll them on breeding, the Derby and the imminent demise of the bluegrass farms of Kentucky. I only get their attention with questions about the state's take of the gambling dollar ("Outrageous, pally") and the conditions of the OTB shop ("Look around, Jack"). It's a lousy atmosphere, dirty, crowded, smelling of failure, the waiting room for a ship that will never come in.
But the race track can be wonderful, ever sunny and green and wrongheadedly hopeful, which is why the dentists will come as long as you don't brush properly. There's always something going at the track, a long shot that can turn your life around. The rituals of the track mask the problems it shares with the world outside: the alcoholism and drug addiction among the grooms and hot walkers, the greed and political corruption that drive the frontside, the hardscrabble life of the everyday trainers and jockeys whose horses fill most of the low-rent races that draw the betting dollars that keep the game alive.
Lou DeFichy thinks the OTB bettors don't really care about horses; they could be betting on the cockroaches in the OTB rooms, he thinks, or on computerized Nintendo horse composites.
If breeding farms go bankrupt, there will be fewer horses. Some day, there may only be enough horses for a dozen live tracks in the country, beaming out TV races to bet on.
This is a scenario the horse-racing lobby is peddling. The lobby wants the tax laws re-revised. Outrageous, pally. I certainly don't want the Government to do anything for the sport of kings that's going to cost me money. Let all those whiney Kentucky breeders who made so much money in the good times go suffer the recession with everyone else.
 A small Maryland breeder, Cynthia McGinnis, agrees with all this in principle, but she has another solution. The prize money in racing is at the top, in the major stakes races run by very well-bred horses owned by very well-bred people. She estimates that 85 percent of the prize money goes to 10 percent of the horses. She thinks that if the purses were more equitably distributed down through the classes, with the first eight instead of four finishers getting a piece, not only would the game be saved, but so would a lot of lovely 2-year-old horses who might otherwise be sold for meat.
Cynthia McGinnis gets emotional here as she describes spirited young thoroughbreds whose owners can't afford them anymore being sold for $200 at auction for overseas consumption. They will be packed into trucks for a last ride to abattoirs in New Jersey where they will be slaughtered and quartered and frozen and loaded on planes to France.
Like all good racing tales, this one has a twist. Cynthia's passionate voice takes on a wicked edge. Do those French housewives cooking filly mignon, she wonders, know how much steroids and other drugs Americans pump into their race horses?
Next time I go to OTB, before the Belmont, I'll see if I can get their attention with that, Jack.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hansel, no longer a tax write-off. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Support A Toe Shoe

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Who was that standing and cheering, so full of pleasure and happiness?
Why, it was all of us, everybody in the huge ballroom, hundreds of us. And what were we cheering and hugging ourselves about? 
 The children, of course, and the young adult artists, but also something we had forgotten how to cheer and cherish -- all the talent and creativity, bounce, zest and desire of New York, the great city of New York. You heard me: the great city of New York.
It happened at a benefit. Can you believe that? Now everybody knows that benefits are necessary. Where else is the money going to come from for this philanthropy or that cause? Particularly now, when the government -- every one of them, city, state, Federal -- is cutting back to the bone and philanthropies, like hospitals or schools for talented children, or causes, such things as human rights or trees, will have to go, just too bad, if you don't kick in yourself.
Yes, but benefits have to be wearisome. Everybody knows that too. It is some kind of a law, and it is very useful. It prevents people at the benefit from getting above themselves just because they can afford a ticket or a table. Boredom is the great leveler, uniting everybody in the room -- donors, beneficiaries and waiters.
 This benefit was on 34th street, which is nowhere -- south of usual benefit country, but not south enough for SoHo chic. It was in the Manhattan Center Ballroom, long closed but now prettied up, fit for the honor of receiving and displaying the beauty and genius of the Dance Theater of Harlem, for which the benefit was organized.
The DTH is a dance troupe, a dance school, and it is an inspiration. Under Arthur Mitchell and his staff, it inspires children to value themselves enough to absorb the relentless disciplines of art. Then it teaches them to dance in such a way as to enrich their lives, and the souls of those who watch them.
Unhappily, New Yorkers do not get to watch them enough. Things are getting tighter for this glory of New York, as it is for the other glories of New York -- the other talent-schools, performing troupes, museums, libraries, concert halls without which this would not be a place worth visiting, and certainly not a place worth actually inhabiting.
Naturally, these are the first to go in times of budget-cutting. The city stands to lose scores of millions in ticket and tourist money, but that's how it goes.
Fortunately, New Yorkers like Gayfryd Steinberg and Elizabeth Ross Johnson Kennan, co-chairmen of the DTH evening, find it difficult to see the cost benefit of allowing the city to commit cultural suicide. But then they are not economists or government officials.
Some of the girls and boys who once danced at DTH have become ballet stars or managers. Others have become executives or doctors. Some of them testified on video that the discipline and self-mastery they learned at DTH stayed with them always and were part of their success in life.
That is obviously true. But the point is not that DTH turns all its youngsters into impresarios, CEO's or brain surgeons. It teaches children growing up in mean streets to find value in themselves, which of course is essential to being of any value to anybody else. Also, it teaches them to dance like crazy.
 I do not know the terminology ballet critics would use to describe what we saw but to me the whole performance was a dance of growth. Through the choreography, very small children grew into somewhat larger children, who became young adult dancers, who became principal dancers and Broadway stars, and then they were dancing together, all separate and all part of each other, in elegant ballet or shaking the place with stomp, as life and art moved them. In the darkened ballroom, it was a sunburst, an hour or so of sunburst that was pure, total New York.
Please, don't write to me telling me I am too old, too well paid, to be sentimental or too whatever to admit how horrible, poor and stenchy New York has become. I know, I know. But, listen, I also know a sunburst when I see one.
So call or write the Dance Theater of Harlem, 466 West 152d Street, New York, N.Y. 10031, or phone 212-967-3470. With very little money, you can support a toe shoe or give a whole year of them to a dancing child.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Powell Was Right

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Time and human disaster had already cast increasing doubt on President Bush's decision to go to war against Iraq. Now the doubts have further weight. For it appears that Gen. Colin Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, opposed the President's course.
So we are told in a new book by Bob Woodward of The Washington Post. He reports that General Powell favored economic and military pressures on Iraq, arguing that they would in time force Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait without war. 
 The knowledge that a military man as universally respected as General Powell advised against the war will surely strengthen the view, held now by a minority of Americans, that the war was unwise. At a minimum it will be harder to brand opponents as unpatriotic, as some Republicans have done.
Mr. Woodward's book, "The Commanders," uses his familiar technique of describing behind-the-scenes events in a matter-of-fact narrative, without identifying his sources. Like others, I have my doubts about that method. But here it has the ring of authority. The words and views ascribed to General Powell and other high officials fit what is known otherwise and sound authentic.
President Bush set the course for war when he announced on Nov. 8 that he was doubling the number of U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia. Just before that, according to the book, General Powell had argued to Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney and then to the President himself for an alternative strategy of containment.
Why did Mr. Bush reject that advice? The book offers no definitive answer to that crucial question, and Mr. Woodward tells us that he was not able to interview the President. But he quotes the President as telling General Powell: "I don't think there's time politically for that strategy."
What that meant turns on whether Mr. Bush, if he spoke those exact words, was using "politically" in an international or domestic sense. He might have meant that he thought the international coalition against Saddam Hussein would not hold together long enough to let sanctions and other pressures work. Or he might have meant that a long-haul strategy would not be popular with American voters.
The war option proved immensely popular. It sent Mr. Bush up to record figures in the polls and dispatched the critics who had called him indecisive and weak. That result echoed the precedents of Grenada and Panama.
One unanswered question about the Persian Gulf crisis has been whether U.S. intelligence predicted the invasion of Kuwait. Mr. Woodward says the Defense Intelligence Agency did, issuing a warning on July 31. He says that Secretary of Defense Cheney rejected that and a further urgent warning the next day, saying that the Iraqi troop buildup was a bluff.
But once Iraq invaded on Aug. 2, the book says, President Bush was consistently hawkish. It says that on Aug. 3 he ordered the Central Intelligence Agency to begin planning covert operations to overthrow Saddam Hussein, and formally authorized such operations on Aug. 15.
General Powell is described as having been distressed when the President took steps toward war without consulting him or having a discussion at a National Security Council meeting. One such occasion was when Mr. Bush said on Aug. 5 that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait "will not stand." That implied a sharp escalation of objective, from preventing an Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia to undoing the aggression on Kuwait. The book says General Powell learned of it by watching the President on television.
Once President Bush had really made his decision for war, by late November, General Powell loyally supported the policy. He and the President will no doubt now resist efforts to divide them. But the war strategy is going to be seen in a different light.
Would a containment strategy in fact have forced Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait in time? And how much time? According to the book, General Powell said it might take as long as a year or two, but it would work.
The alternative strategy looks better all the time now. The war took a dreadful human toll. It did long-lasting damage to the environment of the gulf. It has not produced new stability or security in the region. And it did not result in Saddam Hussein's fall.
General Powell was right the first time.

HEADLINE: The Start Treaty: Finish It or Lose It Richard Burt was chief negotiator in the strategic arms talks from June 1989 through last March.

BYLINE: By Richard Burt

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
After nearly a decade of negotiations, the United States and Soviet Union don't seem able to finish a treaty that would reduce their arsenals of long-range nuclear missiles, submarines and bombers. Only a few technical issues still remain. But if Washington and Moscow don't complete a treaty soon, the opportunity for nuclear arms control may be lost for years to come.
The conventional wisdom is that a strategic arms treaty is a cold war relic and thus no longer a U.S. foreign policy priority. Some say arms control is unnecessary because the Soviet Union's deteriorating economy already establishes a sufficient check on its future military growth. The conventional wisdom is wrong. It assumes that the Kremlin will neither be willing nor able to continue its aggressive nuclear modernization. Given the disturbing changes in the Soviet Union, which has 30,000 nuclear weapons, that could turn out to be a dangerous illusion. Start could play a vital role in shoring up nuclear stability in an unpredictable moment in Soviet history. 
 The nearly completed accord would do three important things. First, it would accomplish the core U.S. goal, which is to focus any nuclear reductions in areas of Soviet military advantage. Thus, the Soviets would be obliged to cut ballistic-missile warheads by more than 40 percent and their highly destabilizing SS-18 missiles by 50 percent. Second, the treaty would protect advanced military technologies, which will be vital for protecting U.S. interests in future conflicts. In particular, it would not constrain the deployment of highly flexible conventional cruise missiles. Third, the accord would establish a regime for intrusive monitoring and verification, including a dozen forms of on-site inspection.
These aspects of the treaty have not gone unnoticed by the Soviet generals and the military-industrial complex. With the balance of power shifting in favor of the military hard-liners, the hard-fought U.S. victories in Start are in jeopardy. For example, there is a growing debate in the Soviet military about the vigorous inspection system, with critics charging that it would enable U.S. inspectors to engage in "legalized espionage."
For the Soviet military, Start does not sufficiently limit new high-tech systems like super-accurate U.S. conventional cruise missiles. More importantly, the Soviet high command could decide to place new emphasis on its own nuclear arsenal in a strategy designed to offset U.S. technological superiority in conventional arms.
Such a development could not come at a worse time. With the military wielding growing influence in internal politics, it could mean Mikhael Gorbachev or any other Soviet leader would have little choice but to accede to a military push for scuttling Start and preserving and modernizing the huge Soviet nuclear arsenal.
We probably still have a "window" for completing the accord, especially now that differences on carrying out last year's accord on conventional forces in Europe seem to have been resolved this week. Mr. Gorbachev still wants a nuclear agreement. But the longer the talks drag on, the easier it will be for hard-liners to reopen agreed elements of the treaty and to win support for a stronger nuclear arms posture more generally.
A delay in finishing the accord would mean that a large portion of the existing treaty would have to be renegotiated under difficult circumstances. The result would surely be an inferior accord. At worst, a delay could mean no treaty at all, together with a more militarized -- and nuclearized -- Soviet foreign policy. We should not permit the Soviet generals to get their way. We should finish Start now.

HEADLINE: Albany's Fair-Weather Foolishness Makes a Rainy Day Worse

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Double Dose of Pain for the Poor" (The Week in Review, April 7) cites two causes for the budget crisis New York and most other states confront today: 
 (1) The "new federalism," which has shifted responsibility from Washington to the states, and
(2) a recession that has dried up tax revenues.
A third and equally important cause remains unmentioned. At the same time as states were having to increase their dollars to fill holes left by the withdrawal of Federal dollars, they were scrambling to decrease their own sources of dollars through policy decisions that cut state taxes or capped local taxes.
In 1987, the New York State Governor and Legislature, in the excitement to give back "the windfall" from Federal tax reform, cut personal and corporate taxes way beyond the windfall. Not only did the cuts benefit wealthier New Yorkers disproportionately, but also Albany then failed to capture the state's growth in personal and corporate income.
In the years of boom, we could have invested in our physical and service infrastructures. Instead, in these times of recession, the chickens have come home to roost, and New York State is cutting services and benefits that have, as your article points out, "a disproportionate effect on the poor."
 
PENELOPE W. PI-SUNYER
New York, April 16, 1991
 
The writer is executive director of the City Project, a not-for-profit organization concerned with health and human services in New York City.

HEADLINE: Nuclear Panel Says Reactor Can Restart, Giving Industry Lift

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
Deciding that one of the most ambitious nuclear power programs in the nation has solved longstanding design and management problems, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today approved the restart of a nuclear reactor at the Browns Ferry plant in Alabama.
The decision, which could open the plant's Unit 2 reactor within 10 days, was hailed today by the Tennessee Valley Authority, which owns and operates the reactor in northern Alabama, and by others in the nuclear power industry as a significant vote of confidence for the utility and the industry.
The reactor has been shut for more than six years, the longest shutdown for repairs in the history of the American civilian nuclear power program.
"The restart of any plant after an extended outage is a sign of an industry where problems are corrected after they are brought to light," said Steve Unglesbee, a spokesman for the United States Council for Energy Awareness, a nuclear power industry trade group in Washington.
Critics of nuclear power denounced the action, saying that the regulatory agency exempted Browns Ferry, just outside Athens, Ala., from a number of crucial safety guidelines, most having to do with the plant's ability to fight fires.
They noted that on Monday, a fire and explosion shut a nuclear power plant in Maine indefinitely. The accident occurred in a transformer and generator at the plant and did not release any radiation to the public.
Although there have been no new orders for nuclear power plants in 17 years, many operators, including the T.V.A., have indicated that they would like to build new plants this decade. The Bush Administration has begun an aggressive nuclear program within the Department of Energy aimed at designing a standard type of reactor that would be almost immune from meltdown. It also wants to streamline licensing of new plants.
The Administration has said it believes nuclear power is safe and produces less pollution than conventional power plants. The pollution argument is beginning to gain ground even among some environmentalists, who have generally opposed nuclear power but who increasingly view conventional power plants as heavy contributors to global warming and acid rain.
 
New Design Being Studied
 The Administration says one new reactor design being considered by the Energy Department for producing materials for nuclear weapons can also be applied to generating electrical power. The design under consideration would consist of four small reactors using tiny uranium pellets for fuel and would be cooled by hydrogen.
Records from the N.R.C. also show that 12 years after the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant near Harrisburg, Pa., utilities have improved operations at nuclear plants. Commercial nuclear power plants are experiencing fewer unplanned shutdowns, fewer accidents and incidents, and are more reliable than ever, the agency says. The number of unplanned shutdowns dropped to an average of 1.6 per plant in 1990 from 7.4 in 1980, according to the N.R.C.
How important these improvements are in swaying public opinion in favor of nuclear power remains to be seen.
Some environmentalists say that the mining, milling, and processing of uranium for fuel is a dirty and ecologically dangerous business. The Government also has been unable to reach a safe and permanent solution for disposing of dangerous radioactive wastes.
 
Staking Their Futures
 Nevertheless, large utilities, especially the T.V.A., are again beginning to stake their futures on generating electrical power from the atom.
"The decision today was a substantial milestone for this company," said Dan A. Nauman, T.V.A.'s senior vice president for nuclear power. "We worked so hard to get here. Since 1985, people have been working seven days a week to get to this point."
Political leaders in Alabama were pleased. State Representative Bobby Denton, a Democrat who lives about 40 miles from the plant, said: "It's great news for the Tennessee Valley region to be close to seeing the plant finally begin producing electricity again. Hopefully, Browns Ferry can now become the model program it was expected to be from the start."
Mayor Eddie Frost of Florence said: "Federal regulators would not allow the unit to be started again if there was a great risk. I'm confident all the problems have been solved." Florence is about 30 miles west of Athens.
Indeed, many residents of Alabama seem unalarmed, even uninterested. "To most people it seems like a done deal," said Pat Byington, executive director of the Alabama Conservancy, an environmental group in Birmingham. "Nobody is talking about it very much."
 
Early, Heady Days Recalled
 The Browns Ferry plant was once the world's largest commercial nuclear plant, a symbol of the atom's intoxicating power. Built at a cost of $1 billion, its first reactor opened in 1974. Two more followed in 1975 and 1977, generating 1,100 megawatts each. The Browns Ferry plant was seen by T.V.A. as the cornerstone of an empire of 17 nuclear power plants the utility planned to build across the South at a cost of tens of billions of dollars.
But soon after it opened, Browns Ferry also became a symbol of the capricious perils of nuclear energy. In March 1975, while the plant was operating at peak power, a workman searching with a candle for an air leak in the plant's cable room accidentally ignited a fire that caused more than $100 million in damage. The fire, which burned below the control room and nearly led to a catastrophe, was one of the worst civilian nuclear power accidents in the United States.
Over the next decade, a series of investigations by the N.R.C. and other agencies, including the Federal Bureau of Investigation, uncovered significant weaknesses in the design, management and operation of Browns Ferry and its sister, the Sequoyah nuclear plant north of Chattanooga, Tenn., which opened in 1981.
 
Three Mile Island Shock
 The inquiries, coupled with higher operating costs and the public uneasiness prompted by the 1979 accident at Three Mile Island, caused the T.V.A. nuclear program to collapse in the mid-1980's. Browns Ferry and Sequoyah were closed. Work on two other nuclear plants ceased. The adventure in nuclear power cost the T.V.A. at least $20 billion and nearly bankrupted the utility.
T.V.A. executives defended their decision to develop a nuclear power program as vital to the economic growth of the utility and the region it served. In 1988, after an expensive repair program, the T.V.A. gained permission from the N.R.C. to restart both reactors at the Sequoyah plant.
The repair program at Browns Ferry has been more expensive, costing more than $1.3 billion to date.
Unit 2 must undergo several more tests before final permission is granted by the N.R.C. administrator in Atlanta to restart it. Mr. Nauman said Unit 3 could be restarted in 1994 and Unit 1 sometime before the end of the decade. The N.R.C. said Browns Ferry was the last nuclear plant left in the United States to restart after an extended shutdown. Four others have been restarted after long shutdowns since 1985.
"It was kind of a black eye for the nuclear industry that Browns Ferry was down," said Mr. Nauman. "Bringing it back on line means it has been brought to today's standard of operation. This plant will produce electricity for a long time."
Critics of the industry said today that the N.R.C. appeared to be especially lenient in its consideration of Browns Ferry. The T.V.A. sought, and the four-member commission specifically granted, an exemption for Browns Ferry from several fire-safety requirements that were made into law as a result of the 1975 accident at the plant. For instance, the commission ordinarily requires nuclear plants to have automatic fire-suppression equipment in backup control rooms. Browns Ferry, though, will be able to use fire extinguishers.
The N.R.C. rules also ordinarily requires fire-fighting equipment for key pumps. Browns Ferry will not need to have the fire-fighting equipment, according to commission documents, because the T.V.A. felt that if a fire developed near the pumps it would not burn for very long.
"These exemptions are authorized by law and will not present an undue risk to the public health and safety," the N.R.C. wrote.
Several groups today said they were upset with the exemptions and the decision to restart Browns Ferry. "It is ironic that here is the plant that had a fire in March 1975 that led to these rules and now they are granted exemptions to fire-protection regulations," said Robert D. Pollard, the nuclear safety engineer at the Union of Concerned Scientists in Washington.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Marketing Executive Is New Head of Godiva

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
When David L. Albright took over as president of Godiva Chocolatier earlier this week, he brought with him more than 20 years of experience marketing greeting cards, paper towels, chocolate mousse, and most recently Pepperidge Farm cookies.
All that marketing expertise will come in handy increasing the popularity of the renowned but flagging Godiva chocolates. At $25 a pound, the chocolates cost several times more than a number of other fancy candies. 
 Mr. Albright, 43, was most recently vice president of marketing for the biscuit division of Pepperidge Farm, a unit of the Campbell Soup Company. At Godiva, also a Campbell Soup unit, he replaces Thomas H. Fey, who resigned.
"My whole career has been devoted to building brands," Mr. Albright said, "regardless of category or whether it was upscale or mass market."
Mr. Albright is still studying Godiva, so he has not decided on whether there will be any major changes there. But last year Godiva had sales of under $100 million, and Mr. Albright acknowledges that the recession has hurt sales, especially at department stores where Godiva chocolates are often sold. Mr. Albright would not discuss profits.
At Pepperidge Farm, Mr. Albright was instrumental in marketing the distinctive white packaging for Pepperidge Farm cookies. "We're very proud of that packaging," he said. "It's almost a Harvard Business School case study in signature marketing."
After majoring in marketing at Villanova University, Mr. Albright concentrated in marketing at Indiana University business school. In 1971, he got his first marketing position selling greeting cards for Hallmark. Later, he joined American Can, where he helped market Brawny paper towels and Northern bathroom tissue, and stayed when the businesses were acquired by the James River Corporation.
In 1984, Mr. Albright set off on his own and formed a frozen dessert company called Glacial Confections Inc. in Westport, Conn. He joined Pepperidge Farm in 1986.
One thing will not change in Mr. Albright's switch from cookies to candy. "Weight control is still going to be a problem," he said. "I'm going to be Wee Willie Wonka for the next couple of weeks."

HEADLINE: Colleges' Private Gifts Up 10 Percent in '90

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Private gifts to American colleges and universities totaled $9.8 billion in 1990, up 10 percent from the previous year, according to a survey by a private educational group.
The increase in donations from corporations, alumni and other private philanthropic sources followed a 9 percent rise in 1989 and a 3.5 percent drop in such giving in 1988, the organization, the Council for Aid to Education, said in issuing its annual estimate on Thursday. 
 Harvard University received the most private support of any single institution -- $213.5 million, equal to $8,743 a student, and up 15 percent from the 1989 level. Stanford University was second, attracting $202.2 million, or $14,325 a student, a gain of 7 percent from the preceding year.
Alumni giving totaled $2.54 billion, up 10 percent over the previous year. Corporate donations were up 11 percent to $2.17 billion, more than double the 5 percent increase in 1989.
Philanthropy from all sources has increased by 55 percent since 1984-85, according to the council. Adjusted for inflation, donations were up 21 percent from five years earlier.
Such giving "is a well-embedded tradition" that has consistently defied fluctuations in the economy and the stock market, said Priscilla Lewis, a spokeswoman for the nonprofit council.
"These days there is also a great deal of emphasis on education as a critical factor in national competitiveness. There is plenty going on now to sustain the tradition of giving to schools," she said.
But she noted that the latest survey covered donations received during the 1989-90 school year, slightly ahead of the recession that economists say began in July.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Lifted by Job Report; Gold Prices Show Declines

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced on world currency markets yesterday, bolstered by a better-than-expected report on United States unemployment.
Gold prices declined. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery fell $1.10 an ounce, to $353.90. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $353.50 an ounce, off $1.30. 
 Traders focused on the much-anticipated unemployment report for April, which showed the nation's jobless rate unexpectedly improved for the first time in nearly a year. The Labor Department said the jobless rate fell to 6.6 percent, from 6.8 percent in March.
Because traders had been positioned for more negative news, there was a flurry of technical buying of the dollar. "It was extremely busy and very volatile," said Kevin Lawrie, director of foreign exchange at the Bank of Boston's office in New York.
The evidence of economic improvement led some dealers to speculate that interest rates are probably headed no lower. Earlier in the week the Federal Reserve surprised financial markets by cutting the discount rate, and major banks followed by lowering their prime lending rate, a key interest rate that serves as the basis for a host of consumer and business loans.
Higher interest rates enhance the dollar by making dollar-denominated securities more attractive to investors.
Still, there was enough skepticism about the unemployment data to prevent the dollar from extending its gains even further. "Changes in the labor market itself may have been behind the aberrational drop in the rate," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with I D E A, a financial advisory concern. He said that many Americans might not be represented by the statistics because they had either given up looking for work or considered themselves self-employed.
In Tokyo, foreign exchange markets were closed for a national holiday. In London, the dollar was quoted at 138.50 Japanese yen. In New York the dollar settled at 138.85 yen, up from 138.15 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound sank to $1.6965, from $1.7170 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.6940 to buy 1, less expensive than Thursday's $1.7193.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ford Aids Workers

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 3

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company borrowed $150 million from a $473 million reserve left over from the 1987-90 labor agreement with the United Automobile Workers union to help pay benefits for laid-off workers. The transfer was announced earlier this week to local union officials by Ernest Lofton, U.A.W. vice president and head of the union's Ford Department, and confirmed by Ford.The auto maker and the union signed a contract last fall requiring Ford to pay up to $1.6 billion in supplemental unemployment benefits. The money will be paid out as needed.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Copper Prices Drop Sharply Amid Signs of Oversupply

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Copper futures prices settled at their lowest level in three months yesterday after briefly touching a 14-month low amid signs that stockpiles are expanding because of slack industrial demand.
On other commodity markets, precious metals also fell; oil futures rose; grains and soybeans were mixed, and livestock and meat futures were mixed. 
 Copper futures settled 1.30 cents to 3.40 cents lower on New York's Commodity Exchange, with the contract for delivery in May down 3.10 cents, at $1.033 a pound, the lowest daily settlement for near-term copper deliveries since Jan. 24.
The May contract price dipped to $1.0305 during the session, the lowest near-term copper price since Feb. 13, 1990. Copper last traded below $1 a pound in early February 1990.
 
Slide Started Last Year

The decline extended a slide that began late in the third quarter of 1990, when slowing industrial production translated into weakening demand for copper. The metal is widely used in the construction, automobile and electronics industries.
Traders disregarded yesterday's Government report of an improvement in the unemployment rate last month and focused instead on a 5,800-ton rise in London Metal Exchange warehouse stocks and a no-strike vote by unionized workers at the Chile Copper Company's Teniente mine unit.
Steve Platt, a metals analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said further selling was prompted by the market's failure to rally on news that a producer, Gecamines of Zaire, indicated that it would not meet its delivery commitments on 1991 shipments.
Since stockpiled supplies are abundant, "many people feel it's not going to make much of a difference," Mr. Platt said.
A weekly report of declining auto sales also weighed on prices, said Bette Raptopoulos, senior metals analyst at Prudential Securities Inc.
"The real factor is the uncertainty about the economy," she said.
Oil futures rose in thin trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, helped by strong chart signals and strength in the European heating oil market.
Crude oil settled 20 to 23 cents higher, with June at $21.37 a barrel; heating oil was 0.57 to 0.85 cent higher, with June at 54.73 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.30 to 0.61 cent higher, with June at 71.36 cents a gallon; natural gas was 1 cent lower to 1.1 cent higher, with June at $1.356 per 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: JOBLESS RATE FELL TO 6.6% IN APRIL, REVERSING A TREND

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
The Labor Department reported today that payroll jobs fell in April but at a much reduced pace and that the unemployment rate edged down two-tenths of a point, to 6.6 percent. The figures point over all to an economy that while probably not yet starting to recover from recession seems to be approaching its low point, analysts said.
They cautioned, however, that the decline in the unemployment rate, the first in almost a year, was probably an aberration. 
 The bond market fell on the news, apparently because traders believed it reflected a stabilizing of the economy, implying that the Federal Reserve would see no further need to cut interest rates to stimulate the economy. Although the lower unemployment number should be good for stocks because it implies economic improvement and stronger earnings, traders showed little reaction, apparently wanting to see further evidence. In a choppy day, the Dow Jones industrial average ended about where it began -- ahead 0.25 point, at 2,938.86.
 
 An Economist's Viewpoint
 For the economy at large, "the rate of decline is tapering off," said Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist for the PNC Financial Corporation in Pittsburgh.
Yet the labor market report, the first comprehensive survey of how the economy performed in April, had some statistics that were highly suspect, and even the White House did not speak of the recession's imminent end.
"The decline in the unemployment rate is good news," said Michael J. Boskin, the President's top economic adviser. "But you always want to see it confirmed over a span of time, not just for one month, particularly where there are some questions about the quality of the data over the past several months."
 
 Contrasting Surveys
 Mr. Boskin was referring to the Labor Department's survey of households, which showed that civilian employment soared by 644,000 last month, mostly because of increases for workers at all levels of government and for the self-employed.
This was in sharp contrast to a decline of 124,000 jobs reported in the department's survey of business and other non-farm payrolls. That survey showed that government jobs also shrank.
Eight of the 11 biggest industrial states showed improvement last month, but New York's unemployment rate showed a sizable increase -- to 7.5 percent, from 6.8. The New Jersey rate eased to 6.5 percent, from 6.8, a statistically insignificant change in light of the relatively small samples used in compiling rates for individual states.
Various analysts said the question was whether the household survey was inaccurate in February and March, when it showed the rate jumping sharply to 6.8 percent, from 6.2 percent, or whether the April decline to 6.6 percent was misleading.
Janet L. Norwood, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress that she found the April survey "difficult to interpret." She noted there were large sampling variabilities and urged analysts to wait for additional data. She said there should be at least two consecutive months of significant change -- more than a tenth of a point -- to signal a clear change in the direction of the unemployment rate.
Most economists had expected the rate to increase to 6.9 or 7 percent last month.
Although it is usual for the ranks of the self-employed to rise in recession, as people who lose jobs go into business for themselves, the report showed a stunning increase of 321,000 last month. In addition, 235,000 workers were recorded as going to work for governments at a time of widespread budget stringency.
 
 Breaking Down the Figures
 The household survey also showed that the number of people who had lost their last jobs, as opposed to quitting them, shrank by 175,000, after rising steadily since the summer. The newly unemployed, those without jobs for fewer than five weeks, fell 228,000, and those without jobs for 5 to 14 weeks fell 159,000.
Unemployment was down somewhat for all major population groups except blacks, whose rate rose to 12.6 percent, from 12.3 percent in March and 11.8 percent in February.
The payroll survey, which is usually considered the more reliable in depicting the state of the economy, showed that the number of goods-producing jobs fell 66,000 and service jobs fell 58,000. This 124,000 total decline was well under the revised March number of 241,000. The new March figure is 35,000 more than initially reported.
Over all, the April decline in payroll jobs was just half the average of the three preceding months.
 
 Less of a Downturn in Factories
 The diminished decline in the number of factory workers was even more pronounced: the 42,000 jobs lost in April compare with an average drop of 115,000 during the preceding five months, the department noted.
Hefty losses, however, occurred in industrial machinery and transportation equipment, even though 15,000 auto workers returned to plants that had been temporarily closed.
Construction jobs fell 20,000, as hiring was short of seasonal expectations for the second straight month, while the number of retail trade jobs fell 40,000, after a combined loss of 180,000 in February and March. The small gain of 4,000 in the financial industry was the first rise since August, and business services gained for the first time since September.
Average weekly hours worked in the private sector edged down by six minutes, but factory hours and factory overtime each gained that amount. Today's payroll report also disclosed that the index of aggregate weekly hours retreated for the second straight month -- to 121, from 121.4.
 
 Adding to Payrolls
 Reflecting large increases from depressed levels, 44.7 percent of private industries added workers last month, up from 36.9 percent, and 41.4 percent of manufacturing industries added workers, up from 30.2 in March.
Average hourly earnings rose five-tenths of 1 percent, to $10.29, the second straight substantial increase.
According to the household survey, 117,398,000 Americans had civilian jobs last month, and 8,274,000 were unemployed, a reduction of 298,000 in the ranks of those without jobs.
Counting military personnel, the jobless rate fell three-tenths of 1 percent, to 6.5 percent. A Labor Department official said that redeployments involving the Persian Gulf had no significant effect on the figures.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Plunge in Confused Day

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates soared yesterday as prices of Treasury bonds plunged in what dealers called a most confused session. The confusion stemmed from outwardly conflicting Government employment data for April.
The "household" survey, for example, showed a rise of 644,000 non-farm jobs last month. That meant the nation's unemployment rate dropped to 6.6 percent in April from 6.8 percent in March. This was the first decline since May 1990, when the jobless number dipped to 5.3 percent from 5.4 percent. 
 Because any positive economic news hurts the market in bonds and other fixed-income securities, the price of the Treasury's benchmark 30-year bonds plunged almost a point, or $10 for each $1,000 of face value, soon after trading began.
 
 Recovery Loses Force

But the same Labor Department report said its "establishment" survey found that the number of nonfarm jobs had dropped by 144,000 in April. When this figure was culled from the report, bond prices began to recover some of their losses. But dealers said the recovery soon lost force, in large part because bond futures prices in Chicago were under pressure all day.
Late in the session the Treasury's bellwether long bonds, the 7 7/8 percent issue maturing in February 2021, were being offered at 96 5/32, down a stunning 1 3/32. This caused their yield to climb to 8.22 percent, from 8.11 percent the day before and 8.20 percent a week ago.
Thus after all the sound and fury over the wave of interest rate cuts during the week, the yield on the long bonds was still up by 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, for the week.
Prices of shorter Treasury maturities posted smaller losses, while the discount rates on bills were basically unchanged on the day.
The sudden rebound in yields caused a sharp reduction in offerings of corporate debt, which had been soaring during the week as companies sought to take advantage of falling borrowing costs.
The interest rate cuts began on Tuesday, when the Federal Reserve cut both its discount rate to member banks by half a point, to 5 1/2 percent, and the more important Federal funds rate, which banks charge one another for temporary loans, to 5 3/4 percent from 6 percent. The next day, many large commercial banks cut their prime rate to 8 1/2 percent from 9 percent.
Yesterday, the Fed moved aggressively to drain reserves from the banking system as the funds rate slipped below its presumed new target of 5 3/4 percent. As demand for the funds slackened before the weekend they traded down to 5 1/2 percent at the close.
"The confusion caused by the April employment numbers couldn't have come at a worse time because the bond market is always edgy before a Treasury refunding," said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president and credit money market specialist at Dean Witter Reynolds. "The market was already a bit edgy because of the record $37 billion of Treasury paper scheduled for auction at next week's refunding."
On Tuesday, the Treasury will auction $13.5 billion of three-year notes, which traded on a when-issued basis to yield 7.12 percent, up from 7.05 percent the day before. On Wednesday, $11.75 billion of 10-year notes are up was sale and these traded on a when-issued basis to yield 8.02 percent, compared with 7.92 percent the day before.
 
Auction Set for Thursday

The auction of $11.75 billion of what will become the Treasury's new benchmark long bonds is set for Thursday. Yesterday, these bonds were traded on a when-issued basis to yield 8.21 percent, up from 8.10 percent. In all, a record $37 billion of new Treasury debt will be auctioned. At the last quarterly refunding in February, a then record $34.5 billion of Treasury paper was auctioned.
Josh K. Stiles, senior North American bond market analyst at IDEA, international economic consultants, said that "besides the confusion caused by the different household and establishment jobs numbers and the normal bearish sentiment before a refunding, there was one bit of good news for the bond market. The growth in the nation's money supply ended abruptly in April. The steady growth in the money supply was supposed to provide fuel for the economic recovery."
Although one month's data does not signal a trend, Mr. Stiles noted, the M-2 measure of the money supply dropped by $4.5 billion in April. Wall Street economists had expected $3 billion in further growth.
 
Transamerica Notes Priced
 Although the pace of corporate debt offerings slackened, some important "names" were priced. These included $300 million of 8.30 percent noncallable notes, due in 1995, of the Transamerica Finance Corporation, a unit of the Transamerica Corporation. A Goldman, Sachs & Company syndicate priced the notes at par, thus offering a yield of 93 basis points above comparable Treasury notes.
Underwriters led by Salomon Brothers priced $100 million of General Motors Corporation noncallable notes, due in 2003. The notes have a 8 7/8 percent coupon and were priced at 99.50 to yield investors 8.944 percent, or 94 basis points more than like Treasury maturities.
The Centex Corporation offered $100 million of 9.05 percent noncallable senior notes, due in 1996, priced at par through a group led by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

HEADLINE: Stocks Seesaw; Dow Rises by 0.25

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
After three good days, Wall Street had a tough time yesterday deciding what to do; conflicting road signs kept investors guessing.
So, after a choppy day that toppled the Dow Jones industrial average 14 points, lifted it 12, brought it down again 14 and lifted it again 19, the Dow ended about where it began -- ahead 0.25, to 2,938.86. 
 Strong rate cuts from the Fed and subsequent reductions in the prime rate lifted the Dow blue chips 26.48 points for the week.
This brought the Dow within 65 points of its all-time high of 3,004.46 set a little more than two weeks ago.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange dropped to 158.2 million shares, from 187.1 million on Thursday, and the 748 advances nearly matched the 749 declines. Sixty-eight stocks climbed to 52-week highs and only five dropped to 52-week lows.
 
 Heavy Program Selling
 Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, reported heavy computerized selling near the opening and strong program buying near the close. But over all, it said, the activity clipped the Dow 8 points.
Wall Street, though, is now in a quandary whether to get in or get out.
On one hand, the Labor Department reported yesterday that the unemployment rate fell last month to 6.6 percent from 6.8 percent in March, or more than expected. That should be good for stocks because it implies economic improvement and stronger earnings. But traders want more evidence.
On the other hand, traders said the Fed drained money from the banking system yesterday to raise the Fed funds rate that banks charge each other to 5 3/4 percent, and that is bad for stocks.
Still, in their current strategy report, Steven G. Einhorn and Abby Joseph Cohen, co-chairmen of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said, "We do not believe that the bull market is over." They said stocks can continue to gain for these reasons:
*Foreign central banks will ease monetary policy.
*Inflation and interest rates in the United States will be held down by weak global growth, falling foreign rates and a rising dollar.
*Economic and profit recovery in the United States could be accompanied by a modest improvement in inflation.
In his weekly report, Greg A. Smith, chief investment officer for Prudential Securities, made a case for another 10 percent rise in stocks.
Without giving names, he recommended banks, insurers, financial agencies, brokerage firms and mutual fund companies.
In one of the day's best gains, Kellogg rose 5 1/2, to 96. Prudential Securities had issued a report on the company, William Blair & Company raised its earnings estimate and Business Week ran a favorable article.
I.B.M. tumbled 2 1/4, to 103 5/8, with 3.2 million shares changing hands after Rick Martin of Prudential Securities recommended its sale and Stephen Smith of Paine Webber cut his earnings estimate.
Storage Technology rose 3 1/2, to 45 1/4, in heavy trading despite the sale of 3.45 million shares at $41 apiece. Stephen Cohen of Soundview Financial, which follows technology stocks in Stamford, Conn., argued that the offering would not dilute the earnings per share because the 8 percent additional stock would be covered by interest on the money raised.

HEADLINE: Businesses in Maryland Gain Priority on Kuwait Contracts

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
The State of Maryland and the Government of Kuwait signed an agreement today to give Maryland companies an advantage in the competition to win contracts to rebuild the sheikdom.
Under the agreement, signed in Annapolis, the state will send a volunteer team of 200 medical personnel and engineers to Kuwait for at least two weeks and, in return, Kuwait will look first to Maryland manufacturers, shippers and service companies as it goes about recovery and repairing war damage. 
 "It doesn't mean we'll get all the contracts," said J. Randall Evans, the state's Secretary of Economic and Employment Development, "but it does mean that if two bids are roughly the same the Maryland manufacturer or engineer or shipping company will get the nod. It means we'll be producing more and employing more and it means more goods will be leaving from our docks and runways.
"There's a tremendous amount of business out there, maybe five years' worth, and the competition for it by companies all over the United States is very intense. We think we're the early bird and will get lots of worms."
Neither Maryland nor Kuwaiti officials could put a dollar figure on how much the agreement might eventually mean to Maryland businesses.
The agreement came about after Maryland's Governor, William Donald Schaefer, a Democrat, traveled to Washington and Kuwait offering medical and engineering volunteers to help Kuwait. He suggested that Kuwait put Maryland ports and companies at the top of their lists when post-war recovery began.
"What really touched me were the humanitarian aspects," the Kuwait Ambassador to the United States, Sheikh Saud Nasir al-Sabah, said today in the Maryland capital. He said that while his country would funnel business contracts to Maryland companies "as much as we can" it also expected to do business with companies elsewhere.
Numerous American business representatives have visited Kuwait in search of contracts, but Mr. Schaefer is the only Governor to make the journey.
"The agreement means that the people of Maryland will join with the people of Kuwait in a special relationship," he said today.
