HEADLINE: Owners, Renters and Strikers Count Costs After Settlement

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Early last week, as service workers wearing red-and-white strike placards began patrolling the sidewalks in front of Manhattan apartment buildings, an official of another New York union took stock of the situation. "It's kind of refreshing," she said. "This is a conventional, old-fashioned strike. Management isn't hiring replacements; it's not trying to break the union. The issues are simply economic."
For those with a financial stake, those economic issues were of considerable importance, of course. Yesterday, with the end of the 12-day strike by doormen, elevator operators, porters and handymen Thursday night, residents and union members began calculating their losses and gains. 
 For members of Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union, the immediate gain was clear-cut: a wage increase averaging 4 percent a year for the next three years. But since service workers in about 1,400 Manhattan buildings were on strike for almost two weeks, their gain is somewhat undercut. Each worker lost almost $1,000 in pay during the strike, and the raise in the first year of the new contract will be a flat $832.
 
Labor's Effect on Costs Varies
 For owners of cooperative and condominium apartments, the workers' raise means higher operating costs. But for many owners, the increase in the monthly maintenance fee could be relatively low, at least this year.
No co-op is precisely like another, and a host of factors will determine how much the settlement will affect anyone's actual maintenance cost.
Labor accounts for about 25 percent of the operating expenses of most cooperatives and condominiums, several real-estate lawyers and industry executives said.
The building workers will get a $16-a-week raise in the first year of the contract, or 3.46 percent. Owners will also pay an additional 1.5 percent for workers' benefits, so the total cost in the first year will be 5 percent.
 
Increase Often Factored In
 That 5 percent rise in labor costs thus represents a 1.25 percent increase in the overall operating cost. So a co-op or condo owner who pays a $1,000 maintenance fee each month might pay $12.50 a month more.
The actual increase will depend on many things, among them whether a co-op board has already allowed for the cost of the new labor contract in its budget. Many boards estimated in their 1991 budgets that the settlement cost would be 5 percent, said Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Association of New York Cooperatives. That would mean no added increase in the current maintenance fee because of the labor contract.
Many buildings also saved money during the strike because they did not have to pay their employees.
The long-term cost of the three-year contract is even more difficult to estimate. The annual increases are compounded. In addition, Ms. Rothman noted, owners will pay the cost of the first year's increase for all three years and the cost of the second year's increase for two years. She calculated that the cumulative result of the agreement on labor costs by the third year would be slightly more than 16 percent.
 
Simplicity of the Issues
 Most renters are covered by rent-stabilization laws and their maximum rent increases are set each June by the city's Rent Guidelines Board. It takes into account fluctuations in many operating costs, from water bills to taxes to labor, in setting rent guidelines.
For many union leaders, the larger significance of the strike lay in its simplicity.
There was considerable relief in having an old-fashioned strike, in which workers and owners battled over something as straightforward as the size of a raise. The building workers strike followed a decade in which many major labor disputes -- from the Federal air-traffic controllers' to Eastern Airlines' to Greyhound's to The Daily News's -- involved cataclysmic struggles between managements bent on curbing, if not destroying, the power of their unions and labor organizations that believed theywere fighting for survival.
Nothing so monumental was at stake in the discord between the apartment owners and the service workers' union.
"In normal strikes, there is often great acrimony between employers and workers, between those who have services withdrawn and workers looking to support their families," said Dennis Rivera, president of the hospital workers' union, Local 1199. But he said he was struck by "the sense of identification of the tenants with the striking porters and handymen."

HEADLINE: CS Holding Cuts Dividend; To Sell 20% of Credit Suisse

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
CS Holding has cut its dividend by nearly a third and announced plans to sell a 20 percent stake in Switzerland's third-largest bank, Credit Suisse. The harsh measures followed a 1990 loss of $587 million at CS First Boston, the New York investment bank that is a unit of CS Holding.
The losses mostly stemmed from reserves set aside to cover potentially bad "bridge" loans for leveraged buyouts. While a big loss was expected, its size prompted CS Holding to take tough steps to bolster capital levels. 
 CS Holding's earnings plunged 77 percent in 1990, to 192 million Swiss francs ($132 million), mostly because of the loss at CS First Boston.
CS Holding cut its dividend to 75 Swiss francs ($51.89), from 110 Swiss francs.
 
Improvement Is Seen
 Wall Street analysts said that CS First Boston was likely to benefit from the turnaround in global stock markets and improvement in the economy, which many economists expect later this year.
For CS First Boston, "last year must be classified as a catastrophe which cannot be repeated," Peter Kuepfer, a member of the CS Holding executive board, said at the company's annual news conference in Zurich on Thursday.
CS Holding said it was confident that profits would revive in 1991 because of improving securities markets and what it viewed as a likely early recovery from the global recession.
"The results of all group units during the first four months lead us to the conclusion that our optimistic assessment is justified," Mr. Kuepfer said.
John Keefe of the Lipper Analytical Securities Corporation agreed that CS First Boston should have higher earnings this year, noting that the entire industry was rebounding.
 
'Junk' Bonds a Worry

"When it rains hard enough, everyone gets wet," Mr. Keefe said. "Trading profits are strong, and there's a buildup in equity underwriting. The entire industry should have a better year."
But he added that "junk bonds," high-yield, high-risk debt securities, might continue to be a worry for CS First Boston.
CS First Boston, 60 percent owned by CS Holding, was hard hit by the collapse of the junk bond market. It had earned $11 million in 1989.
In December, CS First Boston completed a corporate revamping that included selling an additional $300 million equity stake to CS Holding. It also sold part of its bridge-loan portfolio to CS Holding last year. In bridge loans, the investment banker provides financing while more permanent financing for a deal is obtained. But if the deal goes sour, the investment banker is left with the bad loan.
First Boston pared its staff by about 300 in 1990 and now employs 3,700.
The firm told employees last week that it was reorganizing its investment-banking operation to de-emphasize mergers and acquisitions and focus on the capital markets.
Merger activity has plunged since the 1980's as financing virtually dried up after the junk bond market collapse and banks tightened their lending.

HEADLINE: Wall St. Is Suddenly Farsighted

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
Not long ago, the Wall Street definition of long-term planning was "deciding what to do after lunch." But lately, the Street's fascination with a fast buck seems to be cooling.
Brokerage houses and mutual funds are counseling patience, telling clients to invest for the long term. They are emphasizing products, like municipal unit investment trusts and securities from bankrupt companies, that take longer to ripen profitably than those that dominated the 1980's. As experiments, some firms are changing brokers' compensation to discourage hasty trading. 
 A new study from Salomon Brothers indicates that long-term investors are by far the most likely to reap dependable gains from stocks. One mutual fund is even rewarding longer-term investors with the proceeds from an "impatience tax" on those who cash out quickly.
 
 Some Call It Cant

Some on Wall Street question whether the stress on longer horizons is any more than advertising cant, coming when few investment advisers can point to impressive results in the shorter term.
"Last year was not a great year for investors in the aggregate," said Douglas Loudon, a senior vice president at the Scudder, Stevens & Clark mutual fund group. "So a cynic would say, 'Get people to focus on five-year numbers because your one-year numbers don't look very good.' "
In recent advertisements, most of the top mutual fund houses have indeed begun to emphasize long-term objectives and performance records.
"Fidelity knows that outstanding performance doesn't just happen overnight," says a recent advertisement by Fidelity Investments. "That's why we manage over $40 billion in stock fund assets for long-term results." The Twentieth Century Investors chimes in, "Guess who has two of the three top-ranked funds for long-term performance?" And the Franklin Growth Fund urges customers to "consider an investment which has the potential to grow with your long-term needs."
But some mutual fund innovations do go beyond advertising copy. The Genesis Fund, a Neuberger & Berman mutual fund specializing in the stocks of smaller companies, has recently run advertisements that warn, "We discourage short-term investments in Genesis Fund."
That discouragement comes in the only form Wall Street truly respects: a 2 percent penalty on investors who withdraw from the fund in less than a year.
The notion of an impatience tax is not new. It appeared after the 1987 crash, when some mutual-fund families imposed extra exit fees to drive away "market timers," those who try to profit from each spasm in the market by shifting their money among mutual funds. But in a novel twist, amounts taken from those who quickly cash out of the Genesis Fund are not kept as a management fee but go back into the fund for the benefit of all remaining shareholders.
Stanley Egener, president of the Neuberger & Berman Management Company, said a key reason for the penalty was that the fund's portfolio of smaller stocks lacked great liquidity or the ability to absorb sudden binges of buying or selling without sharp price movements. With small-capitalization stocks, Mr. Egener said, "you just don't want the hot money." Patience is essential if small-company investors are to avoid selling into a panic or buying during a boom, he added.
Mr. Loudon of Scudder, Stevens & Clark said his firm asked clients who too frequently zipped in and out of its funds to take their business elsewhere. The last decade rewarded debt, the fuel that fed the takeover engines, he continued; the coming decade is more likely to reward financial strength and stability.
"We're early in the development of this phenomonon," Mr. Loudon said. "But we all realize that the 1990's will be very different from the 1980's."
 
 General Illiquidity

Illiquidity affects other high-profile investments besides small stocks these days. Unlike the "rumor stocks" of the last decade, which could soar on whispers of possible takeovers, many of today's investment options simply do not offer overnight profits.
Distressed securities -- the stocks, bonds, notes and other obligations of financially weak or bankrupt companies -- are expected to be popular with money managers in the years ahead. But shaky stocks and defaulted bonds may be caught for years in the bankruptcy process before investors can reap any rewards. And the market for distressed securities remains small and illiquid, where trades must be made slowly and gracefully to avoid huge price swings.
The Wall Street professionals who are marketing these bankruptcy-based investments to pension funds and other institutional investors preach a message that differs from the quick-buck sales pitches of the past: Don't invest, they say, unless you're prepared to stay the course for years before you can collect your profits.
 
 Interest in Unit Trusts

There are some subtle shifts in the treatment of individual investors as well. Brokerage houses are seeing renewed interest in tax-exempt unit investment trusts, first marketed back in the 1960's.
Unlike a tax-exempt mutual fund, whose manager is paid a yearly fee and can alter the portfolio as he sees fit, a unit trust is essentially a fixed package of municipal bonds with a high entry fee but no continuing management expense. It appeals primarily to investors who favor a buy-and-hold strategy. In the first two months of 1991, purchases were up nearly 60 percent over the corresponding period last year, according to the Investment Company Institute.
Some firms are experimenting with new ways to pay their retail brokers, pegging compensation to the value of assets in a customer's account, rather than to the amount of the customer's trading. This approach, if widely adopted, would make Wall Street's commitment to long-term investment goals more credible, since brokers would no longer be tempted to encourage short-term strategies for the sake of higher commissions.
 
 Fewer Bargains in Stocks

The need to invest clients' money even after a run-up in stocks also moves Wall Street to take the longer view. In the last six months, portfolio managers who traditionally buy only bargain-priced stocks were flooded with fresh cash, invested by people eager to get into the booming market.
But as money flowed in, there were few bargain-priced stocks to be had. Some of these managers privately predict much longer waits to reap the kind of gains on their recent, expensive purchases than they are accustomed to getting on cheaper stocks.
Many investors have become long-term market participants by necessity, as the recession and real estate slump have put quick profits out of reach.
Those with huge sums in real estate, through mortgage bonds or shares in real estate holding companies, must either postpone their paydays or give up a chunk of their anticipated profits. Likewise, shareholders in some troubled banks now realize they must ride out the storm in the financial system before they can bail out at a profit.
The recession further reduces Wall Street's hopes for quick returns, said Richard Linowes, assistant professor of management at the Kogod College of Business Administration at the American University.
"The recession has been sobering but helpful in the long term," Professor Linowes said, referring to Wall Street firms. "It has led to revising the investment philosophy of their investors. There is a push toward more prudent investments of long-term value."
If this shift in mood turns out to be more than a matter of advertising, a recent study confirms that Wall Street could become not only more civilized but also more profitable. While it is widely held that stocks offer higher returns than less-risky investments like bonds, the study shows that short-term investors have a much lower chance of collecting these premium returns than those who are more patient.
"We've come off a period in the 80's when the returns were so fantastic, that it seems inconceivable to suggest that equities would give you lousy returns over a one-year period," said Martin Liebowitz, a managing director at Salomon Brothers. "But that is the case."
 
 Study of Investor Options

In a study he wrote with his Salomon colleague, Stanley Kogelman, Mr. Liebowitz examined the options open to investors who want to be nearly certain of earning at least 3 percent on their money.
The study showed that those with a one-year investment horizon would be ill advised to put more than 30 percent of their portfolios into stocks, which are relatively volatile. This allocation would be very low by Wall Street standards. But those willing to invest for five years could profitably place up to 85 percent in stocks, reaping higher, long-term returns.
In effect, the Salomon Brothers study found, short-term buyers of risky investments, including common stocks, are like workers who take on risky jobs but quit just before becoming vested in a generous pension plan meant to offset those risks.
"It is really kind of surprising how badly this volatility can bite you over the short term," Mr. Liebowitz said. "If you want to capture the premium returns offered by stocks, the longer the time period over which you invest, the higher the likelihood that you will realize the fruits of that investment."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Long-Term Payoffs of Stocks"
 
A new study by Salomon Brothers shows that the stock market, which can be risky for the short-term investor, is more reliable over the long term. How much can investors allocate to stocks if they want to be 90 percent certain of earning at least 3 percent on their investments? The answer depends on investment horizons.
 
Term and percentage of assets to be invested in stocks:
 
One year: 30%
Three years: 60%
Five year: 85%
Six years or more: 100%

HEADLINE: Spending and Learning;
Money's Role Questioned in Schools Debate

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

 BODY:
Five years ago Samuel Billups, principal of Walbrook High School in Baltimore, took a hard look at his school and winced. Test scores were low and students, in his words, "came out not really prepared for anything."
So he created a small school within his high school, with much more teacher attention to students and a stripped-down curriculum. Now those students' test scores, grades, attendance and motivation are soaring. 
 The total price tag: $125,000 over four years to retrain and inspire teachers, plus a little more for new books.
Walbrook High's experience goes to the heart of a central issue facing American education today: Is money the key to improving schools? The answer continues to polarize those who would revamp American education.
Saying "dollar bills don't educate students," President Bush did not offer many when he outlined his strategy two weeks ago for fixing American schools. Without changes in the way schools work, his advisers argue, more money will accomplish little.
 
Advice for Budgets
 Clearly, money alone is no panacea. Spending on education has steadily risen over the last decade; scores have not. Many successful private and parochial schools pay teachers less and spend less on students than public schools. Swollen public school bureaucracies absorb money before it reaches the classroom.
But it is also evident that there are changes that money can buy. Many educators and politicians say Mr. Bush should have sought much more money to fight the poverty and family disintegration that overwhelm many schools, to help prepare poorer students for school and keep them on track once they get there, and to reduce the gap between rich and poor schools.
Those like Mr. Billups who have actually saved failing schools offer this perspective: Spend money to retrain teachers, reduce class size and buy new technology; save money by reducing educational bureaucracy and eliminating, if economy demands it, electives and extracurricular activities.
"I like to say this about school improvement," Mr. Billups said. "Design the Cadillac, although you end up buying the Ford."
Critics of American schools from President Bush down like to cite a damning statistic: Spending on education increased by 33 percent after inflation in the 1980's, without any marked improvement in American schools.
"In general the educators would have you believe that the only thing that really makes a difference is money," said Marc S. Tucker, president of the National Center on Education and the Economy, a research institute that advocates overhauling schools. "There's an increasing crowd of people out there who say, 'Wait a minute; we have been putting out more and more money and we don't see a change in the results.' And they're right."
But many educators argue, and Mr. Tucker agrees, that such statistics do not account for the fact that today many more students are coming to school poorer, worse-prepared and speaking less English than in the past few decades. Immigration rates soared nationwide in the 1980's, as did poverty rates.
Take the Rochester school district. The percentage of students who arrive in kindergarten testing well below average has leaped to 53 percent, from 23 percent, in 20 years, district statistics show. The number of students speaking limited English doubled from 1986 to 1990, and the number of poor children, those who qualified for free or reduced-price lunches, tripled in the 1980's.
 
<Looking for Links
 Debates on whether money helps tend to get bogged down because of the competing statistics and studies. If per-pupil expenditures are measured, the United States is among the top spenders on education internationally; yet it falls near the bottom if the studies measure education spending by a percentage of national income.
The same arguments swirl around research studies that try to trace the connection between spending and student performance. In one widely cited paper, Eric A. Hanushek of the University of Rochester reviewed 187 studies and found no consistent statistical links between teacher salaries, smaller classes and high-scoring students.
Educators reply that most studies do not factor in teachers' abilities and attitudes. Instead, they point to a study of 900 Texas school districts serving two million children by Ronald F. Ferguson of John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. Mr. Ferguson factored in teacher quality, measured by how well teachers scored on required state tests. He found that higher teacher salaries attracted better-qualified teachers, who in turn produced students who scored higher in tests.
But, Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, said, that means good teachers can produce dramatic results with smaller classes, while a teacher who simply uses the same methods for a small class as a large one will not.
As director of the Coalition of Essential Schools, a network of about 150 schools that aim to raise intellectual standards through innovative teaching, Theodore R. Sizer has watched schools make broad improvements, and he, too, said that regardless of how much was spent "none of that is worth a hill of beans unless teachers think differently."
 
The Budgets
Fat Public Schools, Lean Church Ones
The real question, even the severest critics of current education spending agree, is not whether money makes any difference, but where and how well it is being spent.
"This does not say that there aren't some situations in which money is very effective," Mr. Hanushek of the University of Rochester said, "because there are. This says, we can't guess beforehand whether the money will be used effectively or not. The way we run schools now, just providing more money is not going to assure us of better success."
Among the chief culprits, critics argue, are money-eating educational bureaucracies and a web of Federal, state and local regulations.
Compare the public and parochial schools. With fewer bureaucrats and lower-paid teachers, many Roman Catholic schools turn out students who often score higher than public school students on standardized tests.
In New York City, for example, Catholic schools spend about $1,200 on each pupil, as against $7,107 in the public schools. Catholic school teachers in the Bronx earn about $22,000 a year, said Nora Murphy, director of public relations for the Archdiocese of New York's education department. Public school teachers in District 11, in the northeast Bronx, earn, on average, $37,500, said the district superintendent, Frank Arricale.
One reason the salaries in the Catholic schools are lower is that teacher turnover there is higher than in the public schools, leading to more teachers who are newer and are paid less.
District 11, which serves mostly middle-class and working-class students, has one of the smallest district offices in New York, but it still has 16 officials, Dr. Arricale said. They include a budget director, a business manager, a director and assistant director of mathematics and directors of special education, language arts, early childhood programs and programs for gifted students.
 
Heavy on Bureaucracy
 And, to make sure the district obeys all the regulations from Federal, state and city governments, the superintendent has a director of compliance and a director of funded programs.
Most of the 32 school districts in New York City have similar, if not larger, staffs. And supervising them are 3,930 central Board of Education employees.
By contrast, just 33 people oversee the entire network of Catholic schools in New York City. There is no separate district office for the Bronx. Every Catholic school hires its own teachers, and every parish hires its own principal. The same types of jobs are filled as in each public school district, but with fewer layers of bureaucracy.
Private schools are not bound by the same government regulations as public schools, nor do they serve as diverse a group of students. About 100 of the 110,000 Catholic school students in New York City are in small special-education programs, Ms. Murphy said. Catholic schools lack the resources to educate the severely handicapped students whom public schools are required to serve, she added, and, therefore, they do not accept them.
On the other hand, New York City, which has nearly one million students in its public schools, spent an average of $16,746 last year on each of its 119,838 special-education students.
 
Spending Outside the Classroom
 Custodians, often among the highest-paid employees of the public school system, are not unionized in the city's Catholic schools and thus earn less. Public schools are required to provide transportation for students who live a certain distance away and to bus students to desegregate schools. For Catholic schools, providing transportation is an individual decision; some do and some do not.
"A mass educational system is expensive," Dr. Arricale said.
But it is clear that in public schools a far higher percentage of money goes to bureaucracy than it does in private ones. Almost half of all money spent in public schools goes for expenses other than those in the classroom; only 58.5 percent of their budgets in 1988-89 went directly to teacher salaries, benefits and classroom supplies, according to the National Center for Education Statistics.
Food services, interscholastic athletics and other non-instructional services made up 4.4 percent of school budgets. "Support services," which include attendance officers, guidance counselors, psychologists, librarians, administration, transportation, maintenance and data processing, took 33.6 percent.
"Each expenditure taken in isolation is defensible," said Chester E. Finn Jr., a critic of American schools who was a chief architect of Mr. Bush's education strategy. "But what does it say about our priorities?
"Teachers in so many classrooms spend their own money for supples. What a normal person would think to spend money on is first the teacher and then the instructional materials."
Many educators, including Mr. Shanker, the union leader, argue that schools should receive most of the education money directly and then buy various services from the central bureaucracy as needed, like advice on counseling or curriculum. In his Texas study, Mr. Ferguson found that districts that spent the most money directly on instruction produced the highest-scoring students.
Cumbersome bureaucracies are one reason a new crop of education reformers is endorsing "school-based management," where individual schools, not central bureaucracies, wield power.
 
The Wish Lists
Serving the Poor Leads Agenda
If schools pare bureaucracies and reorganize to spend money more effectively, where would money buy the most effective change?
Everyone in education has a long wish list. Mr. Finn, for example, would spend money on longer school days, a longer school year and sophisticated new tests to measure what students know. Almost everyone would buy more technology.
The most urgent and persistent calls for money come from the hard-pressed districts that serve the poorest children. Few would argue that educating disadvantaged children costs more, for services that include remedial tutoring, special education, guidance counselors, social workers and psychologists.
City schools must usually pay more for land, school construction, maintenance, discipline, attendance programs to combat truancy and busing for desgregation, said Carol Ascher of the ERIC Clearinghouse on Urban Education at Columbia University.
Many educators and politicians argue that Mr. Bush should call for dramatic increases in spending on demonstrably successful Federal programs that now only reach a fraction of eligible children. These include Head Start, which prepares needy preschoolers for kindergarten, and Chapter I, which offers tutoring and remedial education to poor children.
Others, like Arthur E. Wise, an expert on school finance, say the Federal Government must act to even the odds between rich and poor school districts. A walk into a poor school will find children using long-outdated textbooks and gymnasiums for classrooms. Wealthy suburban districts, by contrast, have well-equipped classrooms, well-paid teachers and a wide array of courses.
Critics like Mr. Finn say such arguments beg the familiar question:Without fundamental change in the schools that serve the children of the poor, will any new money be well spent?
While these debates continue, educators who have actually turned schools around can offer advice based on experience: Invest in teachers and smaller classes, be creative in reorganizing schools to spread the available money around, and cut out extras.
 
The Success Stories
Baltimore Adapts, As Does Harlem
The changes at Walbrook High in Baltimore show what money can buy, what it cannot and what happens when it runs out.
Mr. Billups, the principal, spent the money he had on retraining teachers to build a shared vision of where the school should go and to help teachers learn the best ways to get there. He used $125,000 raised from local foundations to convene summer training institutes for a core group of educators.
For inspiration, he looked to the Coalition for Essential Schools, based at Brown University. He sent teachers to Brown's campus in Providence, R.I., invited the coalition's director, Mr. Sizer, to Baltimore and brought in students so teachers could test how to apply their new ideas to actual classroom situations.
Other changes that Mr. Billups instituted cost no money at all. He established a school within a school, initially serving 125 of the school's 2,000 students. There teachers taught as teams, consulting daily about students, curriculum and teaching methods. He rearranged class schedules so teachers could have joint planning time. And he offered only one elective a year, allowing students to study a few core subjects in depth.
 
Much Still to Do
 Because of budget constraints, Mr. Billups was not able to do all he wanted to do. The mini-school grew slowly, but next year he plans to include the entire school. He could not afford to hire extra teachers to reduce the student load; instead of limiting each teacher to a total of 80 students so teachers would have more time to assign and discuss demanding homework, Mr. Billups' teachers have 116 students each. In order to buy more textbooks for academic courses, he had to reduce spending for band equipment and vocational courses.
"If you know your money is limited, you're careful of what you buy," Mr. Billups said. "Most of what I bought was teachers' time. We never would have gotten this off the ground had it not been for dedicated teachers."
While Mr. Billups is working on changing an existing school on a tight budget, Deborah Meier founded and directs three new public schools in East Harlem by adding some foundation money onto the public school money she receives.
Her Central Park East schools have won nationwide acclaim. Money is best spent, she said, on training teachers and keeping schools and classes small. She spends extra money on weekend retreats for teachers, to allow them to think about school goals and curriculum.
Ms. Meier's schools also show it costs more money to reach children who are poor or who have troubled families. She pays extra to keep schools open late so children have a quiet place to do homework and can consult with teachers. And she employs a school-family coordinator to handle family problems that hurt students' performance.
The success of Ms. Meier's approach has been seen in lower dropout rates and higher scores in reading and other tests.
Her elementary school costs no more to operate than other alternative public elementary schools, primarily because she was able to attract teachers who share her philosophy. But the high school, where she said she has had to work harder to define the school vision and train teachers, costs an additional $150,000 a year.
To compensate for the extra money spent on teachers and smaller class sizes, Mr. Sizer suggests that schools merge departments and eliminate many electives like vocational education.
In the end, educators say, the argument about spending comes down to this paradox: Spending more money without change is wasting money, but without more money can there be substantial change?
"The folks who say more money will not do the job are right, on one level," said Phillip Schlechty, an educator who is working to transform schools in Louisville, Ky.
"If all we do is give more money to the present system," he said, "we'll do what we've always done and we'll get what we've always got. Without more money committed to development, we can't change the system. So we have to find ways to target money at doing different things."

The Economy
Payroll jobs fell in April, but at a much reduced pace, the Labor Department said, and the unemployment rate edged down 0.2 point, to 6.6 percent. Over all, analysts said, the figures point to an economy that seems to be approaching its low point, while probably not yet starting to recover from recession. But they cautioned that the decline in the unemployment rate, the first in almost a year, was probably an aberration. [Page 1.] 
 Sales of vehicles made in the U.S. and Canada fell 21.4 percent in late April, deflating industry hopes for a quick rebound. [33.]
The State of Maryland and the Government of Kuwait signed an agreement to give Maryland companies an advantage in the competition to win contracts to rebuild the sheikdom. [6.]
 
Companies
The civil settlement in the Exxon Valdez disaster fell apart, and Alaskan and U.S. officials said they expected to go to court to extract even more than $1 billion from Exxon. [1.]
The Navy picked Electric Boat to build a $2 billion attack submarine. General Dynamics, Electric Boat's parent, had said that without the contract it would close the Groton, Conn., shipyard. [33.]
Philip Morris plans to introduce Marlboro Medium, a version of Marlboro cigarettes that has tar and nicotine levels between those of the regular and light versions. [33.]
RJR Nabisco Holdings is taking another big step to reduce the cost of history's most expensive leveraged buyout. It will buy back more than $1.8 billion in high-interest debt. [35.]
CS Holding has cut its dividend by nearly a third and announced plans to sell a 20 percent stake in Credit Suisse. The harsh measures followed a 1990 loss of $587 million at CS First Boston. [34.]
Most anonymous Swiss bank accounts will be abolished, the Government has decided. [34.]
Many of the world's big technology companies want to compete with Intermagnetics, the leading independent supplier of products based on superconductivity. [33.]
Tele-Communications, A.T. &T. and U S West will test whether cable subscribers want expanded pay-per-view services. [35.]
Mitsubishi will buy a one-third interest in Volvo's Dutch operations for $120 million. [35.]
Abraham & Straus will close its store in Hempstead, L.I., and will open a new one in Garden City. [26.]
 
Markets
Long-term interest rates soared as prices of Treasury bonds plunged amid confusion stemmig from outwardly conflicting Government employment data for April. The price of the Treasury's benchmark 30-year bonds plunged almost a point. [33.]
Wall Street's fascination with a fast buck seems to be cooling. Brokerages and mutual funds are counseling patience, telling clients to invest for the long term. [33.]
The stock market had a tough time deciding what to do. After a choppy day that sent the Dow Jones industrial average rising and falling, the Dow ended about where it began -- ahead 0.25, to 2,938.86. It gained 26.48 for the week. [36.]
The dollar advanced on world currency markets, bolstered by the employment report. Gold prices declined. [42.]
Copper futures prices settled at their lowest level in three months amid signs of growing stockpiles. [42.]

HEADLINE: In the Nation;
Upbeat or Down?

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
At home, the Bush Administration is singing one tune about the economic outlook; but abroad, it's following another melody. To Americans out of jobs or looking for customers, Washington is predicting a quick upturn; but to the the Group of Seven nations, it's pleading a need for action to stimulate economic growth.
 The optimistic domestic message is not surprising. Economic recovery is a slow process, and George Bush does not want to find himself still presiding over a recession deep into the election year 1992. The more confidence in the economy that he and his aides can instill in consumers and businessmen, the more likely they are to buy and invest and get things moving again. 
 The independent Federal Reserve obviously has been acting on the assumption that the recession is not over and that the economy still needs stimulation. It has just reduced the discount rate (what it charges banks for loans) by a half-point and the Federal funds rate (what banks charge each other for short-term loans) by a quarter-point. The major banks got the message and quickly followed with a cut from 9 to 8 1/2 percent in the prime rate.
 These concrete actions are in notable contrast to repeated statements of optimism from the Administration and from the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, suggesting that the recession will be short and shallow, with recovery beginning this summer. Even on top of the Federal Reserve rate cuts, the Fed professed to see scattered signs that the low point is near.
 Despite a slight improvement in April unemployment figures, less sanguine observers may find those signs hard to discern in the decline, in March, of 7 of the 11 components in the Government's primary forecasting index. The overall index did rise slightly but only because of an increase in consumer expectations at the end of the Persian Gulf war -- an increase that later surveys showed to be short-lived.
 Some analysts are not certain, anyway, that lower interest rates will be enough to bring the economy out of a recession that is beginning to look as if it will be more severe and long-lasting than Washington, at least, has been predicting. They believe that the recession is attributable to numerous factors other than high interest rates, and that relatively minor reductions in those rates, while helpful, will not do the job.
 Unemployment, though it declined from 6.8 to 6.6 percent in the latest survey, continues to be a worrisome problem. Companies everywhere are laying off workers; General Dynamics, for instance, announced big layoffs this week, despite its participation in a new Air Force fighter plane contract.
 But unemployment is less affected by high interest rates than by low consumer demand, which in turn depresses employers' willingness to maintain, much less expand, production and work forces. The Administration appears to be relying, however, entirely on Federal Reserve rate cuts for countercyclical action.
 Treasury Secretary Brady, meanwhile, sang the Administration's overseas melody at the Group of Seven meeting in Washington. He argued that Britain, Japan, France, Italy, Canada and particularly Germany needed to cut interest rates and stimulate growth, lest the world slip into economic stagnation. Not least among his concerns, and properly so, are U.S. exports; slumping economies elsewhere would mean declining U.S. ability to sell products abroad; that, in turn, would contribute to a longer and deeper U.S. recession.
 This argument apparently was undercut, however, by Mr. Brady's contradictory singing of the Administration's domestic tune -- that the U.S. recession is coming to an end and recovery is about to begin. At least partially because of these conflicting themes, he got nowhere in his efforts to bring about lower rates in Germany and Europe -- although some experts see the possibility that the Japanese might soon lower theirs.
 But if actions speak louder than words, even in Washington, the Fed's interest-rate reductions and Mr. Brady's futile appeals to the Group of Seven can only mean that the Administration is more concerned about the economy than it's willing to admit to American voters.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Neighbors Movement Is Going National;
Try Volunteer Work

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Julia Carlisle describes New York's newest subculture, the "Young, Privileged and Unemployed" (Op-Ed, April 4). The economy's dip and concurrent unemployment, particularly of those educated and trained, should be viewed as temporary, which may be of little solace to those trying to pay rent. But for those young people filled with energy, enthusiasm and work drive, a partial solution to inactivity would be involvement in volunteer work. 
 We at the Volunteer Referral Center were surprised, then delighted, to see how many young professionals come to our office to learn about volunteer opportunities. Volunteering allows individuals to keep up their skills while waiting to be re-employed and offers an opportunity to investigate a career change.
 
NANCY CARR
President, Volunteer Referral Center
New York, April 11, 1991

HEADLINE: Submarine Job Won by Dynamics

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
In a political and economic duel between New England and Virginia, the Navy today named Electric Boat of Connecticut to build its next $2 billion attack submarine.
 Electric Boat, a General Dynamics Corporation division in Groton, Conn., was awarded $614.7 million to build the submarine itself. The balance will go to the vessel's nuclear reactor, weapons and other components. 
General Dynamics had said that without the contract for the vessel, it would close the Groton shipyard -- the nation's largest submarine builder and Connecticut's second-largest employer -- by the late 1990's and eliminate 22,000 jobs.
 
Job Cuts Still Planned
 In a sign of declining military budgets that have sharply pared the Pentagon's weapons orders, General Dynamics said that even with today's award, 10,000 jobs would still be cut at the Electric Boat division in the next five years because of dwindling submarine business. It said earlier this week that it would eliminate 27,000 jobs companywide over four years from its total work force of 90,000.
 The high-stakes battle for the second Seawolf-class submarine -- Electric Boat is building the first -- was cast as a region's economic survival against maintaining diversity in the nation's military industrial base.
 While Electric Boat relies solely on submarine building and overhaul, its rival, the Newport News shipyard in Virginia, also builds the Navy's nuclear-powered aircraft carriers and was viewed by industry analysts as the less vulnerable of the only two shipyards that build submarines in the United States.
 
With the Aid of Experience
 Industry analysts said Electric Boat's experience in building the first Seawolf allowed it to underbid its competitor, a Tenneco Inc. subsidiary, for the same submarine design.
 The Navy made the announcement after the close of stock market trading. Earlier, on the New York Stock Exchange, General Dynamics shares had risen 62.5 cents, to $39, while Tenneco's had risen 37.5 cents, to $44.
 "General Dynamics had the edge and the bottom line was that the program went to the low-cost bidder," said Howard A. Rubel, a senior vice president at C. J. Lawrence Inc. in New York.
 A Navy spokesman, Lieut. Phillip McGuinn, said that after reviewing both proposals for technical ability, industrial base and price, "the key determinant was price."
 Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, the ranking Republican on the Armed Services Committee and a former Navy Secretary, said Electic Boat's bid was $80 million to $90 million lower. But he said the award threatened to undermine what competition remained in the American submarine-building business.
 The Navy's decision stirred both euphoria and relief at the Groton yard, and at General Dynamics headquarters in St. Louis. Last month, the Air Force awarded a contract to a team including General Dynamics to build a new generation of radar-evading fighter planes.
 
'Obviously, We're Delighted'
 "Obviously, we're delighted," said a General Dynamics spokesman, Peter Connolly. "The fact we won was from a combination of the capabilities at the boatyard and the economic arguments we marshaled for our case."
 In Virginia, the mood was predictably downcast as today's award gave Electric Boat a leg up on future bids for Seawolf models.
 "I am extremely disappointed since we made our best possible bid," the chief executive of Newport News and Shipbuilding, Edward J. Campbell, said in a statement. "The loss of that contract will put us at a competitive disadvantage for any follow-on ships in the Seawolf class."
 Mr. Campbell said the shipyard's large backlog and normal attrition would not require the company to eliminate any jobs through 1992. He said the shipyard would reduce hiring immediately to reduce the possibility of layoffs in the future.
 
Review Is Requested
 Senator Warner asked the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, to do a "detailed review of the entire acquisition process" used in the Seawolf competition.
 His actions today were just the latest salvo in what has been a bitterly partisan political fight over jobs.
 Both Electric Boat and Newport News developed the same submarine: a quieter, deeper-diving sub than the existing model, with 40 percent more missiles and torpedoes. The only question was which shipyard would build them.
 Electric Boat won a competition with Newport News several years ago to build the first Seawolf under a $726 million contract. The Navy had originally intended to buy three or four Seawolfs a year and split the business between Electric Boat and Newport News.
 Even after Defense Secretary Dick Cheney reduced the Pentagon's submarine orders to one a year, the Navy was still expected to award the second order to Newport News to promote competition and, in theory, get the best value for the taxpayer.
 But at one only ship a year, it no longer made economic sense to maintain two shipyards for the limited work.
 
A Shortage of Work
 "We need to honestly face the fact that long-term procurement of one submarine per year will not sustain both submarine construction yards," H. Lawrence Garrett 3d, the Secretary of the Navy, told a Congressional committee several weeks ago.
 With regional studies showing a virtual collapse in the southeastern Connecticut economy without the Groton work, Connecticut's Congressional delegation and Electric Boat executives had a final decision on the contract delayed to analyze the effect of a shrinking submarine fleet on the two shipyards and the competitive bidding process.
 In the meantime, Donald Yockey, the Pentagon's top civilian procurement official, ordered the Navy to award the contract on the basis of "overall cost and technical approach."
 Mr. Yockey seemed to disregard language Senator Warner had inserted last year in several military spending bills requiring the Navy to follow a "competitive acquisition strategy," even if it meant awarding the contract to a higher bidder.

HEADLINE: THE KURDS: IN FLIGHT, ONCE AGAIN

BYLINE: By Clyde Haberman; Clyde Haberman, the Rome bureau chief for The Times, has covered the Kurds' flight from Iraq.

 BODY:
AMONG THE REFUGEES huddled on the mountains between Iraq and Turkey, an old saying could be heard again and again: The Kurds have no friends. It was uttered so often among the wretched thousands fleeing Iraq that it became a frayed cliche. But cliches develop because they are at least in part true: over the decades, few peoples have wound up on the short end so consistently as these champions of failed rebellions against central authority. Perhaps no ethnic group so large has gone so long without a homeland.
There are many more Kurds than Israelis and Palestinians combined, yet until now they have received only a tiny fraction of the attention on front pages and television screens. Maybe, some Kurdish leaders say bitterly, it is because they have never believed that the rest of the world had to suffer for their unhappiness. No one has ever heard of a Kurd taking Western hostages, or shooting innocent people at airports, or hijacking an airplane. 
 Now the world's attention is on the Kurds. But their hopes remain as elusive as ever. To refer to Kurdistan is to talk about a country that never existed. It is such an improbable goal that Kurdish calls for independence have become rare, except from a guerrilla band that has been fighting a nasty insurgency to carve out a separate Kurdish state in southeastern Turkey. Most Kurds would settle for increased autonomy and improved economic development in countries where they have sunk toward the bottom of the wage scale.
In mass exodus from Iraq, they faced the gravest crisis in their long history. This was hardly the first time that Kurds have taken flight after a lost cause. But the numbers -- an estimated 1.5 million or more -- were of Old Testament proportions, accompanied by plague and death on a scale rarely seen even in this century of endless horror.
For weeks, an appalled world watched the Kurds' ordeal and wondered if they would make it. Thousands died, many of them children and old people, and thousands more are likely to follow unless a rescue operation led by the United States succeeds quickly, an endeavor that includes the delicate decision, joined by Britain and France, to move troops into northern Iraq to build protected refugee camps there.
Ten days ago, Baghdad promised enhanced Kurdish autonomy. But many Kurds say Iraq is the last place they want to go while Saddam Hussein holds power. They do not even want to stay in Turkey, where Kurds have endured frequent repression and are among the country's poorest people. Most have their eyes on Western Europe and the United States. But the West, for all the loud clucking over the poor Kurds, is hardly throwing its doors open. The refugees are stuck. They cannot move forward, yet they cannot cling indefinitely to the inhospitable mountainsides. Before long, it would seem, a way will have to be found of luring them back to their Iraqi homes, which is one aim of the allied plan to put up guarded enclaves in northern Iraq. The Kurds' fear is that if they return now, they will be forgotten sooner or later. Probably sooner. They have experienced Western amnesia before.

WHILE NUMBERS are hazy, a widely accepted estimate is that there are 20 million Kurds, living in a territory about the size of Nebraska and cutting a wide swath across Iran, Iraq and Turkey, which by itself contains about half the Kurdish population. In each of those countries, they are in the minority. There are also smaller communities in Syria and the Soviet Union.
They are mostly Sunni Muslims of Indo-European stock, clustered into rivalrous clans and probably descended, historians say, from Aryan tribes that settled west of the Caspian Sea some 4,000 years ago. By the seventh century, the word "Kurd" had come into being to describe these people. They had their own language, although it was, and is, fragmented into so many dialects that there is no common tongue for all Kurds. They have their own poets, their own cuisine and their own heroes, who include Saladin, the great 12th-century sultan who fought nobly against Christian crusaders. It irritates more than a few Kurds that Saddam Hussein has wrapped himself in the mantle of Saladin, right down to ordering portraits of himself astride a white charger.
Over the years, the Kurds have come to be romanticized in the West as a race of noble warriors. Romantic notions are easy to come by with Kurds. One reason is that so many of them are blessed with startling good looks. And there is the understandable instinct to root for the underdog. But the Kurds have often been brigands and mercenaries, hiring themselves out to whichever regional power suited their purpose at the moment. Often they choose sides unwisely, and then must pay a terrible price when the winner comes to exact revenge.
That is what happened in one of the great Kurdish debacles of recent days; in 1988, 60,000 of them fled the Iraqi Army, claiming that their villages had been attacked with chemical weapons. That time, Hussein was paying back Iraqi pesh mergas -- the durable resistance fighters whose name means "those who face death" -- for helping Iran during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war.
Past Kurdish migrations after failed uprisings in Iraq tended to be top-heavy with farmers and shepherds, who form the backbone of the pesh mergas. There are plenty of pesh mergas this time, too. But there is also a heavy sprinkling of engineers, physicians, lawyers, managers and teachers -- city people who are unaccustomed to combat and even less to the harsh vagaries of the mountains that separate Iraq from Turkey. Their presence underlines the remarkable nature of this migration, for it means that nearly half of Iraq's Kurds got up and walked.

THE KURDS' DREAMS ARE anyone's dreams. "We want to send our children to school and have enough money to bring them to the doctor," a grizzled nomad told William Coupon, whose photographs of the Kurds of southeastern Turkey appear in these pages. The problem, he said, is that the Turkish military has taken over too much Kurdish land, making it difficult to grind out a living.
One shepherd was no different from young men anywhere. "I spend most of my life walking, but I prefer a Mercedes-Benz," he said. "I don't want to be a shepherd anymore." But then, in a reference to President Turgut Ozal of Turkey, he touched on a politically sensitive point: the great gaps in wealth between Kurds and the larger society. "Ozal has 10 Mercedeses," he said. "But we don't even have a donkey."
These people would not give their names. They felt that they had to trade candor for anonymity, even though they said nothing terribly provocative. Who was to say that Turkish soldiers would not knock on their doors one day to interrogate them? That sense of repression is the unhappy daily reality for Kurds in all the countries they inhabit.
Oddly enough, Turkey, the only nation in the region that can call itself a democracy, has often been least hospitable to the Kurds. The Turks do not even recognize their estimated 8 million to 10 million Kurds as an official minority, a status conferred on much smaller populations of Armenians, Greeks and Jews. Until the last few years, it was considered dangerous for newspapers even to use the word "Kurd"; instead, they spoke of "mountain Turks."
"How happy is he who calls himself a Turk," read banners stretched across the streets of Kurdish cities and towns in the southeast.
Education in any of the Kurdish dialects is banned. In 1983, as a military junta yielded to civilian rule, it passed laws forbidding Kurds to speak their language in public or to play their traditional songs. As recently as last fall, a popular singer was investigated by the police after singing a Kurdish song at a wedding.
Now many Turks call such restrictions self-defeating, especially since they are generally ignored. All they accomplish, critics say, is to make Turkey's splotchy human-rights record look even worse than it is. A few weeks ago, at Ozal's insistence, Parliament finally modified the ban on spoken Kurdish, although books and newspapers written in that language remain strictly forbidden.
Even that relatively small advance required serious arm-twisting by the Turkish President, who encountered stiff resistance from nationalist elements within his own party. Their objections were rooted less in racism than in a sincere foot-in-the-door fear that yielding on language rights today will lead inexorably to separatist demands tomorrow. That is not considered wild paranoia in Turkey, which is still seared by memories of the country's dismemberment after World War I. To many Turks, the guerrilla war waged in the southeast by the separatist Kurdish Workers Party -- an insurgency that has taken more than 2,500 lives since it began in 1984 -- presents a clear and present danger to national security.
In that regard, one could argue that the roughly four million Kurds in Iraq have fared better. At least the Iraqis can say that their Kurds have long been allowed to speak their own language. In 1970, Baghdad went so far as to offer a measure of autonomy to the Kurdish regions of northern Iraq, and did so again last week, in principle. But autonomy has always looked better on paper than in reality. The 1970 program never had teeth, and it is safe to say that, in terms of physical abuse, Iraqi Kurds have suffered more than any other.
In Iran, the dominant Shiite Muslims distrust the Kurds and their more secular approach to religion. Syria refuses to give many of its 900,000 Kurds full citizenship. In the Soviet Union, there are only about 300,000 of them, and they are considered of scant importance.
But in Iraq, the Kurds rank among the most tested victims of this brutal century, their repeated rebellions having led each time to savage suppression by Hussein's forces.
In the 1980's, Iraqi troops destroyed some 4,000 Kurdish villages in the northern oil centers of Kirkuk and Mosul, then resettled hundreds of thousands of people within the region or deported them to the south. They then moved Arabs into the north to dilute its Kurdish character.
All this was done in the name of giving Kurds new homes with plumbing and access to better schools and hospitals. In fact, it was a form of annihilation, one that was made explicit in 1988, when Hussein unleashed poison gas on Kurdish civilians, killing 5,000 of them in Halabja, near the Iranian border. That attack was to repay Kurdish guerrillas -- fighting under the rival banners of their two main leaders, Jalal Talabani and Massoud Barzani -- for helping Iran in its long war against Iraq. Later that year, Iraqi troops sent tens of thousands fleeing into Turkey. That time, too, the Kurds claimed they were hit with chemical weapons.

ONE PROBLEM FOR THE scattered Kurds is that they are generally seen as nuisances, except when they are useful as pawns. And they have often been willing accomplices in their own exploitation. Sometimes, all it takes to get a pesh merga to run off and fight is to put a rifle in his hands -- and even then the person he shoots may well be a fellow Kurd from an enemy clan.
A classic example of this exploitation came in the 1970's, when Iraq's Kurds put themselves at the service of the Shah of Iran. To strike at his enemy, Iraq, the Shah funneled arms and aid to pesh mergas loyal to the greatest Kurdish leader of this century, Mustafa Barzani, father of Massoud. In this clandestine operation, which began in 1974, the Shah had full support from the Nixon Administration. Henry Kissinger, then Secretary of State, called the program "an instrument to dissuade Iraq from international adventurism."
But by 1975, the Shah had different priorities. He struck a deal with Iraq, agreeing to abandon the pesh mergas in exchange for a share of sovereignty over the vital Shatt al-Arab waterway leading to the Persian Gulf. Once again, nobody cared what happened to the Kurds. Suddenly defenseless against the Iraqi army, several hundred thousand of them fled to Iran for sanctuary; the Shah gave them at least that much. But when Mustafa Barzani tried to talk to Kissinger about thisbetrayal, the Secretary would not see him. Instead, he reminded intermediaries that "secret-service operations are not missionary work."
Given all the back-stabbings and self-inflicted wounds, any talk of a Kurdish state -- comparable, say, with the existing Jewish state or a future Palestinian state -- must be dismissed as a pipe dream. No country in the region would tolerate it. During the gulf war, Turkey warned that it would intervene militarily to prevent the rise of a Kurdistan. And Iraq is not about to give up Kurdish areas that account for one-third of its oil production.
Unfortunately for the Kurds, they showed up too late, and with too little firepower, when the region's maps were last redrawn, after World War I and the subsequent collapse of the Ottoman Empire. On one occasion, however, they did come tantalizingly close to winning a homeland.
That was in 1920. There had already been a series of Kurdish rebellions for nearly a century, begun when the Persians and the Ottomans tried to centralize their fading empires and squeezed the Kurds in the process. In 1920, after the Ottomans finally crumbled, Western powers agreed, in the Treaty of Sevres, to create both a Kurdistan and an independent Armenia out of territory that forms what is now eastern Turkey.
But this arrangement was flatly rejected by Kemal Ataturk, the Turkish nationalist hero, who went on to suppress several uprisings and proved himself too strong militarily to be denied. In 1923, with the birth of the modern Turkish republic, the Treaty of Sevres was superseded by the Treaty of Lausanne, which offered the Turks far more favorable terms. Gone was any mention of Kurdistan or Armenia. There the matter has rested.
Considering their history of disillusion and failure, it seems remarkable in hindsight that the most recent Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq thought they could take on Saddam Hussein after his defeat in the gulf war, when he still retained significant military power. Then the United States sealed matters by announcing that this uprising was not its concern. Looking back, it is clear that the Kurds never had a chance, no matter how many Iraqi cities they managed to hold for a while.
So they took to the mountains yet again, this time in frighteningly large numbers. There they sit, awaiting word from their leaders, wondering if they will be able to return to their homes in safety, or whether they face yet another chapter in a long history of betrayal.

HEADLINE: ANTIQUES;
Even in Pinch-Penny Times, Silver Is Holding Its Own

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
Is antique silver recession-proof?
"Nothing is recession-proof," said Michael Koopman, a London dealer, following last month's highly successful silver sales at Christie's and Sotheby's in Manhattan. "But silver seems to be holding its own rather well right now." 
 Mr. Koopman's assessment was echoed by other dealers, collectors and auctioneers, who said the auctions confirmed that the finest 18th-century English tureens and candlesticks have lost none of their luster for bidders during the economic downturn.
On April 18, Christie's realized the highest total ever for a single day of auctioning silver. In a sale of 371 works, 327 were sold for a total of $5.5 million -- eclipsing the $4.9 million paid at Christie's on Jan. 10 for silver from the collection of Imelda and Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines. On April 19, Sotheby's offered 331 items, of which 288 brought a total of $3.2 million, well above expectations.
Even more significant were the dramatic increases in the prices paid for silver made before or after the 18th century and in places other than London. With the supply of the highly coveted Georgian silver shrinking, the prices for 17th- and 19th-century English pieces have now escalated to new levels, along with those fetched by French and German silver produced from the 17th century on.
Of the 10 heftiest prices paid at the two houses, only two were for London-made silver, and both were pre-18th-century examples. A Chinese-styled bowl from 1688 was sold for $198,000 at Sotheby's to a British dealer, Jonathan Norton of S. J. Phillips, and a pair of baroque sconces from 1697 were bought by an unidentified buyer for $148,500. The remaining 10 items were French.
The sale's highest price was $561,000, seven times what Christie's had estimated. The buyer of this tour de force of the rococo style -- a ewer and basin covered with shells, leaves, swans and mermaids -- was a French dealer. Made in 1761 by Louis Samson 2d of Toulouse, the set was from a Philadelphia collection formed in the 1950's and 60's.
Why are people paying higher prices for silver?
"Silver prices never became excessive," Mr. Norton said. "Some of the pieces in these sales were exceptional, and there are more people today who can still spend a certain amount of money for such silver than there were a decade ago."
Mr. Norton paid $330,000 -- more than three times Sotheby's estimate -- for a French neo-Gothic clock, a rarity that he quickly sold to an unidentified American collector. The miniature tower, exquisitely crafted in silver, gilded silver and gold embellished with diamonds, semiprecious stones and enameled pictures, was designed by the Paris jeweler Lucien Falize in 1881.
Among other gilded silver objects that commanded high prices was a pair of Louis XVI candelabra with golden leaves, berry branches, scrolls and snakes that was bought for $264,000 at Christie's. And a Regence-styled 20th-century set of 446 gilded knives, forks and spoons by Puiforcat of Paris was sold for $132,000 -- four times Christie's expectations.
The pedigree of certain pieces also spurred bidding. A Louis XIV pitcher -- undecorated save for molding on the rim and the lobes on the base -- was sold for $159,500, six times Sotheby's estimate, to Mr. Norton. Two previous owners were David David-Weill, the San Francisco-born Paris investment banker and collector, who died in 1952, and, most recently, Henry Ford 2d.
Mr. Koopman of London, who paid $154,000 for a pair of Louis XVI candelabra and $132,000 for a set of four French candlesticks from 1788 -- both at Christie's -- explained why: "There hasn't been merchandise of this quality at auction for a year."
To Kevin Tierney, who heads Sotheby's silver department in New York, much of the success of these sales must be credited to the London dealers, who bought the majority of the important offerings. "They are still as strong as ever," he said of the dealers.
Christopher Hartop, who heads silver sales at Christie's in New York, said silver continues to be collected seriously despite increased problems of security and maintenance.
"The very rich have lots of servants anyway," he said. "And I can think of several serious collectors who buy silver and clean it themselves -- it is the one way to get to know silver."
Mr. Hartop said the energetic bidding at these sales makes him optimistic about the next test of the market -- the $5.3 million worth of English silver from the estate of Hilmar Reksten, a Norwegian shipowner, that is to be auctioned at Christie's in London on May 22.
Eric Shrubsole, a British-born Manhattan dealer, who paid $82,500 for a Georgian tea kettle, said good silver has always held its value. "From the day I arrived on these shores in 1936, I have never known the price of good silver to go down."

GRAPHIC: Photo: One of a pair of English sconces, circa 1697, that recently fetched $148,500--Sales are often well above the auctioneer's expectations. (Sotheby's)

HEADLINE: FILM;
It's Not Just a Man's World for Blake Edwards

BYLINE: By JANET MASLIN

 BODY:
Blake Edwards has once again answered Henry Higgins's question -- "Why can't a woman be more like a man?" -- in ways that make the head spin. In Mr. Edwards's "Victor/Victoria" in 1982, a female singer posed as a female impersonator and thus had the effect of throwing his/her admirers into utter confusion. Now, in "Switch," Mr. Edwards presents a ladies' man whose death becomes the occasion for a celestial prank. As punishment for his transgressions, Steve (Perry King) is sent back to earth in the form of Amanda (Ellen Barkin), a long-haired, leggy blonde.
Mr. Edwards, whose 1989 comedy "Skin Deep" is best remembered for its glow-in-the-dark condom scene, is not inclined toward undue delicacy. So "Switch," in addition to showing what a hard time Amanda has adjusting to high heels, also finds her in amorous situations with a woman (Lorraine Bracco) and with Steve's own former best friend (Jimmy Smits). Mr. Edwards does not shy away from Amanda's curiosity about her anatomy or from her not caring how she sits while wearing a dress. No wonder that, as Mr. Edwards puts it, some aspects of his screenplay "made the men who were considering financing it cringe. It nailed 'em right to the wall." 
 Making "Switch," which opens Friday, meant testing the limits of audience tolerance when it comes to gender-bending humor, but that is what interested Mr. Edwards in the first place. "The behavioral aspect of things that separate men and women has always been of interest to me," said the 68-year-old film maker, speaking from his Culver City, Calif., office. Citing "a fairly dysfunctional childhood," during which he was "raised by women in Oklahoma and had an aunt that even called me 'son,' " Mr. Edwards described a lifelong fascination with finding out what makes women tick. "They've always been a wonderful mystery for me," he said.
If "Victor/Victoria" gave him a chance to explore gender-related differences in the male and female psyches, it also made him wonder how much further he might go. And he had in mind George Axelrod's play "Goodbye, Charlie" (directed on film by Vincente Minnelli in 1964), about a ladies' man killed by a jealous husband and reincarnated in female form. "I remember thinking to myself that there are so many things you can do now that you couldn't do then," recalled Mr. Edwards. So he set out to do a few.
His early version of "Switch" included an explicitly sexual encounter between Amanda and her female suitor and a sexual assault on Amanda, after which she reverted to masculine behavior by chasing her attackers with a baseball bat. Those episodes were either greatly toned down or eliminated after preview audiences rebelled against so much sexual ambiguity. "Where I perceived that the audience would be aware that there was a guy in there," Mr. Edwards said of the bedroom scene between Ms. Barkin and Ms. Bracco, "it turned out that that area made them uncomfortable. I was surprised, because to my ear, it played."
Mr. Edwards's ear has long been attuned to the kinds of wild personality changes that have become one of his trademarks. The split personality, whether in a man with two pregnant wives ("Micki and Maude," 1984) or a demure woman who goes wild under the influence of alcohol ("Blind Date," 1987), is a favorite device. Even his relatively stable characters, like Inspector Clouseau of the "Pink Panther" films or the composer played by Dudley Moore in "10," lapse easily into bizarre behavior. So "Switch" made sense to him even when others balked at its apparent daring.
"Switch" is being distributed by Warner Brothers, but it was independently produced for a variety of reasons. Ever since making "S.O.B." (1981), an uproariously funny attack on the Hollywood establishment, Mr. Edwards has been more popular outside the major studios. "I suspect it became tougher for me to get projects off the ground, but it all depends on whether you have a hit," he said. "You can be Hitler, and if you had a hit you'd be back again."
Years ago, when he proposed making a film about Billie Holiday and was told by a Paramount executive that it might be a good idea to make Miss Holiday white, Mr. Edwards began establishing his independent streak. ("Who do you want, Doris Day?" he remembers asking sarcastically. The answer was yes.) Since then, he has even shot a film in his own house ("That's Life," 1986) as an economy measure, and he remembers what it was like for him and his wife, Julie Andrews, to watch television in bed while a film crew packed up its equipment in the next room. So when it came to making "Switch," Mr. Edwards was ready to take chances.
But finding an actress to play a man trapped in a woman's body was a problem. On Hollywood's A list of potential stars, he said, there were two or three "powerhouse ladies" interested in the material but afraid of it, too. Ms. Barkin was not then an A-list possibility, and Mr. Edwards's backers resisted doing the film without an actress who was a drawing card. "It looked like the project would be dropped for business reasons," Mr. Edwards said. But then Ms. Barkin's success in "Sea of Love" in 1989 raised her a few notches on the Hollywood totem pole. She became acceptable to the film's backers, and she was eager to take the role.
"She loved it, but she was scared to death," Mr. Edwards said. He noted that his star's worries centered not on the film's content, but on her ability to make the material work in comic terms. In preparing for the role, Ms. Barkin studied men in the crew and the director himself. "I'd see her watching and imitating, and I'd catch her at it and she'd smile," Mr. Edwards said.
If Ms. Barkin supplied some of the film's ideas about how men behave, Mr. Edwards contributed his own thoughts about women. Amanda is made terrifically uncomfortable by her long hair, Mr. Edwards said, because he has watched his own daughters and stepdaughters wrestling with their coiffures and "it would drive me nuts." One of his daughters indirectly contributed the film's funniest line, the unprintable retort of a fur coat wearer to an animal rights activist, which she drew from a conversation overheard in Aspen, Colo.
One of the hardest things Ms. Barkin does in the film is to carry her co-star, Mr. Smits, who is much larger than her. "I didn't expect her to do that, and she hurt herself," Mr. Edwards said. "For the rest of her life, she'll have a problem with her back because of that scene."
 Other films besides "Switch," among them Billy Wilder's "Some Like It Hot" (1959) and Sydney Pollack's "Tootsie" (1982), have shown a man learning to view the world from a woman's point of view, hed said. "But here's someone who can't go home and get out of drag at the end of the day."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ellen Barkin as Amanda, formerly Steve, with Blake Edwards on the set of "Switch"--a celestial prank on both sexes (Warner Brothers)
