HEADLINE: HOME ENTERTAINMENT;
A TV Set That Shapes Up Movies

BYLINE: By HANS FANTEL

 BODY:
The mutilation of movies for video presentation may finally come to an end. A new type of television set allows feature films to be shown on a wide screen with the same shape as a movie screen. As a result, it will no longer be necessary to cut off part of the picture to make it fit within the dimensions of the video screen.
The first of these sets went on sale in France in March, and their introduction in other European countries and in Japan is scheduled for September. They will eventually be available in the United States. 
 The shape of the conventional TV screen has long irritated film producers, because the aspect ratio of the TV screen -- the ratio of width to height -- is all wrong for movies. Most movie screens are nearly twice as wide as they are high, whereas television screens are nearly square. Specifically, the aspect ratio of a movie screen is about 16:9; that of a TV screen is 4:3. Thus, showing a movie on a television set is like putting a painting in a frame so small that parts of the picture must be trimmed. This can damage the film's artistic intent.
At present, transferring a feature film to video often requires that scenes shot for the full width of the theater screen be drastically altered. "If you've got two people standing so far apart that you can't see them both on the small TV screen, then we just have to pan and cut back and forth between them," says Steven Bowen of Editel, a video postproduction company that specializes in film-to-tape transfers.
Such panning can destroy the mood and visual composition of a scene, which is why some directors have not allowed their films to be televised or issued on videocassettes.
Film studios, usually more interested in subsidiary profits from video than in artistic integrity, rarely stand in the way of video alterations. On the contrary, some studios now employ video advisers to work alongside directors. Their job is to make sure that the director observes the usual guidelines for video -- that the action stays in the middle of the screen, preferably in close-up, producing images that show up better on inexpensive TV sets with a grainy picture.
Many directors have chafed at these constraints, and there have been earlier attempts to sidestep the problem. One technique, called letterboxing, retains the original screen proportions but reduces the size of the overall image so as to fit the elongated rectangle into the conventional squarish screen.
In one of the more impressive letterbox releases, the panoramic vistas in David Lean's "Lawrence of Arabia" have been preserved, and the videodisk of Akira Kurosawa's "Dreams" does full justice to the film's bold visual concepts. Such exemplary releases prove that the letterbox method -- which can be applied to all current television sets, VCR's and videodisk players -- can preserve a director's artistic intentions.
However, there are drawbacks to letterboxing. The upper and lower areas of the screen are not used and remain blank. This may account for the limited acceptance of letterboxing in this country. As one video producer put it, "American viewers feel cheated if the picture doesn't fill up the whole screen."
On the new wide-screen sets, in contrast, the picture is spread over the whole screen and the overall size does not shrink if letterboxed programs are displayed. Moreover, the sets are compatible with programs presented in the conventional video format, and the viewer may choose alternative modes of displaying the picture: expanding the picture to fill the whole screen by cropping a bit of sky and foreground, or displaying the picture as it is, with black areas on the screen at the right and left.
The new sets also use new circuitry to improve image sharpness so that it approaches high-definition standards expected in the future. When true high-definition television (HDTV) arrives, the sets can be equipped for it by means of an adapter.
The introductory price of the new sets is about $5,000 for a model with a screen measuring 36 1/2 inches diagonally. But once the economies of mass production are applied, the price of some wide-screen models may be only about 20 percent higher than that of conventional sets of comparable size.
No date has been set for the introduction of wide-screen technology to the United States because of the current economic climate. But the French company making these sets (Thomson Consumer Electronics) owns part of RCA and therefore has access to widespread marketing facilities in this country. This corporate link stirs hope that the United States will not lag far behind in getting the new technology.

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL VIEW;
You Want Repertory? Here It Is

BYLINE: By Donal Henahan

 BODY:
Recently in this space I asked a simple question: why has so little music composed since 1950 entered the repertory? Because the problem has puzzled me, I assumed others might also be baffled. Yes and no. A few readers refused to agree that there was a problem and expressed annoyance that a critic would waste time on it. "How much more responsible it would be," protested one, "if you devoted your space to educating audiences about why new music is still being written." (I fear there could be the germ of another irresponsible column in that sentence.)
Other correspondents, however, fairly leapt at the opportunity to send along multipage replies couched in historical, cultural, economic and even psychoanalytical terms. One thesis-size, footnoted letter argued that the whole idea of a masterpiece-based repertory is outmoded: social fragmentation has been taking place at such an accelerating rate in Western societies that "any consensus about culture and masterpieces is already impossible." Other familiar villains: the "choke-hold that academic mediocrities have on their students," the "excessive freedom enjoyed by composers who no longer have to please patrons," the "expansive but disruptive effect" of the post-1950 recording boom, the failure of conductors and other performers "to champion the music they love" . . . and so on. 
 Most correspondents responded to my request for a list of works from the last 50 years that our descendants might find worth hearing again and again. Such litanies tend to be compiled from memory rather than with the aid of reference books, which may explain why the works cited were over whelmingly from the 1940's. That placed them within the required 50-year span but, significantly, before my 1950 cutoff date. Here, however, are some frequently mentioned pieces from the fruitful decade of the 40's:
Strauss's "Four Last Songs," Oboe Concerto, Horn Concerto No. 2, "Capriccio," "Metamorphosen." Prokofiev's Symphony No. 5, String Quartet No. 2, "War and Peace" (first version). Bartok's Piano Concerto No. 3, Concerto for Orchestra. Copland's "Appalachian Spring," Symphony No. 3, "Red Pony," "Rodeo." Thomson's "Louisiana Story." Hindemith's "Four Temperaments." Messaien's "Turangalila" Symphony, "Quartet for the End of Time." Bernstein's "On the Town," "Fancy Free." Barber's "Knoxville," Violin Concerto. Shostakovich's Symphonies Nos. 7, 8, 9, String Quartets Nos. 2, 3, 4. Stravinsky's "Orpheus," Concerto in D, "Danses Concertantes," "Ebony Concerto," Symphony in C. Britten's "Peter Grimes," "Albert Herring," "Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra," "Ceremony of Carols," Serenade for Tenor, Horn and Strings.
Compare that brief, war-scarred period with the four decades since 1950, which have produced, in the opinion of my correspondents, the following repertory suspects (again, not an exhaustive tally):
Stravinsky's "Rake's Progress," "Agon." Prokofiev's "On Guard for Peace" (selections), Symphony No. 7. Messaien's "St. Francis of Assisi" (selections). Bernstein's "Prelude, Fugue and Riffs," Dances from "West Side Story," "Candide" Overture, "Chichester Psalms." Dello Joio's "Triumph of St. Joan." Britten's "Billy Budd," "War Requiem," "Noye's Fludde." Crumb's "Ancient Voices of Children," "Voice of the Whale," "Black Angels," "Eleven Echoes of Autumn." Menotti's "Saint of Bleecker Street," "Amahl and the Night Visitors." Shostakovich's Cello Concerto No. 1, "Festive Overture," Symphonies Nos. 10 through 15, String Quartets Nos. 8, 13, 14, 15. Poulenc's "Dialogues des Carmelites," Gloria in G, Sonatas for Oboe and Piano, Clarinet and Piano, Flute and Piano. Moore's "Ballad of Baby Doe." Berio's Sinfonia. Ligeti's "Atmospheres" and "Lux Aeterna." Carter's Variations for Orchestra, String Quartets Nos. 1, 2, 3. Boulez's "Pli Selon Pli."
Corigliano's Clarinet Concerto. Vaughan Williams's Tuba Concerto, Symphonies Nos. 7, 8, 9. Martin's "Concert Pour Clavecin et Petite Orchestre," Etudes for String Orchestra, Requiem. Schnittke's Requiem. Rutter's Requiem. Panufnik's "Arbor Cosmica." Gubaidulina's "Offertorium." Lutoslawski's Symphony No. 3, Concerto for Orchestra, "Funeral Music," "Chain 2." Penderecki's "Threnody for the Victims of Hiroshima," "St. Luke Passion." Adams's "Harmonielehre," "Chairman Dances." Glass's "Satyagraha." Reich's "Music for 18 Musicians."
Such a scattershot listing obviously reflects only personal, perhaps even eccentric, sympathies. But in a gross way it does suggest, I think, that for whatever catalogue of reasons the flow of high-quality pieces has diminished drastically in the last 40 years. Composers continue to produce works in great quantity: according to the Central Opera Service, 1,526 American music-theater pieces alone were written or had their premieres during the 1980's, more than were counted in all foreign countries combined. The number of orchestral, nonoperatic vocal and chamber works, for which I have no figures, must be staggering.
I am chagrined to say that I still do not know the answer to my simple question. Like the purloined letter, it could be under my nose, too obvious to notice. Or as one cruel reader pointed out, there may not be any such thing as a simple question, only simple questioners.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Airlines

 BODY:
To the Editor: Why is international travel down? It is not because of the fear of terrorism. It is not because of the recession. It is because neither travelers nor travel agents can reach an international reservations clerk at any major airline.
In setting up a trip to Florence and Venice via Paris, I have spent several hours on hold with the reservations clerks. And my agent tells me that she has had to wait up to one-half hour to get through to one. Then the reservations clerk often cannot give the final cost of tickets and refers her to the rate desk for another lengthy hold. 
 Perhaps we'll drive to Vermont.
 
ROGER L. SISSON
Lafayette Hill, Pa.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Connecticut Revaluations Raise Hackles

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
FALLOUT from the excesses of the 80's continues drifting into some unexpected places. One example is the revaluation of real estate in Connecticut, which takes place at staggered 10-year intervals in each of the state's 169 communities.
 In effect since the 50's and designed to distribute property taxes equitably, the revaluations rarely generate more than a handful of protests from individual taxpayers, and they are disposed of expeditiously by local boards of tax review. 
 Not so this year. In Greenwich alone, there have been 3,700 householders demanding redress from a 1989 revaluation. Some 2,200 appeals were filed with the Board of Tax Review last year, and when implementation of the revaluation was postponed for a year, 1,500 more irate taxpayers filed appeals.
 "We are swamped," said Lou Caravella, chairman of the three-member board. "We've had it real good for a long time, now all of a sudden it's caught up with us." Greenwich has requested a second year's legislative grace to finish the job.
 Similar delays are cropping up throughout the state as homeowners resist high revaluations generated by the heady run-up in house prices during the 80's and the current decline in office and condominium values due to vacancies. The overall effect statewide has been a significant shifting of the tax burden from commercial to residential, in some cases creating a 30 to 50 percent tax increase.
 Rather than implement Draconian increases sooner than necessary, many towns, including Greenwich, have continued to tax at their 10-year-old revaluation rates. But that option will soon be eliminated by a law that goes into effect Oct. 1.
 Towns with overdue revaluations are now scrambling to get them done by that date or subject themselves to penalties of 10 percent of their state grants -- in some communities, amounting to millions of dollars.
 "There were no teeth in the law prior to this," said Don Zimbouski, manager of municipal assessments and taxation at the state Office of Policy and Management. "Towns could get a postponement for one year, a waiver for a second year, and then go on using their old assessments with impunity. Because of noncompliance there are approximately 40 towns with revaluations due on Oct. 1, more than I've ever seen."
 "No one remembers anything like this happening before," said Everett Smith, chairman of a selectmen's advisory committee in Greenwich appointed to investigate the basis for all the disputation. His committee submitted a report to the Board of Selectmen last month, charging flaws in the revaluation process that produced overvalued residences and undervalued commercial properties.
But James Ginnan, vice president of Sabre Systems in New Haven, a national revaluation firm that did the work, said Sabre "did a fair and equitable appraisal and we stand behind it."
 Of the 20 revaluation companies certified in the state, only 9 are equipped to handle big communities. Some towns are having difficulty finding a company to hire. "We charge per parcel and we like a large parcel count," said Mr. Ginnan. "It makes our distribution costs easier, like buying in bulk."
The firm handles 17 of the state's largest communities besides Greenwich.
 The revaluation process typically takes two years and 20 evaluators making door-to-door inspections and interpreting sales figures supplied by realtors and municipal agencies. The value of each property is then established from the collected data.
 The Town of Seymour did not implement its 1987 revaluation "because of the outcry against peak real estate values," said Anna Marks, the assessor.
"Now that the market has come down somewhat we just hired MMC of Chelmsford, Mass., to do another revaluation by Oct. 1," she said. "We couldn't get the taxpayers to pay for it any earlier."
Revaluations can cost anywhere from $600,000 to more than $1 million, depending on the size and complexity of the community.
SABRE SYSTEMS is currently working on a Stratford revaluation that was due in 1984. "The town just didn't budget for it," said the assessor, David Valente. "By not doing it, we will now have a steep increase of about 30 percent in residential taxes."
 "Connecticut is losing a lot of business," he continued, "so commercial property is not as valuable. United Technologies and its Sikorksy Aircraft subsidiary pay about 11 percent of Stratford's taxes, but we've had a loss of other businesses and a big drop in condominium values because of oversupply."
 William Bliss, Greenwich's comptroller, said he felt that "10 years is probably too long to wait."
"If you don't revalue promptly," he said, "it can get to be a nightmare, with some people keeping a low value on their properties at the expense of others."
 "Revaluations are threatening," said Robert Tuthill, the Greenwich assessor, "for retired people especially. And a lot of people who bought homes for $1 million are finding that they aren't worth a million any more. Others have multimillion-dollar houses that were grossly underassessed."
 Greenwich has taken pride in consistently having the lowest, or close to lowest, taxes of any Connecticut municipality for generations. A minor contributing factor was the practice of taxing personal property at the same rate as real estate. "It was a matter of interpretation," said Mr. Tuthill, "and we learned that it was the wrong interpretation, so we had to stop it."
 Real estate is assessed at 70 percent of market value at revaluation time, after which the percentage decreases with inflationary pressure until the next revaluation. Personal property, including cars, medical and office equipment, horses, and other items assessed at $1,000 or more, must be taxed each year at the full 70 percent of market value.
On April 25, a bill that would permit a five-year phase-in of a tax increase to lessen its pain gained final passage in the General Assembly. The measure was sponsored by Senator William Nickerson, Republican of Greenwich. The phase-in had been available through a law that expired Oct. 1, 1989.
 The old law permitted the increase to be paid in equal dollar amounts, but the Nickerson bill calls for equal percentage amounts, "making it a gentler transition," he said. Other towns with overdue revaluations are Derby, Groton, Hamden, Meriden, Manchester, Naugatuck, North Branford, Norwalk, Waterbury, West Haven and Windham.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Tax Plans Keep Falling Into Growing Budget Gap

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
AT a news conference last week, State Representative Alan R. Schlesinger, a Republican from Derby, urged that the state sales tax, already the highest in the nation at 8 percent, be hiked to 10 percent. Mr. Schlesinger, whose opposition to an income tax is among the hardest of the hardcore in the General Assembly, said the beefed-up sales tax should also be extended onto previously untaxed items like bus and train tickets.
Hardly anyone, not even Mr. Schlesinger himself, seemed to think that a 10 percent sales tax had much real chance of becoming law. But as the legislator was also quick to point out, none of the other major tax plans put forward over the last two months -- including Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s plan for an income tax -- is in the rosiest of health. 
 With the size of the state's revenue shortfall continuing to grow, passing $2.7 billion for the first time last week, and with the list of ingredients considered indispensable to various legislators growing just as fast, the lawmakers are learning that no one plan has a monopoly on virtues or vices. Mr. Schlesinger, a tax lawyer and a former Congressional candidate, said that one praiseworthy facet of his proposed 2 percent sales tax surcharge is that it would be only temporary, until Connecticut's tax revenue shortfall is resolved. In addition, he said, setting the sales tax at a fat round number would have a sort of mathematical appeal. "Everyone will know what the tax is," he said. "They can calculate it in their heads."
Another voice in the tax-talk chorus was that of the Speaker of the State House of Representatives, Richard J. Balducci, a Democrat from Newington. Mr. Balducci, who has maintained a firm opposition to any tax on wages during his 17-year political career, announced his conversion last week -- sort of.
Mr. Balducci, whose leanings toward an income tax had been rumored in the Capitol for several weeks, spent nearly 10 minutes prefacing his remarks by specifying the elements he needed to see in any budget bill without uttering anything about what everyone was waiting to hear and knew he would ultimately have to try to put into words.
First, he said, any plan must include some formal controls on the growth of state spending. Second, it must be an "economically responsible approach" that will not leave the state with the same old problems later on.
Mr. Balducci's third element was that any income tax plan should have a so-called sunset provision, one that will take it off the books when it is no longer needed. Yet in urging support for a sunset provision for the income tax, he had still to admit wanting a sunrise. "It isn't easy," he said in explaining the awkwardness of the moment. "To me, this is a big step."
The magnitude of the state's budget crisis and the impact of the recession were seen in two small pieces of legislation that moved forward last week in Hartford.
The first was a bill designed to catch tax cheats from other states who buy property in Connecticut, then sell it and make off without paying the 7 percent capital-gains tax on their profits. The bill would allow the state to withhold the first 2 percent of the tax at the time of the contract closing.
But as State Representative Leslie T. Young, a Republican from New Canaan, quietly pointed out, property sellers these days are just about as likely to take a loss on their sales and thus owe no taxes. In all fairness, he said, the state should promise to pay interest on the withheld money in the event it all has to be given back. Mr. Young's amendment passed without opposition.
The second bill was a measure aimed at helping dairy farmers stay in business. It would require the state to make up the difference between a farmer's costs in producing milk and the market price.
Sponsors of the bill, who said that about two-thirds of the state's full-time dairy farmers have gone out of business in just the last decade, said that the current wholesale price for milk -- about $11 per 100 pounds -- is $1 to $2 less than it costs to produce that much milk. The state would pick up the extra dollar to help a farmer break even, for a total cost of $8 million to $9 million a year, the bill said.
But no one seems to know where that money will come from in a budget that already seems squeezed, smashed and pounded beyond recognition.
"We're working to see if we can't free up some money," said Representative Jefferson B. Davis, Democrat from Pomfret, a sponsor of the dairy bill. "I'm not overly optimistic."
 
Next Stop, Fare Hike
 Sixteen months ago, Gov. William A. O'Neill made a big deal out of refusing to go along with a 15 percent fare increase for Connecticut riders of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad. Riders were paying enough and should not pay more, Mr. O'Neill said, in what was widely interpreted as a political move to win favor in Fairfield County for Mr. O'Neill's expected re-election campaign.
Mr. O'Neill and the railroad's parent agency, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, finally settled on a plan that increased fares 15 percent for New York riders, while keeping fares frozen in Connecticut.
Times change.
Last week, the State Department of Transportation announced that the very same 15 percent fare increase over which such a fuss was made under another Governor will finally take effect July 1. This time, department officials said, the increases were in fact prompted by the current Governor.
Mr. Weicker's proposed budget includes cuts in the state's subsidy to Metro-North that will have to made up somewhere, said James Byrnes, the department's Deputy Commissioner for Public Transportation.

LENGTH: 2043 words

HEADLINE: Growth Transforms A 'Sleepy' County

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
FIFTY years ago, the entire population of Ocean County's 33 communities was 38,000. Today, there are more students than that in the county's public elementary schools.
And 50 years ago, 821 poultry farms flourished between Great Bay to the south and Manasquan Inlet to the north, while oystermen raked almost a quarter-million bushels of oysters in a single season from Barnegat Bay. 
 Today, the poultry farms are nearly gone, replaced by rows of houses with neatly tended lawns in front and fenced-in swimming pools in back. And the oysters, their beds disturbed by ground-water runoff and the other effects of of development, have all but vanished from the bay.
The statistics underscore the sweeping changes that have accompanied Ocean County's growth. Indeed, in each of the last three decades, as hundreds of thousands of residents migrated to the county from the urban environs of New York City to the north and Philadelphia to the west, the population grew faster than in any other county in the state.
"The whole way of life here has changed," said Pauline S. Miller, director of the Ocean County Cultural and Heritage Commission. "This was just a rural little sleepy area. But when a county adds 100,000 more citizens every decade, you know that has to have an impact."
Indeed, since 1960, when Ocean County's population first topped 100,000, more than 325,000 new residents have been added to the county's population rolls. According to 1990 census figures, the population of Ocean County, the state's second-largest county in land area after Burlington, now stands at 433,203, an increase of more than 300 percent in 30 years.
In contrast, the state's most populous county, Essex, which had 923,545 residents in 1960, has seen its population decline to 778,206. And Hudson County, despite an influx of Hispanic immigrants, has steadily lost population in every decade since 1930; Hudson now has 553,099 residents.
Ocean County's growth, officials say, is attributable to several factors, including relatively affordable real estate, better-than-average school systems and proximity to three major employment markets -- New York, Philadelphia and Atlantic City -- each a little over an hour's drive away.
But Alan W. Avery Jr., assistant director of the Ocean County Planning Board, said one factor overrode all others.
"The single most important aspect of Ocean County's growth is the Garden State Parkway," he said.
In the summer of 1954, New Jersey's shore resorts were directly linked to the densely populated northeastern part of the state by the opening of the toll road, which now runs the length of the state from Montvale to Cape May.
With the parkway, Mr. Avery said, Ocean County was suddenly an easy drive from New York City and the North Jersey communities. Tourism flourished as carloads of vacationers crowded the sands that stretch from Point Pleasant Beach in the north of the county to Long Beach Township in the south.
Many of the vacationers of the 1950's, he said, eventually became the permanent residents of Ocean County in later years.
As baby boomers grew older and started families of their own, he said, the parents started looking for places to retire. Because property values in northern New Jersey had been steadily increasing, these empty nesters found themselves with large equity reserves.
 
Staying Close to Families
 Forsaking Florida for the more familiar Jersey Shore, and wanting to remain within driving distance of their children and grandchildren, many North Jersey couples headed down the parkway to Ocean County.
"They've been able to sell their homes up north, realize a profit and move down here to retire," Mr. Avery said.
And thousands did. Officials estimate that as many as 125,000 residents now live in Ocean County's 60 retirement communities -- private developments that set minimum-age requirements for residents. The communities range from sprawling tracts of small, almost identical houses to exclusive villages of custom-built homes with shared amenities like swimming pools, tennis courts and clubhouses.
According to statistics compiled by the New Jersey Department of Labor, Ocean County led every other county in the state in residential construction during the years 1980 to 1989. Nearly 50,000 building permits were issued for residential units in the county during that period.
At the same time that retirees from North Jersey were heading south, officials say, their children were finding it more and more difficult to buy first homes up north because of inflated real-estate prices. They too started looking toward Ocean County. In Dover Township, which is the county seat and located on Barnegat Bay, the average assessed value of residential property in 1988 was $114,788.
 Mr. Avery said many young couples decided to trade commuting time for bigger houses and better schools and moved to the Jersey Shore.
 
'This Was Our Only Chance'
 Wayne J. Sandberg and his wife, Joanne, who recently signed a contract to buy a house in Dover Township, present a typical example. They are purchasing a three-bedroom house for $109,000.
"We figured that if we're going to buy a house, this was our only chance," said Mr. Sandberg, who will commute to his job as a truck driver in Secaucus. "It will take me about an hour and 10 minutes to get to work," he said. "It takes my bosses who live on Long Island even longer."
The Sandbergs currently live with their children in a rented house in Franklin Lakes. "Franklin Lakes is nice," Mrs. Sandberg said, "but we could never buy a house up here. It's just too expensive."
She said she was looking forward to the move because "the air is cleaner, the schools are better and most of my friends are down there already."
 
Concentrated in Northeast
 The greatest concentration of residents in Ocean County live in its northeastern corner, on the mainland, along the upper reaches of Barnegat Bay. Brick Township, for example, with 66,473 residents, is a bustling community that is bordered on the east by Point Pleasant and on the west by the Garden State Parkway.
And Dover Township is a sprawling bayfront community with more than 76,000 residents -- a mixture of lifelong Ocean County residents, recently arrived young families and retired citizens living in adult communities like Holiday City, Greenbriar Woodlands and the Gardens of Pleasant Plains.
Despite the steady growth the county has enjoyed, some officials say the time may have come to assess whether continued development is appropriate. Mrs. Miller, of the county's Cultural and Heritage Commission, said the current economic recession and the slowdown in construction might be a good thing.
"Maybe people will use what's already been built rather than just go ahead and build more," she said. "It's sad to see how much of the county has been destroyed by growth."
 
Increased Congestion on Roads
 The impact of unchecked development on the county, she said, is apparent in increased congestion on local roadways, the destruction of historic buildings and the pollution of Barnegat Bay by "too many houses, too many sewers and too much ground water running off into the bay."
She said that "a 10-minute drive to a mall 10 years ago can take a half-hour today." And, she said, "it's a constant battle to keep houses on our Main Streets."
She cited a case in the early 80's, when an Italianate mansion built in 1868 on Washington Street overlooking the Toms River in Dover Township was demolished, despite protests by her agency. A parking lot now occupies the site.
The county's public school system is also experiencing growing pains. At least 16 of the county's 30 school districts are either building or planning to build new schools or additions to existing schools, said Joseph F. Zach, Ocean County Superintendent of Schools.
"The problem has been that the growth always stays ahead of the solution," Mr. Zach said. "As the districts grow, they build a new school, and a couple of years later, they're overcrowded again."
Mr. Zach said there were now more than 62,000 students in the county's public schools. More than 40,000 of them are in the elementary grades.
 
'Bursting at the Seams'
 The county has two colleges. Georgian Court College, in Lakewood, is private. Ocean County Community College, in Dover Township, is a public instution that offers a two-year associate's degree; it is brimming with students.
"We're bursting at the seams," said Dr. Milton Shaw, president of the community college. In the fall semester of 1990, Dr. Shaw said, 7,464 students registered for classes -- a phenomenal enrollment, considering that the college has graduated a total of 13,051 students in its 25-year history.
Dr. Shaw said he expected enrollment to continue to increase for at least the next six years, which will probably mean holding additional classes later in the day and moving some courses to off-campus classrooms in the public schools.
 Peter Schnell, chairman of the Ocean County Tourism Advisory Council, said the county's explosive growth rate of the last few decades was expected to subside, now that real-estate prices in other parts of the state had leveled off. The future, he said, is likely to see a more orderly expansion of the county's commercial sectors, coupled with a rebirth of the industry that put Ocean County on the map in the first place: tourism.
 
'Limitless Market for Tourists'
 "We have a virtually limitless market for tourists," Mr. Schnell said, referring to a study prepared for the casino industry indicating that as many as 50 million people live within a 10-hour drive of Atlantic City, which is only 50 miles down the Garden State Parkway.
<> <>
 Northern Ocean County is no longer the tourist mecca it once was, primarily because many former vacation bungalows are now year-round residences. But Mr. Schnell said the southern portion of the county was becoming increasingly popular among tourists.
He said Island Beach State Park, which is north of the Barnegat Inlet, and Long Beach Island, which is south, represent Ocean County at its best: long stretches of pristine sands and relatively uncrowded beaches.
And new development is highly restricted, Mr. Schnell said, both along the shore and within the vast interior pinelands district that covers almost half of the county's 638 square miles. The shore area, he said, is regulated by the State Coastal Area Review Board set up in 1973 under the Coastal Area Facilities Review Act. And development in the pinelands is monitored by the 15-member state Pinelands Commission, which was established in 1979.
As for northern Ocean County, Mr. Schnell said, any new development is likely to be less residential.
"It's happening already," he said. "There are office buildings being built, the hospitals are expanding, they're widening the highways."

 
Shift in Retirement Housing
 Indeed, H. Hovnanian Industries, a Tinton Falls developer that has built more than 14,000 residential units in Ocean County, is now shifting its focus from single-family retirement condominiums to commercial construction and the development of "congregate care facilities," which are blocks of efficiency apartments for elderly citizens.
Edele Hovnanian, vice president of the company, said the single-family residential market for retirees was becoming glutted, as aging residents of retirement communities moved out of their homes and into congregate-care developments or decided to live with their children.
Despite such predictions, retirement communities are still being built and retirees are still moving south.
"It's a different life altogether here," said Charles Loguidice, 66, who with his wife, Victoria, 65, recently moved to Lionshead Woods, a new retirement development in Lakewood, from their home in Brooklyn.
Mr. Loguidice, who lived in Manhattan after he arrived in this country from Sicily as a child, said that in his younger days he would never have predicted he would be living at the Jersey shore.
"When I moved out of Manhattan, I thought Brooklyn was the country and Ocean County was the boondocks," he said. "Now, when I go to New York, I can't wait to get back home."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Amid Layoffs, the Froth Is Gaining

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
FIGHTING recessions used to be a two-front war. The Federal Reserve cut interest rates, and the politicians raised spending and cut taxes.
This recession is different. The Fed is battling, and seems determined to keep cutting rates until the economy notices. But governments are laying off workers -- 25,000 last month -- as they gasp for funds. 
 The evidence that the Fed is winning its war is sketchy at best. The unemployment rate of 6.6 percent in April would be greatly cheering, if anyone believed it. The trouble is that the rate, which is based on a household survey, is not supported by payroll figures, which tend to be more reliable. The best that can be said about them is that the rate of layoffs seems to be slowing.
"The economy is still in recession, but it is moving along the bottom," says Deborah Johnson, an economist at C. J. Lawrence. "It needs consumer spending to get moving again." Unfortunately, the surge of consumer confidence that greeted victory in Iraq seems to be fading.
Still, Washington and Wall Street seem to be in agreement that recovery is at hand, even if the figures don't prove it. Stock prices managed a small gain this week, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 17.82 points, to 2,938.86, in the wake of the third consecutive cut in the discount rate.
Actually, the end of recession seems to be taken for granted now among traders, if not economists. This is a rip-roaring bull market, the kind that rewards enthusiasm and punishes caution.
Last fall, for example, anything that was associated with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts was viewed with suspicion. Now, investors line up to buy Duracell shares for four times what the K.K.R. insiders paid three years ago.
For sheer stock market excitement, the tale of Conseco is instructive. Conseco is a heavily indebted insurance company that has been growing by acquisition. Sometimes it puts the debt on its balance sheet; sometimes it doesn't. There have been questions about whether it is too slow to write off the cost of acquisitions. Last October, shares in Conseco sold for $17. This week they hit $74.
The game going on now at Conseco and more than a few other stocks is known as short squeezing. As the price rises, speculators who bet that the price would go down are being forced to run for cover. Brokers are urging customers to buy the stock simply to profit from the shorts' misery.
"It's a classic battle, and the bulls are winning right now," said one Conseco short last week, admitting that he was having increasing difficulty hanging on. "It's a slaughter."
Short squeezes tend to be brief and bloody, and there often are two classes of losers. First come the shorts, then those who bought in hopes of squeezing them and held on too long.
So far, most shorts seem not to have given up. When they do, this rally may be history; bull markets often end when the short interest tumbles. It is possible that occurrence will coincide with a new fear that the recession is not ending, and a suspicion that the Fed cannot win this war by itself.

LENGTH: 1609 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/April 28-May 3

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
So Many Auto Makers . . . and So Few Sales
 

What's wrong with Detroit? Partly the recession, but only partly. Between them, the domestic auto makers lost $1.85 billion in the first quarter because of weak sales. "Abysmal," said Lee Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation. It could have been worse -- $723 million worse -- if the General Motors Corporation had not sold its building in New York. And in the final quarter of 1990, the companies lost $2.1 billion. So what's going wrong? Not technology. Since 1981, the Big Three have spent $121.9 billion upgrading plants and equipment. Not quality. Many of their cars are now world-class. "The problem is overcapacity in the industry," said Malcolm Salter, chairman of the Harvard Business School's advanced management program. "In 1989, 9.9 million cars were sold, a good year. Even so, North American plants operated at only 76 percent of capacity." In a slow year, like this one, he said overcapacity could be as high as two million units. Part of Detroit's strategy has been to shut excess plants. But then foreign companies open new ones. "Even after all the plant closings and the ones planned for this year, Detroit will still operate at just 75 percent of capacity," Mr. Salter said. It will get tougher. "They have to keep bringing out new models to differentiate themselves from the others." That takes time and even more money.
 
A Smaller General Dynamics
 
The General Dynamics Corporation will share in what could be the most lucrative military contract in history -- $95 billion over a decade to build 650 planes for the Air Force. And last week it won a $2 billion contract to build a new attack submarine. But even that is not enough to keep it whole. Over the next four years, the nation's second-largest military contractor will let 27,000 workers go. With the threat from the Soviet Union diminished, Washington is cutting back on weapons. Because it failed to diversify into the commercial market -- 87 percent of its revenue comes from the Government -- the company has no choice but to scale down. "The downsizing is not cyclical," said Gordon Adams, director of the Defense Budget Project, in Washington. The industry is shrinking.
 
Duracell Brightens the Market
 
When Duracell International Inc. went public last week, its stock charged up the market. The initial offering was at $15, but by the end of the day, the stock had jumped $5.75 to $20.75, sparking a rally in which 20 million of the 30 million shares offered changed hands. It finished the week at $21.25. The success of the deal testifies once more to how hot Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company is right now. The buyout firm acquired Duracell in 1988 for $5 a share. Why all the fuss about Duracell? Analysts think it is one of the best-run companies in the business.
 
NBC's Shaky Success
 
For six years he kept NBC No. 1 in the ratings. But now Brandon Tartikoff, chairman of NBC's entertainment group, is going to the movies. He is becoming chairman of Paramount Pictures, the money-losing movie maker owned by Paramount Communications Inc. He may be making the move just in time. While NBC remains No. 1, with cable No. 1 means less than it used to. Viewership is off and the networks are losing money. Rumors have even been circulating -- strongly denied -- that the General Electric Corporation, NBC's parent, might put NBC up for sale.
 
A New, Improved Dow
 
It's a little like rewriting the Bible. Dow Jones & Company changed the make-up of the 30-stock Dow Jones industrial average to better reflect the economic importance of services and the entertainment industry. It added the Walt Disney Company, J.P. Morgan & Company and Caterpillar Inc. -- the most stocks changed since 1959 when four were replaced. It removed the Navistar International Corporation, the Primerica Corporation and the USX Corporation from the list. J.P. Morgan is the first bank to be included in the average. Even with the changes, the Dow still reflects industrial America. Most of stocks are in the manufacturing and resource sectors.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY


Bush Gets His Way on Rates
 
After weeks of shouting, the Administration has finally gotten its message across to Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. The nation is in a sticky recession -- the White House says -- that can only be cured if interest rates go lower. The Federal Reserve has finally complied. Last week it lowered the discount rate, the amount it charges member banks to borrow short term, from 6 percent to 5.5 percent, the lowest rate since 1987. It also lowered the funds rate, the amount banks charge each other to borrow. That rate dipped from 6 percent to 5.75 percent. Will the drop in rates work? The prime rate at banks around the country slipped half a point to 8.5 percent, the lowest since 1987. For people with loans tied to the prime, that means more money in their pockets. Now, if they would just spend.
 
Uneven Gains on Housing
 
New home sales moved up 1 percent in March -- welcome news from the Commerce Department. It follows on strong gains of 18.6 percent in February. But does it mean the end of the recession is near? To some, yes. "This confirms our judgment that the bottom of the cycle was in January," said David F. Selders, chief economist at the National Association of Homebuilders. But even with two months of gains, sales so far this year are still 21.1 percent below last year. And the gains are uneven across the country.
 
Figures on Jobs Don't Jibe
 
The numbers are confusing. Unemployment fell to 6.6 percent in April from 6.8 percent in March. That's good. But the payroll report, which records by computer how many people are actually working, fell by 125,000 for the month. That's bad. Yet the household survey, another component of the figures released last week by the Labor Department, showed an increase of 600,000 jobs, which is good. "That's a tremendous discrepancy," said Lawrence Chimerine, senior adviser to DRI Inc., a research firm. The Labor Department says the survey is picking up the large number of people who have started businesses and are working at home. "I have trouble believing that," Mr. Chimerine said. "The payroll numbers are the reliable ones. I have to conclude we're still losing jobs."
 
Misleading Indicators
 
Judging from the way it moved, the index of leading indicators is a very murky crystal ball. On average, according to the Commerce Department, the indicators rose: 0.5 percent for March, following a 1.2 percent rise in February. But if looked at individually, 7 out of 11 fell. Curiously, they were the ones linked most closely to the economy's day-to-day performance. The gainers were stock prices, the number of new building permits issued, the size of the money supply and consumer expectations. Important, yes, but not to everyone. Among the indicators that fell were the number of hours worked, new orders for consumer goods and new orders for plants and equipment -- important all around. The result is that "we're still declining but at a slower rate," said Richard B. Berner, an economist at Salomon Brothers in New York. How much longer will the economy decline? Mr. Berner expects an upturn before summer's end.
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Bad Economic News Travels
 
They call it the English-speaking recession because the United States, Britain, Canada and Australia are all in a slump. But now the recession may be learning Japanese. "The leading indicators are sharply down for the sixth month in a row and the money supply is contracting," said Madis Senner, an international money manager in New York. "Their economy could come to a dead halt." And last week the Conference Board, a business research group in New York, released a report that was equally pessimistic. "Housing is in virtual collapse, consumer confidence is down and fixed investment -- which is 25 percent of the economy -- will be up by just 1 percent," said Gail Fosler, who compiled the report. "Estimates were Japan would grow this year by 5 percent," she said. "Now they're down to 3.5 percent. It could go lower."
 
Full Speed Ahead on Mexico?
 
President Bush wants negotiations with Mexico over a proposed free-trade agreement to be put on the fast track. That would let the Administration cut a deal Congress could not negotiate, only pass or kill. But last week, a coalition of 60 organizations -- labor unions, environmentalists and border-state farmers -- told Congress to go slowly. They are worried the fast track will end in a sour deal, one that allows companies to take advantage of Mexico's lax pollution laws. Will President Bush be able to stay on the fast track? Most analysts say yes.
 
The Twilight of the Trabant
 
It looked like one of those toy cars in front of the supermarket -- 25 a ride. But for 36 years, the Trabant rattled windows, lost hubcaps and fouled the East German air. The car's two-cylinder, two-stroke engine mixed oil with gas and had no smog device. Its body -- the same design since the beginning -- was of brittle fiberglass. And it went from zero to 60 miles per hour, Germans joked, in just under 15 minutes. But they were loved. Three million were made by Volkseigener Betrieb Sachsenring in Zwickau. Last week, the final one rolled off the ramp. When the Berlin Wall fell, the Trabant met its match and lost. It could not compete with Volkswagen -- which took over its aging plant -- Mercedes-Benz, Opel or B.M.W. But then again, a Mercedes can cost more than $100,000, Trabants just $2,000.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Drug Stocks as a Global Play

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
Bolstering its reputation as recession-proof, the pharmaceutical business is prospering on both sides of the Atlantic. Demand for prescription drugs continues to be strong, although French Government agencies have cut the prices of several products this year and Germany has also started to squeeze prices.
"In a recession, the health-care industry sure beats the steel business," said Andy Markey, treasurer of Johnson & Johnson, the world's largest health-care company. Johnson & Johnson does more than half its business overseas. 
 Abby Joseph Cohen, a vice president and strategic investing adviser with Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York, views drug companies as attractive investments with above-average growth, whether they are based in the United States, Britain or other European countries, "and perhaps in Asia as well."
"The companies are seen as classically defensive buys, unrelated to interest rates, recession or anything else," said Jo Walton, a pharmaceuticals analyst in London with Shearson Lehman Brothers. "When people are ill and growing older, demand rises, regardless of economic conditions."
Ms. Walton said drug sales were growing worldwide by 10 to 12 percent a year, although in a recession many governments seem "less willing to allow drug prices to rise." Government agencies control drug prices in most industrial countries but not the United States. She said France, for example, sharply cut the price of three strong-selling products at the beginning of the year: Merck's cholesterol drug Zocor, Eli Lilly's antidepressant Prozac and the Hoffmann-La Roche injectible antibiotic Rocephin.
"On the flip side of this," she added, "companies are being much more aggressive about prices for new drugs." She said Glaxo recently introduced a new anti-asthma drug, Serevent, which is "10 times as expensive" as the leading older asthma drug in Britain.
Ms. Walton likes Hoffmann-La Roche, Pfizer and SmithKline Beecham. Roche's pharmaceutical sales are growing by 21 percent, she said, and the company may get Food and Drug Administration approval this year to market DDC, a new AIDS drug, in the United States. Pfizer has a "very strong pipeline, with new product launches coming through," she added. "And SmithKline is still reaping the benefits of cost savings in its merger with Beecham."
On the down side, some drug makers worry about divisions that sell candies and other consumer products, including SmithKline Beecham, Johnson & Johnson and American Home Products.
The recession can also be a problem for European drug companies like Ciba-Geigy, Bayer and Rhone-Poulenc, which also make chemicals that are hurt by the slowdown, said Viren Mehta, a partner at Mehta & Isaly, a New York research firm specializing in pharmaceuticals. Nevertheless, Mr. Mehta recommends Glaxo, Bayer and Ciba-Geigy.
Mr. Mehta also sees values in small European biotechnology companies. He said, "Many European companies are every bit as good as the American companies." Shares of 40 American biotechnology companies were up 55 percent in the first quarter of this year, but fell back in April, recording a gain of 49 percent for the first four months.
By contrast, Mr. Mehta said, the European biotechnology companies rose only 11.5 percent in the four months. He likes Serono, based in Geneva; Immuno, based in Vienna and listed on the Zurich Stock Exchange, and Synthelabo, based in Paris.
The moves last week by the Federal Reserve to push down interest rates are only of indirect concern to pharmaceutical companies. Drug makers typically carry little debt. Not surprisingly, they borrow in countries with low rates and park their cash where rates are high.
When the Fed acted last week, American-based companies hoped that the dollar would weaken, increasing the value of sales made in foreign currencies. But the Bundesbank refused to lower German rates. So the dollar has continued to strengthen, which may mean slower growth later this year for American companies when their foreign sales are translated into dollars.
A strong dollar is good news, however, for Glaxo P.L.C. and SmithKline Beecham. Both do much of their business in the United States but report their sales in British pounds.
SmithKline's sales, for example, were 4.5 billion last year, of which 2 billion was in the United States. "We hedge the risk by buying and selling futures and making forward contracts" in both pounds and dollars, said Philip Ward, a SmithKline spokesman in London. "We look at our budgeted profits and cover the profits we expect to make" in case of sharp swings in the exchange rates.
Mr. Markey at Johnson & Johnson said hedging activity in the industry is increasing. He said, "We do selective hedging on our cash flows." Whether the hedging operations should be included in American company financial reports is under review at the Financial Accounting Standards Board, the quasi-official body that decides such questions.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 8; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1075 words

HEADLINE: Technology;
Outdoor Equipment Designers Reset Their Sights on Fanatics

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
At Marmot Mountain Works, a mountaineering store in Berkeley, Calif., Joshua Bodine has spent as much as two hours fitting a customer with a new backpack.
As often as not, the pack Mr. Bodine fine-tunes to cling to the customer's back has been created by Dana Gleason, one of an elite group of American designers creating advanced mountaineering gear. 
 Designers like Mr. Gleason are riding a new wave of interest in the environment and rugged outdoor sports, and Mr. Gleason's company, Dana Design, based in Bozeman, Mont., has in the last two years attained a reputation for building backpacks that excel in load balance and comfort.
"I'm a monomaniac," he said. "I think about packs all the time." Dana Mountaineering now employs 85 and has two factories. Its packs are selling in Japan as well as the United States.
Dana itself represents a shift back to traditional concerns in the outdoor equipment industry. After the outdoor gear boom of the 1970's, companies like Eddie Bauer and Patagonia, which had gained prominence supplying expedition and climbing gear, shifted their product lines to what are called soft goods -- apparel and fashion.
But now that is changing again. "We've had more Earth Day awareness, and with the recession people look toward muscle-powered sports for outdoor recreation," said Terri Perlman, a buyer for backpacks and climbing equipment at Recreational Equipment Inc., an outdoor-equipment cooperative headquartered in Seattle.
As a result, there is interest in top-of-the-line packs that may cost anywhere from $250 to $500 and that employ the latest in lightweight materials as both frames and fabrics.
Since pack designers must design for the most demanding users, they frequently pioneer ideas. "We have to be fanatics," said Mr. Gleason. "If things don't work right for us, we hurt physically."
Mr. Gleason has found competition from several other designers. Mike Scherer is a designer at Kelty Inc., one of the leading names in the mainstream backpack market. Mr. Scherer has revitalized the Kelty name with several unusual designs.
Another prominent rival is Wayne Gregory, who in the early 70's pioneered the first advanced designs for internal packs -- those whose frames are sewn inside the fabric. His company, Gregory Mountaineering, dominated the high end of the pack market in the first half of the 80's, but in recent years has slipped behind Dana Mountaineering.
Backpacks in the 90's use ultralight aerospace industry materials and often sport brilliant multicolored fabrics, straps and fasteners. This gear has little in common with the equipment built by the first generation of high-tech pack designers in the 60's. Those packs replaced wood frames and leather shoulder straps with frames made with braised-aluminum tubing and cotton or nylon back bands to hold the frame away from the back. Later innovations included the waistband, which permitted backpackers to shift some of the pack's load from shoulders to hips.
Today's state-of-the-art backpacks are intended for demanding users who may spend as much time on rugged cross-country traverses as they do on more civilized trails. They usually have internal frames made out of exotic materials like aluminum alloy, carbon fiber or even titanium.
Recently, the pack builders have begun experimenting with a variety of new design ideas. One change is the use of molded polyurethane for fitting the packs more closely to the back and waist. Thin sheets of polyethylene add rigidity and keep objects in the pack from poking the wearer in the back.
Compared with traditional external frames, internal-frame designs ride closer to the back and have less sway, a desirable quality for moving off trails and for back-country skiing, in which an external frame may interfere with poling.
The search for greater performance and durability has also led designers like Mr. Scherer to search for new fabrics that are more durable than pack cloth or cordura nylon. Two years ago Kelty, for example, introduced a new line of packs that use a phenomenally durable cloth made from a new fabric called Spectra.
Developed by the Allied-Signal Corporation, the material is stronger than Kevlar, the material used in bullet-proof vests, for the same weight. Spectra, which is half the weight of traditional pack materials, permits the design of packs that are as much as two pounds lighter than identical packs using conventional materials. But Spectra is very difficult to dye and the material is available only in white.
The material comes at a high price -- $35 a yard, almost 10 times the price of conventional materials. That is one reason the new packs cost $400 to $500. "It's a small market," Mr. Scherer said.
The biggest difference in design philosophy comes in suspension design, the foundation of a modern internal frame. Wayne Gregory pioneered the idea of using two thin stays of aluminum alloy that stretch from the shoulder straps to the waistband. By custom- bending the stays to the user's back he was able to get a more comfortable fit and a superior ride. "I'm the guy who started the madness of bending frames," said Mr. Gregory.
But four years ago, while he was on a long backpacking trip on the John Muir Trail in the Sierra Nevada, Mr. Gregory was alarmed to notice that most of his packs had not been fitted correctly in the stores. As a result, he has modified his design approach. He now uses a carbon fiber stay instead of aluminum alloy and after measuring more than 100 backs has come up with a standard design that he says works for most hikers.
Mr. Gleason of Dana and Mr. Scherer of Kelty disagree with this approach, and they still require that their packs be custom-fitted for each user.
Both Gregory and Dana now use carbon fiber stays, which they say provide greater vertical stiffness for load transfer between shoulders and hips as well as a livelier ride and better torsion than was provided by aluminum. Mr. Scherer, who is passionate in his search for ways to cut weight, has settled on extremely thin -- and more costly -- titanium stays.
Mr. Gregory acknowledges that he has lost the lead in the market to Mr. Gleason's Dana packs, but he says he is working on a new model to be introduced later this year.
"Dana is going to have to look at what I'm doing," he said, in a recent interview. "I was dormant for about five years, but I'm very inquisitive about new technologies."

HEADLINE: All About/Trucking;
A Whole Lot of Shaking Going On

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
When the trucking industry was deregulated in 1980, thousands of new companies sprang up seeking to take advantage of the new ease of entry and greater freedom to set their own prices. Hundreds of existing companies expanded quickly, adding non-union divisions and entering new markets ranging from pickup and delivery to storage.
A decade later, many of the new entrants have gone out of business and scores of established companies have also gone under, victims of fierce competition and an inability to adapt to an unregulated market. 
 The biggest winners in this new world have been the four trucking giants -- formerly dominant, now even more so.
United Parcel Service in Greenwich, Conn., which had $13.6 billion in revenues last year is by far the industry leader. Its familiar brown trucks and vans operate in all markets, from long distance hauling to pick up and delivery.
Consolidated Freightways in Palo Alto, Calif., is next with $4.2 billion in revenues last year, followed by Roadway Express Inc., in Akron, Ohio, with $2.97 billion and Yellow Freight Systems Inc. in Kansas City with $2.3 billion. Unlike the others, Yellow operates only a long-haul business.
In 1989, the latest year for which revenue comparisons are available, the top four companies accounted for 47 percent of the total revenue of the top 100 trucking companies. In 1980, the same four had had just 29 percent of the market.
"There's been a shakeout with the leading carriers grabbing a bigger and bigger piece of the pie," said Graeme Lidgerwood, a transportation analyst at CS First Boston in New York. And, she added, these giants will get stronger yet as new entrants find it more difficult to raise the capital they need to grow and take advantage of the cost savings that size can bring.

 
 
Full Loads and Not
Differing Logistics in a Split Market
 The American Trucking Associations divides the industry into two major segments: full truckload and less-than-full truckload, dropping U.P.S. totals from the broken-down segments because of the special nature of that operation.
Many companies compete in both markets although the less-than-full-truckload segment is larger by far.
The logistics of sending a fully loaded truck containing goods from a single company to a single destination are quite different from those of routing less-than-full truckloads to several destinations. In the latter case, trucks sometimes load and unload packages at depots all over the country before making it to their final stops.
As might be expected, Consolidated, Roadway and Yellow dominate the less-than-full segment of the market. Together, they control 45 percent of that market.
In the less concentrated full-truckload segment, the four leading companies, all far smaller than the less-than-full giants, together controlled just 11 percent of that segment.
Top among the full-truckload four is Schneider National Carriers Inc., which had $832 million in revenues last year, based in Green Bay, Wis. J.B. Hunt, with $580 million is in Lowell, Ark. Builders Transport Inc.,with $252 million, is in Camden, S.C. And Werner Inc., with $240 million, is in Omaha, Neb. None of these carriers were in the top 100 before the industry was deregulated.

 
 
Little-Guy Growth
Startups Proliferate Despite Failure Rate
 Unlike the airline industry, where very few new entrants have emerged to prosper since the early days of deregulation, there are still hundreds of new trucking companies, many quite small, springing up every year as bright-eyed entrepreneurs set out to seek their fortunes.
Indeed, the number of trucking companies -- in all three categories set up by the Interstate Commerce Commission -- has proliferated from 18,045 in 1980 to 33,283 in 1985 and 45,791 in 1990.
The mortality rate of these carriers remains high, as the new companies "find out the hard way that it's not easy," said Russell B. Capelle Jr., director of statistical analysis for the American Trucking Associations. "Many disappear within months."
But the actual number of failures is declining. From a high of over 1,500 companies a year shutting down between 1985 to 1986, the rate has dropped to about 1,200 failures a year, he said.

 
 
The Squeeze Ahead
Railroads, Soft Rates and Pay Hikes
 As others have stumbled, the big three -- Yellow, Roadway and Consolidated -- often found they could buy equipment and terminals at bargain prices. They also hired the pick of their ailing competitors' drivers and took over the failed companies' customers.
All helped consolidate their dominance of the industry. And Ms. Lidgerwood of CS First Boston is now wondering whether another round of shakeouts is in the making.
"I'm very disturbed that there is continuing pressure on rates," she said. An increase of 5 percent in January of 1990 by the less-than-full-truckload carriers "just about evaporated and several others were often undercut," she said. Another stab at 5.5 percent rise last month, she said, may not yield as much revenue as expected because of discounting.
Many large companies, hurting in the weak economy, are scouring the industry for low bidders, pitting trucker against trucker in an ever-rougher market.
And the industry recently negotiated a new contract with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters that calls for an increase in wages of about 3.3 percent a year. With benefits, that increase is more like 4 percent. Obviously, the new contract adds to the squeeze on trucking profits.
The plight of the full-truckload carriers may even be tougher since many are losing business to the railroads. With the double stacking of truck containers on rail cars, the railroads have cut costs and improved service on long-haul segments -- West Coast to Chicago, for example.
So far, the trucking industry has been able to keep its share of the transportation market constant at about 78 percent. But cost pressures may cause the full-truckload segment to see some erosion against other forms of transportation.
Some companies are even conceding their long-haul routes along the major corridors to the railroads, according to Ms. Lidgerwood. For example, one major carrier, J.B. Hunt,has an agreement with the Sante Fe Pacific railroad under which it turns over its long-haul freight between Chicago-to-Los Angeles to the railroad.
And this sort of give-up could spill over into less-than-full segment, not to mention shorter hauls.
 
 
 
YELLOW FREIGHT TAKES THE HIGH ROAD
 The 10,000 orange trucks of Yellow Freight Systems Inc. have become as familiar to drivers as the McDonald's restaurants on the nation's highways. They seem to be everywhere.
It was not always so. When deregulation went into effect in 1980, Yellow Freight was a major less-than-full-truckload carrier but it did not have a strong presence in all parts of the country.
"We were transcontinental, but we had a lot of gaps," George E. Powell 3d, the president and chief executive of the company, recalled.
In 1981, the Kansas City company had 248 terminals, 13,250 employees and revenues of $936 million. But with the onset of deregulation, the firm began to spend hundreds of millions of dollars buying up terminals and equipment from bankrupt competitors and building new terminals to knit together a strong nationwide route system.
The company is now the nation's largest handler of less-than-truckload freight, with 640 terminals, 28,000 employees and revenues of $2.3 billion last year.
At the height of its expansion, Yellow was spending well over $180 million a year, setting an all-time high of $193 million in 1984. Now, with that network in place, capital spending has begun to drop, totalling $162 million last year. The drop in spending has enabled Yellow to reward its stockholders. It raised their dividend last year to 23.5 cents a share, from 19 cents.
But Mr. Powell said that while the company expected to spend less, that could change if there was pressure to quickly adopt new technology like automatic freight handling systems.
Mr. Powell recalled that the conventional wisdom in the early part of deregulation was that service to smaller communities would dry up. The volume of traffic, it was believed, was not there to make it worthwhile for a carrier the size of Yellow to go there.
Instead, he said, the large carriers found that they had to reach into the smaller communities to generate the volume that would support the huge systems they were building.
During the next decade Mr. Powell said, the large companies will be looking for ways to grow in an industry where most markets have been saturated with service.
"The challenge will be find new opportunties to be profitable," he said.
