HEADLINE: Israeli Economy Is Keeping Many Jews in U.S.S.R.

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, May 3

 BODY:
The Israeli Government is openly acknowledging for the first time that tens of thousands of Soviet Jews are postponing or canceling their moves to Israel because of the country's inability to provide jobs for those already here.
In dozens of emotional speeches over the last 18 months, Israeli leaders have tied the nation's hopes for the future to the successful absorption of the Soviet Union's Jews. Now they admit that they are failing. 
 Late last month the Government revised its official estimate, saying that no more than 200,000 Soviet Jews are now expected to move here this year rather than the 300,000 to 400,000 expected before. Some officials say the number may actually fall even lower.
"This is a real tragedy," said Michael Kleiner, head of the Parliament's Immigration and Absorption Committee. "At least half have decided that for the time being they have changed their program. We're talking about a snowball gaining speed."
The Bank of Israel, in a major report just issued, warned that unless the Government immediately carried out fundamental economic changes to create new jobs, up to 200,000 of the Soviet Jews who have just arrived would decide to leave over the next several years.
Even now, the nation's unemployment rate stands at about 11 percent, the highest rate in recent times. By the end of the year, the Bank of Israel's and other economists estimate, the rate could rise to between 13 and 18 percent. And when that happens, the bank study says, thousands of the new immigrants as well as many other Israelis will probably flee.
The study does not try to guess where these people might go. But it seems likely that many would try to move to the United States.
The financial problems causing the rising unemployment are manifold. The economy is heavily state controlled; more than 60 percent of the nation's economic activity is the result of Government-related spending. Year after year the statistics show sluggish growth, double-digit inflation and a currency that seems to be forever declining in value. Those are not conditions that promote the creation of jobs.
Time and time again over the last two decades, public and private economists have urged the Government to divest itself of its extensive, poorly managed business and industrial holdings -- to free up the economy so it can grow and create jobs.
Nonetheless, a new study published by American economists at the Institute for Advanced Strategic and Political Studies in Jerusalem says the economy is still "riddled with money-losing state-owned enterprises, a huge Government bureaucracy, dozens of official monopolies and cartels, massive taxpayer subsidies of manufacturers, price controls applied to a quarter of all consumer goods, tariff and nontariff barriers to free trade, foreign exchange controls, Government domination of the capital markets, Government ownership of 93 percent of Israel's land, oppressive levels and rates of taxation and bureaucratic hurdles to entrepreneurship."
Israeli economists acknowledge much of that. But almost every attempt at change is stifled by a Government so tied up in inter-ministerial bickering that it never seems able to carry out any of its plans. Just as important, the all-powerful national labor union representing 90 percent of the state's workers often calls strikes that shut much of the country down when it believes its interests are threatened. Under those twin pressures, little ever seems to change.
In another report, published almost two years ago when the nation's unemployment rate was first approaching 10 percent, the Bank of Israel issued an urgent warning that the Government must immediately put together "a well-thought-out, long-term economic strategy" to create new jobs. "Only a few would deny the need for a drastic reduction in the current level of Government intervention," it added.
Now, Michael Bruno, Governor of the bank, said in an interview this week: "There've been changes. But they've been very, very slow. Too slow."
 
 'Looming Disaster' In Economy Seen
 Alvin Rabushka, a senior fellow at the Hoover Institute at Stanford University and the principal author of the Institute for Advanced Strategic and Political Studies report, draws a darker conclusion. Israel's leaders, he writes, are making no discernible effort to face up to "the looming disaster of Israel's economy, together with the squalid farce being made of the Russian immigration."
In fact, every plan offered so far to address the unemployment and immigrant absorption problems advocates greater Government intervention in the economy, not less. That is not only because of political inertia. The dozens of Government-controlled enterprises have grown to be an important vehicle for patronage appointments and other political debt-paying.
And so, the institute study says, "the Israeli vision of the future is to continue down the same failed, dismal path of more and bigger Government."
The immediate victims are the Soviet Jews.
Just over 254,000 new immigrants have moved here since January 1990, and more than 90 percent of them are from the Soviet Union.
This comes during a period when most Israelis have had little to feel good about and much to regret, including the Palestinian uprising, endemic political crises, Israel's declining image abroad and most recently the Scud attacks during the Persia Gulf war. But the mass Soviet immigration has seemed the one bright spot on an otherwise bleak horizon, an affirmation that the country was still vital and attractive.
 
 Early Welcome Is Now Fading
 A year ago Israelis were ebullient when the immigration first swelled to a rate exceeding 10,000 people a month. The nation's leaders and hundreds of other people flocked to Ben-Gurion International Airport each night to greet the newcomers with flowers and song.
Now, to many Government officials, the charts illustrating the rising monthly immigration rates last year -- 10,300 in May 1990, 15,294 in July, 35,294 in December -- seem to stand more as a threat, even a rebuke, than as a warm record of accomplishment.
The Government gives all the Soviet immigrants living subsidies -- Israelis call that the "absorption basket" -- to carry them through their first year here. During that time, they are to learn Hebrew, find a place to live and adjust to Israeli society.
Some find at least part-time work in that time. But the vast majority enter the serious job market only when their subidies run out. And with few if any new jobs available, the graphs showing last year's arrivals are now seen as predictors of this year's unemployment problem -- 10,300 more jobless Soviet Jews this month, 15,294 more in July and so on.
Already, the Government reported this week, of the 124,000 people looking for jobs in March, 40,000 were recent Soviet immigrants.
Few new jobs are being created for these people because over the last five months, the Israeli economy has shown no growth, largely because of war-related problems.
And even the predicted improvement in the year's second half seems unlikely to keep pace with the rapid rise in the population brought on by immigration. That was true last year, too. Israel's gross national product grew by about 5.5 percent; growth rates typically fluctuate over a wider range here than in the United States because Israel has a far smaller economy. But population grew by more than 6 percent in 1990, meaning that "as a measure of potential living standards," Mr. Bruno said, the economy showed a decline.
 
 Pathetic Stories About the Desperate
 As a result, the Israeli press is filled with pathetic stories about desperate, hungry, unemployed immigrants.
The cover article in last week's Jerusalem Post weekend magazine carried the headline, "Dire economic conditions drive some Russian women to the streets as prostitutes." The Jerusalem Report, a weekly news magazine, carries an article this week on "Soviet immigrants drowning their absorption troubles in alcoholism." And a spate of news reports in recent days have quoted grocery store managers nationwide who say hungry Soviet Jews are increasingly turning to shoplifting.
For a long time, many immigration officials tended to gloss over these problems, trying to focus public attention instead on the drama of the mass migration. But now they are unable to avoid talking about the dark side of the phenomenon.
"The lack of employment starts to be a problem that will bring very terrible demonstrations in the summer when tens of thousands of these people finish their absorption baskets and there won't be any work for them," warned Moshe Nativ, director general of the Jewish Agency, the quasi-governmental organization largely responsible for bringing the immigrants here.
Just a few weeks ago, the most immediate problem seemed to be the crushing housing shortage. Though some new prefabricated homes are now going up, homes remain in short supply. Nevertheless, the focus of concern has now turned from housing to unemployment. As Simcha Dinitz, head of the Jewish Agency, put it, "If you have a house and you don't have a job, then all you have is a place to sit and think about the fact that you are unemployed.
"The problem here is hope," he added in an interview. "We have to try not to destroy their hope that they will eventually find a comfortable place in this society."
 
 Soviet Jews 'Waiting to See'
 Because of his job, Mr. Dinitz has usually been one of the most boosterish of Israel's immigration officials. A month ago, when Soviet immigration started picking up again after a severe drop during the gulf war, he happily predicted in an interview that the number of immigrants in March, 13,386, would nearly double in April, to 25,000. This estimate was based on the number of Soviet Jews applying for visas at the Israeli Consulate in Moscow.
In fact, the April number turned out to be 15,885. And now even Mr. Dinitz acknowledges that "many Soviet Jews are extending their Israeli visas for an additional period of time," adding, "They are postponing their departure, waiting to see what will happen here."
If the nation's economic problems are not remedied quickly, he added, "the number coming here will drop, even if the situation in the Soviet Union remains tense."
"It's already started," he said. "And even those who have already come here will start looking for a way out. They will look at Israel as a transit station, not a final destination."
To Mr. Dinitz as well as most other Israelis, this would be viewed as nothing short of a national tragedy. And to avert that, Government ministers are racing to offer plans for creating jobs. All the proposals, however, seem to share one feature -- greater Government intervention or control of the economy.
As an example, late last month Finance Minister Yitzhak Modaii suggested that Israel's large industrial concerns create new positions for 50,000 immigrants who would work as "helpers" for one to two years; the Government would pay their salaries. But Parliament scornfully rejected the idea.
Absorption Minister Yitzhak Peretz proposed that the Government intervene in virtually every sector of the economy to force employers to hire 85,000 Soviet Jews.
Mr. Dinitz's plan involves Government intervention, too.
"Look, I'm all for privatization and everything," he said. "But this is like a war we are fighting, and wars are not fought by private companies." With that, he called for extensive new Government-directed projects to build and improve the country's infrastructure.
 
 Top Leadership Seen as Absent
 No matter their merit, none of these or any of the other plans proposed in recent weeks or months has been put in place.
"It's not that there's no plan," said Ora Namir, head of the Parliament' s Labor Committee. "There's a whole library of plans of all the Government ministries to deal with the employment problems. The problem is the absence of the Prime Minister to direct the problem is very blatant."
On Tuesday, Mr. Dinitz led a delegation of international Jewish figures to what they described as an "urgent meeting" with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to discuss "the crisis." Mr. Dinitz said they had urged him to take over direct control of the Government's immigration policy. A participant in the meeting said Mr. Shamir had expressed sympathy and sincere interest but made no promises to take any specific new steps.
Looking over it all, Shaul Amor, a respected member of the Parliament's Finance Committee from Mr. Shamir's Likud Party, called for "an emergency plan to stop this terrible deterioration in the unemployment situation."
But then, sadly, he concluded, "I don't believe that there will be any change."

HEADLINE: The Fresh Air Fund, at 115, Seeks Families and Donations

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES

 BODY:
For thousands of children living in the city's poorest neighborhoods, summer vacation means sitting on stoops or watching street life from fire escapes and tenement windows.
But 10,000 children will have the chance to roll in the grass, swim in a pond and gaze at a starry country sky through the efforts of the Fresh Air Fund, which today begins its 115th annual fund-raising campaign. 
 The Fresh Air Fund, a nonprofit agency, has given poor city children summer vacations in the country since 1877, when the Rev. Willard Parsons of Sherman, Pa., asked members of his rural congregation to open their homes to children from New York's slums. Since then, more than 1.6 million children have had Fresh Air Fund vacations.
Through its "Friendly Towns" program, city children between 6 and 16 years old go live with volunteer families.
 
Picking Up Bugs
 For 9-year-old Wendy Quintanilla of the Bronx, a Fresh Air Fund summer is one of simple pleasures. It means swimming, playing on the beach and picnicking with her hosts, Kent and Laurel Morsch in Killingworth, Conn. She has spent the last two summers with them, in a neighborhood she says is filled with "pools, houses and birds." She likes to watch and pick up frogs and bugs, but lets them go "wherever they want." And last summer, she rode a "beautiful black horse" at a nearby farm, and has won the grand prize in a Fresh Air Fund drawing contest.
Last year, stemming a 20-year decline, the fund increased its number of host families, said its executive director, Jenny Morgenthau. It formed more committees to recruit families, Ms. Morgenthau said, since its traditional corps of volunteers -- homemakers -- has greatly diminished.
Now, about 7,000 families in 316 towns have a Fresh Air Fund child in their house for two weeks or more. Some live just minutes from the city; others are as far away as Vermont, Maine and Canada.
About 2,500 more children go to four Fresh Air Fund camps on a 3,000-acre site in Fishkill, N.Y., in Dutchess County. The camps include a planetarium, a wildlife refuge, a wilderness trail and a model farm. Last year, the fund began to send homeless families to camp on weekends. It also operates a "career awareness camp" in August for 100 junior high school children, and a "career awareness" program throughout the year that stresses responsibility, independence and goal-making, Ms. Morgenthau said.
This year, she said, more parents than ever want to give their children a respite from the sweltering streets.
"Given the recession and budget cuts," she said, "city parents are really dying to get their kids out. They want to give them a break."
It costs $314 for the Fund to sent a child to a family and $819 to send a child to a camp. Most of the expenses are for insurance and transportation. One-fifth of the budget is spent on administration and fund-raising. Because it is a member of United Way, which solicits donations through corporations, the fund cannot seek other corporate sponsorship. About 80 percent of its donations come from individuals.
 
Choose Age and Sex
 The Fund hopes to raise $3.7 million by October, and now has about $1.7 million.
Children are chosen based on financial need. Many come from families on public assistance, and are referred by 54 social-service agencies.
Like Wendy Quintanilla, about 60 percent of the children who stay with families are invited back again, and many stay longer than two weeks. A host can choose the age and sex of the guest. Families with a disabled child often invite children who have a similar disability.
Some Fresh Air Fund children stay in touch with their families for a long time. Ms. Morgenthau said she knows of a man in his 70's who still visits his host "father" in his 90's. And many families stay in touch with their Fresh Air Fund children throughout the year, she said, spending holidays with them and watching them grow up.
Donations may be sent to the Fresh Air Fund, 1040 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10018. Families who wish to be hosts may call (800) 367-0003 or (212) 221-0900.

HEADLINE: Commencement;
Baker, at Rice, Hails Exploit of a Forebear

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d spoke at Rice University in Houston yesterday, 60 years after his grandfather delivered the commencement address there.
Mr. Baker did not mention his recent trip to the Middle East or the progress of peace talks in the region. 
 But he told an audience of 3,000 how his grandfather, Capt. James A. Baker, a Houston lawyer, unraveled the mystery surrounding the death of the university's founder, William Marsh Rice.
Rice was poisoned in 1900 by his valet, who forged a will and had planned to steal his money, which included the university's endowment, Mr. Baker said.
But Captain Baker uncovered the plot and saved the endowment. He was often described as "a big Texan who could not be corrupted by any means," Mr. Baker said, and is considered the university's foster father.
 
'Work Hard, Study Hard'
 "It was the captain who told me, 'Work hard, study hard and stay out of politics,' " Mr. Baker said. "Well, two out of three isn't bad."
Mr. Baker warned against the proliferation of weapons around the world and the influence of war on younger generations.
"Fragile democracies need stable economies and a secure environment in which to grow," he said. "New generations can be caught in a vicious cycle of drug use and trafficing, and terrorists can exploit the instabilities of change for their own ends."
Mr. Baker, who graduated from Princeton University, has kept close ties to Rice. In 1985, he donated his papers as former Treasury Secretary to the university's Woodson Research Center.
But it is Captain Baker's protrait that hangs in Baker College, a campus dormitory.

HEADLINE: Home Sales Continue to Rise in New York Area, Brokers Say

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
An upswing in home sales that began in January has been sustained in three months of active buying across New York City and its suburbs, real-estate executives and lenders say.
Although the housing market remains subdued compared to the mid-1980's, and selling prices in many cases remain more than 20 percent lower than their peak, demand has clearly strengthened since last year. Lenders report greater demand for mortgages, real-estate brokers say their sales volume has increased sharply, and people who have been looking at homes for a year or more say they have now decided to buy as sellers have become less willing to give steep discounts. 
 The recovery appears strongest for lower-priced homes, and some experts say that it may be short-lived. But as the industry is poised at the start of the traditional summer buying season, many others believe that the region's long housing slump has reached an end.
 
Waiting for Rock Bottom
 Michael Neglia, a New Jersey civil engineer, became a buyer recently with his fiancee, Christine Knack, after they made up their minds that the tide had turned. "Our strategy has been to wait until the market hit rock bottom, and I think we've succeeded," he said. They contracted early in April to buy a three-bedroom home in Westwood for $185,000, only $1,000 less than the seller had asked. One reason he bid that high, Mr. Neglia said, is that he had missed out on four other houses after bidding too low.
"Nobody can say for certain that we've bottomed out, but we sure have come down from the peak," said Charles Becker, a human-resources executive who moved to Manhattan from Chicago a year ago, rented an apartment, and last month contracted to buy a three-bedroom cooperative, in need of a new kitchen and bathrooms, on East 86th Street near Park Avenue.
"I don't see much downside risk," he added.
In a sequence that brokers say has become increasingly common recently, Mr. Becker said his first bid for the apartment was countered by someone else who offered more money. He then raised his bid, agreeing to a price that he declined to disclose, but said was in the "low-$400,000 range." It was also $23,000 more than the seller had originally asked.
 
High-End Sales Lag
 Demand appears strongest for moderately priced homes within the reach of first-time buyers. Thousands of higher-priced homes -- suburban houses priced over $300,000 and Manhattan apartments priced over $500,000 -- are languishing on the market, and some experts say the slump will continue for people trying to sell these properties.
"We may have to see prices ratchet down a little more," said Therese E. Byrne, a real-estate analyst for Salomon Brothers, the securities firm. She added that the recent sales spurt may simply be a "false bottom" in the slump that has been prompted by an exaggerated sense of consumer confidence that came with end of the Persian Gulf war.
Indeed, although no one knows for certain why the upswing began in January, experts say it corresponded to a surge in confidence that was also reflected in stock trading when the air war began in the gulf in January.
But that confidence may be eroded as employers in the New York area, struggling with the recession, announce more layoffs this year, Ms. Byrne said.
Inventories of unsold homes remain large, and there is no evidence of a return of the buying frenzy the propelled the market before 1987.
Nor will any continued upswing in sales necessarily be spread equally across the region. Suburban markets, where hundreds of new homes have been sold at auction over the last year, now have smaller excess inventories, and some experts believe that those markets will strengthen more quickly than New York City, where a spate of auctions are planned this year and serious problems continue to plague many poorly financed cooperative apartment buildings.
 
'Very Strong Demand'
 Still, applications for mortgage loans have increased sharply. Although lenders attribute part of the increase to homeowners seeking to refinance at lower rates, they say most of the demand comes from buyers.
"This has to mean very strong demand for new purchases," said Ellen Feldschreiber, president of the Manhattan Mortgage Company, one of the New York region's largest brokers of mortgage loans from more than 20 banks and savings and loans. She said the number of applications rose 39 percent in February, 47 percent in March, and 42 percent in the first three weeks of April, compared with last year.
Industry executives say sales increases are not yet reflected in the numbers of real-estate closings, which are normally used as a gauge of market activity, but which follow the execution of sales contracts by two months or more.
But the number of new contracts, which generally require the buyer to make a substantial down payment, is on the rise. In Manhattan, Douglas Elliman, a brokerage and management company that deals in expensive cooperatives and condominiums, said it had executed 242 sales contracts from Jan. 1 to April 25, compared with only 134 in the comparable period of 1990.
Another large Manhattan broker, the Corcoran Group, said new contracts began to increase in February, when its customers signed 35, compared with 26 a year earlier. In March and the first three weeks of April, its sales volume more than doubled, with 97 contracts signed.
In Westchester County and Bergen County, the number of new sales contracts was about the same in the first three months of the year compared to the year earlier, but brokers in both counties said sales activity picked up momentum in March and April.
"We think there is no question this market has passed bottom," said Ralph R. Ragette, a broker in Eastchester and president of the Westchester Board of Realtors. He said sales by his own company increased 15 percent in January, 7 percent in February and 25 percent in March.
In a report last month, the National Association of Realtors, a trade group in Washington, said existing home sales rose 0.6 percent across the nation in March compared with last year, the second consecutive monthly increase. It said sales in the Northeast were particularly strong, rising 4 percent.
 
Competing Bids
 With demand strongest for relatively inexpensive homes, analysts say it is too early to tell whether enough of these properties will be sold during the summer to create a fresh surge of demand for more expensive homes, as people move up to larger, newer and better located residences.
One family that has managed to move up is the Hellers -- Harvey, Debra and their 8-year-old triplets -- who in early April contracted to buy a four-bedroom home in Pomona, in Rockland County, for a price in the "mid-$200,000 range." They first had to sell a three-bedroom house in Spring Valley, which they put on the market, priced at $207,000, in January 1990.
Mrs. Heller said they grew so frustrated trying to sell the Spring Valley house by December, when their asking price had come down to $184,000, that they took it off the market. But when they listed it again on March 1 for $179,900, she said, buyers lined up.
The next day, a Saturday, two house-hunters were in her living room making competing bids, she said. The Hellers accepted $176,500 from one of the bidders; hours later, someone else arrived who offered to pay their full asking price if the sales agreement fell through.
"People still want to buy houses," Mrs. Heller said. "I just don't think this market is going any lower."

HEADLINE: Causes of Crisis: 7 Fat Years, Then Recession

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
For months a faltering economy and plummeting tax receipts have set the rhythm for the Dinkins administration as it scrambled to stay ahead of the bad news.
While Mayor David N. Dinkins may eventually be held to account for some of the confusing steps his administration has taken -- like offering pay raises the city could not afford or announcing and then not making thousands of layoffs -- many of the city's problems have far deeper roots. The Federal Government has systematically cut its commitment to cities, the state may be in worse financial straits than the city, and the city bureaucracy added 49,000 jobs during the 1980's, far more than justified by revenues. 
 But the most pressing cause of the current budget turmoil is the recession, which has already rolled through most of the economy, from Wall Street to restaurants to retailing. It slashed, by the State Comptroller's estimate, 44,000 jobs last year, the worst job loss since the 1970's. Most economists expect at least as many jobs to be lost this year -- and the taxes those wage-earners paid will be lost too.
 
'Seven Fat Years'
 This blow was especially powerful because city government grew so extraordinarily during what one fiscal analyst called "the seven fat years" -- roughly 1983 to 1990. The economy had been bubbling, and, for a while, tax revenues poured in faster than the city's bookkeepers expected, letting the city take on burdens it could not support when the economy weakened.
During those years, the number of employees in city agencies and schools soared by 49,000, a 25 percent increase, replacing virtually everyone cut during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's. And, with enormous political and social pressures to expand government services to the poor and homeless, spending began growing faster than dependable tax revenues could. The difference was made up by a variety of gimmicks and one-time revenues.
During the 1980's, Federal aid to the city was slashed more than 50 percent, city officials said. When Federal subsidies for centers for the elderly and day care for children were cut, for instance, the city made up the difference instead of closing centers. If the Federal Government was paying the same share of the city budget as it was a decade ago, officials said, Washington would be sending the city $2.5 billion more, enough to solve most of the city's budget problems.
 
Bill-Paying Problems
 New York State, which provided critical aid to the city in the last crisis, is hardly in a position to help this time. Faced with his own budget deficit, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has proposed slashing aid to the city by $600 million. An impasse between legislators and the Governor over passing a budget has undermined confidence that the city will be able to pay its bills at the end of next month.
Union leaders say the state lowered income-tax rates too much during the 1980's, resulting in deeper revenue losses than expected. "They ended up cutting taxes by billions more than they expected," said Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. "A major mistake, big time."
When Mr. Dinkins took office last year, there were already warnings about fiscal problems. In an early symbolic decision, he delayed the hiring of one class of police officers until he was sure the city could pay for them.
But many of the administration's budget-cutting efforts remained more symbolic than real, independent fiscal analysts said. For example, to balance the current budget, Mr. Dinkins used $500 million from bond refinancings by the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which sells bonds on behalf of the city.
And the work force continued to grow. Now, despite more than 1,000 layoffs and attrition at many agencies, there are still more people on the city payroll than there were a year ago. Just last week, despite the fiscal troubles, 2,000 more police officers -- paid for through special taxes -- were hired.
Fiscal analysts have repeatedly warned the Mayor that he faces years of a continuing imbalance between expected spending and revenues.
"You have to give both the Mayor and the Governor their due in recognizing national and local economic problems," said Raymond D. Horton, research director of the Citizens Budget Commission, a research group supported by businesses. "But when you strip all that away, there is a failure of public policy as well."
Last October, in one lurching week, Mr. Dinkins approved an unexpectedly expensive labor settlement for teachers, proposed a sweeping expansion of the police, and then, in an abrupt reversal, froze hiring and said he was considering laying off 15,000 workers.
A few months later, he announced 11,000 layoffs, but almost no one actually was let go. Teachers were spared when they agreed to defer a portion of their wage increase. Nearly all other Civil Service employees were spared when the Mayor decided to use attrition instead.
Since January, Mr. Dinkins has been unsuccessfully seeking to negotiate concessions with other unions -- wage deferrals, furloughs or reduced benefits.
But union leaders dismissed these, asking what they would get in return. They have refused to concede anything more until the Mayor develops a plan showing how the city will extricate itself from its worsening problems.
So, as the fiscal picture darkened and Mr. Dinkins faced a May 10th deadline to present his budget, he finally put together a detailed plan for deep slashes in city services and presented it yesterday to the Governor, union leaders, and city officials at Gracie Mansion.

HEADLINE: Identity Becomes Central to Debate as Democrats Prepare for 1992 Race

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DES MOINES, May 4

 BODY:
The quest has begun yet again to define what a Democrat is and what a Democrat stands for, in a way that can attract a majority of the voters.
During the Democrats' long exile from the White House the quadrennial search for "new ideas" has often seemed a grim and bloodless exercise. But in recent weeks, even as many in the party acknowledge the long odds against them in the 1992 Presidential election, the debate over ideas, themes and messages has acquired some vigor and even drawn some blood. 
 Some broad outlines of the 1992 model of the Democratic candidate, if the party's centrists have their way, are emerging: He or she is passionately solicitous of the middle class, consumed with education and training, committed to change in social welfare programs and concerned about health care, but, of course, also fiscally responsible.
 
Nominee Will Define Party
 The national Democratic Party will be largely defined by its choice of Presidential nominee, and that race is still in its earliest stages, with the former Massachusetts Senator, Paul E. Tsongas, becoming the first official candidate this week. But other potential candidates, including Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia and Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, are testing campaign themes.
And this weekend, two groups of Democrats are adding their voices to the debate: the Coalition for Democratic Values, a liberal group meeting here today, and the Democratic Leadership Council, a group of centrists and conservatives who are gathering Sunday in Cleveland.
The leadership council, which is pushing hard for a redefined Democratic Party that is closer to what it sees as the nation's political center, has already engendered some friction, with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, a principal standard-bearer for the party's left.
Recent history is not auspicious for Democrats who hope to redefine their party. Gary Hart built his 1984 campaign for the Presidential nomination around the promise of "new ideas" and a break from the liberal orthodoxy of the past; party regulars gave the nomination to Walter F. Mondale, the candidate of organized labor and other traditional constituent groups.
Michael S. Dukakis, the 1988 Democratic nominee, struggled to present himself as a new kind of Democrat, a non-ideological manager who resisted the liberal label, only to be devastatingly cast by the Republicans as a soft-on-crime, card-carrying member of the American Civil Liberties Union.
 
'A New Politics'
 Still, Governor Bill Clinton of Arkansas, chairman of the leadership council and a potential Presidential candidate in 1992, argues that there is a growing movement among Democrats for "a new politics."
Both parties, he says, are groping for a vision beyond Reaganism in a process that should have occurred in the 1988 Presidential campaign but did not. "The steam had run out of the logic of the Reagan revolution and nobody wanted to go back to 'The Federal Government can solve all your problems and we've got the money to do it,' " Mr. Clinton said recently in Little Rock.
Most of the ferment in the party is over domestic policy; there is widespread agreement among Democrats that this is their strong suit and their best chance of returning to power. Moreover, after the war in the Persian Gulf, in which most Congressional Democrats voted against the President on the use-of-force resolution, many Democrats have little stomach for an internal review on foreign policy.
One of the most striking parts of the domestic message that is emerging is the impassioned appeal to the middle class that is being expressed in proposals including tax breaks and college scholarship programs.
The outrage that liberals long brought to the plight of the poor is now being extended to working families who, many Democrats contend, have been squeezed and buffeted in the 1980's. "Middle-class families pay more taxes than they ever have and the average weekly wage, after taxes, is lower now than it was in 1959, one year before John F. Kennedy challenged this country to get moving again," Mr. Gore said in a recent speech.
 
Dealing With the Spending Label
 There is a powerful political imperative behind this: Democrats are keenly aware that they lost much of the middle class to the tax-cutting Republicans in the 1980's and that they became increasingly viewed as a big-spending party most concerned with the poor. Republicans assert that Democrats will have a hard time changing this image because the Democratic-controlled Congress has a history of ever-fatter budgets and ever-higher taxes.
But Mr. Wilder, who has the advantage of being a Washington outsider, has put fiscal responsibility at the heart of his message. The Virginia Governor, who will speak to both Democratic groups meeting this weekend, told the liberals gathered here today that "the biggest threat to this nation's future prosperity" was "those Washington insiders who have mismanaged the American people's tax dollars for far too many years."
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, who is expected to embark on some national travel after reaching a state budget agreement, has been arguing that the Federal Government has been abdicating its responsibilities and foisting its burdens onto the states.
Many Democrats are also putting a new emphasis on values. For example, Mr. Clinton talks about injecting more personal responsibility into government programs. "Democrats need to say there are people who need our help, that we have to help," he said. "But we should only take money from middle-class taxpayers and give it to other people who need it if we also require them to behave responsibly with the money we give them."
 
The Theme of Competitiveness
 This would include requiring welfare recipients to pursue education, training and job placement and "cracking down on child-support violators," he said.
Democrats are also returning to the theme of economic competitiveness in the world marketplace, with a new emphasis on the importance of education and training. Mr. Tsongas, running as a pro-business liberal, is urging Democrats to reject the politics of rich-versus-poor and to focus instead on helping businesses compete.
While there is considerable consensus on many of these themes, some people on the party's left, notably Mr. Jackson, are sounding alarms. Mr. Jackson, who has a long history of friction with the leadership council, was clearly miffed at not being invited to speak in Cleveland, and particularly after Al From, the head of the council, defended the decision.
Council officials said Mr. Jackson would be welcome as a participant, but Mr. Jackson, who accuses the council of pushing the "suburbanization" of the Democratic Party, declined.
This morning's meeting of liberals, meanwhile, opened with fiery populist rhetoric, including pointed criticism of the proposed free-trade treaty with Mexico. The treaty is supported by many party centrists, but strongly opposed by much of organized labor because of its potential impact on jobs.
As the Democrats began their latest exercise in self-definition, Mr. Tsongas issued a quiet warning this morning. Democrats face two dangers, he said: heading in the path of the British Labor Party and remaining ideologically pure and out of power, or becoming "Republican wannabes" and losing their souls.

HEADLINE: Bangor Journal;
Maine Refines the Welcome Home

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGOR, Me., May 2

 BODY:
Since long before dawn, about 50 men, women and children had waited in the Bangor International Airport terminal for the next plane load of troops to arrive from the Persian Gulf.
And like any other group of adoring fans, they came offering "Welcome Home" posters, homemade cookies, beers and cheers. 
 "You're back, you're back!" called 42-year-old Valerie Bellomy to the 201 bleary-eyed members of the Army 62d and 223d transportation companies who tramped into the terminal. "I don't know any of them," she said. "But we want them to know how grateful we are for what they did for our country."
For most small towns across the country, such celebrations have happened once or twice since the Persian Gulf war ended. But here in Bangor, which has the closest American airport to Europe as well as low landing and refueling fees, jetloads of soldiers have stopped daily on their way home. The homecoming scene has taken on a life of its own.
Day after day, and often in the middle of the night, up to 1,500 Mainers have crowded into the tiny terminal here to offer hugs and back slaps to the troops.
Like many others in the crowd, Mrs. Bellomy and her two daughters, Mary Jane and Adrian, have greeted all but a few of the flights. That means crazy sleeping schedules, missed classes and hours of waiting in the airport.
More than 50,000 troops have stopped here on their way home from the gulf, making Bangor, a city of 35,000 people, the busiest port of entry in the country for homecoming soldiers.
"This is beautiful," said Specialist Thomas Gay, who grabbed a rambunctious handshake from a flannel-shirted man with long blond hair.
"Hey, man, welcome back, welcome back," said James P. Sargent, 43, of West Sullivan, Me.
Not far away, Specialist Rene Ely, whose transportation company was on its way to Fort Bliss, Tex., autographed a souvenir shirt.
"I'm just so happy to see these people here," said the 21-year-old soldier, who was returning from six months in the desert. "I figured we'd be forgotten about because you don't hear that much about us," she said, blinking back tears.
For Maine, a sparsely populated, rural state, the big welcome has seemed a bit out of step. Maine bills itself as a hospitable place, a "vacationland," but one sticker often seen on truck bumpers reads, "Welcome to Maine -- Now Go Home."
Still, in a state with a small-town state of mind, neighborliness is a way of life, residents say. The airport celebrations, which began with a small group of patriotic Bangor residents, offer the best of both worlds. The celebrations are a way to experience the happiness over the gulf victory, and to show support for the troops without long-term involvement. The troop layovers last an hour or so.
So far, enthusiasm for the homecomings has continued to mount. At a time when most other news revolves around the depressed regional economy and rising unemployment, the euphoria of the homecoming celebrations has been a welcome relief, residents say.
Daily updates on arrivals are broadcast on local radio stations and printed in The Bangor Daily News. A special telephone recording was set up to give round-the-clock troop flight information.
Military officials say news of the greetings here has been passed on to other troops soon to embark, prompting numerous requests from soldiers to return through Bangor.
Americans from as far away as Connecticut and Prince Edward Island have come to Bangor.
"I'm here because I just wanted to welcome them home," said Linda Graham, who rode a bus five hours from Boston.
"I lost my job recently, and I heard about this and just wanted to come," she said, as the troops reboarded their jet after an hour of celebrating. "This is meat for the soul."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Almost all of the more than 50,000 troops who have passed through Bangor, Me., airport on return from the Persian Gulf have been welcomed by cheering crowds. One Vietnam veteran greeted returning soldiers. (Brian Swartz)

HEADLINE: Health of Kenya Political Prisoner Seen as Perilous

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 4

 BODY:
A prominent Kenyan editor and lawyer, whose imprisonment in solitary confinement by the Government here has raised international protests, is in deteriorating health and may be suffering from a brain tumor, medical tests indicate.
The editor, Gitobu Imanyara, who is 37 years old, was taken from his prison cell to a Nairobi hospital, after having seizures during a court bail hearing. A Government physician, Dr. Paul G. Kioy, said in a medical report that there was "a real possibility of an intracranial structural abnormality." Mr. Imanyara's own physician, Dr. Gichuru Kuria, wrote a medical report for the courts that said that if Mr. Imanyara was kept in solitary confinement, he could "easily asphyxiate to death if he gets a grand mal seizure while alone in a room."
 
Decision on Bail Soon
 Mr. Imanyara faces a bail ruling on Wednesday. He has been denied bail on five occasions since being arrested more than eight weeks ago, after the publication of the February issue of the Nairobi Law Monthly. Since April 22, he has been in Kenyatta Hospital receiving treatment and undergoing tests. 
 The Government has charged him with sedition, citing an editorial that suggested that some posts were being allotted according to an individual's tribe.
Mr. Imanyara, the winner of several international journalism awards this year, had also been arrested and detained last year. He faces a second sedition charge arising from a 1990 issue of the magazine that called for a multi-party system in Kenya.
Mr. Imanyara's case and poor condition presents a difficult problem for senior Government officials who control the judiciary and in effect will decide whether the editor is granted bail.
President Daniel arap Moi and his close associate, Energy Minister Nicholas Biwott, are described by diplomats and lawyers here as hard-liners on Mr. Imanyara. The editor's magazine, with its legal articles and pro-democracy point of view, attracts a significant readership in cities and towns.
 
The Foreign Aid Factor
 Others in the Government believe that Kenya cannot afford further cuts in economic aid from Western donors, which might come if Mr. Imanyara is kept in prison. These officials, aware of Kenya's weak economy and of the popular frustration that results, expect an international outcry if anything happens to Mr. Imanyara while he is in custody.
In an unusually swift reaction from Washington, the State Department called his arrest "another denial of freedom of expression in Kenya," and called on the Government to release Mr. Imanyara without delay.
Western diplomats in Nairobi said that Kenya's major donors -- the Nordic countries, Germany and even Japan, which normally remains silent on internal political questions -- had urged the Kenya Government to free Mr. Imanyara or face the possibility of aid reductions.
In Congress, the Imanyara case has helped prompt increasing disaffection toward Kenya, which used to be a favorite African aid recipient.
The new foreign assistance bill offers no increase in aid to Kenya, in contrast to other nations, which have been designated to receive part of an overall 20 percent increase in aid to Africa.

HEADLINE: BUSH SEES THREAT TO FLOW OF IDEAS ON U.S. CAMPUSES

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 4

 BODY:
In a commencement address at the University of Michigan today, President Bush attacked what he called the "notion of 'political correctness,' " saying it had led to "inquisition," "censorship" and "bullying" on some college campuses.
In a speech devoted to three "freedoms" -- "enterprise, speech and spirit" -- the President joined a growing political backlash against the idea that free speech should be subordinated to the civil rights of women and minority members. 
 "Ironically, on the 200th anniversary of our Bill of Rights, we find free speech under assault throughout the United States, including on some college campuses," Mr. Bush told an audience of 8,300 graduates and more than 55,000 others gathered in the University of Michigan football stadium.
 
Old Prejudices and New
 "The notion of 'political correctness' has ignited controversy across the land," he said. "And although the movement arises from the laudable desire to sweep away the debris of racism, sexism and hatred, it replaces old prejudices with new ones. It declares certain topics off-limits, certain expressions off-limits, even certain gestures off-limits. What began as a cause for civility has soured into a cause of conflict and even censorship."
Today's speech was Mr. Bush's first on an issue that has divided campuses around the nation.
In the first of five commencement speeches he will make over the next few weeks, the President wanted to address where America is headed domestically in the wake of the Persian Gulf war.
Believing that Americans feel a mixture of optimism and anxiety about the state of the nation, Mr. Bush sought to move his "kinder, gentler" rhetoric a step forward, exploring attitudes on racism and sexism and raising the level of the public debate on tolerance toward minorities, asking whether it can be "federalized," as he put it, or whether it is a matter of individual responsibility.
The speech to Michigan graduates reflected the influence of the President's new head speech writer, Anthony Snow, a former editorial writer for The Washington Times, who was hired to bring a harder edge and ideological spirit to Mr. Bush's speeches as he moves toward the 1992 election.
Mr. Snow is working with Dorrance Smith, the President's new assistant for media affairs, and David Demarest, the director of communications, to make Mr. Bush's speeches more pointed and topical. White House officials said the three felt that the hot topic of political correctness could be used as a vehicle to talk about the need to promote, but not legislate, tolerance on the nation's campuses.
White House officials said the speech fit into a pattern of Presidential positions on civil rights. For instance, in opposing the Congressional measure that would have made it easier to sue employers for job discrimination, Mr. Bush said the Government should fight bigotry, but not if that meant court-imposed quotas for women and minority members.
At Michigan today, Mr. Bush said that Americans should be alarmed at the rise of intolerance and bigotry but that they should also be alarmed at the "growing tendency to use intimidation rather than reason in settling disputes."
 
'Division and Derision'
 "Neighbors who disagree no longer settle matters over a cup of coffee," he said. "They hire lawyers and go to court. Political extremists roam the land, abusing the privilege of free speech, setting citizens against one another on the basis of their class or race. Such bullying is outrageous. It's not worthy of a great nation grounded in the values of tolerance and respect. Let us fight back against the boring politics of division and derision."
"Political correctness" originated as an ironic term for a broad range of generally liberal attitudes, especially in support of expanded rights for women, ethnic minorities and homosexuals. But it has been seized by many conservatives and traditionalists, on campus and off, as a term of derision for those who espouse such attitudes to the exclusion of other rights, especially free speech.
In one celebrated case this academic year, Brown University expelled a student who shouted racist slurs, touching off a debate about freedom of speech on campus. In New York in March, a City College faculty committee rebuked two professors, one black and the other white, for comments about racial superiority; the case raised the question whether academic freedom included the right to espouse inflammatory teachings and beliefs about race and culture.
In a third case, Nina Wu, a sophomore at the University of Connecticut, was ordered to move off campus after gay students protested a sign she had posted on her dorm room making fun of "preppies," "bimbos," "men without chest hair" and "homos." After a Federal lawsuit was threatened, the university let her move back on campus and revised its code of conduct.
 
Praise for Ford and King
 At Michigan today, the President said he would focus on "the nature of freedom," and he praised Americans like Henry Ford and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. for having the "vision" to "transform a world."
"When governments try to improve on freedom, say by picking winners and losers in the economic market, they fail," he said. And he criticized government programs that "have tried to assume roles once reserved for families and schools and churches."
"This crusade backfired," he said of President Lyndon Johnson's "Great Society" program to fight poverty. "Programs designed to insure racial harmony generated animosity. Programs intended to help people out of poverty invited dependency. We should have learned that while the ideals behind the Great Society were noble, and indeed they were, the programs weren't always up to the task.
 
Call for a 'Good Society'
 "We need a 'Good Society' built upon the deeds of the many -- a society that promotes selflessness and action. The Good Society does not demand agonizing sacrifice. It requires something within everyone's reach: common decency and commitment.
Mr. Bush has himself been attacked over the issues of free speech and divisiveness to which he devoted most of today's speech.
In 1989, critics complained that he was interfering with the Bill of Rights when he proposed a constitutional amendment against burning or destroying the American flag. And in the 1988 campaign, he and his campaign manager, Lee Atwater, were accused of practicing the politics of racial division with the campaign advertisements focusing on Willie Horton, a black convict who raped a white Maryland woman. Before Mr. Atwater died this year at the age of 40, he apologized for that campaign tactic.
Though Mr. Bush was heckled today by a small group of students who opposed the Persian Gulf war, the response was generally warm. Walter Harrison, Michigan's executive director for university relations, said the debate over "political correctness" had been "engaged here now for the last year," and he called the President's speech "helpful, to the extent that it opens the discourse on this issue."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush and his wife, Barbara, during commencement exercises yesterday at the University of Michigan. The President was later hospitalized after complaining of shortness of breath while jogging. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times) (pg. 32)

HEADLINE: OUTDOORS;
Shooting Fish Has Become an Endangered Sport

BYLINE: By Richard D. Lyons

DATELINE: SOUTH HERO ISLAND, Vt.

 BODY:
John Roy peered out the kitchen window of his 200-year-old farmhouse atop this island in Lake Champlain, pointed with his pipestem to the neighboring marsh and ticked off the reasons why nostalgia isn't what it used to be, at least not for him.
"When I was a boy I used to catch frogs down there in the creek, but now the frogs are gone," the amiable dairy farmer said. "But what I liked to do most then and now is shoot pickerel and it looks like this might be the last year I can because they're trying to take it away." 
 On a sunny day Roy takes his Springfield .30-06 bolt action rifle out of the closet, puts on his waders, ambles across the road to the marsh, trudges through the muck to a tree stump that gives a firm footing, and peers into the shallow water waiting for a fish. The most popular are pickerel, but other targets include Northern pike, muskies and carp.
At the right movement he points the weapon down, and fires at such an angle that the slug hits the marsh bottom underneath the fish, thus sending out shock waves in the water that stuns the fish and forces it to the surface and into Roy's net.
Deer rifles are the most common, although almost any type of gun may be used, including handguns. A state hunting or fishing license is mandatory, and the law bans shooting from bridges and culverts.
This bizarre method of fishing is allowed only in Lake Champlain and parts of its main tributaries. Indeed, New York and Vermont were the only states in the country where fish shooting was popular and legal for more than a century until Albany banned the practice in 1969. It remains legal only in Vermont, for two months in the spring, but a bill in the State Legislature may be bringing an end to the sport.
"That's the point, it isn't a sport at all," said Representative Jane Mendicino of Essex Junction, one of the bill's main supporters.
 An avid angler since she was a child, Mendicino said using a rifle to catch fish during their spawning season is unsporting because they are then at their most vulnerable and have almost no chance to escape.
She, and others, also have pointed out that shooting can be dangerous because spent slugs can and do ricochet in odd directions, and most importantly, that the hunters' tramping through swamps and marshes during spring spawning season disturbs the eggs and the fry, thus eventually reducing the pool of fish available for others.
"The shooting is depleting our stocks of trophy Northern pike at a time when fishing for them has become extremely popular in Vermont, and surveys have shown a major decline in muskies as well," she said. "This is a threat to our fishing, our recreation and our tourist industry."
Any hint of harm to Vermont tourism sends shivers through a state whose struggling economy has been hit by a fall in farm income and uncertainties in its high tech industries.
Mendicino also is chairwoman of the Fish and Wildlife Committee of the Vermont House, which adopted her bill by voice vote a month ago and she is hoping her bill will be passed by the Senate, where lobbies representing fishing groups are divided on the issue.
Witnesses speaking for clubs of walleye and bass fishermen have supported the argument that shooting threatens important species of fish, a notion bolstered by studies of the State Fish and Wildlife Department.
But members of the Sporting Alliance for Vermont's Environment and the Vermont Federation of Sportsmen's Clubs have opposed the bill, holding that shooting is a time-honored practice by relatively few people that has little impact.
"You wouldn't find 10 to 15 people in the state still doing it," said George McNeill of the Sporting Alliance, although others put the number in the hundreds, many shooting illegally.
John Roy helped block passage of a similar anti-shooting bill four years ago. A prosperous farmer with 250 cows, Roy has served as a South Hero selectman for 25 years and as such is attuned to the cut and thrust of local politics.
He summed up the opposition saying that if stocks of sportfish are seriously depleted other measures besides banning fish shooting should be taken, such as restricting ice fishing which usually takes place at the start of the spawning season.
"In February and early March you can see guys out on the lake, each with a dozen tip-ups," he said. "Why not restrict their fishing, too, if the stocks are down?" But it may be that which rankles Roy the most is the realization that part of his heritage is being threatened.
Roy's father and grandfather -- the family has lived on the island for more than a century -- were fish shooters and he can remember the time when "my father got 12 fish with one shot, one weighing 19 pounds."
"The kids today have cars and boats and if they want to go fishing, they just head out for the middle of the lake for salmon and trout," Roy said. He noted the drop in rabbit and squirrel hunting, the building of more homes, as well as new roads into the area and said, "The outdoors that I knew as a kid is not here anymore."
"The outdoors that was part of my life, and that of my father and grandfather, is vanishing. I think they call it 'giving way to progress,' but I'm not so sure."

HEADLINE: The World;
Some Lessons From A Failed Assault On a Japan Inc. Fortress

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
FOR the last two years, T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman who hates to be called a corporate raider, has been devoted to a colorful if quixotic effort to breach one of the strongest fortresses in Japanese business, the corporate empire built around the Toyota Motor Company.
Armed with a $1 billion, 26 percent stake in the Koito Manufacturing Company, one of Toyota's key electrical suppliers -- the kind of stake that even the richest Japanese, much less an American, rarely has a shot at obtaining -- Mr. Pickens has battled in Tokyo and on Capitol Hill for a place on the company's board. He acknowledged that he was more interested in making a point than in making headlights: Only from the inside, he contended, could he strip bare how "Japan's cozy system of corporate relationships stops competition, harms consumers, and ultimately spells doom" for American communities when Japanese competition arrives. 
 Last week, just as J. R. Ewing was packing it in on "Dallas," Mr. Pickens said his real-life show, too, had run out of fresh episodes. Koito, and by extension Toyota, had made it clear that no amount of political pressure would force it to allow an unwanted intruder into the tent --- especially one with a reputation as a takeover artist. But his fight shined a bright light on a lot of myths about how a new age of "mutual interdependence" is leading to an inexorable convergence of American and Japanese styles of capitalism. And it has begun to focus the American business community more than ever on the question: Is America wiser in the long term to battle the anti-competitive but highly efficient way Japan organizes its corporate life, or is it wiser to learn from it?
 For years Americans have said that much of the blame for their failures in the Japanese market falls on what the Japanese call "keiretsu," the loose grouping of "family" companies that own chunks of each other's stock, finance each other's operations, supply each other with parts and technology and keep unwanted outsiders at arm's length. Almost every major Japanese company belongs to one; the leaders of the most famous keiretsu, the heads of Mitsubishi Motors, Mitsubishi Electric, Mitsubishi Bank, and numerous other Mitsubishis, meet for a monthly lunch in Tokyo that, if held in New York, would probably land them in Federal court on collusion charges.
 
A Challenge in America>
 Indeed, keiretsu are facing their first real challenge in America: the Federal Trade Commission has begun investigating whether the "American-made" parts for the cars the Japanese are building in the Midwest are really American, or are coming from the subsidiaries of old Japanese suppliers who are following their parents -- and, some charge, freezing out American competitors.
Mr. Pickens encouraged the examination of such practices, though his battle with Koito ultimately failed because there were many unanswered questions about his own dealings. He bought the stock from a Japanese entrepreneur who, after failing to get Toyota to buy it at a premium, took it to Mr. Pickens in hopes that an international incident would arise. He also lent him the money to buy the shares, apparently guaranteeing him against risk.
 That allowed Koito to claim that Mr. Pickens was not the true controller of the stock. So every time Mr. Pickens demanded that Toyota come clean, the Japanese demanded that he do the same.
No one laments the oilman's departure more than the Japanese press, which tried to dress him in cowboy suits, gladly repeated charges about corporate Japan they dared not make themselves, and reveled in the annual-meeting faceoffs between the drawling Texan, the stony-faced Koito management and Japanese gangsters who would fill the meeting room and hurl epithets.
Few doubt what Mr. Pickens would have discovered if he had succeeded in getting onto Koito's board. While the company is publicly held -- Toyota has only a 19 percent share -- its loyalties are solely to Toyota. The firm is run by ex-Toyota executives. When times are tough in Toyota City, Koito agrees to absorb more than its share of the pain. When times are good, Toyota and Koito effectively negotiate over the profits Koito gets.
In short, life for a Japanese supplier like Koito is sometimes uncomfortable, and only marginally profitable. Why do they do it?
In an article in The Harvard Business Review late last year, Kuniyasu Sakai, the owner of several small electronics companies, likened the relationship to that between a daimyo, one of the landholders who commanded Japan's castle towns, and his loyal samurai. "From the day a subcontractor accepts the first contract -- probably from a small subsidiary of one of the giant companies -- it has given up its freedom, it is told what to make, when to put it on line, and how much it will get for it on delivery," Mr. Sakai wrote. Moreover, there is no thought of doing business with others: Nissan would almost never buy from a Toyota supplier, unless ordered to by the government -- as the United States demanded as part of negotiations last year about "structural impediments" to trade.
 
Lessons for America
 Indeed, there is some evidence that the keiretsu system is starting to fray at the edges, partly because of trade pressure and partly because companies further down the food chain are growing more independent. But some Americans say the system has its advantages, for those on the inside.
"There is reliance on one long-term supplier, there is commitment, there is trust, there is technological help early on and there is much lower transaction costs," Joseph Gorman, the head of TRW, a major auto supplier that has struck gold in Japan, said last year.
Keiretsu also means never having to say you are bankrupt: Nissan last year took virtual control over Fuji Heavy Industries, which makes Subarus, without firing anyone or mounting a takeover. One question now is whether that applies to distant members of a family: Chrysler bought a big stake in Mitsubishi Motors two decades ago and Lee Iacocca is now negotiating for the Japanese company to come to its rescue.
Indeed, the Japanese look at their own economy, and at America's, and say it is a poor time for Washington to be lecturing them about how to organize corporate enterprise.
"General Motors has had all the makings of an integrated system like ours," a senior Toyota executive said recently. "It has a huge network of captive suppliers. It has its own financing system. It just never learned to use it right."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Rome's 100-Year Hunt For a Middle Ground

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
AN aura of secrecy has long surrounded the Vatican. But one of its best-kept secrets has been entirely unintentional. For a century popes have been elaborating a systematic body of social thought that attempts to steer a path between capitalism and socialism. Whatever the importance of this teaching to Catholic leaders dealing with social problems, most of the laity has been scarcely aware of it. Now the word is spreading, helped last week by Pope John Paul II's important encyclical on the economic and moral lessons of the collapse of Communism.
The encyclical, "Centesimus Annus" ("The Hundredth Year") commemorated the centenary of "Rerum Novarum," the 1891 document by Pope Leo XIII that was the first in a long series of statements by popes and other church authorities on modern economic and social problems. The new encyclical gives a qualified blessing to market economies, while warning capitalist nations not to ignore their own serious failings. 
 "Centesimus Annus" is only the centerpiece for what sometimes looks like a year-long floating seminar on Catholic social teaching. Dioceses and over 60 Catholic colleges and universities are sponsoring conferences on the subject. Teaching materials have been sent by the American bishops' conference to every parish in the United States. The interest seems to have been encouraged by the bishops' pastoral letters on war and peace in 1983 and on the economy in 1986. It also reflects a growing local awareness of poverty and homelessness.
 "I have seen more discussion of Catholic social teaching this year alone than in my entire lifetime," said Msgr. George G. Higgins, one of a small group of priests who have tried to use social teaching to resolve problems of labor relations and poverty.
Coming more than a century after Adam Smith and almost half a century after the Communist Manifesto, Leo XIII's "Rerum Novarum" was a belated response to capitalist industrialization and to the socialist challenge that it stirred. From Leo's time on, the Church has tried to chart a path between unregulated free enterprise and socialism.
 
Variations on a Theme
 Thus the popes defended private property and the authority of social units like families, communities and unions against centralized state power, but they endorsed government intervention to assure that workers were protected from exploitation and poverty. They rejected the doctrine of class conflict but defended the right of workers to organize and condemned the concentration of wealth.
In fact, from decade to decade and pope to pope, these themes were recast in distinctly different ways. Leo XIII was a conservative reformer whose defense of private property as an inalienable right was considerably modified by later popes. In 1931, Pope Pius XI put forth a plan for organizing economic life according to joint employer-employee associations. But tainted by association with the schemes of dictators like Salazar in Portugal and Franco in Spain, the idea quietly disappeared from papal writings.
Pope John XXIII's encyclicals in the 1960's widened the grounds for government economic intervention and reversed a ban on forming alliances even with moderate socialists. Social doctrine broadened its focus to take in international problems, and it endorsed concepts of human rights that the 19th-century papacy had shunned.
These shifts have led some critics to deny that Catholic social teaching really constitutes a coherent tradition. Complicating the problem, most documents include many qualifications, as a consequence of papal caution and a desire to conciliate different viewpoints within the church.
But the qualifiers have not been sufficient to fend off critics from both left and right. Catholic social teaching has consistently recommended measures that temper economic competition, disappointing capitalists, and has called for class harmony rather than conflict, disappointing socialists and revolutionaries.
In "Centesimus Annus," Pope John Paul II has added a new chapter. Where previous encyclicals have tended to treat market competition as a form of economic anarchy and economic self-interest as simple greed, he hails the market's efficiency and approves of its capacity to harness self-interest. The encyclical also focuses on the need to develop productive forces like scientific and technological know-how, organizational skills and entrepreneurial risk-taking.
Alongside these departures from past teachings, however, the Pope sets a devastating picture of impoverishment and demoralization in the Third World and even in the rich nations that is as brutal as anything Pope Leo XIII denounced a century ago.
 
Market Mechanisms
 Because the Pope clearly looks to a form of market economy to deal with these problems, some conservatives believe that Catholic social teaching is now firmly in the capitalist camp and must concentrate on how a country's culture can promote personal and public morality.
"The Pope is suggesting that the structural arguments are pretty well resolved," said George Weigel, president of the Ethics and Public Policy Center in Washington. "He is concerned now with the third leg of the triad -- a moral culture capable of sustaining the free economy so that politics and economics can serve the common good."
Others believe that questions of economics and questions of morality cannot be so neatly detached. They suspect that remedying the evils the Pope highlights may still require considerable political and economic reform. "The message that markets work is a message the United States has absorbed," said John Carr, secretary for the bishops' office on Social Development and World Peace at the United States Catholic Conference. "The message for us is that the workings of the markets still have to be guided and restrained so that human participation and dignity is protected."
But that debate is only one among many opened up in this centenary year: How can Catholic social teaching be cross-fertilized with the traditions of other religious groups? Will this teaching say more about the situation of women, mentioned only fleetingly in "Centesimus Annus"? Why is papal teaching evolving and empirical in regard to economics but much less so in areas like sexual morality or reproductive technologies?
And for Mr. Carr, the centenary means something else, that this body of teaching is "no longer just for a few dedicated people but for the whole church," integrated into education, preaching and worship.

HEADLINE: The Region;
Learning Economics

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
THE protest that crippled the City University of New York campuses for more than three weeks unraveled last week, with protesters apparently failing to block plans for a yearly $500 tuition increase and a $92 million reduction in the university's budget.
The defeat, a contrast to the conclusion of a 1989 protest that brought a reversal of a tuition hike, suggests that when fiscal times are tough, a strike over financial issues will squander much of its force. 
 Even many of the university's 200,000 students, concerned about graduation and professional credentials, tired of the drama. In the case of Borough of Manhattan Community College, they took matters into their own hands and recaptured an occupied building.
But the strike did paradoxically draw attention to an issue that has hovered over the university for more than 20 years, since it began a policy of admitting all high school graduates. How much longer can the university -- and the state government that largely funds it -- afford to keep tuition low and continue to admit all comers, including many who are not prepared to do college work?
Most policymakers believe the university, like its counterparts in other states, may have no choice, since it produces a portion of the well-educated workforce necessary to keep the city's economy competitive. But clearly it is becoming more difficult to pay for skilled faculty, modern laboratories and up-to-date libraries while at the same time expending enormous resources educating students who stand only a 50 percent chance of graduating.
Choices have to be made, and for now, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is choosing both to trim the university's budget and raise tuition.
