HEADLINE: The Region;
The City Strains to Hit A Financial Target That May Be Too Small

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
IMAGINE a huge 747 jetliner trying to land on a dirt strip that ends abruptly after 200 feet and you will have some idea of the financial exercise the Dinkins administration is currently engaged in.
One of the provisions of a state law that was passed in 1975 in response to the city's last fiscal crisis was that New York must have no more than a $100 million deficit at the end of each fiscal year. If it exceeds that target, the Financial Control Board automatically assumes responsibility for overseeing the city's finances, with powers that are Draconian compared with those the Mayor normally has. 
 This provision was one of several designed to encourage financial discipline on the part of the city. However, some leading political figures are beginning to question whether it is having that effect. At the time the law was passed, New York City's budget was about $13 billion, and the $100 million target encouraged strict discipline. Today, with the budget just under $30 billion, it tends to produce wild fiscal contortions as the June 30 end of each fiscal year approaches.
Not all of these contortions can be attributed to poor financial planning. The city is only now getting a reading on how much personal income tax to expect from the raft of filings that were sent in on April 15, and the tax is one of its largest sources of revenue for this period. The city won't know how much it will receive in bank and corporation taxes until June 25, and the state won't distribute the final sales tax revenue for the fiscal year until July 12 -- after the all-important fiscal-year cutoff has passed. There are few steps the city can take so late in the fiscal year to make up for any unexpected shortfalls.
"It's going to be close right to the end," said Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the Control Board, which is made up of the Governor, the Mayor, the City and State Controllers, and three private members.
Of course the city tries to anticipate these final payments by making projections based on revenues from previous periods and its outlook for the economy. But with the economy still sinking, such projections are even more perilous than usual. The Dinkins administration set aside a $150 million reserve fund in anticipation of potential year-end problems. But that fund was quickly earmarked for shortfalls that had already arisen. In the last few weeks as the estimate of the budget deficit has grown from about $340 million to $465 million the city has had to scramble to find other ways to end the year with a balanced budget.
Several weeks ago the city shut down some of the computers that generate its checks in order to see what purchases were in the pipeline. It then canceled $90 million worth of those purchase orders and will submit another $200 million to a committee that is to decide which ones are truly essential. Since the city's target of $100 million is based on generally accepted accounting principles, products or services not received before July 1 don't have to be counted as expenses in the current fiscal year. It is also considering issuing new bonds to pay interest on old ones, a proposal that the City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, has not yet approved.
For the city to be taking steps that may only worsen next year's fiscal picture in order to meet an artificially set target strikes some as a questionable exercise. On April 16, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo suggested that perhaps the $100 million target should be raised. Bond investors promptly registered their lack of enthusiasm for the idea by forcing yields on New York City bonds higher, an indication that they thought such a change would make New York City more of an investment risk.
The Governor quickly withdrew his suggestion. But some other political leaders are saying quietly that they think the idea is a legitimate one deserving more consideration.
Ms. Holtzman points out that $100 million is now equal to less than one-third of 1 percent of the budget, a target that is unrealistic for even the nimblest of financial managers. "It's too small a margin of error," she said. "The number ought to be changed to reflect modern-day facts."
Ms. Holtzman has suggested that the target be based on a reasonable percentage of the budget, rather than a specific dollar figure. She has not said what that percentage figure should be.
The frequent rejoinder is that nothing can be done about this problem because bond covenants would prohibit it. However, Mr. Proctor of the Control Board says the purpose of the law was to provide a package of measures that reassure bond investors. Changes can be made, he said, as long as the sum of the measures enhances bondholder protection. If there is further review, he said, another issue that deserves reconsideration is the Financial Control Act's prohibition of stabilization, or rainy-day, funds, a financial tool he considers essential at the local governmental level. As part of a broader package, he said, "bond covenants would be a surmountable issue," although the law would have to be amended.
One group that would have no problem with changes to the workings of the Financial Control Board is labor. Barry Feinstein, the influential leader and president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, thinks it would be appropriate to amend the law. But then, he added, "I think it would be a good idea if there was no Control Board at all." He noted that a "sunset" provision calls for it to expire of its own accord by the year 2008. And that, he said, taking the long view, "is just around the corner."

HEADLINE: Easier Money;
Who Benefits As the U.S. Cuts Interest Rates to Fight Recession

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE American recession, now nine months old, reached a turning point of sorts last week. Weeks of optimism that it will end soon gave way to doubts, not only among the naturally melancholy but even at the Federal Reserve, which is often the last to admit that a recession might be more severe than was initially predicted.
So the Fed applied its standard remedy. Noting that industrial production is still falling because people aren't buying much of the products that factories make -- or enough of anything else -- it cut two pivotal interest rates in hopes that easier credit would lead to a livelier economy. 
 The great goal of the policy makers trying to reverse this recession is to get consumers to spend more, much more. The new interest-rate reduction, the fourth by the Federal Reserve this year, is in line with that goal, and was applauded by President Bush and Democrats like Speaker Thomas S. Foley with more than the usual vigor.
But where does that leave things?
On the big question -- when will the recession end -- the prevailing view remains that it will be over by late summer, though some who hold that position are less certain of it than before. "I have become a bit less optimistic that the recession will end on schedule," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at Mellon Bank, who welcomed the Federal Reserve's action. In the meantime, the effects of interest-rate cuts seem certain to be much more complex than the theory behind them. The idea is to end the recession as quickly as possible by making loans more attractive for all sorts of people: As the borrowers spend, the economy expands. The reality is that just as recessions don't hurt everyone equally, the Fed's remedy helps some more than others.
The biggest winners are corporations, banks and the Federal Government itself. Much of the benefit to consumers trickles down to them slowly, if it arrives at all.
"The consumer is not yet benefiting greatly from all the Fed's actions," said Albert T. Sommers, a senior economist at the Conference Board, a research organization supported by corporations.
What the Fed did on Tuesday was to reduce the banks' cost of funds, so they can then charge less to lend out this money. The panel reduced two benchmark interest rates under its control, the discount rate, which went down to 5.5 percent from 6 percent, and the misnamed Federal funds rate, which fell to 5.75 percent, from 6 percent. The discount rate is what the Fed charges to lend money to banks and the Federal funds rate the interest that banks charge each other for short-term loans.
Discount rate lending is minuscule and interbank lending relatively small, but together the two interest rates serve as a benchmark for what commercial banks like Morgan Guaranty or Chase Manhattan pay on savings accounts, certificates of deposit and other forms of borrowing. Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities -- what the Government pays when it borrows money -- also decline in tandem with the Federal funds rate.
As the Fed allows the banks to reduce the interest they pay, the banks should pass along some of the savings by reducing the interest they charge. That is what they have done in past recessions, but in this one the banks have held back until recently, keeping most of the savings for themselves, as higher profits, to recoup some of the tens of billions of dollars they lost in shaky real estate loans in the 1980's.
The Fed has endorsed this behavior as necessary to restore the banks to good health, although the tactic can prolong the recession. Stephen Brobeck, executive director of the Consumer Federation of America, argues that with this policy, the Fed is short-changing consumers.
The banks have relented noticeably only in the last few months. Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages, for example, have fallen from an average of 10.25 percent last October to just over 9.25 percent today, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association.
That is about one-third of the decline in the rate that banks paid for funds over the same period, but it is a boon to consumers -- probably the best break they are getting on rates in this recession, economists say.
Payments on a $100,000 mortgage -- either a new one or one that a family refinances -- drop by about $60 a month, to roughly $820, when interest rates decline by a percentage point. And that $60 is money that consumers can spend on other purchases.
The biggest beneficiaries of the Fed's current rate reductions are commercial borrowers, as they always are in recessions. One victory came last Wednesday, when major banks lowered their prime lending rate by half a percentage point, to 8.5 percent.
The rate had been 10 percent on Jan. 1, and the decline since then should have gone hand-in-hand with the decline in rates for certificates of deposit, said Nancy R. Lazar, an economist at ISI Group Inc., a Wall Street brokerage house. If it had, the prime would be 7 percent today, she said. But even at 8.5 percent, corporate America gets what amounts to an infusion of cash.
The prime is another benchmark rate, in this case a benchmark for business. When companies take out short-term loans for office buildings, factories, machinery, raw materials or what have you, they usually pay floating interest rates that rise and fall with the prime and are either a percentage point or two over or under the prime.
When the prime drops by half of a percentage point, as it did last week, the result is a reduction of nearly $5 billion a year in installment payments on the $1 trillion in commercial loans outstanding today. Since January the savings have been $12 billion to $15 billion at an annual rate, which can be diverted into new machinery, or can trickle down to consumers as salaries for new jobs, more overtime pay, bigger raises or higher dividends on stock.
The trickle down is not very evident yet. The Labor Department, for example, announced on Friday that while jobs disappeared in April at a slower pace than in March, 125,000 jobs nevertheless disappeared, mostly as a result of layoffs. And both wages and overtime have been more or less stagnant this year.
Not that there haven't been some benefits for consumers. Home equity loans and some personal loans issued by banks are also often tied to the prime rate or to the rates on Treasury securities that respond to Fed rate cuts. But these total only $150 billion. Installments on mortgages with variable interest rates also can be refinanced periodically at lower rates, although most of the $3 trillion in outstanding home mortgages has been borrowed at fixed rates.
But most consumer loan rates have not declined. The rate paid on the nation's $280 billion in auto loans has remained at about 12 percent, on average. And the cost of owing $750 billion in credit card debt, department store charges and similar revolving loans has risen slightly, to the 18 to 19 percent range.
"Just as we have seen interest rate cuts passed through to the prime, we should see them passed through to the consumer, on things like auto loans and credit cards," said David W. Mullins Jr., vice chairman designate of the Federal Reserve. "As the spreads widen, banks will begin to give. What you have to have is consumers running around looking for lower rates."
But because of the rise in defaults and personal bankruptcies, consumer rates won't decline until a recovery begins, said Robert Dugger, chief economist at the American Bankers Association. "The decline in the cost of funds for banks has been more than offset by the increase in bankruptcy costs," he said.
Mr. Brobeck of the Consumer Federation agrees that rates won't drop, but for a different reason. "The market pressure on the banks is not there," he said. "Consumers are irritated by the high rates, but they are not sufficiently upset to tear up their credit cards."
But neither are they buying much with them, which leads Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist, to say, "The end of the recession keeps getting pushed ahead month after month, and it is becoming a sure thing that 1991 will be a negative year for the economy."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Getting the Royal Treatment, Tabloid Style

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
"SEPARATE HOMES," screamed the front-page headline in The Sun two weeks ago. The story -- "an extraordinary series of disclosures," in the tabloid's understated prose -- was presented as an inside account of prickly and distant relations between Prince Charles and Diana, the Princess of Wales, provided by a former security policeman, whose post was outside the gates of Charles's country house in Gloucestershire. The story included the kind of intrusive details, real or invented, about separate households, the bedroom decor, waking hours, eating habits, likes and dislikes of Charles and Diana, that feed the public obsession with the British Royal Soap Opera. The Sun ran the security guard's tale for a few days ("Tomorrow: More Amazing Revelations"), while the other Fleet Street tabloids scrambled to follow.
Last week, the royal road show was off to Brazil for an official visit and upbeat headlines. The image polishers at Buckingham Palace concede that these appearances are stage managed. The most popular set piece in the royal repertoire is Diana hugging children, "preferably black or AIDS victims or both, to put it cynically," says John Haslam, a palace press officer. And Diana did precisely that at a hospital in Sao Paulo. Again, the Royals were plastered all over the front pages of the tabloids for another solid week. 
 On May 14, the head of the House of Windsor, Queen Elizabeth, or "The Boss," as the tabloids sometimes call her, will arrive in Washington for a state visit. For Britain's mass-circulation tabloids, the Queen's trip to America should be something of a breather since the sovereign is the least-controversial member of the royal family and treated reverently by the press.
But this is shaping up as a rigorous year for the reporters the palace refers to as the "royal rat pack," and The Sun's security-guard saga was just an early salvo in the fight for stories and readers. Royal milestones loom: the family's biggest star, Diana, turns 30 on July 1; and the 10th wedding anniversary of Charles and Diana is on July 29. Other subjects with the ability to rouse readers look scarce. Now that the gulf war is over, the "salute to our heroes" genre of tabloid pieces is gone. And with Margaret Thatcher gone from 10 Downing Street, the political story is less colorful and spirited.
Much of the royals coverage seems little more than trivial gossip. But to the big London tabloids, it is a grimly serious business, journalistically and financially. Stories on the royals are a crucial element in the tabloid formula. Michael Shea, the former palace press secretary, recalled that he was once asked if he kept clippings of the tabloid stories. "I said that if you clipped out the royals stories, there would be nothing left of the tabloids," he said. And for all the fabrication, there are old-fashioned scoops: advance word of engagements, pregnancies, divorces or family traumas like Prince Edward's decision in 1987 to drop out of the Royal Marines.
The financial stakes in the royal rat race are high. Despite the recession, Rupert Murdoch's paper The Sun (circulation 3.7 million) makes an operating profit estimated at more than $100 million a year, and the Sunday tabloid News of the World (circulation 4.8 million) is another moneyspinner that depends on royals stories. Robert Maxwell, the new owner of The Daily News in New York, is the other big tabloid proprietor on Fleet Street. His leading titles -- The Daily Mirror (circulation 3 million), The Sunday Mirror (circulation 2.8 million) and The People (circulation 2.4 million), also a Sunday paper -- serve up a steady stream of royals stories.
The royals press includes not only newspapers but also a corps of authors and magazines, both specialized titles like "Royalty" and "Majesty" and general magazines like Time Warner's "People." Diana holds the all-time record for People cover appearances at 44, eight more than her closest rival, Elizabeth Taylor.
But the real cutting edge of royals coverage is the "rat pack," the 30 or so reporters and photographers who do the shoe-leather work. They scoff at the kind of "whither the monarchy" pieces that the grayer, broadsheet newspapers occasionally run. They regard most book and magazine writers as parasites who feed off the tabloids, clipping their stories and rewriting them. Come rain or shine, when the royal roadshow is in motion the rat pack is there, often jockeying for position behind police barricades. The veterans have traveled the world, from the Australian Outback to the White House. They cover the daily stories and stalk the manifold layers of palace sources, armed with guile and cash. (The tabloids have been known to pay tens of thousands of dollars to palace employees for information.)
For a decade, the acknowledged master of the craft was Harry Arnold, the senior royals reporter for The Sun, who last year jumped to The Daily Mirror. Mr. Arnold's credits include a string of exclusive stories dating to the days when Charles started going out with Diana. One scoop was about the conversation that led up to the wedding kiss on the balcony of Buckingham Palace watched by millions: Prince Andrew encouraging Charles to do it to please the half-million people assembled below, Charles resisting, then asking the Queen's permission, and finally . . . Competing tabloids hired lip readers to review the video, hoping to discredit the Arnold story. But they merely confirmed its accuracy. "My mole was on the balcony with them," Mr. Arnold confided. "But I'll never say who it was."
In late 1987, when the Duchess of York was pregnant with her first child, Beatrice Elizabeth Mary, the story ran in The Sun more than a week before the palace confirmed it. Later, the Duchess saw Mr. Arnold at an official function and said his sources must be well-placed since only five people had known she was pregnant. "Six, ma'am," he replied.
The palace tends to regard the press with upper-class disdain. But the royals also recognize that the monarchy must be accessible and seen to be serving the public or it could be dissolved. So with a carefully calculated blend of mystery and accessibility, the royal family poses, performs and keeps the soap opera going. "They're helping us to help them -- there's no question of that," said Mr. Arnold of The Mirror.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Citizen As Consumer

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
Here in our town, municipal elections are greeted by many with a feeling of resignation and despair. Across the river in Manhattan, up in Albany, down in Trenton the chief executives are like alligator wrestlers as they tussle with their budgets, trying to get a hold on something mean, slippery, and obviously more powerful than they are.
Here in our town it is much the same, except that many of us who meet on street corners to compare our astronomical tax bills accept that the alligator has already eaten us all.There is a kind of municipal inertia, part machine politics, part union clout, part historical mandate. "The more things change, the more they stay the same," say the newcomers. "Ah, they're all bums," says one old sailor who has seen it all, seen the factories close and the port sicken and die. 
 At no time is this feeling greater than during school board elections, which took place last week. And so it came as a great surprise to some of us when the reformers won. Now we will sit back and see if they can do any good, or if inertia is inexorable. In our town, the school system is spending just over $12,000 a pupil. That should make it roughly the elementary equivalent of Stanford. Instead, people who are able to send their children to private and parochial schools because they believe the public schools are substandard.
This makes us like many other urban residents in the country.
The cupboard is bare, and taxpayers everywhere are looking around to see where the money has gone. And the answer, in so many cases, is that it has been badly spent. The laboratory in which we've learned this most convincingly is our schools. It is harder to get a handle on waste and malfeasance at the Department of General Services. But schools are somewhat quantifiable.
Are children reading at grade level?
Is the teacher-pupil ratio reasonable?
How many of the high school graduates go on to further schooling? Where do they go?
Would you send your kids there? Do the teachers?
There is a national consensus building that there needs to be radical change in our public schools. But it seems to me that it is a consensus built around a larger agenda, a feeling that the pain of taxation has become so great that we must be absolutely convinced that we are paying only for what makes sense. We do not want to discover, as we did in our town, that a Board of Education carpenter made almost $70,000, $40,000 of it in overtime.
Elected officials talk about hard choices. But what we really need are the right choices. More cops on the street, fewer behind desks. More dollars in the classroom, not in administrative offices. More street sweepers, not more special assistants to the deputy commissioner. Every manager who proposes economies should be forced to justify each director, associate director and assistant director in his department before he lays off a single social worker, sanitation man or secretary.
But the converse must apply, too. At a rally of municipal employees in lower Manhattan last week, there was a rallying cry: Tax the rich! Along with that demand should come a pledge: that union leaders will devote themselves as conspicuously to shortcomings among their members as they have to the shortcomings of management. That would improve their public image.
I think many of us still believe in trade unionism. We're simply not sure we can afford any union if it protects inept workers, outmoded perks and the well-being of the union leadership at the expense of the consumer.
The teachers here in our town have negotiated a 30 percent salary increase over three years. There are just more than 330 teachers in the system, and only about 3,300 kids.
We can't afford that.
And in this also we are like so many towns across America. The boom has gone bust. The citizens have become consumers. And what we want is simple: we want value for money. There aren't any heroes or villains; there are only the people who deliver, rank and file and managers alike, and the people who don't. In these times, we can't carry the latter on our backs any longer. That's money from our pockets, and our pockets are empty. We are as irascible and fierce as any alligator. Man bites budget: that will be the story, in our towns.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Gen. Powell's Lament

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Gen. Colin Powell favored strangulating Iraq by economic and defensive military means and opposed President Bush's emerging war strategy, as late as October. That's what the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs and/or his aides told Bob Woodward for his new book.
 Does the revelation of this brief apostasy vindicate the war critics? Why did the general tell such an explosive story? What does the Woodward account suggest about the workings of the Bush Presidency? 
 The answers are: 1. No vindication, but the Powell position shows the critics had strong arguments shared by many in the Bush Administration. 2. The leaking of the story points to the general's concern for his posterity and the deepest worries of the military establishment. 3. Bushville, like most recent Administrations, is not a good place for open and honest discussions in which "the players" take long, hard looks at the facts and options.
A jovial, ill-disciplined lot. Too bad for us.
 War critics will certainly welcome the company of General Powell. They made a legitimate case for giving economic sanctions a longer run before going to war, and they deserve the respectability imparted by the general's shadow.
 Mr. Bush, however, chose the right course. Neither General Powell's early qualms nor the bloody mess of postwar Iraq derogates from this central point: President Bush correctly set out to destroy Iraq as a military threat to its neighbors and to the West's oil lifeline -- and he did it. It's doubtful that the world would have been able to sustain long-term military presence and sanctions. But even had that proved possible, Saddam Hussein's military superiority over his neighbors would have remained intact, and he still would have been able to murder his own people.
 As for the general telling tales out of school, he can be forgiven. He looked at the size of Iraqi forces and the messiness of war, and trembled at the potential costs -- like any sane person. If the war went sour, he wanted his marker of dissent on record. He is, after all, an outstanding man, a black man and a leader of men who could and would be President.
 But the general also reflected the scars inflicted on the military by the Vietnam war and wanted to protect his cherished institution. Vietnam destroyed public faith in the military, and the Pentagon struggled for years to re-establish public trust. Rightly, General Powell was not eager to throw all away again, perhaps irrevocably, in an impetuous Persian Gulf war of highly uncertain popularity.
 Mr. Woodward, an editor at The Washington Post, makes much of General Powell's bureaucratic somersaults. He recounts how the general feared to tell the President of his preference for continued sanctions, how he meekly had to package the sanctions option alongside the Bush war option and pretend that both were equally plausible.
 But, alas, that's what it's like talking to the boss in the capital city, or almost anywhere else. Presidents unfortunately take dissent for disloyalty. Most of them have got to be surrounded and cajoled -- as Clark Clifford, the ultimate master of counseling presidents, relates in his forthcoming memoir, which includes hair-raising stories about trying to walk Lyndon Johnson out of Vietnam.
 General Powell was also described by Mr. Woodward as unhappy about sloppy White House meetings where alternatives "were not completely discussed" and where "clear decisions rarely emerged." It is hard to believe, however, that the amorphousness of government meetings deranged such an experienced warrior. He served as N.S.C. adviser to President Reagan and knows that the real meetings usually take place later in the Oval Office, among the innermost intimates.
 Perhaps the most striking feature of the Woodward book is that many of these Bush intimates are now beginning to nibble away at each other with nasty little stories. Until a couple of weeks ago, Bushville had been the very model of a discreet and self-satisfied bunch of moderate-conservatives who seemed to be getting along quite well.
 Their civility was a pleasant change for Washington. But apart from the bold stroke against Iraq, it was purchased at the price of doing nothing. Maybe if the Bush team enjoyed a little less conviviality, they might look outside their windows and do something for the rest of us.

HEADLINE: Good Sense on Mexican Trade

 BODY:
President Bush has responded constructively to critics of his proposed free-trade pact with Mexico by pledging to protect U.S. workers and the environment. In a 70-page statement, the White House promises to retrain dislocated workers, preserve existing U.S. environmental standards and incorporate environmental reviews into the negotiating process.
These assurances are not airtight and establish some troubling precedents. But the response answers legitimate fears and paves the way for Congress to approve fast-track legislation, committing it to vote on trade pacts promptly and without amendments. As a matter of economics, free trade with Mexico is not all that important. But as a matter of politics, it could provide pivotal endorsement of market reforms under way in Mexico, Chile and the rest of Latin America. 
 The Bush pledges will, however, create some knotty problems. They promise generous assistance to workers laid off by the pact. But why do these workers deserve help any more than, say, construction workers who are laid off because of recession? And why do environmentalists warrant a place at the negotiating table rather than, say, human-rights activists? If trade pacts become hostage to single-issue pleaders, efforts to knock down trade barriers and spur growth will be sabotaged.
The Administration has made intelligent compromises. It emphasizes training assistance, rather than cash grants, for dislocated workers in order not to blunt incentives to find new jobs. The plan would reimpose tariffs if Mexican exports in a particular industry surged; but the backtracking would only be temporary. And all potentially disruptive provisions would be phased in slowly.
On the environment, Mr. Bush is equally sensible. He guarantees that no U.S. standard will be negotiated away. But he refuses to guarantee, as some demand, that the Mexican environment go unscathed. Environmentalists are upset that the Bush plan doesn't promise a complete environmental analysis of the trade pact before negotiations are complete; and U.S. standards appear vulnerable to the process of settling disputes. Here, the Bush plan might be usefully amended.
In the present case, free trade makes economic and political sense for both Mexico and the United States. But some workers will lose their jobs. Mr. Bush's obligation was to construct a safety net for them, while securing the greater economic gain for everyone else. The Bush plan isn't ideal. And environmentalists have proposed some useful changes. But it's a well-constructed foundation.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Rethink Railroads Before It's Too Late

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Congress Votes to Halt Rail Strike" (news article, April 18) states that "Except for the business of a few small regional railroads, all freight service stopped moving" during the strike's less than 24 hours. This passing reference to the only growing sector of a shrinking industry misses a key point. Regional and short-line railroads, more than 200 of which have been formed since industry deregulation in 1980, now operate 22 percent of the country's rail mileage. 
 Those that are unionized typically function under locally negotiated work rules, avoiding the tired old issues of 108 miles a day and five men in a crew. Their safety record is exemplary (ask the insurers) and service generally superior (ask the customers).
With the major rail carriers continuing to lose market share and to disinvest in physical plant, and union membership in a state of steady decline, isn't it time for management and labor to get together and formulate an enlightened new vision for this industry -- one that will stimulate traffic growth, create new jobs, improve profitability, attract investment capital, reduce highway congestion and benefit the environment?
The real transportation crisis we face is not the threat of a strike now, but the longer-range danger of continued downsizing of our railroad system because of Congressional refusal to recognize economic reality: that an industry burdened by archaic laws that raise its costs of doing business cannot compete effectively in an economy driven by price and service.
Sooner or later, the public must realize that Government policy should encourage stabilization of the remaining rail network before many more communities lose their access to it.
 
GEORGE C. BETKE JR.
Chairman, Farmrail System Inc.
Clinton, Okla., April 18, 1991

HEADLINE: Why Not Child-Care Loans on Same Terms as Student Loans?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
My husband and I fairly well fit the New York City family portrait in your article on two-paycheck families (The Week in Review, April 21), but we have two children under kindergarten age, a boy who just turned 5, a girl at 20 months. Our annual child care costs about $20,000. For the reasons you state, I work full time -- economic necessity, protection against financial dependence on my husband, as well as the feeling of self-worth a paycheck brings and the respect from others (husbands included) that a professional salary brings. 
 But after looking at the finances, I've had my doubts. I believe child care is a family expense. Both parents are responsible for the care of the children, and men should not be let off the hook. What's the answer? Look to the model of student loans for college-age kids. Preschool child-care expenses are concentrated in a five-year span. Why not offer long-term, low-interest financing for preschool child care?
The alternative is the route my husband and I have been forced to take -- pay for child care from disposable income, while accumulating credit-card debt at 20 percent interest, based on three-year payback (that has paid for clothing, car repair and other routine expenses). I wish we had been able to borrow on the terms of my husband's student loans -- 10-year payback at 7 percent to 12 percent, with no penalty for early payment on more of the principal.
We would finish off the debt, just in time for college tuition. But perhaps we would have managed to sock away savings for that if our child-care costs in the early years had been spread over a longer period.
I would add that I see this as a model only because we have free public school available for kindergarten to 12th grade but not for earlier preschool years, at least not in most places.
 
LINDA WAGNER
Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., April 21, 1991

HEADLINE: Why Not Child-Care Loans on Same Terms as Student Loans?;
Stereotypes and Saving

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"For Some Two-Paycheck Families, the Economics Don't Add Up" (The Week in Review, April 21) perpetuates the worst stereotypes of the working mother. It's she who is responsible for the baby, the sitter and, of course, dinner. 
 And if that wasn't enough, I find truly ludicrous your suggestion that it may not be a significant financial benefit to have $6,000 more a year in income after expenses (not anticipating raises or promotions in the short term).
That paltry $6,000 can be invested for college. With a zero-coupon Treasury bond, $27,000 would be available.
I'm a freelance marketing writer-creative consultant and the mother of a 10-month-old daughter. I worked from a home office before she was born and continue to do so. My husband works for a Fortune 500 company. Since self-employment leads to erratic cash flow, we learned how to economize before the baby. Most of the time my husband takes his lunch to work. I eat at home.
The money your hypothetical couple spends on food taken out or eaten in is profligate. They could probably shave some from their clothes budget too, shopping sales and discount stores. With more left over, maybe the wife's work would become more financially significant.
 
AMY ZIPKIN

HEADLINE: Escape From Tiananmen Square: A Chinese Odyssey

BYLINE: By Nicholas D. Kristof ;Nicholas D. Kristof is chief of the Beijing bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
WERE YOU FOLLOWED?" LIU XIANG ASKED anxiously, by way of greeting. It was a bright September day last year when we met for dinner at a restaurant in the center of Beijing. He hardly touched his food, spending much of his time looking over his shoulder. A fugitive from the law, Liu was very different from the easygoing physics student who, the year before, was at the center of the democracy movement at Tiananmen Square.
"They're closing in," he said in a whisper. "The police have been asking around town about me, and I've got to leave very soon. But this time I've got to get to Hong Kong safely. Otherwise, it's all over." 
 Liu Xiang (pronounced lee-o shahng) was haunted by the memories of the prison from which he had just escaped. Each night he had the same nightmare. "In my dream, they beat me, and I try to explain that I didn't really mean to escape, and they just keep on beating me and beating me." Each night he would wake, his body in a cold sweat, his heart pumping wildly.

IT ALL BEGAN WITH A MIDNIGHT SNACK. LATE ON THE evening of April 18, 1989, Liu Xiang went out with some friends to eat and ran into a crowd of Beijing University students marching toward Tiananmen Square. Caught up in the excitement, Liu joined the march. That decision changed his life.
Gangly, with close-cropped hair, Liu was then a 23-year-old senior at Qinghua University, one of China's premier colleges. A member of the Communist Youth League, he was at the time a firm supporter of the Communist Party. He remained a supporter even as the democracy movement sucked him in, as it did millions of others around the country. But then came the crackdown, and Liu found to his horror that the Communist Party had no compunctions about declaring war on him and his fellow students.
Fleeing to southern China, Liu entered a world he scarcely knew existed -- a free-for-all zone of bribery, smuggling and criminal gangs. He escaped to Hong Kong in April 1990, requesting asylum from the British authorities. Instead, he was returned to China some days later. Thrown into prison, he learned to rely on his fists as well as his brains. He managed to escape and make his way back to Beijing. By then it was summer and the police were on his heels. He fled south once more and again sneaked across the border to Hong Kong. Last month, he arrived in New York to start a new life.
Liu Xiang's two-year odyssey affords an unusual glimpse of China's underside, where the regime's repressive apparatus is sometimes more pathetic than terrifying. Corruption, greed and passive resistance conspire to frustrate the hard-liners' ability to capture democracy movement fugitives like Liu Xiang.
In Maoist times, it probably would have been impossible for a political fugitive to escape China once, let alone twice. In past campaigns of repression, the party was able to mobilize the masses to turn in their neighbors, even their family. This time, ordinary Chinese sided with the fugitives.
Escape stories of the democracy movement activists may differ in the details but they all share one point: none of the activists would have been able to escape if it were not for the assistance of a range of people along the way, from peasants to Communist Party officials. Liu Xiang found that acquaintances everywhere were willing to lie for him, bribe for him and forge identity papers for him. These acquaintances showed him that, particularly in southern China, the security network is tattered. Liu found his way out through the holes.
What Liu's two-year ordeal also underscores is the way the British overseers of Hong Kong sometimes seem to be doing Beijing's bidding. Sending a democracy movement activist back to China, to face the possibility of a long prison sentence, is hardly in keeping with the professed British ideals of fair play and common decency. However, the British authorities hold the view that the best way to manage Hong Kong is not to vex China but to maintain stability and allow for a graceful exit in 1997. Liu seems to have been a victim of that policy.
It was in Hong Kong, while hiding as an illegal immigrant after his second escape, in December 1990, that Liu recounted details of his life after the June 1989 crackdown at Tiananmen Square. Speaking mostly in Mandarin, his words punctuated here and there with prison jargon, sometimes drifting into the functional English he learned in school, Liu Xiang gave a Dantean account of his journey through the many circles of a Chinese Communist hell.

QINGHUA UNIVERSITY, A SPRAWLING CAMPUS nestled in the northwestern outskirts of Beijing, is the M.I.T. of China. In China, only a tiny elite pass the examinations to get into any university, and those who succeed tend to find higher education a liberating experience.
After slaving away in high school and struggling to pass college entrance examinations, they finally have the chance to fall in love (romance is banned in high schools) as well as the time to reflect on life and politics. One of the few burdens foisted on them is that of history: students have played an important role during China's major upheavals of the last 100 years, and they sometimes hold themselves responsible for the direction of their nation.
My wife and fellow New York Times correspondent, Sheryl WuDunn, met Liu Xiang while she was interviewing students at Tiananmen Square shortly after the democracy movement began. Liu was bright and articulate, one of a handful who would phone us with information about plans for demonstrations and other student activities. We met with him often, and he impressed us as courteous, gentle and eager to be helpful. Without appearing manipulative, Liu Xiang charms those around him.
One of his greatest skills is in cultivating guanxi (connections) -- a critical talent in China. China is not so much a market economy or a socialist economy as a guanxi economy. Everything from jobs to cars to videos is distributed largely on the basis of guanxi. Knowing this is how the system works, Liu would collect guanxi the way some people collect postage stamps.
Back in the spring of 1989, in his ramshackle dorm, with books and clothing strewn about, Liu and his five roommates complained about hard-line policies, but not about the system itself. On one visit, I asked Liu if he was anti-Communist. "Of course not," he said, a bit horrified. "We all support the Communist Party. We want to reform it."
Liu Xiang's father, an officer of the People's Liberation Army, had been killed during a gun battle in the Cultural Revolution and was later declared a martyr by the Government. Liu grew up in the ancient city of Xian, in north-central China, and was raised as a believer in Communism.
When the 1989 student democracy movement began, he didn't want to get involved. "It's very tough to get into Qinghua University," he explained, "and if you get in trouble then it's all down the drain." Yet it was impossible to stay away from Tiananmen Square. First he watched from the sidelines. Then he helped carry to waiting ambulances those classmates who had gone on hunger strikes and had fainted. He stayed with them as they were revived, and he saw them pull the IV tubes from their arms to resume their fast. Liu was moved in a way he had never been before.
A radio buff, Liu was asked by several of his friends -- student leaders -- to help set up a loudspeaker system at Tiananmen Square to air news about their movement. Liu helped run the "broadcast station," as they called it, and also served as a liaison with a number of foreign journalists.
Then, in the early morning hours of June 4, his world was shattered. "We had expected tear gas that evening, but nobody thought the soldiers would fire on the people," Liu Xiang recalls. "We were shocked, and that was when my attitude toward the Communist Party changed. Everything we believed in suddenly collapsed."
At 4 A.M., heading with some friends for the area around Tiananmen Square, Liu found tanks burning and the People's Liberation Army behaving like an invading force. The students spent much of the next few days harassing troops and playing a dangerous cat-and-mouse game with them along the alleys around the main roads. Twice, bullets narrowly missed Liu, and once, he says, he helped set fire to an armored personnel carrier -- a capital offense in itself.
The Army quickly consolidated its control over the capital. Many students and workers were detained, and the security forces began daily interrogations of Liu Xiang on the Qinghua campus. Obliged to write day-by-day accounts of his activities during the democracy movement, Liu omitted any mention of his involvement in the broadcast station or his role in setting fire to the personnel carrier. The authorities knew nothing about those matters, and grilled him instead on his contacts with student leaders and with me and Sheryl.
The university refused to allow Liu to graduate, and the questionings continued all summer. The authorities were sure he wasn't telling the complete truth, but he had one advantage over them: they didn't know what he had actually done.
"I figured if I lied, I'd be able to get a diploma and resume a normal life," he says, and so he lied about almost everything. He denied any role at Tiananmen and insisted he had met my wife and me only casually and briefly. Yet even during that terrifying time, he managed to outwit the police, who were keeping us under partial surveillance, to meet with Sheryl and to brief her on the crackdown and the interrogations on the campuses. Beneath his affable exterior was clearly an iron resolve, a courage that sometimes bordered on the reckless.
As in almost every part of the country, the investigations at Qinghua were subverted by a massive cover-up by students, professors and even Communist Party officials. At the risk of their careers and their freedom, officials intervened and lied to protect those involved in the Tiananmen movement.
At Qinghua, some well-placed individuals secretly met with Liu and other students who were under investigation. "They would tell us, 'The authorities know this much, so tell them that, and no more,' " Liu says. One sympathizer helped Liu obtain a photocopy of his university diploma, so that he could pretend to have graduated.
There was, however, no sign that the investigation was drawing to a close. As the summer wore on, Liu Xiang began to worry that time was running out. When the regular Qinghua students returned to campus for the fall semester, the authorities would be able to question more people and might learn that he had been lying about his democracy movement activities.
After a number of student acquaintances were arrested, he became even more nervous and finally obtained some false documents from a friendly official. He then secretly arranged to flee to the southern city of Shenzhen, adjacent to Hong Kong.

TWELVE YEARS AGO, Shenzhen was little more than a farming community. But as soon as it was declared a special economic zone -- an area modeled on the frenetically capitalistic Hong Kong -- it was transformed almost overnight into a boom town. Hong Kong entrepreneurs found that they could save on labor costs by transferring their garment and toy factories across the border. Today, Hong Kong companies employ some 2 million Chinese workers in Shenzhen, which has a population of 1.9 million, and the surrounding towns of Guangdong Province.
In most of China, jobs and apartments are assigned. In Shenzhen, and to a lesser extent elsewhere in Guangdong, it is possible to find a job and rent an apartment on one's own. This has corroded the Government's control mechanisms and created a wealth of new opportunities -- for criminals as well as more conventional entrepreneurs. Among the concrete-block apartment houses and thriving shops are people who will supply ID cards to those who want a new identity. In Maoist China, there was nowhere to hide; now there is Guangdong.
Criminal gangs have also moved in. The gangs, known as Triads (derived from the Cantonese name for the Three in Accord Society, the "three" being heaven, earth and man), have a long history in China. Triads fled after the 1949 revolution to Hong Kong and Taiwan; there, in close proximity to China, they have remained powerful, providing "protection" to nightclubs, for example, and periodically getting into terrifying turf battles in which hoods go after one another with cleavers.
With the weakening of Communist controls over the last dozen years, the Triads set up branches in Shenzhen and other parts of Guangdong, running smuggling, gambling and prostitution rackets. (According to the Shenzhen authorities, in just the last five months of 1990 more than 60 criminal gangs were broken up.)
Liu Xiang thought that in such a free-for-all he could get a job with no questions asked. Ordinary Chinese are not allowed to enter Shenzhen without a special certificate, but Liu was able to go through guanxi and get the necessary documentation. Liu's new papers, which were under his own name, proclaimed him a worker who had never participated in the democracy movement and who was going to Shenzhen as a buyer for a factory.
Shortly after arriving in Shenzhen, in September 1989, Liu Xiang found a temporary position in an office assigning Chinese sailors to jobs on foreign ships. Liu told his employer he had not taken part in the democracy movement, showing the bootleg photocopy of his diploma as evidence. "If I had been involved," he declared, "how would I have the diploma?"
Struggling to rebuild his future, Liu systematically went about cultivating guanxi in Shenzhen. Through a network of new friends, he found someone with connections to the Public Security Bureau, and he managed to extend his length of stay in Shenzhen.
He also made connections with the criminal underworld. Those gangsters whom he met were not caricatures out of a kung fu movie. Some were well-educated and ambitious young people alienated from the system and were drawn to the easy money to be had from smuggling and other illegal activities.
As a final backup, in case the authorities caught up with him, Liu used his job to obtain an ID card in the name of a sailor whose papers he was handling for the agency.
Unfortunately, Liu Xiang did his job so well that his boss decided to hire him permanently. While on a trip to Beijing in early 1990, the boss dropped by Qinghua University to check Liu's file (all Chinese have a personnel file, whose contents they are not allowed to see) and was horrified to learn that his star employee was being sought by the university authorities for fleeing in the middle of investigations.
Upon returning to Shenzhen, the boss promptly dismissed Liu Xiang. Liu then joined the gangs, helping them trade currencies on the black market. "We made a lot of money in a short period," he says, grinning at the memory.
Meanwhile, Qinghua officials had informed the Public Security Bureau in Beijing that Liu was working in Shenzhen. Soon, two Beijing policemen were in Shenzhen, questioning people about Liu's whereabouts. Liu Xiang felt the net tightening around him. It was time to leave for Hong Kong.

OVER THE NEXT FEW weeks, Liu borrowed maps of Hong Kong, memorizing the street names and geography of the border area. He got Hong Kong currency, and he went to places frequented by Hong Kong tourists, to see what set them apart from mainland Chinese.
"I decided that the head and feet were most important," he says. "Hong Kong people have fancy haircuts and they wear imported shoes. Plus a lot of them wear blue jeans."
So Liu invested in a pair of imported athletic shoes and an expensive haircut. The only giveaway was a chipped and rotten front tooth, an obvious product of Chinese dentistry.
Hiring a boat to take him all the way to Hong Kong was too expensive, so Liu arranged to make his escape on Zhong-Ying Street, a shopping district straddling the border. One side of the street is China; the other, Hong Kong. It is an area crammed with shops selling everything imaginable, from gold jewelry to traditional medicines to pornographic magazines.
Residents of China need special permission to visit the street, but Liu and two friends used their guanxi to pay a bribe equivalent to $106 (several months' salary for a factory worker) so that the Chinese People's Armed Police would look the other way. Hong Kong police are stationed along the street to prevent residents of China from slipping into the British territory, and Liu and his friends sneaked through back entrances and alleys until they got to a gulf of water separating them from Hong Kong.
"We found a private boat that would take us across the water," Liu says. "When the marine police were changing shifts, we crossed the channel." On April 22, 1990, after being dropped off on shore, Liu and his companions hiked across some hills and then flagged a minibus. They went immediately to Chinese University, whose student union had sent delegates to Tiananmen Square during the democracy movement.
Liu Xiang's problems seemed to be over. At Chinese University, he was treated as a hero, and he and his friends were put in touch with the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of the Patriotic Democratic Movement in China. The three subsequently turned themselves in to the Hong Kong Government and requested asylum.
Although Liu and his friends were kept at a detention center, they were treated courteously, and there seemed to be no problems. Liu had documents, including photographs and testimonials, confirming his role at Tiananmen.
On their seventh day in Hong Kong, immigration officers told the three to get their belongings ready, shook their hands and wished them well. Liu was elated. But then a long bus pulled up, and he froze. It was not the van used to take people back to the center of Hong Kong. Instead, it was the bus used to repatriate illegal immigrants to China.
"There must be some mistake," Liu protested, but the police forced him and his friends on the bus. Liu's voice hardens as he speaks of the Hong Kong Government's decision.
"It was contemptible," he says. "We'd been betrayed by the Hong Kong Government. We were so shocked and angry, and we figured we'd be sentenced to 10 years in prison."
The Hong Kong Government declines to discuss specific cases. The territory's British overseers have briefly, and as secretly as possible, provided refuge to some prominent democracy activists from China before sending them on to Europe or the United States. But the Hong Kong authorities have done this unenthusiastically, worried about the reaction from Beijing, and have systematically moved to curb criticisms about China that would upset its leadership. Hong Kong has not allowed some prominent Chinese dissidents living abroad to visit the territory. Films critical of China are censored.
In most parts of its former empire, from India to Africa, Britain tried to nurture democratic governments in the territories it was leaving. In Hong Kong, it appears to have done the reverse, and democracy forces in Hong Kong charge that British officials have done this so that London can maintain smooth diplomatic and trade relations with Beijing.
British and Hong Kong Government officials dispute such charges. They assert that Hong Kong cannot survive without China, and that openly supporting a small number of democracy activists would only hurt the great majority of Hong Kong residents in the long run.

THE FEW MINUTES on the bus as it returned to China were among the worst in Liu's life.
He knew that the Hong Kong authorities provide a list of all the illegal immigrants they repatriate. He also knew that the papers and photos he was carrying -- intended to document his involvement in the democracy movement and therefore win him asylum -- would get him swift punishment from China. He hid these under the bus seat, knowing that he was riding in a Hong Kong bus that probably would not be searched.
As many as 100 people are repatriated each day from Hong Kong. Most are illegal immigrants from Guangdong Province and are released, on payment of a small fine, once they can prove they are from the local area and have no criminal record. Those from distant provinces, like Liu Xiang, are interrogated to make sure they are not wanted for some crime. Sometimes they are sent back to the Public Security Bureaus in their hometowns, a process that can take months.
From the list provided by Hong Kong, the Chinese knew Liu's name, but he lied about his identity, claiming to be a worker from Xian and giving a false address. Eventually, of course, the police would realize that he had given a phony address and might beat the truth out of him, but he hoped to be free by then. He asked a detainee who was about to be released to phone a friend in Shenzhen and explain the situation. The Shenzhen friend promptly went to great lengths to bribe the guards to release Liu.
"The guards took the 'gifts,' but said that to release me they needed proof that I didn't have a criminal record," Liu says. "My friend tried to get that, but it was very difficult to get the necessary paper forged. In Guangdong, it's usually easy to get things done with money, but in this case we had some difficulties." The friend did get one such forged document, but it didn't look authentic and the friend decided not to run the risk of using it.
Liu was transferred first to Zhangmutou Detention Center and then to Yangcun Detention Center, both in central Guangdong. The conditions were similar: up to 40 prisoners to a cell and up to 10 sleeping in a single, oversized bed. In addition to the beds, the cell contained a basin of water and a hole in the floor for a toilet.
Meals consisted of cold rice with warmed-over vegetables. "The biggest problem was that there wasn't enough food," Liu says. "If somebody spat out a rotten or disgusting vegetable on the floor, someone else would pick it up and put it in his mouth, even though the guards would beat us if they saw us doing that."
Liu, who is 5 foot 11, weighed 172 pounds when he entered prison and just 147 pounds seven weeks later. In addition to hunger, the prisoners constantly suffered from mosquito bites and a particularly ferocious kind of bedbug that left their legs covered with angry red welts.
At the detention centers, as in all Chinese prisons, order was established in each cell by the "boss" -- a prisoner who bullied his way to the top of the heap and ordered the other prisoners around. Liu felt frighteningly out of place, but he was lucky enough to be physically larger than most of the other prisoners.
At Yangcun, in another bit of good fortune, the boss in his cell was a fellow northerner and Mandarin speaker. "Big Brother, please take my watch," Liu told the boss as soon as he was in the cell. The boss warmed to such flattery (and no doubt would have taken the wristwatch in any case), and soon Liu became one of his strongmen. They would rough up new arrivals, looking for money hidden from the guards. The money would be used to buy cigarettes, food and clothing.
When the boss was moved to another prison, Liu Xiang took over. As though he had taken on the coloration of the jungle, the college boy was now a gang leader, forcing other prisoners to wash his underwear and give up their money and sometimes even their food. When they disobeyed, he ordered his strongmen to beat them up. One might expect Liu, formerly an advocate of democracy, to be embarrassed about his activities as a boss, but he is unapologetic.
"Originally, I didn't want to do it, but then I realized that in prison everything depends on this," he says, clenching a fist. "If you don't beat them up, then you'll get beaten up. And then you'll end up washing their underwear. In there, the only thing that matters is violence. There's no morality, just power."
That attitude reflects a general moral uncertainty of recent years. China's main sources of moral values -- traditional Confucianism and revolutionary Communism -- have largely collapsed, and many young people today speak of a crisis of faith. Some have turned to religion, others to drugs or various cults, to give their lives meaning. Even the outpouring of support for the 1989 democracy movement seemed to have stemmed partly from a popular yearning for a noble cause to believe in.
That student movement has given rise, in turn, to a new and powerful imperative: protect the student participants. Thus, while many young people are complaining about their nation's spiritual vacuum, there have been countless cases of ordinary people displaying enormous moral courage in protecting student dissidents. Even as Liu is matter-of-fact when he talks about beating people in prison, he is scrupulous about not getting anyone in trouble for helping him.
Ironically, it was Liu's assertion of brute force, not his principles, that got him in trouble in prison. Liu had ordered his henchmen to beat a newcomer suspected of hiding his money, but the guards broke up the fight and then decided to teach Liu a lesson. They beat him and locked him in a separate cell, with his wrists handcuffed tightly behind his back.
"I was left lying on the wet cement floor," he says. "There was nothing inside, just a hole for a toilet, and it was clogged and the floor was very wet. The handcuffs were terribly tight, and after 15 minutes I was sweating and my blood couldn't circulate. I called the guards, but they didn't come. I kicked the door, and kept kicking for an hour or so. Finally, a guard came and loosened the handcuffs a bit, but by that time I couldn't use my hands. There was no feeling in them."
After 20 agonizing hours, Liu was returned to his regular cell.

WHILE IN PRISON, Liu Xiang spent his time humming a popular Chinese rock song -- "I Have Nothing" -- and searching for a solution to his problems. "What I thought of most was getting out," he says. "What I worried about most was my Mom. If she heard I was in prison " -- he pauses and shivers -- "it would be terrible."
He thought his best opportunity to escape would be while working on the prison farm. "I decided the best time was when it rained, because then it's harder for them to drive their motorcycles around looking for you, and they won't try as hard to find you." So on June 12, 1990, after a thunderstorm, Liu made his move.
He was working in a large vegetable field with seven other prisoners. Security is relatively lax in Chinese labor camps, because traditionally there is no place for an escaped prisoner to run. On that day, only three guards were on duty, and the prisoners were scattered about the field. Liu began to work near the guard who was paying the least attention.
"When the guard wasn't looking, I slipped behind a hedge," he says. "I was ready to say that I needed to relieve myself." But the guard didn't notice and Liu crawled to the edge of the field and then through another hedge functioning as a kind of fence. Since Liu had not been convicted of any offense, he was wearing civilian clothes and was able to hurry along the road and hitch a ride on a truck. A sympathizer had smuggled a small amount of money to Liu, which enabled him to make his way to Canton, where he hid with friends.
He then made his way back to Beijing by train -- using tickets purchased by a friend -- and even though he was a fugitive from the law, he was welcomed by his buddies. Almost no one had qualms about seeing him or helping him. Yet to his friends, Liu seemed a changed man. He was no longer an idealistic university student but a prison-hardened young man who had had a taste of the fast life in Guangdong. He boasted of his underworld connections and of the invitations to join the gangs.
By late summer, Liu had regained some of his weight and had had his bedbug bites treated. But he also was getting increasingly edgy, terrified that the police were closing in on him. He decided to escape once more to Hong Kong.
Having jettisoned his documents while being repatriated to China in April, Liu Xiang had to spend $42 on a bribe to get a new pass to go in and out of Shenzhen. He arrived in Shenzhen in the fall of 1990 and renewed his underworld guanxi to see if they could help him flee to Hong Kong. But this time he found himself running into one obstacle after another. Some smugglers were willing to take him by boat to Hong Kong, but then they were arrested. His friends who had arranged the bribe for him to get to Zhong-Ying Street had also been arrested.
While waiting to work out a solution, Liu had his hair permed to look more like a Hong Kong resident. The best time to cross the border, he decided, was on a public holiday, when few Hong Kong police are on duty. He selected Christmas Day, which is a holiday in the British colony.
Working through his guanxi, Liu was able to join a group of Shenzhen residents visiting Zhong-Ying Street on Dec. 25. As the other tour members gawked, Liu slipped through the back doors and alleys on the Hong Kong side of the street and made his way to the water. With his usual aplomb, he offered to help a group of elderly Hong Kong people carry their bags onto a ferryboat. He had a terrible moment when he saw that Hong Kong police were beside the ramp, looking for Chinese illegal immigrants, but he marched brazenly toward them. The police recognized the elderly people Liu Xiang was helping and let the group pass.
On the other side of the bay, Liu Xiang took a taxi to meet some friends, who gave him refuge. But inquiries to the Hong Kong Government ran into a stone wall. The highest levels were advised of his situation in detail, but they refused once more to grant him asylum. This left him an illegal immigrant in Hong Kong, subject to arrest and repatriation at any time.
Liu considered various ways to reach the United States, including smuggling himself on a freighter, but in the end another method was found (details of which cannot be revealed here). On April 12, Liu Xiang arrived in the United States and was admitted by the immigration authorities because of his political background. As this article goes to press, Asia Watch -- the human rights organization -- is trying to find a university to take Liu for the next academic year.
"I think I will love New York," Liu Xiang says exuberantly, a few days after arriving. "It's great. And after seeing police all over the streets in Hong Kong and China, and being afraid of them, I notice that there are very few police on the streets of New York. That leaves a very favorable impression."

PUB-DATE: May 5, 1991,

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 5; Financial Desk
