HEADLINE: Grace Pastiak's 'Web of Inclusion'

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

DATELINE: LISLE, Ill.

 BODY:
Last fall, Tellabs Inc., a maker of sophisticated telephone equipment, received an important order that would have to be completed by the end of the year. Instead of simply posting overtime notices, as would happen in many factories, Grace Pastiak called a meeting of the plant's workers.
"I knew that it was getting into the holiday season and many of the people would have family demands," said Mrs. Pastiak, director of manufacturing for one of three operating divisions. 
 Standing on a ladder in the middle of the plant, she spoke to the workers. "I gave them some choices," she said. "I said we could tell marketing we could only do half. We could bring in contract labor, or we could shift some production outside. After we talked about it, they said, 'Go for it' and that's what we did." The workers readily put in overtime to get the job done on time.
Mrs. Pastiak appears to be not just another plant manager. Instead of writing memos or limiting her discussions to one or two lieutenants, she prefers a more personal approach. She communicates directly with her people on the plant floor, trying to infect them with a zeal for producing high-quality products. And she fiddles endlessly in search of a better production set-up.
It is a style that Judy B. Rosener, a professor at the University of California at Irvine, calls "interactive leadership" and that some researchers have suggested is distinctive to women. The female managers who exhibit it, Professor Rosener wrote in a December article in the Harvard Business Review, "encourage participation, share power and information, enhance other people's self-worth, and get others excited about their work."
Sally Helgesen, a journalist and author of the book "The Female Advantage -- Women's Ways of Leadership" says the phenomenon affects the configurations of their staffs. She concludes that women tend to form flat organizations, rather than hierarchies, that emphasize frequent contacts among staff members and the sharing of information. She calls these networks "webs of inclusion."
 
An Evolving Role
The developments, these researchers say, are an outgrowth of women's evolving role in the work force. While earlier generations of female executives seemed to delight in proving they were tougher than any man, "a second wave of women," Professor Rosener wrote, "is making its way into top management not by adopting the style and habits that have proved successful for men, but by drawing on the skills and attitudes they developed from their shared experience as women."
Grace Pastiak, who, at the age of 35 is one of the rare female managers in manufacturing, may be representative of this new generation. But she says her style stems from reading and courses rather than from her orientation as a woman. "I don't think it is gender-specific," she said.
"I have the bias that people do better when they are happy," said Mrs. Pastiak, who attributes her style in part to her education in sociology and early jobs in social work. "The old style of beating on people to get things done does not work."
In fact, whether this more nurturing management style is more distinctive to women than to men is a controversial issue. Indeed, Professor Rosener's article touched off a spirited discussion in a subsequent issue of the Harvard Business Review. (Box, page 6.)
One woman who is free to run a business as she chooses, Barbara Grogan, the owner of Western Industrial Contractors, a heavy-equipment moving company in Denver, said: "Women do lead and manage differently. There is no real hierarchy in my office, and we never have meetings. Nobody controls information and power. We just make it happen."
Ross Webber, a professor of management at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, thinks there is a general drift away from a hierarchical, military-style management style. "In the broadest-brush terms, the decline of the hierarchy as a source of power, and an emphasis on the ability to build coalitions, is the central management trend of the past 25 years," he said. "As such, it has been a helpful trend for women managers."
For her part, Mrs. Pastiak, as the supervisor of a work force of 170 people, provides a test case of whether the factories can work effectively without relying on the traditional rigid command structure.
Although high-ranking women are found in abundance in the professions and in important staff positions in large corporations, fewer have moved into jobs of authority in manufacturing. "It may be a supply-side problem," Professor Webber observed. "Women do not want to manage in blue-collar, union situations."
There is a culture of flexibility and innovation at Tellabs that has probably permitted Mrs. Pastiak to go further with soft management methods than might have been possible in more tradition-bound companies.
Founded in 1974, Tellabs employs 2,100 in a nonunion shop and has annual sales of about $200 million, which means it is still tiny to be competing with the likes of A.T.&T., Northern Telecom, Siemens, NEC and Fujitsu.
The company operates at the intersection of the communications and computer industries. It produces products for the big long-distance and regional telephone companies as well as concerns that have their own telephone and data communications systems. A typical product is an echo canceler, which blocks out the mysterious third voice that can be a nuisance during long distance calls.
 
Committed to Training
 Mrs. Pastiak is regarded by bothher bosses and subordinates as an effective manager, and the numbers seem to back this up. She meets production targets 98 percent of the time, compared with an industry standard that she puts near 90 percent. And it is a record she keeps without seeming to be preoccupied with the output, attendance and cost reports that are the production manager's staples.
Instead, she is a champion of worker empowerment, worker education and Japanese quality methods. She takes two full days each month, for example, to teach a course in what the company calls Total Quality Commitment -- a task that she believes most male managers in her position would assign a subordinate.
Speaking to factory workers gathered in a conference room, she bubbles with enthusiasm as she goes over her personal formula for improving quality by systematic problem solving. An astute instructorm making sure her students get the message, she repeatedly focuses their attention: "What is the purpose? What is the process? And what is the payoff?"
About a dozen workers are taken at a time from their usual task of assembling circuit boards to attend the hourlong sessions. Mrs. Pastiak considers it time well spent, despite the loss of production time. "I cannot think of anything more important that I should be doing than empowering people," she said in the flat twang of a native of northern Illinois. "I want people to have a sense of accomplishment."
Not that production is neglected. Sitting in her corner office, Mrs. Pastiak reaches for a thick red binder filled with documents listing output by shift. "I get daily reports on what we shipped and weekly reports on other key measures," she said.
But she says the staff's development means she does not need to spend as much time studying reports. "The stronger the teams become, the less they need you," she said.
 
Worker Self-Reliance
 That throws more of the problem-solving to workers on the factory floor, said Tom Sharpe and Tim Murphy, two of her subordinates. "We get daily reports on why things did not ship," said Mr. Sharpe. "Usually it is for a reason out of our control. If it is within our control, we fix it and then cut the boss in on what we have done."
The proof of the production line's self-reliance: its ability to fill 98 percent of its orders. "In another plant, something may need to be done, but people say, 'That's not my job' and the order goes unfilled," Mrs. Pastiak said. "Around here the attitude is 'what do we have to do to get the order to the customer.' "
Mrs. Pastiak said it helps if top management reinforces this every-person-matters mentality. Even though the recession has cut orders, no production workers have been laid off. Instead, workes have shifted to four-day weeks until orders picked up. (The company reported a loss of $968,000 for the first quarter, compared with a profit of $2.54 million last year.)
 Most of Mrs. Pastiak's subordinate managers are men, many of whom say she manages differently than men in senior roles. Duane Dhamen, a project manager, said in referring to the head of another division, "he talks to one or two key people and lets the information filter down to the ranks." By contrast, Mrs. Pastiak "puts a stronger focus on the team and open communications," he said.
Another manager, David Gladstein, said: "If Grace left tomorrow, we would still be a team, at least for a while. But with a different individual, it could change."
Mrs. Pastiak did not know a capacitor from a resistor when she came to work at Tellabs as a buyer in 1977.
At that time, recalls Michael J. Birck, a former Bell Laboratories engineer who was one of the founders of Tellabs and remains its president, sales growth was rapid, but it was clear the company's manufacturing operations were dragging it down. "We had a 35.8 percent gross margin in 1985, which is no way to survive," he said. "At that level we could not invest enough in new products to grow." The aim was at least 45 percent before taxes and depreciation and interest costs.
In addition, there were serious quality problems, a significant threat in an industry that emphasizes reliability. "Mike Birck went into one of our stockrooms and checked some of our products," recalled Edward McDevitt, a vice president. "Only 70 percent of the samples he chose performed to specs."
Rather than try to solve the problems by shifting production overseas, as some companies have done, Mr. Birck asked Mr. McDevitt to start applying Japanese manufacturing methods, like just-in-time inventory control and statistical quality control. Mr. McDevitt, in turn, chose Mrs. Pastiak to lead a pilot project in the Lisle factory in mid-1986.
"I knew that Grace was good at teaching and training, and I knew she would move any roadblocks in her way," he said.
Under the new process, individual workers were trained to inspect their own work and given the right to shut down production until errors were corrected. Rather than working on parts of a product, like welders on an automobile assembly line, workers were organized into teams. Each team assembles a product from beginning to end, and each member of a team is trained to do multiple jobs.
The pilot project was successful. Work-in-process inventory went down 80 percent. The time it took to fill an order went from 22 days to two. Financial margins improved as well. Last year the company, whose shares are traded over-the-counter, reported that its gross margin had widened to 44.9 percent.
While the project was under way, Mrs. Pastiak spent most of her days on the factory floor, changing the way the circuit boards were assembled, soldered and tested. She rearranged so many machines that the maintenance crews would try to hide when she came around. "They would say, 'That woman is moving furniture again,' " Mrs. Pastiak recalled.
The success of the pilot led to companywide use of the technique and to Mrs. Pastiak's promotion to director of manufacturing in 1987, making her the highest-ranking woman line executive in the company. (Among staff jobs, women hold the titles of general counsel and the head of a software development project.)
 
A Few More Hurdles
 Grace Swanson met Robert Pastiak at Tellabs. "He actually worked for me for a while, which was interesting," she said.
They have two small children: Annie who is 2 1/2 years old and Brian, 17 months. Mrs. Pastiak said she drops the children at a day care center in the morning and picks them up in the evening. She concedes it is a less-than-ideal arrangement.
Nevertheless, being part of a two-income couple may also have given her more latitude to act than her male peers. "I may have more freedom to innovate, because my paycheck is not the sole support of the family," she said.
Still, even at Tellabs, some of her female colleagues doubt that a woman can go to the very top. They said that in general the men who control manufacturing companies need to become more comfortable with women as colleagues -- and their styles -- before they begin bestowing vice presidential titles on women.
"It is a comfort-level thing," said Diana Kreitling, a former manufacturing supervisor who is now in marketing. "Most of the male managers are in their mid-40's to 60's, which is about half a generation ahead of us. Their real concern is, 'Can I tell this joke? Can I go golfing with her? What about business trips?' "
 
 
The Pay Lag Persists, Whatever the Reasons
 Despite women's progress in the corporate world, there is still a long way to go, according to Wendy Reed-Crisp, director of the National Association for Female Executives in New York.
"As women get into a field, salaries go down because women are willing to work for less," she said. "It has happened in public relations, real estate and some parts of advertising. Women are desperate for the opportunity, so they undersell themselves."
Ms. Reed-Crisp said her organization includes about 250,000 women in middle to upper management, entrepreneurial roles and the professions. Membership has increased by 90,000 in the last two years, as the recession has prompted women fearful of losing their jobs to try to build networks.
According to Ms. Reed-Crisp, statistics comparing women's pay with men's tend to understate the disparity because they include union contracts, which mandate equal pay for women members. "If you take the 60 or 65 cents we earn to the man's dollar and take the union women out, then we would probably drop to 38 to 40 cents," she said. "I told the women who thought they were doing so well during the 80's that it looked good because of the Teamsters."
Arline Easley, an economist in the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor noted, however, that this comparison left higher-paid union members on the men's side of the equation. The trend for the last decade, she said, has been a closing gap between pay rates, although a difference certainly remains.
Women tend to spend less time on the job because of family obligations and have historically had less opportunity for on-the-job training and advanced education, she said. These factors have tended to hold down women's pay scales.
The unvarnished truth? Unlikely to surface, given the sensitivity of all pay issues. At Tellabs Inc. spokesman, asked about Grace Pastiak's situation, said she is paid the same as the men in like jobs. But he would not disclose her pay.

 
 
HOW WOMAN LEAD
 Excerpts from Judy Rosener's article "Ways Women Lead," printed in the December 1990 issue of the Harvard Business Review, and some of the responses it generated.
 
"I call their leadership style 'interactive leadership' because these women actively work to make their interactions with subordinates positive for everyone involved. More specifically, the women encourage participation, share power and information, enhance other people's self-worth and get others excited about their work."
 JUDY B. ROSENER, University of California, Irvine.
 
"Most people are oriented toward finding differences between men and women and tend to downplay the similarities they show. Judy Rosener falls into the same trap. ... Instead of observing men and women at work to ascertain whether they indeed act differently, she asked them to discribe their styles."
 CYNTHIA FUCHS EPSTEIN, City University of New York
 
"Our data also found women were somewhat more likely to be described as charismatic leaders, leaders with whom subordinates want to identify, leaders with whom they could form strong, emotional attachments."
 BERNARD BASS, State University of New York, Binghamton.
 
Judy Rosener's "findings show that top women succeed because they are women, not in spite of it."
 MONIQUE R. SIEGAL, Management Related Services, Zurich.
 
"I do agree that this participative style comes more naturally to women. But the Japanese, a very male-oriented culture, seem to have perfected the art of
participatory management.
 CAROL R. GOLDBERG, Avcar Group, Boston.
 
"I would like to remind the 'New Age' feminists that Athena, the Greek goddess of war, was just as much a woman as was Aphrodite, the Greek goddess of love."
 JEFFERY A. SONNENFELD, Emory Business School, Atlanta

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Making Money by Printing It

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
Perhaps it was an odd move for Martin Ferenczi to leave the button-down world of corporate banking to run a rough-and-tumble start-up in a business he barely knew. But as he begins his second year at the Banknote Corporation of America, a printer of currency and other high-security documents, he doesn't seem to be suffering from anything other than creative chaos.
Banknote is the offspring of two giants in the $200 million industry -- the United States Banknote Company and the American Banknote Company -- that established it last year when they sought approval to merge. 
 "The Justice Department said there must be a competitor and the competitor had to be credible," said Mr. Ferenczi.
The merged entity, the United States Banknote Company, enlisted a venerable Paris-based currency printer, Francois-Charles Oberthur, which had been looking for entree into the American market. Oberthur acquired assets of American Banknote. It also hired Mr. Ferenczi away from Chase Manhattan Bank, where he was a managing director.
In a year, says Mr. Ferenczi, Banknote has reached sales of about $10 million. Banknote's part of the pie includes visas, car titles, Federal food coupons and stock certificates.
Mr. Ferenczi, who is 36 years old, recognizes opportunities where some see only criminal behavior. Technical advances make it is easier to forge "unsecuritized" documents like gift certificates, for example.
The volatile state of the modern world is also good for currency printers. "Changes in regimes help; inflation helps," Mr. Ferenczi said.

HEADLINE: K Mart and Gauguin

BYLINE: By Kenneth Brower; Kenneth Brower's most recent book about Micronesia is "A Song for Satawal."

 BODY:

THE EDGE OF PARADISE
America in Micronesia.
By P. F. Kluge.
244 pp. New York:
Random House.
$21.95. 
 Micronesia is the littlest and least known of the -nesias. It is a smaller place than Polynesia, and though it has had its Captain Cooks, Fletcher Christians and Paul Gauguins, they seem scaled down somehow -- miniheroes who have failed to capture world attention. Micronesia has also had its Margaret Meads and Bronislaw Malinowskis, only more anonymous ones -- ethnographers who have failed to titillate quite as Melanesia's have.
The world is vaguely aware of Bikini Atoll in the Marshall Islands, which was ruined by H-bomb testing; of Truk, in the central Carolines, where a Japanese fleet lies sunk in the lagoon; of Tinian in the Marianas, from which the Enola Gay took off with the Hiroshima bomb; and of Peleliu, in the western Carolines, the site of one of the bloodiest and least necessary battles of the Pacific war. But that's about it. The oldest joke about the former United States Trust Territory is "Mike who?"
Micronesia's small islands and coral atolls are scattered over three million square miles of the western Pacific. Since their discovery by Magellan in 1521, the islands have been ruled in turn by the Spanish, Germans, Japanese and Americans. They are diverse, lovely, troubled places now trying to find their own way.
P. F. Kluge, the author of "Eddie and the Cruisers" and a former correspondent for The Wall Street Journal, was sent to the islands by the Peace Corps in 1967. He arrived during the American epoch, when Micronesia was called the United States Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands. He was what he calls a "high-caste" volunteer, his job not to build latrines but to edit a quarterly called The Micronesian Reporter. He traveled widely. He got the big picture.
One of Mr. Kluge's sidelines was writing speeches and manifestoes for island diplomats negotiating Micronesia's future. Among those diplomats was Lazarus Salii of the Palau archipelago. In 1985, Salii, years after Mr. Kluge's departure, became the second president of the new republic of Palau (one of the four entities that emerged from the old Trust Territory) and he was its second president to die by the gun. (The first one was murdered.) Troubled by Salii's death, apparently a suicide, Mr. Kluge traveled back to the islands in 1989. "The Edge of Paradise" is his account of that trip from the Marshall Islands in the east to Palau in the west, his hunt for clues about Salii's death and for clues about his own ambivalent love for the islands.
No one has better captured the face and the feel of Micronesia in transition. Describing an atoll in the Marshall Islands, Mr. Kluge writes, "The houses are few and far between, tin and wood shacks with carefully swept crushed coral yards, the day's laundry spread out, like a bright carpet, or hung on washlines, like paintings at an outdoor gallery. . . . Odd blend of K mart and Gauguin."
Mr. Kluge's details are sharp and so are his summary evaluations: "It isn't the beauty of Palau. There are lots of beautiful places, postcard pretty. It's not the friendliness of the people, that's for sure, because there are many people more hospitable than Palauans. Not the climate, hot and funky, not the food, not the culture. It's Palau's sense of itself, its pride, malice, opportunism, mystery."
The United States has been roundly criticized for neglecting the obligations of its trusteeship and not preparing the islands well for independence, but Mr. Kluge does not paint the Americans as villains and the islanders as victims. That is the easy path taken by most of the journalists and documentary film makers who spend two or three weeks in Micronesia before doing their exposes. Indeed, the view that the islanders have been helpless pawns of American strategic planners is more patronizing than any stance colonial bureaucrats ever took there. Reality is more complicated. And Mr. Kluge, in describing the present unhappy state of island society and economy -- its crumbling infrastructure and its crippling debt, for instance -- shows there is plenty of blame to go around.
I first came to Micronesia in 1971, four years after Mr. Kluge. And my experience there paralleled his in an eerie number of ways. I can vouch for everything he says about island heat, island sunsets, island women, island fever, the sweet-sad ambiance of ramshackle island capitals. I have had to deal, as he has, with the certainty of islanders that my note-taking was for the C.I.A., and then with the bafflement of editors over my obsession with these insignificant bits of real estate.
"The Edge of Paradise" is a stream of observation and recollection that is almost always acute, but I'm not sure Mr. Kluge has fashioned a suitable frame for it. His story line follows the search for clues about Lazarus Salii's life and death, but that often seems more a device than a genuine quest.
Mr. Kluge's Micronesia is a Micronesia of provincial capitals. His characters are the movers and shakers of the various archipelagoes. "The essence of Palau," he writes, is "beer, conspiracy, and cha-cha music." Certainly, the Palau of brown-skinned Machiavellis in white Gucci shoes is real. It is the arena in which Palauan history, such as it is, is being made. It is probably where a Micronesian reporter ought to be. And Mr. Kluge describes it better than anyone.
But there is another Palau where Mr. Kluge spends little time: an island of coral reefs, rain forests, small villages, outer islands, of wide, square-toed feet that have never known Guccis. Those bare feet have propelled divers down to some of the richest coral reefs in the world.
A persistent melancholy runs through this book, a you-can't-go-home-again theme. There might have been less of this had Mr. Kluge spent more time on the actual edges of paradise, in places where things change less -- out on the reef, with a polychromatic string of reef fish on his belt. If you linger in its towns, Micronesia can indeed be a depressing place. If you get away from them, Micronesia is still something like paradise.
"The Edge of Paradise" is a good book, true to its reality. Occasionally, though, I found myself wishing Mr. Kluge had written it 20 years ago, when his love for the islands was simpler.
Still, as a guide to the new Micronesia, Mr. Kluge is peerless. In a restaurant on Majuro Atoll he notes, for example, "that certain way waitresses have of not walking but slouch-sliding across the floor, arms swinging, thighs a-swish, but zori-clad feet never leaving the floor. Forward progress is barely measurable, ultimate arrival punctuated by a bored, sighing collapse into an empty chair, followed by a bemused scrutiny of the customer reading the menu. The steak? We don't have. Cheeseburg? We don't have."
This is not the sort of ballet that would drive most people to tears, but I almost cried when I read it. This young woman has waited on me on half a dozen archipelagoes. In her, I think, more than in Lazarus Salii, Mr. Kluge has found the real essence of his Micronesia.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

SECTION: Section 10; Page 5; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1196 words

HEADLINE: Focus: Northern Vermont;
A Big Drive to Bring Back Better Times

BYLINE: By KENT SHAW

DATELINE: NEWPORT, VT.

 BODY:
HARD times are no stranger to this city of 4,400 residents at the confluence of two major rail lines just south of the Canadian border.
City officials, however, hope to bring back the good times by attracting Canadian manufacturers and other commercial ventures through incentives and by developing the waterfront with business and commerce, entertainment and housing. 
 As late as the 1960's, passenger trains roared daily into Newport, which lies at the southern end of Lake Memphremagog. In those days, the pristine 30-mile-long glacial lake was crowded with fishermen taking advantage of legendary spawning runs of salmon and rainbow trout.
Only the occasional freight train arrives here now, and the lake's stock of fish is so depleted that even modest catches make the daily newspaper.
The dairy industry that was the basis of Newport's rural economy for as long as anyone can recall is gasping for breath, and milk prices have fallen below the cost of production. And the city's long-vibrant garment and logging industries are in decline, the former from foreign competition, the latter from the drop in housing construction.
To make matters worse, a snow drought has left nearby Jay Peak wanting for ski customers for the last several years.
Unemployment in Orleans County, with a population of 24,500, has soared past 14 percent -- to 14.4 near the end of last month -- by far the worst in Vermont.
 Most promising for turning matters around, city officials say, is bolstering longstanding ties with the neighboring province of Quebec, where interest in finding a gateway to United States markets is keener than ever. Many Canadian manufacturers have taken advantage of Newport's status as one of three job zones created in the mid-80's by the Vermont Legislature.
Codet Inc., a Quebec outdoor apparel maker, leased state-subsidized space to get a foothold south of the border. The company recently announced that it had outgrown its space and would buy a warehouse from the Slalom Corporation, a skiwear maker that went out of business in February.
Although the state has proposed cutting the job zone budget of $56,000 by as much as $40,000, local officials say the pursuit of Canadian business is going to remain a high priority in northern Vermont. The Greater Newport Area Chamber of Commerce has begun joint ventures with its Canadian counterparts, touting Newport's large population of French-speaking residents.
Development of the waterfront is another key, city officials say, although they admit that a difficult permit process, the clash of environmental and development interests and financing all present obstacles.
MOST recently, the city became one of eight finalists in a bid for state funds for a $187,000 bicycle and pedestrian pathway around the bay that would connect the waterfront, city parks and downtown. State officials are expected to announce the winner -- all eight projects involve bicycle or other alternative transportation projects -- before summer.
Jobs were foremost on the minds of the City Council when it announced support for a 150-bed correctional center in Newport, a state proposal that drew fierce opposition in at least two other towns. Planners say the $16.5 million center would generate about 125 jobs and bring more than $2 million a year into the area's economy.
A challenge by environmental groups was turned down by state environmental officials, who issued the final state permit in mid-April. The state has appropriated the funds and all that is needed for construction to start is an Army Corps of Engineers permit.
Mayor Douglas Spates, who operates a florer and landscaping business and whose rental apartments make him probably the city's biggest landlord, said the center would be a significant component of revival.
"We looked at it and saw 100 or 125 very stable jobs," he said.
 Along the waterfront, at least two large development projects are on hold under circumstances that illustrate some of the problems of Newport's economy. Although they have all the necessary permits, developers of both properties, citing financial uncertainty, have backed off for now.
One of the developers, Chet Greenwood, president of the local Prouty and Miller lumberyard, says he hopes to find a buyer for his 7,000-square-foot Landing Restaurant and an expansive development plan that goes with it. Mr. Greenwood had planned a 74-room hotel atop the restaurant and 44 condominium units next door. The project, which he estimates would cost $4.5 million, would offer the only overnight accommodations other than private cottages for visitors to the 30-mile-long lake.
Each of the condominium apartments, whose size and layout are undecided, would be offered at $125,000 and would come with a reserved boat slip. An additional 64 slips would be available to the public on a first come first served basis.
Mr. Greenwood spent $60,000 on planning and permits, but the project is in limbo because of doubts about financing.
Another potential obstacle to the project is Vermont's public trust doctrine, under which all bodies of water must be open to the public and which could make any private use of public waters subject to challenge. Last year, the Chittenden County Superior Court invoked the doctrine in striking down a marina project on Lake Champlain, although it involved only private slips.
IN 1989, the state's Supreme Court ruled that only the Legislature had the power to define public trust. Despite wrangling over how it should be construed, no clear picture has emerged from the Statehouse, except for one special-interest law approving a large waterfront project in Burlington involving commercial construction and a park.
Mr. Greenwood said a development like the one he planned could benefit the local economy by attracting, not only as tourists but also as potential investors, the many Canadians who visit each summer in expensive yachts.
"But I don't know how long I can just sit on a piece of property like this," he said. "That's why I've put it on the market."
He is asking $1.2 million for the 300-seat restaurant, seven acres of waterfront property, all necessary permits and the architectural plans.
The other developer, John W. Stevens, a realtor and a member of the City Planning Commission, is also concerned about running afoul of the public-trust doctrine if he goes ahead with plans for a $600,000 restaurant-marina across the broad bay from Mr. Greenwood's land. He also has all needed permits.
Rather than build permanent docking space, Mr. Stevens has proposed installing floating moorings and ferrying visitors ashore by dinghy. He said he would go ahead if he can get financing.
"Actually, all that's holding it up now is money," Mr. Stevens said. "The banks are all in an upheaval."
His restaurant would be the third on the lake. Besides the Landing, there is a McDonald's in Magog, on the northern tip of the lake, 15 miles into Quebec.
Mayor Spates says he is intent on energizing a city government that he feels has been complacent about trying to shape the city's future. "We've been asleep at the wheel for a long time," he said.

PERSON: SHAW, KENT

HEADLINE: FOCUS;

HEADLINE: Women in Business Expand a Network

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: TARRYTOWN

 BODY:
HAVING "a business of one's own" has become a reality for increasing numbers of women, as was clear from the record turnout at this year's Showcasing Expo sponsored by the Westchester Association of Women Business Owners.
The seventh annual Expo, held late last month at the Marriott here, provided a marketing and professional networking opportunity for the 250 association members as well as 195 nonmember business people from New York, Connecticut and New Jersey. 
 This year, 94 companies in 75 business categories showed their products and services. The diversity encompassed everything from A. R. Budget Pest Control in Yonkers, owned by M. Darroux Palmoze, to Lois B. Cook, a high-tech Henry Higgins in White Plains who helps foreign-born executives lose their accents.
The recession, with its layoffs, has forced more women to become entrepreneurs, said Myra Packman, a lawyer and the association's president. "Others," she said, "are motivated by a desire for the independence that comes from being your own boss."
 
Founded 12 Years Ago
 The association was founded 12 years ago by a dozen female business owners, and it has grown steadily, Ms. Packman said. Members find that by banding together, she said, they can more readily obtain insurance, credit and financing for their businesses.
"As a trade association, we have more clout than any of us has individually," said Peggy Tomarkin Greenawalt, the association's president-elect. Ms. Greenawalt, who started her marketing-communications company, Tomarkin/ Greenawalt, five years ago after two decades in advertising, said hers was the "story of our times."
"After the agency I was working for was merged into a larger one," she said, "I was literally propelled into starting my own business. After I left the agency, several former clients called me at home and offered me various assignments. Eventually, I had enough business to warrant opening an office in Hartsdale, and then another one in Manhattan."
Ms. Greenawalt, who displayed some of her agency's work at the show, continued: "Unlike other professional organizations I belong to, we're not in hot competition with one another. There is so much diversity in our businesses that we're able to buy goods and services from one another."
 Six years ago, Ms. Cook saw an opportunity in the influx of international business people in Westchester. She left her job as a speech pathologist in the public schools and started her own business, Speech and Communications Professionals. While executives with accents are her speciality, she serves a diverse clientele whose ages range from 1 to 91.
"I stuttered as a child, which is why I got into speech pathology as an adult," Ms. Cook said. "I know firsthand how confidence can be gained when you get rid of speech problems."
At the Expo, viewers were intrigued by the black box Ms. Cook uses to track voice pitch on the screen, much like an EKG shows heartbeat patterns. After Ms. Cook described her program to eliminate foreign accents, she was asked if she could get rid of a New York accent.
"Many people, not just New Yorkers, want to lose their regional accents," Ms. Cook said. "Besides accent reduction, we also use other techniques to combat mumbling, nasal tones and sloppy speech."
 
Competence and Control
 Good speech, she added, suggests competence and control, "which is very important in today's competitive marketplace."
Ms. Cook said her membership in the association had been helpful in allowing her to develop her own business skills. "A lot of valuable information, hands-on information, is available to us in meetings and seminars," she said. "Listening to the experts talk about such things as how to develop a market plan and how to publicize your company has helped me."
Seasoned business owners, Ms. Packman said, take fledgling entrepreneurs under their wing.
"We have the kind of support group I haven't found in any other professional organizations I belong to," she said. "Our members are generous in giving their time and sharing their knowledge."
Erika Krieger, a new member, has an architectural practice in Dobbs Ferry. Her display at the Expo featured many of her blueprints. "I've made good contacts," she said. "In my profession, I've found that advertising is not enough. The Expo gave me a chance to get my name in front of a lot of people and helped me get my foot in the door of a couple of prospective clients."
Ms. Palmoze, a former nurse from the Sudan who is now a United States citizen, started A. R. Budget Pest Control in Yonkers a year ago with a partner.
 
'I Like the Work'
 "We began with a small apartment complex and moved into institutional and commercial buildings," she said. "Many of our clients are in the fast-food business. I like the work. I think of it as sanitation.
"I've met other women in business through the association. I find it very useful since most members give generous discounts to other members, which includes things that I need, such as accounting and legal services."
Dr. Ellen Cohen Lewis and Dr. Donna -DeRosa are chiropractors. Dr. Lewis is a partner in the Family Chiropractic Office in Larchmont. Dr. DeRosa practices in Yonkers. Although they are in the same profession, each said she did not feel threatened by the other's membership in the group.
"We know there is room for both of us," Dr. Cohen said. "The competition here isn't the same as you'd find at a meeting of chiropractors. I have several patients who came to me through my membership" in the association.
"I've found the Expo is a good place to talk to people," Dr. DeRosa said. "Many people who came to my booth were surprised to find that there are women chiropractors. As a matter of fact, the numbers of women in the profession are growing."
Andrea Lublinski runs a video company, which produces advertising programs that air weekly on local cable channels. Her real estate series, "House Hunters," shows interiors and exteriors of houses on the market. Mrs. Lublinski said she made it a practice to buy the goods and services she needs in her business from other association members.
 
195 Nonmember Exhibitors
 "We help each other," she said. "We support each other. That's what we're all about."
Anne Cahalane of the Marine Midland Bank in New Rochelle had a display table at the Expo to market the bank's services.
"Every business needs a bank," she said. "The Expo is a good place for us to pick up customers for our special services geared for small businesses. Business owners who work alone, for instance, don't have to come in to the bank. We'll send someone out to them."
Sharlet Brennan, who heads her own public relations agency in Katonah said that the 195 nonmember visitors to the Expo were "a strong indication that the goods and services our members have are valued by the business community at large."
In past Expos most of the activity was generated by members selling to one another, Ms. Brennan said. "That's still an important part of the Expo," she said. "But this year, we also had several exhibitors who weren't members, including some men who were eager to reach our markets."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Among exhibitors at the Showcasing Expo were Lois B. Cook, top, a language consultant who helps foreign executives lose their accents, and Erika Krieger, an architect; The exhibition floor at the show sponsored by the Westchester Association of Women Business Owners.
(Photographs by Jim Estrin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Eight Years of Living Languorously

BYLINE: By Herbert S. Parmet; Herbert S. Parmet's most recent book is "Richard Nixon and His America." He is Distinguished Professor of History at the City University of New York.

 BODY:

PRESIDENT REAGAN
The Role of a Lifetime.
By Lou Cannon.
Illustrated. 948 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $24.95. 
 Lou Cannon's latest portrait of Ronald Reagan, his third, is the best study of that enigmatic Presidency yet available. The tone is judicious, the hyperbole limited and the coverage compre hensive.
In "President Reagan: The Role of a Lifetime," Mr. Cannon of The Washington Post -- one of the few reporters who have covered Mr. Reagan's entire political career from the Governor's house in Sacramento to Washington -- describes a mostly stage-managed Administration. Ronald Reagan, as virtually every report illustrates, was the most inattentive and indifferent of Presidents, largely following the "scripts" that led him through his eight years in the White House. Ultimately, however, his greatest strength was his ability to sell, to utilize his considerable gifts for mass leadership. Less an ideologue than an idealist, even a dreamer, Mr. Reagan believed "that he was not really a politician at all," Mr. Cannon says, "but simply an actor on loan from Hollywood who had entered politics because he wanted to restrain the power of an increasingly intrusive government." He acted upon inspiration and inspired in return.
Handlers usually protected Mr. Reagan from himself and from the press. Their man was at once intellectually lazy and intuitively shrewd. The scripts were followed as long as they were convenient as he went through "the role of a lifetime." Mr. Reagan, Mr. Cannon writes, "may have been the one president in the history of the republic who saw his election as a chance to get some rest."
Mr. Cannon depicts Mr. Reagan's fantasy world, one that "had been created in Hollywood, out of material he brought with him from the Middle West." His unshakable optimism forever seemed to deny the realities of a boyhood blighted by his alcoholic and frequently unemployed father. He was also a self-serving visionary with faith in a mythic America, one who, at the end, "succeeded in reviving national confidence at a time when there was a great need for inspiration."
Above all, Ronald Reagan was also a natural politician. Virtually every new account demonstrates that the stage and not the Statehouse or Capitol Hill may be the most effective launching pad for power in a picture culture. The Iran-contra travesty was a perfect example of how a politically astute actor finessed what Mr. Cannon does not doubt was his personal involvement. A President with poorer survival talents could well have been impeached.
Foreign leaders, even his ideological kin, were astounded, as Mr. Cannon puts it, by "how a man of his background could become president of the world's most powerful democracy." Whatever it was, they wanted to touch it, "bottle it and take it home and use it themselves." To Mr. Reagan himself, neither that nor much else seemed mysterious. As Mr. Cannon stresses at every chance, he believed in what he wanted to believe. "There's nothing wrong with that," the President said to a columnist at a dinner party. "I do it all the time." Following White House disasters dating back some two decades, Mr. Reagan, ironically, revitalized faith in Government itself. The office, he demonstrated, could function after all. Under him, the "impossible Presidency" seemed easy. He set the pace and the national agenda.
He made the American left appear hapless. He gave power and respectability to the modern conservative movement, which had been smoldering ever since the early post-World War II years. It was Mr. Reagan and not his staff, albeit he was the most managed President in history, who, according to Mr. Cannon, "established the priorities for the major accomplishments and debacles of his presidency."
The President who had called the Soviet Union an "evil empire" finally supped with the villains themselves. The unrelenting Cold Warrior, the alleged anti-Soviet ideologue, dipped pens with Mikhail Gorbachev. Rapprochement with the "evil empire," writes Mr. Cannon, may have been Mr. Reagan's major achievement. "But," Mr. Cannon later adds, "his greatest service was in restoring the respect of Americans for themselves and their own government after the traumas of Vietnam and Watergate, the frustration of the Iran hostage crisis and a succession of seemingly failed presidencies."
Mr. Cannon's portrait is paradoxical. Not for a long time, perhaps never, will the contradictions be fully understood. Ronald Reagan's characteristic detachment frustrated those who tried to gain his attention and verged on a dereliction of duty. On the day of the 1983 economic summit, James A. Baker 3d, then chief of staff, realized Mr. Reagan had not read his briefing book. When Mr. Baker asked why, Mr. Reagan responded, "Well, Jim, The Sound of Music was on last night."
He nevertheless took what happened at Chernobyl as a warning about the potential of nuclear disaster, and responded. Not once, when implementing his Reaganomics, did he consider the obvious inability of the "rising tide" to "lift all the boats." He remained the idealistic nationalist, and that was where he functioned best. Mr. Cannon covers all this and much more. His Gipper often seems like Knute Rockne himself.

HEADLINE: When Michael Met Mickey

BYLINE: By Joseph Nocera ;Joseph Nocera is the business columnist for GQ magazine.

 BODY:

THE DISNEY TOUCH
How a Daring Management Team
Revived an Entertainment Empire.
By Ron Grover.
Illustrated. 315 pp. Homewood, Ill.:
Business One Irwin. $22.95.  
 I took my 7-year-old daughter to Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla., last fall. We were among the millions who help make the Walt Disney Company's huge theme park the most popular tourist attraction in the world. For three days, in addition to visiting the various Disney attractions, we lived in a Disney hotel, ate in Disney restaurants and shopped in Disney stores, often using Disney scrip. When my daughter wanted to spend a day at the nearby Universal Studios theme park, I persuaded her that the Disney/M-G-M park would be just as much fun (Disney's practice of selling multiple-day tickets gave me compelling reason to do so).
We both came away dazzled by the experience, though for different reasons. Like children the world over, my daughter found Disney World thoroughly enchanting. I, on the other hand, found myself admiring what Ron Grover calls "The Disney Touch." To spend time, as an adult, at a Disney theme park is to be impressed by the company's extraordinary marketing abilities, its obsessiveness about getting the little details right, its shrewd talents as a land developer. Even when you know you are being manipulated -- when you realize that every time you exchange a real dollar for a Disney dollar you are giving the company a short-term, non-interest-bearing loan -- it's hard not to stand in awe of the Disney operation.
It was not always thus, as Mr. Grover points out early and often in this straightforward account of the modern Disney juggernaut. In 1984, 18 years after the death of Walt Disney, the company was in obvious decline, its theme parks lackluster, its movie division bereft of ideas, its profits dwindling. Corporate raiders were swarming. To ward off the raiders, the company hired the president of Paramount Pictures, Michael Eisner, to run Disney. This book is, essentially, a paean to the business skills of Mr. Eisner, whom Mr. Grover calls "one of America's most creative executives."
Mr. Grover is the Los Angeles bureau chief of Business Week, and his brief on behalf of Mr. Eisner and "Team Disney," as he calls the people Mr. Eisner brought in to effect the turnaround, is persuasive. They revived the fortunes not just of the company's theme parks and movies, but also of its television arm, its once-fabled animation division, its home video unit and on and on.
In Mr. Grover's view, Team Disney succeeded largely by being smart, hardheaded businessmen. They understood that "Walt's classic characters -- Mickey, Minnie, Donald, Pluto, Goofy -- [were] the asset base on which the company prospered," and they knew how to exploit those assets commercially. They had a flair for marketing. They cut the toughest deals in Hollywood; Mr. Grover recounts the oft-told story of how Disney, with such films as "Down and Out in Beverly Hills," revived the careers of fading movie stars like Richard Dreyfuss and Bette Midler, whom it preferred to bigger-name stars because they would work cheap. Indeed, if the author has one criticism of Team Disney, it is that the group's hardheadedness can veer toward ruthlessness. In a recent incident, for instance, Peggy Lee, the singer who co-wrote the songs and provided the voices for four of the characters in the 1955 Disney animated film "Lady and the Tramp," won a $2.3 million judgment against the company because it refused to negotiate with her when the movie was released on videocasette. As Mr. Grover dryly points out, no division at Disney has flourished more during the Eisner revival than the litigation department.
Still, as impressive as this tale is, one comes away from "The Disney Touch" feeling that the author has told only half the story. My own sense of Mr. Eisner is that for all his concentration on the bottom line, he has always had a feel for what made the Walt Disney Company so magical. Mickey and Minnie Mouse are economic assets, without question. But to stop there, as Mr. Grover does, is to diminish them. They are also wonderful characters who, for over 50 years, have managed to capture the imagination of successive generations of children. That, ultimately, is what Mr. Eisner understands. Is it any accident that under his direction the company has created its first memorable cartoon characters since Walt Disney died -- the characters who populate the 1989 hit film "The Little Mermaid"? I don't think it is, though you wouldn't know it from reading "The Disney Touch." Practically the only thing Mr. Grover tells us about this movie is how much money it grossed.
Of course, it did gross $84 million.

HEADLINE: Japan Shouldn't Cut Off North Korean Trade

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a doctoral candidate writing a dissertation on Japanese-Korean relations, I was not wholly satisfied with "The Next Renegade State," Leslie H. Gelb's April 10 column on North Korea.
I agree that North Korea and its not-yet-inspected nuclear facilities at Yongbyon present a potentially destabilizing threat to the region and that Tokyo should make International Atomic Energy Agency inspection of North Korean nuclear facilities and the end of North Korean arms sales a condition for normalization of relations and Japanese economic aid. 
 Mr. Gelb also argues that in the meantime, Tokyo should cut off all trade with Pyongyang. I fail to see what this would achieve.
The global collapse of Communism, coupled with the success of South Korea's policy toward Moscow and Beijing, has placed Kim Il Sung's regime in its greatest diplomatic isolation. And an all but collapsed economy, combined with an imminent power transition after Mr. Kim's death, make North Korea a potential powder keg. Thus, it hardly seems wise to call on Tokyo to take an intransigent attitude in talks with Pyongyang. A Japanese trade embargo on North Korea would further isolate a desperate and aging dictator.
Such isolation might lend credence to Pyongyang's hard-liners, who are waiting to overthrow Mr. Kim's less-than-competent son once he inherits power. This would destroy any chances that the country's younger generation of more rational and pragmatic technocrats would have at reviving North Korea's economy with Western credits and aid.
Japanese sources do not see a normalization settlement for at least five years. United States intelligence analysts predict that North Korea will be able to produce a nuclear explosion within that same period. The most plausible way of getting Pyongyang to sign a full-scope nuclear safeguards agreement is for Tokyo to continue whetting North Korea's appetite for normalization with Japanese trade.
 
VICTOR D. CHA
New York, April 15, 1991
 
The writer, a doctoral candidate in political science at Columbia University, is scheduled to go to South Korea as a Fulbright scholar in the fall.

HEADLINE: Decline in Taxi Ridership Has to Do With Decline in Cabbies

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The recession is not the only reason for decline in taxi ridership (news article, April 25). During a lifetime in New York City, I have never seen cab drivers so ill suited to their work.
The archetype for generations of cabbies was a streetwise, schmoozy native who got you there quickly and threw in colorful chat. They had no fear of driving to the Bronx or Brooklyn and didn't need directions.
 The drivers we hail today have trouble communicating or are stone silent. In a cab I hailed recently, two men sat in the front seat. When I got in, the man next to the driver explained he was the translator. The driver spoke no English.
Add to that getting a driver in Manhattan to go to Brooklyn and other boroughs. I started writing down drivers' names and filing complaints at the Taxi and Limousine Commission. I won my cases. The drivers had to pay $150 fines, and the offenses went on their records.
Anyone traveling outside Manhattan should be prepared to copy name and hack-license number of a driver who refuses to take you. Once you've got the driver's license number, you'll be surprised how cooperative he gets. A licensed driver is required to take you anywhere in the five boroughs.
 
ANDREW MC CARTHY
Brooklyn, April 25, 1991

HEADLINE: Several Issues in This Week's U.S. Sales

 BODY:
The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for this week includes bills, notes and bonds, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills totaling $17.2 billion.
For the remainder of the week the market will be preoccupied with the Treasury's quarterly refunding, a record $37 billion. 
 Tomorrow, the Government will auction a three-year note, followed on Wednesday by a 10-year note auction and on Thursday by an auction of new 30-year bonds, the market's bellwether issue.
By late in the day Friday the outstanding three-month bill was bid at 5.47 percent and the six-month bill was bid at 5.57 percent. In when-issued trading the three-year note was offered at a price to yield 7.12 percent and the 10-year note to yield 8.02 percent. For the long bond, the when-issued yield was 8.21 percent.
Government agency financings expected this week include a $650 million issue of Student Loan Marketing Association floating-rate notes, due Nov. 14, with pricing today.
The Federal National Mortgage Association will be announcing tomorrow the interest rate for its $900 million offering of debentures due May 11, 1998.
The following fixed-income issues are scheduled this week:

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
British Publisher Enters the U.S., Forgoing Its Past Noms de Plume

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
After more than 15 years of conceiving, editing and producing books for Alfred A. Knopf, Random House, Little, Brown and other publishers, Dorling Kindersley Ltd. of London has decided to publish books under its own name in the United States.
Backed by an investment of about $500,000 and an eight-person office in Manhattan, the American arm of Dorling Kindersley plans to publish 22 books this fall and another 35 to 40 next spring. 
 In the fall of 1992, it expects to publish 70 titles and it is aiming for sales of $25 million within three years. In keeping with Dorling Kindersley tradition, all the books will be nonfiction, most will be reference works and all will be heavily illustrated.
 
'Absolutely Unique' Product
 If those aims sound unrealistic, given the depressed state of publishing, there are few doubters among rival publishers. And some publishers think Dorling Kindersley, with its emphasis on illustrated reference books, cannot miss. "Their product is absolutely unique in the marketplace," said Joseph A. Kanon, the head of the Houghton Mifflin Company's trade and reference division.
Despite an informal policy of not distributing books of other publishers, Houghton Mifflin recently agreed to take on those of Dorling Kindersley, largely because of Houghton Mifflin's success in publishing under its imprint books produced by the British house. These include "The Way Things Work" by David Macaulay, which has sold more than a million copies worldwide.
In fact, the 300 or more titles that Dorling Kindersley has produced for publishers in about 20 countries have sold more than 80 million copies -- and no title, its executives contend, has sold fewer than 100,000. As a result, revenues for the fiscal year ending June 30 are projected at $70 million. And its future revenues could grow sharply if the company prospers in the American market.
In relative terms, at least, Dorling Kindersley already prospers in the United States, where it derives 28 percent of its sales. But having successfully evolved in Britain from packager (or book producer) to publisher, it wants to do the same thing here.
 
'Next Stage in Our Growth'
 "We take a global view of publishing, and we view the American market as the next stage in our growth," said Peter Kindersley, the chairman, who co-founded the company in 1974 to produce books for other publishers.
Christopher Davis, the deputy chairman, added: "This is not a matter of vanity. It's a move that's market-driven."
Dorling Kindersley's reasons for wanting to publish here, instead of continuing merely to produce books for others, is not hard to understand: A publisher stands to make more money -- often several times more -- than the packager. That's because a publisher derives the revenue from the sale of the book (minus author's royalty, production costs, overhead, etc.), while packagers usually earn what is essentially a royalty on each sale. On a big-selling book, the difference can be substantial.
Publishers buy books from packagers for a variety of reasons, including to help fill their lists or to enable them to publish in areas in which their own editors lack interest or experience. They also buy very expensive illustrated books from packagers, who are able to keep retail prices from soaring by selling them to publishers in many countries. While packagers sometimes pay royalties to their authors, most packaged books are produced by their salaried staffs or by authors who are are paid a flat fee.
Dorling Kindersley Inc., the American company, will preview its fall list of 7 adult and 15 children titles at the convention of the American Booksellers Association, beginning June 1.
Steven Sussman, who heads the American company, can hardly wait. 'We'll have our first books out in September," he said, "and we'll begin seeing revenue by December. We want to be the pre-eminent publisher of reference books."
Two months ago, the Microsoft Corporation bought a 26 percent stake in Dorling Kindersley for an undisclosed price, giving the company the right to create software from existing Dorling Kindersley books.
 
Valuable Arrangement
 Starting from scratch, many publishers would be at a disadvantage, at least with booksellers, who are more likely to buy books from publishers they know than from those they do not. That is why Dorling Kindersley's distribution arrangement with Houghton Mifflin is valuable for the new American house -- and potentially valuable for Houghton Mifflin, because distributors typically receive a percentage of each book sold.
Also valuable is Dorling Kindersley's record of producing best sellers. These include "The American Medical Association Family Medical Guide," published by Random House, with worldwide sales exceeding five million; "The Good Housekeeping Illustrated Cookbook," published by William Morrow, with more than 2.8 million copies sold; a series of gift books published by Bantam Books, with more than 1.2 million copies sold, and the Eyewitness Books series for children, published by Knopf, with more than 7.5 million copies sold.
 
Investment inReference Books
 Mr. Kindersley explains his company's success by saying that no other publisher will invest so heavily in reference books. "And if they are prepared," he said, "they have no worldwide system for selling them."
That may be an exaggeration, but only a slight one. As for why the large publishers allowed Dorling Kindersley to fill that niche practically uncontested, Mr. Kanon of Houghton Mifflin explained: "For economic reasons, they have had to think globally in a way American publishers did not, until now. In order to make these books work over the years, they had to publish worldwide."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Christopher Davis, left, the deputy chairman of Dorling Kindersley, and Peter Kindersley, the company's chairman and co-founder, see the American publishing market "as the next stage in our growth." (Jonathan Player for The New Yokrk Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Auctions Expected to Draw Buyers

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
The credit markets face a record volume of Treasury debt issues at the quarterly refunding auctions this week, but analysts expect the sales to attract buyers because of the recent rise in yields.
The markets ended last week in confusion, amid conflicting readings of the Government's economic data for April. After several important interest rates were lowered by the Federal Reserve and big commercial banks, the Government on Friday issued contradictory data on employment trends last month. 
 The Labor Department's survey of American households showed a sharp rise of 644,000 non-farm jobs. The increase was the first reported since May 1990. But in the same report, a survey of businesses showed the number of non-farm jobs fell 124,000 in April.
 
Revision of Data Expected
 "Although the confusion that swept the bond market Friday was understandable, it should have been obvious that something was wrong with the April employment data," Jeremy J. Siegel, a professor of finance at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, said in an interview during the weekend. "The jobs data have rarely been so contradictory, and we are sure the numbers will be revised in the next report."
But Professor Siegel also saw a positive side in the drop of Treasury securities prices on Friday. "The sharp price declines that raised the yields on Treasury notes and bonds on Friday should help the market absorb the record refunding," he said. "In fact, we think the auctions will attract many foreign buyers, as well as the dealers who wound up absorbing much of the Treasury paper at great cost after the last refunding in February. At the moment, the yields are quite attractive relative to other investments."
 
Confusion Reigns
 Yields tumbled last Tuesday when the Fed cut its discount rate for member banks to 5.5 percent, from 6 percent. More important, it caused the Federal funds rate -- which banks charge each other for temporary loans -- to fall to 5.75 percent, from 6 percent. The next day, commercial banks began cutting their prime lending rate to 8.5 percent, from 9 percent. But confusion over the unemployment data caused rates to bounce back. By late Friday, the Treasury's 30-year bonds closed with a yield of 8.22 percent, up from 8.20 a week earlier, thus eliminating the large gains made earlier in the week when interest rates were falling.
The $37 billion refunding will begin tomorrow when the Treasury auctions $13.5 billion of three-year notes. Based on when-issued trading late Friday, this normally popular maturity is expected to yield 7.12 perent. On Wednesday, $11.75 billion of 10-year notes go on sale; these yielded 8.02 percent at the end of last week, The auctions will end on Thursday with the sale of $11.75 billion of 30-year bonds, which traded on a when-issued basis to yield 8.21 percent.
 
Positive Yield Curve
 Norman Robertson, senior vice president and chief economist of the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, also expects the auctions to go well, largely because of the uncommonly positive yield curve between the 30-year bonds and the discount rate on 90-day bills, which was 5.47 percent late Friday.
Another reason for his optimism, he said in a telephone interview, was that "these yields may not last long and the market knows this because there are ample signs that the recession is bottoming out." Mr. Robertson added that this view was not based on the "strange employment statistics," which he considered an aberration.
But the flood of corporate debt issues that has inundated the market could slow the decline in interest rates, Mr. Robertson said. Most top corporate borrowers price their debt offerings off comparable Treasury maturities, and as yields on Treasury bonds fell early last week many companies seized the occasion to sell debt issues.
 
Close to a Record Volume
 Statisticians at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei said $5.9 billion of corporate debt came to market last week, which they said could be close to a record volume for a week.
Far less optimistic about an economic revival is S. Jay Levy, chairman of the Jerome Levy Economics Institute of Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y. "Because private fixed investments, which are the major source of profits and economic growth, will remain depressed well beyond 1991, the economic recovery will be largely invisible for quite a long time," Mr. Levy said.
He cited several reasons for his pessimism. For one, "the economy is still overleveraged, overpriced, redundant in fixed assets and the market value of its services," he said.
 
Intensified Problems Seen
 He added that he also expected financial problems to intensify as corporate and private debtors depleted their cash and faced defaults. Another problem is that it may take years before the battered commercial banks are able to relax their tight lending policies.
Economic recovery will also be retarded by continued Government deficits that force it to compete with the private sector for available credit, Mr. Levy said. The current practice of state and local governments of raising taxes or reducing services will also stall a recovery, he added.
Mr. Levy said that "the revival in residential real estate is over-ballyhooed and won't soon stop the decline in housing construction outlays."
"Although consumer confidence soared after the Persian Gulf war," he added, "consumer spending, the major engine in any economic recovery, shows no vigor to jump-start the recovery."

HEADLINE: Economic Memo;
Consumers Are Willing but Weak

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
With surveys showing a sharp rebound in consumer confidence after the Persian Gulf war, one might assume that it would not be long before the economy itself started to pull out of recession. The nation's households, after all, account for two-thirds of economic activity -- half of this at retail counters and half in paying for things like sailing lessons, subway tokens, boarding-school tuition and the monthly mortgage.
But the improvement in consumer psychology, now ebbing a bit, is not quickly translating into a spending surge, for reasons ranging from debt to demography. 
 An obviously concerned Federal Reserve moved last Tuesday to spur the economy by making another round of cuts in interest rates.
 
The Only Resort
 Right now, the consumer sector "is the only place that you could get a significant demand gain that could pull the economy out of decline," said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Dean Witter Reynolds.
One reason consumers loom so large is that they are responsible for a bigger-than-usual share of the contraction in the current recession. Another is that there does not seem much likelihood of getting such a boost elsewhere, either from spending by government or from the stimulus of business investment or exports, both of which show signs of faltering.
The main problem seems to be that the consumer, like the nation President Bush described at his inauguration, may well have more will than wallet.
There are various possible explanations for this situation, some of them at variance with what consumers sometimes tell pollsters, some not seeming to square with one or another set of figures.
One prominent theory, ostensibly supported by daily headlines as well as anecdotal evidence, is that American society, from the Federal Government to the ordinary worker, is overwhelmed with debt. Companies default on bonds, individuals in record numbers resort to bankruptcy, and ever-fewer states command triple-A credit ratings.
But experts disagree sharply about indebtedness. Should it be measured against assets that have also increased -- assuming that debtors have, say, healthy stock portfolios -- or against income that would normally be called upon to service it?
Relatedly, some maintain that consumers are reeling from declines in the value of homes or other real estate, an almost unheard-of situation for decades and a psychological depressant on top of a financial one.
Yet if people were really worried about excessive debt and deflation of assets, economic theory suggests they would be raising their savings and paying off some loans. But the meager personal savings rate in this country, 4.1 percent for the first quarter of 1991, is half a point lower than in 1989 and 1990. Is the consumer simply unable to save?
 
Shrunken Incomes
 Another explanation for at least part of the reduced consumer spending is that the baby-boom generation has entered middle age and, with houses furnished and college expenses looming, is realizing that the time has come to cut out the $100 designer jeans and other extravagances. Perhaps this shift will show up before long in higher savings rates.
But the dominant view is that the consumer is mainly restrained not by debt or demographics but by shrunken income -- a painful inability, after inflation and taxes, to make ends meet.
"At work has been a classic compression of household purchasing power," asserted Stephen S. Roach, a top economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. He finds an exceptionally tight link between income and spending in recent years, the two falling since the third quarter of 1989 at "virtually identical" rates of five-tenths of 1 percent and seven-tenths of 1 percent, respectively.
Last summer, real disposable personal income turned negative and then accelerated during the autumn quarter to a 3.5 percent rate of decline. Last month, the Government reported some moderation in the slide, to a rate of 1.6 percent.
 
Taxes Rise; Inflation Worsens
 Susan M. Sterne, president of Economic Analysis Associates in Stowe, Vt., called these figures dismal. She noted that recessions typically bring tax cuts but that this time taxes, mainly excise taxes, have been raised. Inflation, meanwhile, has worsened instead of eased as measured by the three-month core rate that leaves out energy and food.
Policy makers expected a brisk rebound after the gulf war, "and we are not getting it," Ms. Sterne said, adding, "The consumer's income has just eroded too far."
Incomes, of course, depend largely on employment, and the number of people without jobs is 1.4 million above what it was last July, when the recession officially began. Thus, aggregate as well as individual buying power has been cut. And while lower interest rates act as a general spur to the economy, rate cuts tend to shrink the investment incomes of retired people and others with savings.
 
A Chicken-and-Egg Issue
 Indeed, incomes are both causes and effects in the economic firmament, and whether they rebound or not depends on a complex interplay of the forces of demand, production and employment.
Henry Ford, for one, discovered that by raising his workers' pay to the then unheard-of level of $5 a day in 1914, he was enabling them to buy his company's cars, fresh stimulus for the circle of business activity.
So whether or when the consumer obtains the means -- as opposed to the desire -- to help lift the economy out of recession is sort of a chicken-and-egg issue, Mr. Rippe said, one not lending itself to precise analysis. An end to job shrinkage, however, would be a good beginning.
 
'A Relatively Subdued Rebound'
 Mr. Roach finds a resumption of income growth already "in the cards," aided by the reversal of war-related jumps in oil prices that should increase disposable income by about half a percent over the coming year. He said business inventories have now been "decisively" liquidated, so that even a small pickup in demand would lift production and extend working hours.
But he, along with Ms. Sterne and others, fret about the apparently permanent loss of service jobs in recent years, many of them high paying.
"Tempering the income rebound," Mr. Roach said, "will be a slowdown of white-collar hiring in the 1990's -- a by-product of a dramatic restructuring of America's service sector that is already having an impact on banks, securities firms, insurance, telecommunications, airlines, retail trade, accounting and advertising. The net result is a relatively subdued rebound of income, limiting consumption gains to 2.8 percent from mid-1991 to mid-1992, well below the nearly 5 percent rebounds of the past recoveries."
