HEADLINE: White House in Shift on Job Relief

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
The White House, in offering enticements to win approval for trade legislation it sorely wants, has abandoned a position that has been held dear by the Bush Administration -- and earlier by the Reagan Administration. It has also revived a debate over whether the Government should give special help to workers who lose their jobs because of competition from imports.
To win labor backing for trade expansion in the 1960's, the Kennedy Administration came up with a plan to provide payments and retraining benefits to workers hurt by imports. In recent years, the Reagan and Bush Administrations have tried to kill the program. 
 But to court support for the authority to negotiate a Mexican trade pact, President Bush has agreed to consider benefits specifically related to labor problems that are likely to arise from trade expansion with Mexico. Through its about-face, the Administration hopes to undermine a powerful coalition of labor, textile, environmental and other interests, all of whom fear that an agreement with Mexico will cost jobs and hurt the environment because of looser Mexican standards.
 
Evolved Over 3 Decades
 In a letter to Congress last Wednesday, Mr. Bush agreed, among other things, to consider "adequate assistance and effective retraining for dislocated workers."
The pledge means the Administration will work with Congress to shape a new or improved package of worker services. It represents a shift in the longstanding position of both the Reagan and Bush Administrations that special import adjustment programs are unnecessary.
Such assistance has evolved through several pieces of legislation over three decades. But some members of Congress and union officials say current assistance is not adequate to deal with the possible employment shocks that could result from a Mexican accord.
The Administration has different expectations. Instead of shocks, it sees a net gain in the employment rolls, reflecting trade and economic growth spurred by the lowering of tariff walls.
Yet even the Administration's studies acknowledge that Mexican imports could hurt certain sectors, like the fruit and vegetable industries of Florida, Texas and California and the glass and cement industries elsewhere.
Perceptions of this vulnerability and the anxiety on Capitol Hill were behind the policy change announced on Wednesday, Administration officials said.
"Obviously, we're hoping to work out an acceptable compromise with the Hill," one senior trade official said.
 
Prefer Current System
 While Administration officials state their willingness to bargain on trade adjustment, they stress their preference for the system already in place under the 1988 Economic Dislocation and Worker Adjustment Assistance Act, which provides retraining services and needs-related payments to all laid-off workers, not just those forced out by imports.
In its first three years, the act served some 700,000 workers in such industries as autos, timber, electronics, copper, food processing, aerospace, military and steel.
But many Democratic members of Congress prefer the trade adjustment assistance concept originated by John F. Kennedy in 1962 and amended in 1974 in connection with another bid for trade expansion.
The main differences are that the Kennedy approach relates specifically to job losses from imports and provides much larger entitlements. Workers certified as displaced by trade compeition get up to an additional 26 weeks of unemployment insurance.
Critics say this is unfair, providing greater benefits to a worker who loses a job because of international competition than to one displaced by domestic competition. And with the globalization of the United States economy, it is often difficult to make the distinction between the domestic and international competitive forces that may be the cause.
Yet another significant difference between the two programs is that services under the Kennedy approach are distributed at the Federal level, while economic dislocation services are delivered by the states and local bodies. Critics say the latter approach creates disparities in the distribution of benefits.
Over the last three years, the Administration has unsuccessfully tried to terminate the trade adjustment assistance program.
 
Higher Appropriations
 But the Democratic-controlled Congress refuses to let it die. This year's appropriations for the trade adjustment program are $191 million, compared with $100 million in 1990. Appropriations for the economic dislocation program are $527 million, compared with $514 million in 1990.
According to Labor Department statistics, the economic dislocation program costs $1,200 a worker, and its training programs succeed in placing 70 percent of those enrolled; trade adjustment costs $7,000 a worker and has a 35 percent placement rate.
"Given the choice of the two, we opt for the one with the higher success rate," the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said last week.
 
New Aid From Congress
 Recent legislation suggests that Congress has taken an increased interest in stepping into situations in which workers are affected by Federal programs, a development that could strongly influence the trade adjustment debate, said Howard F. Rosen, a senior official in the Carter Administration's Labor Department who is now a research associate at the Institute for International Economics.
Under the Clean Air Act and the Defense Department Reauthorization Bill, both enacted last year, Congress insisted on compensating workers hurt by its own legislation.
Under the Clean Air legislation, Congress allocated an additional $50 million a year for the next five years to assist coal miners who might lose their jobs as a result of that law's proscriptions against acid rain. The Defense Department legislation similarly provides compensation for those who lose their jobs because of the closing of military bases.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENTS;
Wilder Cancels at Bridgeport Day Before He Was to Speak

BYLINE: By LEE A. DANIELS

 BODY:
The University of Bridgeport in Connecticut, besieged by a yearlong faculty strike and financial problems, held its graduation exercises yesterday -- but its featured speaker and honorary degree recipient stayed home in Virginia.
Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, who was supposed to deliver the main address at the private university's commencement, told university officials Saturday afternoon that he would stay away because the bitterly contested faculty strike had not been resolved. 
 Governor Wilder was replaced as the keynote speaker by another honorary degree recipient, Lee Salomon, a senior vice president of the William Morris talent agency, and the ceremonies were held without disturbance, a university police spokesman said. Walter Wager, a university spokesman, said that while Mr. Wilder's name was never mentioned during the graduation exercises, there were several oblique references to his decision.
"The general feeling was that he had every right to decline to come, but that it would have been appropriate to do so 120 days ago, 90 days ago. Not the day before," Mr. Wager said.
 
'Inappropriate to Attend'
 Janet D. Greenwood, the university's president, issued a statement yesterday that the cancellation was "extremely disappointing and disturbing to all of us, especially the students, to whom commencement is the climax of their higher education."
Laura Dillard, Mr. Wilder's press secretary, said yesterday that "given the circumstances, the Governor felt it would be inappropriate to attend." She said he had waited until Saturday before deciding because "he was hoping that there would be movement that would enable him to attend."
In February, Ms. Greenwood invited Mr. Wilder to the ceremonies, which marked the 30th anniversary of the school's granting an honorary degree to the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. Ms. Greenwood had become a friend of Mr. Wilder's when she was president of Longwood College in Virginia.
Ms. Dillard said Governor Wilder's staff had previously indicated to university officials that the faculty strike might prevent his appearing. But university officials told The Associated Press on Saturday that Mr. Wilder's decision came as a surprise, particularly because a member of his security team had arrived in Bridgeport on Friday. Mr. Wilder was scheduled to arrive Saturday in time for a fund-raising dinner.
A spokesman for striking faculty members at the university and a spokeswoman for the major national association of university faculty members, which has vigorously supported the dissident teachers, said their groups had urged Mr. Wilder not to attend.
The Governor has been prominently mentioned as a contender for the Democratic Presidential nomination. Crossing a faculty picket line, particularly in a dispute as fractious as that at Bridgeport, could have harmed his standing with education associations and organized labor.
Richard Tino, a striking professor of communications, said yesterday that the strike by the local chapter of the American Association of University Professors began on Sept. 1, when 120 faculty members walked off their jobs in a contract dispute.
The striking faculty members objected to the university's insistence that nearly a third of the 158 faculty positions at the institution be eliminated, that the salaries of those remaining be cut by up to 30 percent and that the teachers give up academic privileges long accepted as standard, like choosing what books to use and what courses to teach.
Mr. Tino said some professors have returned to work. But 70 faculty members, most of them tenured, remain on strike.
 
Syracuse University
John Naisbitt, author of "Megatrends," the best-selling book that made global finance sexy, told the 4,680 graduates of Syracuse University yesterday that the United States will be the major player in the coming "single-market world" and therefore their opportunities will be great.
Mr. Naisbitt and his wife, Patricia Aburdene, the authors of "Re-inventing the Corporation," and "Megatrends 2000," received honorary doctoral degrees in humane letters during the school's 137th commencement.
"As we globalize we are moving toward a single-market world," Mr. Naisbitt said. "That's the larger, emerging trend, a world where there is free trade amongst all nations. Single-market Europe 1992 is but a step to single-market world and as we continue our trend during the 90's to a single-market world the U.S. will continue to be by far the largest free-market economy in the world."
Ms. Aburdene was the keynote speaker at the School of Information Studies' commencement on Saturday.

HEADLINE: Brazil's Plans For Economy Drawing Fire

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRASILIA

 BODY:
Without fanfare, the central bank here has quietly placed into circulation Brazil's latest and highest-denomination bank note, the 10,000 cruzeiro bill.
Engraved with Amazon snakes, the new note is worth $34. A year ago, when Fernando Collor de Mello became President and promised to end inflation, 10,000 cruzeiros amounted to $134. 
 For many Brazilian and foreign business people, the new note symbolizes a widespread loss of faith in the team that dictates economic policies here. It is a loss of credibility that is bound to hang over Mr. Collor when he makes his first state visit to the United States in June.
Brazil's economic press has taken to referring to this capital artificially planted in Brazil's central savannah as "Fantasy Island."
 
Virtually Ignored in Cities
 A price freeze, decreed in January, is virtually ignored in Brazil's coastal cities, where 80 percent of the population lives. In the first four months of this year, prices jumped by 75 percent. "The price freeze has already become a joke outside of Brasilia, which continues to insist on treating it with a seriousness that is touching," the O Globo newspaper in Rio de Janeiro wrote, after listing local price rises in items from blue jeans to freezers.
The centerpiece of last year's anti-inflation program -- the freezing for 18 months of most checking and saving accounts -- has generated revolt among Brazil's increasingly skeptical middle class. Many people doubt the Government will repay the money with full interest.
Using such blunt terms as theft and larceny, judges up and down Brazil's coast -- from Sao Paulo to Recife -- have ordered the unfreezing of bank accounts. In lines snaking around courthouses, as many as 150,000 people filed petitions in March and April to get their money back.
Fearing a sudden avalanche of $20 billion into the hands of people who no longer trust banks, economic officials are fighting to persuade the Supreme Court to declare the actions of the lower courts invalid.
[In another assertion of judicial independence, a judge here on Thursday ordered the arrest of Ibrahim Eris, president of Brazil's central bank. Mr. Eris hid for six hours in the bank's headquarters, until the bank's lawyers won a stay.]
 
Jump in Unemployment
 Further weakening support for Mr. Collor, the number of unemployed in Sao Paulo continues to grow, topping the one million mark in April. The current unemployment rate in Brazil's largest city is 12 percent, double the rate of recent years.
"The Government took away all the savings, put a lot of people into the street, and for what?" asked Costa Ferreira, a Congressman from a political party that backs the Government. "The gross national product fell and inflation continued."
Indeed, economists fear that Brazil is approaching another price explosion. "The public deficit is not under control; prices will probably explode by August," predicted Cesar Maia, an opposition Congressman who last February offered a rare voice of support for the price freeze.
In an unusual flash of frankness from Government economic officials, Mr. Eris, the president of the central bank, recently said: "There are still doubts over the true intentions of the Collor Government's economic policy -- if it is free market or interventionist." Many people here read his comments as a prelude to resignation.
Last year, Brazilian companies invested more money overseas than foreign companies invested here. Brazil, traditionally among the top five beneficiaries of Japanese investment, slipped to 23d place.
According to a recent study by a British bank, Brazil was the only one of Latin America's five largest debtors to suffer from net capital flight last year. While $1 billion left Brazil in 1990, capital repatriation topped capital flight in Argentina, Chile, Mexico and Venezuela.
"The bottom line is that the Government does not have any credibility," said Riordan Roett, an American bank consultant who organized a meeting in Sao Paulo this month of the World Economic Forum. In one yardstick of Brazil's stock overseas, the forum last year drew 280 business executives. This year, attendance was 135, virtually all of them from Brazil.
"There is no confidence in the team," Mr. Roett said. "There is no dialogue. There are no consultations. They treat businessmen like children."
Indeed, the mixture of petulance and arrogance that Brazilian business executives often attribute to the nation's Economy Minister, Zelia Cardoso de Mello, could be seen during an interview here.
Asked to list her team's first-year successes, Ms. Cardoso groaned. "I've answered that so many times that just to think of answering yet one more time really bores me," she responded with irritation. "I don't know how actors manage every night to repeat the same line."
Some of Brazil's poor international image stems from the Government's glacial progress in renegotiating payment terms for its $60 billion foreign debt with private banks. After six months of talks, Brazil and the bankers in April reached an agreement in principle on the repayment of $8 billion in unpaid interest.
Brazil not only has the world's largest arrears with private banks, it has the fastest-growing arrears, according to the Institute of International Finance. Figures compiled by this Washington-based bank group show Brazil's arrears almost tripled in two years, to $9.5 billion in March from $3.4 billion in 1989.
After a year of diplomacy, tension between Brazil and its creditors flared into the open in April. In Nagoya, Japan, at the annual meeting of the Inter-American Development Bank, Japanese officials avoided scheduling meetings with the Brazilians. At a dinner, Ms. Cardoso exchanged sharp words with David C. Mulford, the United States Under Secretary of the Treasury.
In her speech to the delegates, Ms. Cardoso branded as "illegitimate and unacceptable" a move by the United States, Europe and Japan to suspend approval of a $350 million loan for Brazil until progress was made on the interest arrears. With the loan suspended, the Brazilians quickly reached an agreement and the loan was approved.

HEADLINE: Texas Dome: Haven or Hazard? - A Special Report;
Site for Toxic-Waste Cave Stirs Texas Political Fight

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DAYTON, Tex.

 BODY:
Here on the verdant coastal lowlands of Texas, a little-known company is pursuing one of the most risky, politically sensitive and potentially lucrative goals in American business today -- a permit from Federal and state authorities to build a huge hazardous-waste disposal site.
Beneath the rice fields, 30 miles from Houston, Hunter Environmental Services Inc. wants to bury toxic waste in mammoth caverns carved into a salt dome more than 60 million years old; the subterranean salt formation is so large that were it above ground it would dwarf Mount Everest; the length of each proposed waste-storage cavern would be taller than the Empire State Building. Regulatory clearance for a large project like Hunter's is the holy grail of the $25-billion-a-year waste services industry. Only a couple of such permits have been granted in the last few years, none for salt-dome sites. 
 Hunter's story is partly that of an extraordinary corporate gamble, of a company that two years ago had a consulting business with 2,000 employees and annual revenues of more than $100 million yet sold everything to pursue the salt-dome project.
 
Enormous Potential Reward
 The reward for Hunter could be enormous. Analysts place the value of the permit the company is seeking at perhaps $500 million, given the size of the proposed project and its potential profitability. By contrast, the total value of Hunter's shares today is roughly $50 million. "If you make it, the payoff on this project is very, very large indeed," said J. Anthony Forstmann, a professional investor and a Hunter backer.
The Hunter case also deals with an issue crucial to the national debate over disposing of hazardous waste in a way that does not damage the environment or pose health risks to people living near disposal sites. And finally it is a story of the rough and tumble of local politics as seen in a costly campaign to try to influence state politicians and government officials. The company has spent nearly $5 million in two years on lawyers and lobbyists alone, and the costs are mounting.
Nowhere is the toxic-waste issue more sharply drawn than in Texas. Because of its big oil and chemical industries, the state is by far the biggest producer of toxic waste, generating more than 20 percent of the annual nationwide total of 270 million tons. Most states have become more reluctant to allow new toxic waste sites in recent years, and several have tried to curb imports of out-of-state waste. Such attitudes are scarcely surprising given the toxic-waste industry's history of problems, both unforeseen and ignored. Indeed, the Environmental Protection Agency is concerned that the "not in my backyard" policies adopted by states raise the prospect of sharp conflicts between states.
"Siting new disposal facilities is one of the most difficult challenges politically," said William K. Reilly, the E.P.A. administrator. "But for the sake of the environment, we must face up to siting decisions. Each state must be proportionately responsible for assuring safe, high-quality disposal capacity."
 
The Politics
 
A Sudden Change In the Climate
The political climate in Texas, a state with a reputation for giving business a free hand, shifted abruptly in November when Ann Richards, a Democrat, was elected Governor, promising a 'new Texas" with tougher environmental standards.
Until then, Hunter seemed well on its way toward getting its permit. It had begun the process more than two years earlier, preparing roomfuls of technical documents, meeting with citizens' groups in high school gymnasiums, and lobbying politicians and officials. Now, the Governor's office is occupied by a person who twice during her campaign stumped in Dayton, attacking the Hunter plan.
She has harshly criticized the Texas Water Commission, which would grant the state permits, saying the commission is too lenient, and she has pledged that things will change under her stewardship. "No more will hazardous-waste facilities be rammed through the permit process over the objections of local communities," she declared.
Hunter's permit application is set to go before the commission this summer in hearings that amount to a public trial. Testimony and deliberations will probably take months. The Hunter proposal has also been caught up in a legislative fight in Austin, the state capital.
The Governor is pushing legislation that would result in a moratorium on toxic-waste permits for a year or so until strict rules are developed. The company's lobbyists have pressed hard to change phrasing in the bill so that Hunter's permit hearing could go ahead unless the E.P.A. or the Water Commission decides that new rules tailored for salt domes are required. Hunter succeeded in getting the wording of the bill changed in the State Senate, and the House will make its decision soon.
Hunter has hired a small army of well-connected lobbyists, lawyers and image polishers. They include Robert S. Strauss, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and his Austin law firm of Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld; Lee Biggart, the former chairman of the Water Commission, and Hill & Knowlton Inc., one of the nation's largest public relations firms.
The lobbyists and lawyers declined to discuss specific tasks they have performed in return for their $5 million in fees, for fear of "giving away our strategy," explained Paul Seals, an Akin, Gump partner and former regional counsel for the Environmental Protection Agency in Dallas. Some of the money was for legal fees for the permit application. Mr. Biggart said the lobbying efforts were mainly individual meetings with state legislators and government officials; he said these sessions were usually carefully orchestrated and time consuming.
"A lot of politicians wish the hazardous-waste problem would simply go away," Mr. Biggart said. "But when we present Hunter's case to people one by one, they come away convinced that this is a solution to the problem."
The company's executives say they have not made any financial contributions to politicians. "This is a permit business for us now," said Oliver A. Kimberly Jr., Hunter's chairman. "And the risk we face is 100 percent political."
The project's opponents say they are not unimpressed by the scope and the expense of Hunter's campaign of persuasion. "They haven't missed a political move," said James Blackburn of Blackburn & Carter, a Houston environmental law firm opposing the project. "And they have deep pockets."
 
The Advocates
 
Single-Minded Missionaries
Keith Price, an environmental consultant, was attending a municipal utility trade show in San Antonio in the summer of 1983 when he wandered by the stand of a company that specialized in fashioning caverns in underground salt domes for the storage of oil and gas, like the Government's Strategic Petroleum Reserve along the Gulf Coast. He chatted, picked up some leaflets and began pondering the notion of burying hazardous wastes in domes. His curiosity grew into a belief and then a mission. "It's become a kind of religious commitment for me," he said.
But one that has been severely tested. In the mid-1980's, he sought approval for a salt-dome venture near Palestine, Tex., north of Dayton. It ran into local resistance and was abandoned when, after a bit of legislative sleight of hand, the proposed site was declared a groundwater conservation district in 1987. The lesson, he said: "Get more involved with the community. And tell your story to everyone who will listen because it's a darn good story."
It was a story that certainly impressed Mr. Kimberly in 1988, when Hunter bought Environmental Science and Engineering Inc., where Mr. Price was working. "Everyone who has touched this project has become a missionary," said Mr. Kimberly, who is 57 years old and an investment banker by training.
Yet by the summer of 1989, the high costs of pursuing a hazardous-waste permit were apparent. To help accomplish the task, the company moved to sell its consulting operations. Hunter was an environmental consulting firm with 2,000 workers and more than $100 million in revenues; in 1990, it made Inc. magazine's yearly list of the fastest-growing small public companies in America. Now, it is down to a staff of 15 people. And in the nine months ended in December, it reported revenues of just $1.7 million. Today, the principal asset of the company, based in Southport, Conn., is a $19 million holding of shares of Cilcorp that it took in payment for its consultancy business. Its current revenues derive mainly from the dividends on those shares.
 
The Theory
 
Idea Bolstered By Nuclear Tests
Using salt domes for storage has proved to be generally successful for oil and gas, with more than 1,500 storage caverns in the United States. Leakage has not been a problem, with the handful of accidents coming from blowouts of corroded pipes.
As part of their argument for the domes' impermeability, enthusiasts point to the nuclear bomb tests conducted in the Tatum salt dome in Mississippi in the mid-1960's.
The Government was suspicious that the Soviets were cheating on the test-ban treaty by detonating atomic bombs deep in Siberian salt caverns, beyond detection.
To see if such blasts could go undetected, the Atomic Energy Commission set off a five-kiloton nuclear device in the Tatum dome in 1964. The bomb was small beside today's 1,000 kiloton bombs but still mighty enough to do what one might expect to be a fair amount of damage to the salt walls of a hole in the ground; the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima was 15 kilotons.
The explosion showed up on seismic monitors and created a cavity 100 feet in diameter. But the salt formation, the testers said, did not leak radiation. Later, the Government set off a second bomb in the Tatum dome. Since 1972, the Federal Government and Mississippi authorities have conducted yearly tests of the drinking water in the area and found no indication of radioactive leakage from the dome, the Energy Department says. The Soviets, it was later determined, were not testing in salt domes.
Many experts say the domes should be equally resistant to leakage of hazardous wastes. And the Tatum dome example is what convinced several Hunter executives and investors of the advantages of salt dome storage. "That's what really sold me," Mr. Kimberly said.
So far, however, salt domes have not been used for holding toxic industrial waste, which in the United States includes arsenic, lead, mercury, benzene, chloroform, carbon tetrachloride, vinyl chloride and dozens of others.
Some geologists and toxic-waste experts caution that a safe atomic test in one salt dome does not necessarily prove that another dome would be ideal for storing hazardous waste. Salt domes -- the dried remains of a sea that existed in the Mesozoic Era and covered much of Texas, Louisiana and Mississippi -- vary in purity, with some having pockets of gypsum, water or gas. "Not all salt domes are created equal," said H. C. Clark, an emeritus professor of geology at Rice University, who is advising the City of Houston.
These experts warn that a salt dome could be susceptible to leaching or leakage over time, especially if the hazardous chemicals react with one another. Under the Hunter plan, the waste would be mixed with ash, solidified, crushed into pea-sized gravel and dropped into the caverns. But the toxic materials would not be treated chemically to neutralize them, an expensive process. "Hunter says that containment alone is enough," said Richard Fortuna, executive director of the Hazardous Waste Treatment Council, a trade association. "But experience has shown us that containment alone is not enough."
 
The Deals
 
Promises to Allay Community Fears
A graying 48-year-old Louisiana native, Mr. Price is president of the company's Texas subsidiary, Hunter Industrial Facilities Inc., the corporate name on the permit application. He directs the company's campaign from a two-story home converted into an office in Dayton. Adversaries acknowledge that he is a skilled advocate, equally at home discussing the technical features of the project or trading bass-fishing stories with the locals.
In two years, he has appeared before dozens of community meetings with local people and has had his home picketed by protesters. To allay fears and win converts, Hunter has pledged to guarantee the value of home prices within three miles of the site, to avoid trucking hazardous wastes during hours that school buses make their rounds, and to donate $100,000 a year in college scholarships for local high school graduates once the operation is up and running. Hunter's consultants say the big waste project and accompanying industrial park could eventually create 12,000 jobs in a rural area of high unemployment.
The company has won some local support. C. Scott Parker, the Mayor of Liberty, the county seat, which is six miles from Dayton, has fought for seven years against a proposal to put a hazardous-waste landfill nearby. But after studying the Hunter plan, he said he had found no real flaws, calling it "probably the best solution we have to storing hazardous waste."
 
The Opponents
 
A Local Group With Dedication
Hunter's opponents appear every bit as committed and dedicated as the company. Since Governor Richards's election, they also have gained a good deal of political power. The Houston City Council and several community groups oppose the project.
In addition, a telephone survey of 439 people in the adjacent region found 73 percent opposed to the Hunter project even if it would help the local economy, said C. Bruce Stratton, chairman of a local citizens review committee, which does not plan to take a position on the Hunter proposal.
The opponents say the salt dome plan involves too many uncertainties: the safety of transporting hazardous waste, drainage from the site during heavy rainfall and the possible danger of slow leaching from unforeseen chemical reactions. They point out that the site is less than 10 miles from Lake Houston. "We're left with an experimental facility that would be awfully close to the water supply of a major city," said Professor Clark of Rice University.
Much opposition comes from a group called Friends Insist Stop Toxic Waste, or FIST, founded in 1989 by Chris Sagstetter, a 38-year-old homemaker from Huffman, a small town near Lake Houston. She has opposed the plan with a single-minded passion. The battle has consumed her time, eaten into her household finances and, she acknowledges, clearly contributed to the recent breakup of her marriage.
"This is a war of attrition," said Ms. Sagstetter, who last month began work as an environmental specialist for Houston's health department.
 
The Next Move
 
A Difficult Vote For the State
The Environmental Protection Agency sets national waste-disposal standards, but most states, Texas included, are delegated the authority for approving or rejecting hazardous-waste projects.
And the Texas decision rests with the Texas Water Commission, unless the Legislature passes the special moratorium. Each of the commission's three members is a political appointee of former Gov. William Clements Jr., a pro-business Republican who was once an oil industry executive. They will not say how they are going to vote, but the odds seem to favor a pro-Hunter decision.
Yet, the chairman, B. J. Wynne 3d, a 35-year-old former counsel to Governor Clements, acknowledges the double pressures of having to deal with the state's hazardous-waste problems and the political opposition to the granting of permits: "I'm sitting at the leading edge of this problem, and we're overwhelmed by it. You can't make these decisions based on public opinion, but I ain't a potted plant."
And the commissioners' ruling may be challenged. "If they are going to approve a salt dome, we'll take them to court," said Jacqueline Warren, a senior attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental organization.
Hunter is confident that it will win the salt dome permit and, if then challenged in court, that the E.P.A. would stand by the state ruling and that the challenge would be beaten.
For Hunter, each new delay means that it keeps spending money at a rapid rate with little to show for it, except increasingly edgy investors. "It's been torture," said Arthur Samberg, president of Dawson Samberg Capital Management, which holds a stake.
Mr. Kimberly said: "What keeps me going is my belief in the project, that this will be good not just for the shareholders but also for Texas and the nation. And sure, it's fun to make money."

HEADLINE: There's No Place Like Chittenango

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHITTENANGO, N.Y., May 4

 BODY:
When corporate sponsors suddenly pulled out of a plan to bring Munchkins back to the Land of Oz, people here were distraught. Unless help came from somewhere over the rainbow, they joked morosely to one another, the plan was dead.
But Chittenango, the birthplace of L. Frank Baum, the creator of Oz, decided to press ahead on its own. With bake sales and door-to-door pleas, it scraped together enough money to fly three Munchkins from the cast of "The Wizard of Oz" to the Oz Festival on Saturday. Now the village is hoping to bring even more. 
 All of those who played the main characters in the 52-year-old M.G.M. classic are dead. But about two dozen of the 124 Munchkins are alive, and many would be honored to come to Chittenango, said 75-year-old Meinhardt Raabe, who officially pronounced the Wicked Witch of the East dead ("As coroner, I must aver, I've thoroughly examined her."), and is the unofficial Munchkin patriarch.
"It's a thrill, really," Mr. Raabe, who lives in a retirement community in Florida, said in a telephone interview. "I'll come in costume. I'll march in the parade. I'll speak to the Rotary Club and various other organizations. I guess if you want to get down to brass tacks, you could say it's an ego trip."
 
Auntie Em's and Oz Ice Cream
 To people in Chittenango, the Munchkins would add living history to their celebration.
"They were there; they were in the movie," said Tom Cooney, a festival organizer. "Someday they'll go, and then that's it. All you'll have is celluloid."
The 13-year-old annual festival fulfills a passion in this community of 4,700, which lies 15 miles east of Syracuse but seems to fancy itself as part of a different world altogether.
There is an Auntie Em's Pantry here, which serves Oz Cream Cones; a Tinman Hardware Store; an End of the Rainbow Gift Shop, and an Emerald City Lanes Bowling. There is even a yellow brick road in the center of town, though it is closer in size to a sidewalk and the color of the bricks has faded over the years to shopping-bag brown, a point of some local controversy.
 
Not Even in the Credits
 Chittenango has raised enough money to pay the air fare of two of the Munchkins -- Jerry Maren, who handed the welcoming lollipop to Dorothy, and Margaret Pellegrini, a sleepy-head Munchkin. And two newspapers in Syracuse have kicked in for Mr. Raabe and his wife.
There are Munchkins in other parts of the country who would like to come, though some of them would probably demand fees, Mr. Raabe said.
This is a legacy of the unfair treatment that many Munchkins believe they received in making the movie, for which they received nominal pay, no royalties and not even credits by name at the end of the movie: It just says, ". . .and the Munchkins."
"Fifty years ago, there was terrible prejudice against little people, and we just accepted it," Mr. Raabe said. "A lot of the Munchkins have wised up since then."
But Mr. Raabe, who spent 30 years after the movie as a public relations executive for Oscar Mayer and Company, is not looking for anything from Chittenango other than his travel expenses.
"Looking back, I'd say being in 'The Wizard of Oz' was one of the proudest accomplishments of my life."
Many other Munchkins seemed to agree. "How many movies are there that a great-grandmother like me can sit down with a great-grandchild and enjoy today?" said Mrs. Pellegrini, who lives in Glendale, Ariz.
The uproar in the town arose two weeks ago when a group of Syracuse-area businesses, which had pledged to pay for the air fares and hotel rooms of at least four Munchkins, said they had to back out because of the recession.
 
3-Year-Old Knows All the Words
 Festival organizers at first feared they were sunk, but then vowed to push ahead, and now are thinking of trying to bring in other Munchkins and perhaps two of Mr. Baum's relatives: a 75-year-old granddaughter and an 82-year-old niece.
In Chittenango, where last year's festival drew 12,000 people, the influence of the movie seems almost pervasive.
"My 2-year-old watched it twice the other morning," said Barbara Evans, an organizer of the festival.
Kathy Daviau, the festival's co-chairwoman, said, "My 3-year-old can lip-sync the whole movie."
Proceeds from this year's Oz Festival are being set aside for a Museum of Oz, which residents hope to build to honor Mr. Baum and his 14 Oz books. The first, "The Wonderful Wizard of Oz," published in 1900, was the basis of the movie by the slightly shorter name.
Organizers have added an educational note to the festival, whose theme will be "We're Off to Read the Wizard and the Wonderful Books of Oz."
"We're telling our kids that reading books can help you develop the important qualities in life," Mr. Cooney said, "like brains, courage and a heart."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The town of Chittenango, N.Y., has had an Oz Festival for the last 13 years. A commemorative Oz postmark and Oz stamps adorned a letter mailed from Chittenango during last year's festival. (Michael J. HEADLINE: Dinkins Seeks Ways to Save Some Services

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Having proposed budget cuts that would darken New York City's streets and dry up its swimming pools, Mayor David N. Dinkins will embark this week on negotiations with municipal unions and state officials intended to avoid such severe service cuts and to preserve the city's traditional broad-shouldered mission.
"I don't want to lose shelters and playgrounds and pools and beaches, and losing some of those things would be counterproductive anyway," Mr. Dinkins said in an interview yesterday, 24 hours after holding elaborately choreographed meetings with state and city officials and union leaders to outline his plans for coping with New York's enormous fiscal problems. 
The cuts, carefully calculated to seem unpalatable if not unbearable to the public, would eliminate a range of social programs for which the Mayor campaigned -- like drug treatment for women and children -- and essential services -- like road-cleaning and garbage recycling. The plan calls for laying off more than 27,000 full- and part-time workers starting in July.
 
'It's So Painful'
 But at a time when some of his own business advisers have said the scope of municipal government must shrink, and days before he must submit his plan to the City Council for review, Mr. Dinkins likened the deepest cuts to a train he hopes to derail by pressuring the unions and the state for help until the local economy turns around. He made clear that he had no intention of willingly presiding over a scaling back of the city's mandate.
"I think it is good that we take care of those who are vulnerable and I would hope that we continue to," he said, adding that he hoped to find ways to perform services more efficiently or get the state and Federal governments to pay more of the cost. "There's all kinds of flowery language about how a civilization is measured by how they treat their young and their elderly," the Mayor said. "That's why it's so painful as we do these cuts." Mr. Dinkins wants to avoid the worst of the cuts he proposed, and his aides said there were some other possibilities that he refused even to wave as red flags, like proposals to eliminate 6,000 day-care spots or drop-in shelters for the homeless. "There are just some things he doesn't even want to be associated with," one senior aide said.
The Mayor, under intense pressure to show how he would keep the city's $29 billion budget balanced in the face of huge gaps in the current and coming fiscal years, staked out his position in a daylong series of meetings on Saturday with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo; Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, and others.
"Everybody we talked to was helpful from the Governor on down," Mr. Dinkins said, but added, "I understand there's a difference between saying nice and helpful things and deliverance."
Participants in the meetings said city officials did not make specific demands of the unions or hold detailed discussions of the proposed cuts, but gave all the parties the bad news at once in the hope of moving beyond the recriminations and jockeying that have stalled any meaningful negotations for weeks.
"It was basically show," one city official said. "But on the bright side, nothing fell apart. The unions did admit they were willing to help the city."
Mayoral aides said they now expected union leaders to begin specific individual discussions about what concessions in wages, work rules and benefits they can make. City officials say they hope such concessions will save at least $600 million. That would go a long way toward offsetting the more than $1 billion in the latest round of cuts Mr. Dinkins outlined Saturday. Those cuts came on top of $1 billion in cuts and more than $1 billion in taxes he had already proposed to help close a budget gap of nearly $3.5 billion in the fiscal year that starts July 1.
"There's going to have to be a lot of back and forth," one senior city official said. "They're going to have strings attached to a lot of their money and there are going to be ways that we're not going to want to spend it, and out of that will come a number. They won't get all their jobs back and we won't get all that we want."
Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said yesterday that in the coming days he and other union leaders "will sit down quietly and start to determine what chunks of money might be available -- we've got to look at where the money is."
But even if the unions made concessions like deferring wages or changing health benefits, city officials said, there would undoubtedly still be some layoffs since some of the programs Mr. Dinkins would want to restore do not require more workers but money for supplies and services.
The plan Mr. Dinkins sketched on Saturday did not address how the city would close a budget gap of $465 million in the rest of this fiscal year. City officials have said they believe they can solve that problem but so far have only frozen spending for supplies and suggested possible options.
 
Sole Approval Power
 Mayoral aides said they did not expect any big breakthroughs before Mr. Dinkins is required to submit his proposed budget to the City Council on Friday.
Since the Council has the sole power to approve or modify the Mayor's plan, that means the political dance will grow even more complex, with Mr. Dinkins, the Council, the unions, the Governor and others all maneuvering to reflect their own priorities in the budget that has to be passed by June 30.
Mr. Cuomo, who has repeatedly expressed skepticism at the city's fiscal management and reluctance to offer the city help unless unions agreed to concessions, met privately with the Mayor at Gracie Mansion on Saturday and, aides to both officials said, pledged to do what he could to assure that the city received at least $250 million in additional help from the state.
City officials said that could take the form of direct revenue sharing or relief from state mandates on things like class size for special education programs. But with the State Legislature deadlocked for weeks over how to close a $6 billion gap in the state budget, aides said Mr. Cuomo had cautioned that there were no guarantees.
"The Governor was very upbeat about the whole thing," said one aide to Mr. Cuomo.
One of the biggest uncertainties in the budget mix is how much help Mr. Rohatyn and the Municipal Assistance Corporation will offer and when. The watchdog agency was set up to borrow money on the city's behalf when it was shut out of the credit markets in the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, and city officials hope to tap its financing powers for $200 million to $300 million in aid.
But Mr. Rohatyn, a strong critic of Mr. Dinkins's decision to grant substantial wage increases to municipal unions, has said the corporation would "have to be the caboose, not the engine" of any rescue plan and could only help after seeing a comprehensive plan for dealing with the city's problems over the next several years.
On Saturday, Mr. Rohatyn, a close adviser to the Governor, said he would study the plan and give some indication of how the assistance corporation might help within a couple of weeks. He also issued a stern warning that if the state did not pass a budget soon, depriving the city of aid it has been counting on, it could set in motion a series of events that would severely limit the ability of the state, city and the corporation itself to borrow money in the bond markets.
Senior Dinkins administration officials said they took both comments as a positive sign. Without a convincing plan to solve the city's budget problems, city officials have worried that they might not be able to sell $600 million of bonds on time next month, a failing that could trigger a takeover of the city's finances by a state panel, the Financial Control Board, and possiblly leave the city short of cash to pay its bills.
 
Wide Range of Cuts
 Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the control board, said last night that he had not yet seen a copy of Mr. Dinkins's proposal and could not comment on the plan until he did.
Besides proposing to shut off one-quarter of the city's street lamps and close all 32 public swimming pools, Mr. Dinkins warned of a wide range of cuts likely to meet fierce resistance from community and advocacy groups and distaste from his own commissioners.
Among the proposed cuts sure to generate controversy was the suggestion to suspend entirely for one year the city's garbage recycling program. That would send 1,000 more pounds of trash a day into the city's last-remaining and fast-filling landfill, Fresh Kills on Staten Island.
"It is not the type of program you can turn on and off," said Sanitation Commissioner Steve M. Polan. "It would be a tragedy in terms of eliminating the gains we've made in reducing the amount of garbage going into Fresh Kills."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Iraq Christian Minority Begins to Look for Door

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 5

 BODY:
In the northern Iraqi town of Dohuk the other day, three middle-aged women, enveloped from head to toe in long black veils, did something that is very unusual in this part of the world.
They walked straight up to a Western male correspondent, and one of them, pulling back her veil, said in English, "We are Christians, and we want to go to America." 
 "America, America," her two companions chanted. Then all three crossed themselves fervently several times before scuttling back into the crowd, where they were soon indistinguishable from all the other veiled Muslim women, moving like black cones along the street.
With the end of the Persian Gulf war and an announcement that Iraqis will be allowed to travel abroad again next month after a nearly nine-year ban, a wave of restlessness is sweeping through this country's roughly 800,000-member Christian minority, with many saying they want to leave for good.
 
Invitation to Leave
 This restlessness attracted at least semi-official attention last week when a magazine called Babil -- the Arabic for Babylon -- that is owned by President Saddam Hussein's son, Udai, published an article suggesting that those disloyal enough to want to leave should do so now. Good riddance to them was the implication.
The article never mentioned Iraq's Christians by name. But Christians have been quick to see themselves as the target of a rebuke.
To judge by external signs, Christians here seem as ostentatiously loyal to the present Government in public as everyone else in this country.
At the Virgin Mary Church, the Rev. Afran Rassam of the Chaldean Catholic Church, an Eastern Rite of Roman Catholicism, keeps a large color picture of President Hussein on his office wall, alongside an even gaudier lithograph depicting the Sacred Heart of Jesus.
On the living room wall of his house at St. Joseph's Church, the Rev. Louis Shabi, another Chaldean priest, has hung a painted plate carrying a picture of the President in Arab headdress, staring out at the ivory crucifix on the wall opposite.
 
Many Have No Complaints
 Many Christians say they have no complaints about the way the Government has treated them, although they add that they have suffered persecution under earlier regimes.
Iraq's ruling Baath Party has always been a secular political movement, interested in material goals and with no time for Islamic fundamentalism.
"This Government has been good to us," Father Shabi says. "We do not complain."
But he acknowledged that there are "ignorant people" who sometimes accuse the Christians of being Europeans, not Iraqis, although the Chaldeans claim descent from the disciples of the Apostle Thomas, who came here from Jerusalem in the first century, long before the rise of Islam.
In fact, it is the gulf war more than anything else that has unsettled Christians here. During the conflict, many say, they were identified with the American-led coalition forces attacking the country and were discriminated against.
A Christian translator recounts how his wife was thrown out of the local shop when she went to collect the family's monthly ration of low-priced food. "They told her, 'If you want food, go and ask Bush for it,' " he said.
Many other Christians tell of being called Crusaders or "members of the coalition" because of their religion.
While Iraq's 600,000 Chaldean Catholics are by far the largest Christian group in this predominantly Muslim country of more than 18 million people, there are also smaller numbers of Syrian and Armenian Catholics as well as members of the Orthodox Greek and Armenian faiths and some Protestants.
For many Christians, the urge to leave stems not only from a sense of oppression resulting from the gulf war but also from a complex mixture of economic and social factors.
Prospects in general do not seem bright in a country that will probably be shackled with reparation repayments to Kuwait for years. And some Christians fear discrimination against minorities if conditions worsen.
 
Hurt by Economic Slowdown
 Some Christians say the postwar economic slowdown is already hitting them hard. Often better educated than Muslims and fluent in English or French, many had taken jobs with foreign concerns that have now departed or at embassies that are closed.
Past waves of immigration also mean that Iraqi Christians often have relatives in countries like the United States, Australia and Canada who can help them start a new life abroad. Sometimes foreign branches of their churches help them to emigrate.
"The young see this as their chance to go," said an Armenian Christian woman who was visiting the Virgin Mary Church today and whose son lives in San Francisco.
However much they support the Government in public, Iraqi Christians sometimes give the impression that they regard themselves as a beleaguered group by the very piety with which they practice their religion.
At evening High Mass at the Virgin Mary Church last Sunday, there was barely standing room inside.
 
Rituals Carefully Observed
 A packed congregation sang hymns in Chaldean and Arabic to Arab rhythms thumped out on an electric organ with the gusto of Bible Belt gospelers.
The finest points of ritual were meticulously observed, with everyone genuflecting and crossing themselves on entering and leaving.
During the service a steady stream of congregants briefly left their places to kiss the feet of a statue of St. Francis. The entire congregation appeared to take communion.
Asked to explain such fervor later, Father Shabi smiled gently and recited an ancient Chaldean proverb that says those who have been bitten by a snake always fear the sight of its skin.
"It means we remember that we have known difficult times," he said.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
U.S. GENERALS SEEK BIGGER IRAQ HAVEN

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SILOPI, Turkey, May 5

 BODY:
Senior American military commanders here said today that they wanted to extend the allied safe-haven area in northern Iraq to include the city of Dohuk in an effort to draw hundreds of thousands of Kurdish refugees down from their perilous mountain camps.
The commanders said Kurdish leaders had told them that if the area was not extended to Dohuk, a major center about 50 miles south of the Turkish border, several hundred thousand refugees, or half the total in the border area, might stay in the camps. The refugees were said to prefer risking death from summer heat and disease rather than return to homes and villages still under the control of President Saddam Hussein's army. 
 "If we go into Dohuk and secure Dohuk, the bulk of the refugees in the mountain can go right home," said Dayton Maxwell, the State Department's disaster assistance coordinator here. "You don't need camps. We could take care of the bulk of the refugees just by securing Dohuk."
"If we don't go into Dohuk," he said, "then we have to plan on winterized shelters for over 300,000 refugees."
The American commanders have made what one described as strong recommendations that Dohuk be taken, but thus far there has been no permission from Washington to move south.
"It is a highly sensitive political decision being made in the United States," a senior American official here said. "I can categorically say no decision has been taken."
While more than 40,000 Kurds have come down from the nearby mountains in the last week to their old homes across the Iraqi border in the area of Zakho, about 300,000 more are taking shelter in the remote eastern mountains. Zakho is safely under the control of American, British, French and Dutch troops.
Many other Kurdish refugees are from villages razed by Mr. Hussein's forces and from other areas to the east and south, outside allied control.
Kurdish tribal leaders in the Cukurca and Uzumlu camps, where most of the refugees are from the Dohuk area, have insisted in meetings in recent days with Brig. Gen. Richard Potter, the United States Special Forces commander whose men are in the Turkish mountain camps, that they will not come down until the area is under the protection of allied troops.
There are indications that the Iraqis are pulling back from Dohuk and also suggestions of widespread looting by Iraqi soldiers. Journalists driving down the highway have seen abandoned posts and individual soldiers waving sheepish salutes, but have been stopped by roadblocks outside the city.
"They seem to have reduced their presence there something on the order of 20 percent in the last 12 hours," said Col. James Jones, commander of the 24th Marine Expeditionary Unit, adding that an Iraqi infantry battalion and eight tanks from forward positions had been withdrawn.
About 400 American marines, with armored vehicles and anti-tank missiles, moved down to the southern slope of the plains today, positioning themselves closer to Dohuk. American paratroopers to the east also moved closer to the town. American planes and helicopters have been conducting reconnaissance flights over the area.
 
Broadening Questions
 The Dohuk issue illustrates how the Administration's decision to aid the Kurdish refugees by a swift military deployment -- spurred by televised coverage of their suffering -- has quickly broadened into other questions. These include how long American troops will stay, how the Kurds are to be protected from Baghdad's wrath in the future, and whether protection will create the nucleus of an independent nation long sought by the Kurds.
But American commanders are more immediately concerned with the coming hot weather, believing that snow-fed streams in the mountains will dry up within a month and that disease could spread. There have been reports of cholera in the Cukurca camp.
"Dohuk is key," Colonel Jones said, pointing out that the city contains a large reservoir, controls the major highways in the region and is surrounded by rich farmland and valleys. It also contains a hydro-electric generating plant in an area largely without electricity.
"Dohuk is not only militarily significant," he said. "It is also economically significant and the administrative center of the northern area. If you poll people on the mountain, three-quarters will say Dohuk. Dohuk is on the tip of their tongues."
 
Many Bypassing Zakho
 Experience with the emergency relief effort, which is still being improvised, indicates that the Kurds are largely bypassing the refugee transit camp being built at Zakho. There are now about 6,000 people living there, military officials said today.
The initial plan to build a second refugee camp near Amadiya in the newly opened eastern sector of the security zone is being reconsidered. One possibility is building a series of way stations to help refugees make their way back home.
"Look at the statistics," said Maj. Jim La Fleur, the civil affairs staff officer for Task Force Bravo, the military operation on the Iraqi side of the border. "If we open up Dohuk, it's going to take the place of building a hell of a lot of camps."
But an expansion south, while driven by realities on the ground, could raise other problems, some officials said.
"It could enmesh us deeper," an American official said, "and create further aggravation with the Iraqi regime."
Mentioning Kurdish areas farther to the east and south, a Western diplomat asked, "Once you are in Dohuk, does that force you to go to Mosul, and once in Mosul, then to Erbil?"
 
How, and How Long, to Protect
 Further, setting up such a zone could raise the question of how, and how long, it could be protected.
"If you were Saddam, wouldn't you just wait?" a diplomat asked. "Whatever presence there is has to be limited in time."
The idea of an expanded zone protected by Western troops is also appealing to the Kurdish Pesh Merga guerrillas, emerging in numbers from their hideouts in the hills.
"I think the creation of Kurdistan is now closer than ever before," said a guerrilla commander known as General Ali, who controls the zone around Zakho.
Surrounded by his men, armed with AK-47 rifles and grenade launchers, in a new base in a schoolhouse in the Iraqi mountain village of Begova, a dirt-poor place of stony roads and corrugated-tin shacks, the guerrilla leader said:
"We want the zone to make up all of Kurdistan in Iraq only. We want the United States Army to take over all of Kurdistan in Iraq. When the Iraqi army leaves Dohuk, we will go to Dohuk. All of the refugees from Dohuk city who are in the mountains will return back to their homes when the Iraqis are gone."
Fear of the Iraqi troops is widespread among the Kurdish refugees; the security cordon of Western troops that encouraged refugees from the Zakho area to return does not exist in Dohuk. About 15,000 mainly middle-class refugees from the Zakho area, in what the Turks have set up as a camp for Muslim pilgrims just over the Turkish border, are refusing to go back, saying Iraqi secret and plainclothes police are still in evidence.
Still, American officials are worried about the increase in the last two days of refugees coming into the Zakho camp.
"They can see that conditions in the mountains are not good," said Mr. Maxwell of the State Department. "We're a little afraid the floodgates are starting to open, and we're not quite ready."
"This is the most complicated refugee problem in the world," Mr. Maxwell added, worrying about the relief effort dragging on, perhaps as long as the winter. "We're talking megabucks. Megabucks and megaproblems."

Kurds to Resume Baghdad Talks
 NICOSIA, Cyprus, May 5 (Reuters) -- Iraqi Kurdish leaders will return to Baghdad on Monday for a second round of autonomy talks with President Hussein's Government, a spokesman for the Iraqi Kurdistan Front said today.
In a telephone call to Reuters in Nicosia, the spokesman said the delegation would carry to Baghdad a set of ideas for a political settlement of the Kurdish issue "within the framework of a united, democratic Iraq."
The front is an umbrella group of the main parties seeking self-rule for their region in northern Iraq. Massoud Barzani, leader of the Kurdish Democratic Party, will lead the delegation, the spokesman said. The talks had been scheduled for last week but were postponed.

HEADLINE: Guilty Plea in '88 Theft Of a Rodin Sculpture

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, May 5

 BODY:
An unemployed truck driver has pleaded guilty to an armed robbery in which a 12-inch bronze sculpture was taken from the Rodin Museum here on Nov. 23, 1988.
The truck driver, Stephen Shih, 27 years old, pleaded guilty on Friday to taking the 127-year-old sculpture, "The Mask of the Man with the Broken Nose" by Rodin. During the robbery, three museum guards were handcuffed.
 A plea agreement, in which Mr. Shih also pleaded guilty to the robbery of a supermarket, called for a sentence of 7 1/2 to 15 years in prison. The bust, valued at $75,000, was found undamaged on March 10, 1989, in the basement of an apartment building partly owned by Mr. Shih's mother.

HEADLINE: Tartikoff's TV Valedictory: It's Tougher Now Than Ever

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
NBC was still the No. 1 network last week when the chief architect of its six years of prime-time leadership, Brandon Tartikoff, announced that he was leaving network television to run a movie studio.
Eleven years earlier, when Mr. Tartikoff began running the NBC entertainment division, the network was in a shambles -- a distant, hopeless third in the ratings, the joke of the television industry. 
 The punchline is that NBC's ratings in the 1979-80 television season were 40 percent higher than what the network scored when it won the ratings race this season.
No television executive has ever enjoyed the reputation that Mr. Tartikoff fashioned for himself in pulling NBC out of the ratings cellar in the early 1980's -- and none is likely to have it ever again, several industry executives said after Mr. Tartikoff's appointment as the new chairman of Paramount Pictures.
Although that lofty assessment of Mr. Tartikoff's abilities is widely held in Hollywood, NBC has seen its ratings plunge in the last two seasons even as Mr. Tartikoff was continuing to choose the programs. "Brandon is a brilliant guy," said one senior NBC executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, "but we've been going down the past two years with the same guy flying the plane."
Still, the television business -- especially the power and position of the broadcast networks -- has so fundamentally changed that most executives believe no network programmer can ever again have as much long-term impact as Mr. Tartikoff had. Indeed, although Mr. Tartikoff said last week that "someone with vision could still have impact," he added that "they would have to have the resources and support I got."
When Mr. Tartikoff took charge of NBC's programming in January 1980, the only limits on his prospects were his own creative abilities.
Now, Mr. Tartikoff said, the job is defined by its limits. These include limited ratings expectations because of all the new channels competing for viewers; limited margin for error because of the diminished network reach; limited patience from new corporate managers with no broadcasting background, and limited profits, leading to limited budgets.
 
No Longer a Shock
 "Think about this," Mr. Tartikoff said in a telephone interview from his NBC office in Burbank, Calif. "In my first year as president of entertainment, NBC had only $48 million in profits. That was considered shocking, that a network could be that close to breaking even. Now it is commonplace to think that two networks could get through a year and not make any money."
Indeed, CBS lost money last year and expects to post a loss for the current television year.
The changes have mainly to do with two factors, Mr. Tartikoff said: the "power shift" away from the networks and the overall economics of the business.
The television landscape has been reconfigured in the last decade, he said. "In 1980, cable had not hit criticial mass; neither had VCR's. There was no Fox network."
The last decade saw the emergence of cable stations like the ESPN sports channel and Turner Network Television as the percentage of households with cable television roughly tripled to about 60 percent. In addition, syndicated programs proliferated on independent broadcast stations.
 
'Last Colossus of Programming'
 Even in the less-crowded television arena of 1980, Mr. Tartikoff was not an overnight success.
"Tartikoff was the last colossus of programming," a senior industry executive said. "That's gone forever. There's no patience left in the business. Brandon had two and a half rough years. Nobody could afford to be that patient with a program executive now."
Indeed, NBC's slide in the ratings grew so steep between Mr. Tartikoff's first season and 1983 that managers for NBC's affiliated stations pressed for him to be discharged. But Grant Tinker, then NBC's chairman, had complete faith in Mr. Tartikoff's talent and complete patience with the difficult situation he was then facing. Mr. Tinker shrugged off the complaints of the affiliates.
Mr. Tartikoff said, "I had Grant Tinker supporting me and Fred Silverman teaching me." Mr. Silverman had been the original giant of network programming, having pushed first CBS and then ABC to the top of the ratings before he became corporate president of NBC.
But that quality of talent is not evident at the networks today. Instead, Mr. Tartikoff said, "The networks have all these numbers-crunchers considering how to save money by cutting back on the network service in prime time." He added, "That was unheard of 10 years ago."
So was putting on programs purely because they are cheap to produce, as the networks do now with the spate of so-called reality shows moving into prime time. "Does the world really need 'True Detective' and 'American Detective' in the same season?" Mr. Tartikoff asked.
With programs now costing so much more to produce, some formats are all but closed to programmers, he said.
"Nobody makes 'The A-Team' anymore," Mr. Tartikoff said. "Nobody makes action-adventure anymore because it costs too much and it doesn't sell in syndication. Producers don't want to do an hour show for you anymore. The diversity is not what it used to be."
 
Best Writers and Producers
 Mr. Tartikoff revived NBC's fortunes in the 1980's by recruiting the best writing and producing talent, and giving them good time periods and plenty of time to make a program work.
"That strategy is commonplace now, too," Mr. Tartikoff said. And it has helped drive the costs up. The best writer-producers -- like Steven Bochco ("Hill Street Blues," "L.A. Law") and James Brooks ("The Simpsons") -- now make long-term expensive deals, which include commitments for shows to get on the air.
"People get commitments for three or five series on the air," Mr. Tartikoff said. He noted that Linda Bloodworth, the writer of "Designing Women," received five commitments from CBS.
"She's good, but that means she's crowding out somebody else," he said. "Maybe she's going to crowd out the next Steven Bochco from getting an opportunity on your schedule. ABC has made a lot of these commitments. They are almost in the position we found ourselves in at NBC when we had all this heavy-hitting talent lined up. You start locking yourself in, and then you start cutting loose other talented people."
 
New Economic Realities
 Later this month, Mr. Tartikoff will give a speech that lays out his strategy for dealing with the new economic realities facing television programmers. "We can't keep doing business the way we did 10 years ago," he said. "Instead of letting the corporate bean-counters come up with ideas like cutting the budget for developing series by 20 percent, we have to start asking ourselves if we can do the same programming job with 10 people instead of 30."
Mr. Tartikoff said he would have moved NBC in that direction if he had stayed. Last year, he said he hoped that before he left the network, he would have restored NBC to dominance in the 1990's as he had in the 1980's, retiring "undefeated."
"I guess I'm not quite going out like Sandy Koufax," he said last week. "This is more like Koufax going out with a 15-14 season."

LENGTH: 416 words

HEADLINE: Perils on the Mountaintop

 BODY:
President Bush's irregular heartbeat may not be tied to the pressures of his job and those he visits on himself. But the news that he suffered atrial fibrillation while jogging near Camp David surely serves as a reminder of the uncertainties of life, not least life at the top of the mountain.
You can catch a lot of lightning up there. No man in this country is more exposed politically to sudden runs in the economy, the whims of foreign policy and rapid shifts in public opinion. 
 A mere two months ago, Mr. Bush was riding the crest of a decisive military victory. His approval rating reached an astonishing 90 percent, and even his opponents seemed to have conceded him the 1992 Presidential election. Now the news is filled with the sad plight of the Kurdish refugees, dismal unemployment statistics and depressing evidence that turmoil in the Soviet Union has slowed progress toward arms control.
Reversals of Presidential fortune are hardly new. President Reagan's popularity plunged 20 points when it was learned that he had tried to trade arms for hostages. But Mr. Bush brings to the normal worries of his job an almost abnormal faith in the virtues of perpetual motion. He plays tennis, throws horseshoes and fishes, often one right after another. He virtually lives on Air Force One.
This pace has not always served him well. Late last summer, after Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait, Mr. Bush refused to abandon a scheduled vacation in Maine so that he would not be a prisoner in the White House, as Jimmy Carter appeared to be during the hostage crisis. So he played golf in the rain, every day, literally running from tee to green, and when he got back to Washington he soon lost control of the budget debate and began saying silly things like "read my hips."
Mr. Bush's irregular heartbeat has already inspired renewed interest in Vice President Quayle's qualifications. This could become even more of an issue if Mr. Bush receives anesthesia and the 25th Amendment is invoked. Yet those worries are only part of a larger concern about vulnerability -- not the vulnerability of the Presidency itself, but of those mortals who occupy it.
The White House, as usual, has tried to be reassuring, and one aide went to great lengths to tell reporters that Mr. Bush busily worked on his briefcase materials in the helicopter that took him to the hospital. But it would be even more reassuring if Mr. Bush heard a different refrain, the one about moderation in all things.

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
'To See Oursels . . .'

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The American press takes pride in courageous scrutiny of those who hold power in our society. Today the press should be summoning up the courage to look at itself.
Self-examination is urgently needed in our business after our performance in the Persian Gulf war. Most of the press was not a detached observer of the war, much less a critical one. It was a claque applauding the American generals and politicians in charge. 
 In the press I include television, its most powerful component now and the most egregious official lap dog during the war. For the most part the broadcast networks simply transmitted official images of a neat, painless war. Or worse: put a gloss of independent corroboration on those false images.
And they were false. The officials told us belatedly that only a tiny percentage of all those explosives rained on Iraq were actually like the images we saw: bombs neatly zipping down the chimneys of military targets. No one could have guessed that from the utterly unskeptical press.
Nor could most Americans have understood, from their press, that the allied bombs were destroying the civilian infrastructure of a modern society. Early on reports from Baghdad said that city of four million was without electricity, running water, sewage. But our press hardly noticed.
There was scarcely a mention either of Iraqi deaths. The only American journalist I saw who wrote consistently about those casualties was Colin Campbell of The Atlanta Journal and Constitution. To most of the press it was as if Iraqis did not matter -- as if they were not fully human.
But perhaps the most dangerous shortcoming of the press was its failure to keep asking whether the war was necessary or wise. Once the bombing started, that fundamental political question was mostly put aside.
A savage attack on the performance of the press in the war appears in the May issue of Harper's Magazine. It is by the editor, Lewis H. Lapham, and is entitled "Trained seals and sitting ducks."
"The bombardment of Baghdad began on Jan. 17," Mr. Lapham writes, "and within a matter of hours the newspaper and television correspondents abandoned any claim or pretension to the power of independent thought . . .
"The televised images defined the war as a game, and the military command in Riyadh was careful to approve only those bits and pieces of film that sustained the illusion of a playing field (safe, bloodless and abstract) . . ."
Mr. Lapham takes a conspiratorial view of President Bush's whole performance from the time Iraq invaded Kuwait last August. He suggests that the President decided almost at once to go to war, in order to control oil prices, revive the U.S. military budget and divert attention from economic recession at home.
"But none of these happy events could be brought to pass," he writes, "unless a credulous and jingoistic press could convince the American people that Hussein was a villain as monstrous as Adolf Hitler, that his army was all but invincible, that the fate of nations (not to mention the destiny of mankind) trembled in the balance."
And that is what the press did, Mr. Lapham charges. "The Administration well understood that the media couldn't afford to offend the profoundly conservative sympathies of their prime-time audience, and so it knew that it could rely on the media's complicity in almost any deception dressed up in patriotic costume."
The Lapham article is hyperbolic. But it includes much that should make editors and reporters and columnists think about what they did during the war -- and consider whether it was indeed credulous and jingoistic.
Of course the press was at a terrible disadvantage in its on-site coverage of the war. The military, breaking with long American tradition, barred correspondents from the front except for small, controlled pools. Moreover, the public was in no mood to hear complaints from the press.
But the control and the censorship, outrageous as they were, cannot excuse the compliant, unquestioning attitude of the American press. We glorified war and accepted its political premise, forsaking the independence and skepticism that justify freedom of the press.
