HEADLINE: Hatcher Begins Battle to Regain Spotlight in Gary

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARY, Ind., May 5

 BODY:
On the streets of this faded steel city, many people still refer to Richard G. Hatcher as Mayor, almost four years after he was voted out of office, and they pronounce the title and name as one word: "MayorHatcher."
For some, it sounds like a curse, for others a password to a proud past. 
 Mr. Hatcher, 57 years old, became one of the country's first black mayors of a major city when he was elected in 1967, and held office for two sometimes stormy decades until he was defeated in what some say was a referendum on his combative personality. It was a style forged in the civil rights movment.
 
Seeking the Spotlight
 Now, like a former boxing champion eager to recapture the glory of the spotlight, Mr. Hatcher is running for his old job in the election on Tuesday.
"He likes being Mayor," said Ronald Cohen, a history professor at Indiana University Northwest here. "It gives him an identity, a platform, which he hasn't had for the last several years."
It was a shaky platform. Mr. Hatcher presided over the city at a time when much of urban America was undergoing painful and profound change: disappearing factory jobs, fewer Federal dollars, rising crime and disease, dying steel mills and middle-class flight, black and white.
Today, much of Gary's business district is lined with boarded buildings and out-of-work people. And opinions have remained divided.
"People were tired of Hatcher; that's why he lost," said Jacqueline Jones, a 37-year-old businesswoman. "They were tired of the city going down, down, down. They were tired of him blaming his problems on somebody else. We don't want to go back."
 
Hatcher's Core Support
 But Mr. Hatcher has retained a core of intensely loyal followers, many of whom remember when life in Gary was heavily segregated and politics was "just for white folks," in the words of an elderly man who was waiting to hear "MayorHatcher" speak at a church last week.
To them, Gary's problems in Mr. Hatcher's five terms were part of a nationwide decline of the inner city. They said Gary suffered more, perhaps because it relied so much on one industry: steel. Steel was why Gary was founded in 1906, they say, and steel was why it was suffering now.
In his early days Mr. Hatcher was a symbol of progress, of black people's getting a piece of the pie, even as the pie began to crumble. He became a bright star in the national movement for black political empowerment.
"I think the people of Gary see him as a historical figure," said James Lane, the author of a city history. "The question is whether they think his time has passed and it's time for new strategies or whether we need to revive some of that spirit of the 60's."
Many people said they thought that question was answered in 1987 when Mr. Hatcher was ousted by a low-key, nonconfrontational black politician, Thomas V. Barnes, in the Democratic primary. Mr. Barnes is running for a second four-year term.
Since Mr. Hatcher's defeat, there has been a wave of black politicians, like Mr. Barnes, who won high office and headlines for their philosophy and their politics, which are perceived to be more moderate. These include Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia and Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York.
 
'Crossover Politicians'
 "I call them crossover politicians," Mr. Hatcher said in a recent interview. "In an effort to be more acceptable to the white majority, they are unwilling to address, at least publicly, those issues that are considered as black issues: poverty, racial and economic justice, housing, adequate health care. Those are fairly universal issues, but they are still afraid to address them."
He added, "My question is, how dear is the price they are willing to pay?"
Mr. Hatcher, in his shirt sleeves and loosened tie, was sitting in his Gary home as he discussed his comeback campaign and his life out of office. He has spent the time teaching at a university and practicing law.
On a nearby wall was a photograph of the fiery Indiana basketball coach, Bobby Knight, whom Mr. Hatcher said he "loves and respects" for standing firmly for his beliefs, popular or not. It is a picture of the well-known incident in which Mr. Knight flung a chair across the court during a game.
"I believe there is some indication that the country is ready for more progressive politics than that which we've seen during most of the 1980's," Mr. Hatcher said. "There are people who represent progressive politics and their presence seems to be growing."
He smiled and said, "We'll soon find out whether that trend is evident here in Gary."
On Tuesday the voters will choose among nine candidates in the Democratic primary. In this city, winning the Democratic primary is tantamount to being elected.
 
The Field for the Race
 Aside from Mayor Barnes and Mr. Hatcher, only two other candidates are thought to be contenders: Dozier T. Allen, the head of the area's welfare office, and Scott King, a lawyer and the only white in the race in this city that is more than 80 percent black.
Gary's problems are numerous and entrenched. Many banks and businesses abandoned the city over the last 20 years for suburban shopping malls.
White flight, already a steady stream to the suburbs, became a flood soon after Mr. Hatcher's first mayoral victory. After he won the Democratic primary, hundreds of white voters switched parties and voted for the Republican in the general election. After Mr. Hatcher won that race, too, more "For Sale" signs went up.
Thirty years ago, Gary's population flirted with 180,000; today it is 116,000.
Much like Detroit, Gary is now a mostly black city surrounded by mostly white suburbs and towns and the relationship between the city and the surrounding communities has often been strained, especially while Mr. Hatcher was Mayor, his critics contend. Mr. Hatcher often feuded with Gary's neighbors over the operation and improvement of an airport and other development issues. Sometimes the feuding took on racial overtones.
"He chased a lot of people away with all that black power talk," said Jesse Pruitt, 63, who said he used to support Mr. Hatcher.
John Key, 33, who supports Mr. Hatcher, said, "If there were confrontations with the suburbs, Mayor Hatcher didn't initiate them. He only told the truth."
 
The Confrontational Image
 Mr. Hatcher said he does not deserve his image as militant and confrontational.
"I'm very mild-mannered," he said. "I never raise my voice. I don't scream at people. But I say what I believe."
Mr. Barnes built much of his successful campaign around a pledge to reach out to the surrounding communities. The theme of his administration has been "stressing the positive."
It was the decline of the steel industry that hit Gary the hardest. The city's biggest employer is the USX Corporation, formerly United States Steel. About 7,500 people work there now; in the early 1980's, there were 25,000, and in the early 1970's, about 35,000.
Beyond the ghostly business district, the scene is far from bleak in this city on the southern end of Lake Michigan. The working-class neighborhoods are filled with neat bungalows and lawns. White-collar workers, many from Chicago, a 30-minute drive away, have begun buying up the large homes that overlook the beach and lake.
But Gary's heart remains sick, and it is divided over Mr. Hatcher's campaign.
"I wish he'd go away," Mrs. Jones said. "We don't need him. His day is over."
But Claudia Terry, a secretary, said: "I love MayorHatcher. If I could, I'd vote for the man three times. He supports his people. What's wrong with that?"

HEADLINE: BUSINESS SCENE;
Recovery Awaits Housing Revival

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
AS the recession enters its 10th month, all eyes are on home construction. When Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, talks of a recovery, he is counting on new-home construction, particularly the building of single-family houses, to give the economy its first lift. Other economists share his view that without the stimulus of home building, the recession could drag on.
Will home construction revive soon, as Mr. Greenspan hopes? No one is in hotter pursuit of the answer to this question than David Seiders, chief economist at the National Association of Home Builders, and he says, "The demand may be there for new homes, but the builders may not be able to get the financing to build them." 
 In sum, a bullish forecast -- even from a trade association yearning for an upturn in construction -- is hard to come by, although some hopeful statistics have appeared. Sales of older single-family houses have risen sharply in recent weeks, and so have purchases of newly built houses that had gone unsold for a while.
As sales pick up, the inventory of homes awaiting buyers shrinks and the day approaches when builders will sense enough demand to resume building. Perhaps the inventory is low enough now. It totals 2.76 million single-family houses, down from three million last year. By comparison, the inventory averaged 2.25 million in the mid-1980's, when housing construction was robust.
"What we have is a housing sector going from being a drag on the economy to being somewhat of a positive," said Robert Giordano, director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
That's the good news. The bad news is that housing construction itself -- that is, the number of groundbreakings for single-family houses and apartments -- has declined steadily from 1.1 million units at an annual rate last September to 900,000 in March, the most recent figure. Permits to build houses soon have risen slightly in the last two months, but construction has not.
When the turnaround does come, changing demographics will make the potential for a residential construction boom less than in the 1980's, because fewer households are being formed. Residential construction groundbreakings, or starts, hit 1.8 million in 1986, but the upper limit in the early 1990's is likely to be only 1.4 million units a year, said Robert Murray, an economist at the F. W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill. which collects such data.
What's more, while the inventory of unsold single-family homes is shrinking, the vacancy rate in apartments is quite high, discouraging construction. And multifamily buildings represent roughly 20 percent of total residential construction starts.
Beyond these obstacles, the biggest one is the difficulty builders are having when they apply for a construction loan. During the 1980's, when home prices kept rising across the country, lenders considered almost any builder a good risk because they were confident the house being built could be sold for more than enough to cover the loan.
Now, with price trends uncertain, banks are demanding that builders have enough spare savings to pay off construction loans if the houses they finance cannot be sold at high enough prices. Many potential builders cannot meet the new requirements, no matter what the demand might be for their projects, said Robert Dugger, chief economist for the American Bankers Association.
"It used to be that there was so much demand for housing that it did not matter what the builder's net worth was," Mr. Dugger said. "The house would sell, and the bank knew it."
Still, an upturn in home construction -- with single-family houses leading the way -- has often marked the beginning of the end of American recessions. Such construction is not by itself enough to reverse a recession, accounting as it does for only about 5 percent of the nation's annual economic activity. But home sales and construction, dependent as they are on lending, usually respond more quickly than other industries to the Fed's efforts to push down interest rates, a traditional recession remedy.
As construction rebounds, so do orders for the appliances and furnishings that go into new homes and, if all goes according to past scripts, purchasing agents at hundreds of companies outside the construction industry will regain confidence that business at their companies will also pick up.
So they will begin to stockpile goods, and production everywhere will rise. "That's the real kicker in a recovery," said Albert T. Sommers, a senior economist at the Conference Board. "And home construction is the leader in this process."
It is the visible signal of a new willingness to purchase -- a signal that has not blossomed yet.

HEADLINE: Small-Business Ownership Poll

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
Despite an increase recently in the number of women who own businesses, most small businesses formed in the 1980's were owned by middle-aged men, a survey released today said.
The nationwide telephone survey, conducted in mid- March for I.B.M., polled 400 companies, each with fewer than 50 employees. 
 In addition to finding that 81 percent of the businesses were owned by men, the survey found that the owners' average age was 43. It also said 72 percent of the owners had started their business instead of purchasing an existing company and that 38 percent of the owners had been dismissed or laid off from their previous jobs.
Thirty-eight percent had college degrees, and nearly 70 percent started or bought their businesses alone.
The survey found that 44 percent were Republicans, 20 percent independents and 20 percent Democrats.

HEADLINE: CAREERS;
M.B.A.'s Told To Look Into 'Green' Jobs

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
WITH jobs harder to find for new M.B.A.'s, placement directors work harder to find spots for them, and some are looking at environmental organizations.
"I can show them many opportunities in the environmental field," Susan Cohn, an assistant placement officer at New York University's Stern Graduate School of Business, said last week. She said she might be among the first counselors at leading graduate business schools to focus on opportunities in the "green" area. 
 The environment is a niche many M.B.A.'s do not think about, she explained, because there has been so much emphasis on engineers and scientists in the field.
It is obvious that environmental organizations, ranging from Federal and state governments to public service organizations to private companies, need the help of environmental specialists including lawyers. Less obvious, she contends, is that environmental organizations need business school graduates to do administrative work -- accounting, finance, marketing, public relations, personnel and other functions where skilled management can make a difference.
Furthermore, top management attitudes and actions in the environnmental area "can make or break companies," she believes, explaining that many top managers today are not knowledgeable about environmental problems and need advice. The bottom line can often be affected, she said, mentioning the Exxon Valdez oil spill as an example.
Miss Cohn, a 1982 graduate of Hampshire College in Amherst, Mass., majored in environmental studies. She also obtained certificates in organic gardening and livestock management from the University of California at Santa Cruz.
Armed with these credentials she found a job in Alaska. "It involved economic development related to agriculture and fisheries," she said. "I spent three years in a town called Shungnak, on the Kobuk River, near Kotzebue. The aim was to teach people how to handle their jobs, giving consideration to the environment, as well as to develop job opportunities for Eskimos."
Then she returned East for a master's degree in career counseling at New York University.
"I got a job at the N.Y.U. graduate school of business to work on career development last April," she said, "and I looked at niches where jobs might be found for M.B.A.'s. Students desperately need to explore new job areas."
She has been finding opportunities in the environmental area, and at the same time she has been compiling what she calls the first "Green Directory" for M.B.A.'s, naming companies and advocacy groups interested in the environment.
The timing was ripe, she said. Already some future M.B.A.'s at N.Y.U. are gaining experience. One has joined Ernst & Young, the accounting firm, where she will do marketing projects for its environmental consulting group from now until next fall. Another is working at Earth Work magazine to develop marketing strategy.
Salomon Inc., the investment firm, has hired one business-school student to do environmental research while he continues to take courses at night.
Miss Cohn said also that five students were interning this summer in New York at J. Ottman Consulting Inc., which specializes in environmental marketing.
Procter & Gamble recently hired a student partly because of his environmental interest and knowledge, she said. His summer internship will be in Hong Kong.
"Renew America, an advocacy group in Washington, is looking for an executive director," she said. "That could be a good job for an M.B.A."
Many large companies, she said, already have vice presidents in charge of environmental affairs, like Robert Holland at Colgate-Palmolive. Small and mid-sized companies probably need better trained staff members with a knowledge of the environment, and they are beginning to hire a few experts, she said. Many business-school graduates already have a scientific or engineering background to which they could quickly add some environmental expertise -- an idea for currently unemployed M.B.A.'s.
At N.Y.U.'s graduate business school, Prof. Michael Darling has added study about the environment into both a basic marketing course and a product development course. Also, Prof. Thomas Gladwin will teach a course called global environmental resource management in the fall.
As in other relatively new career fields, there are few environmental textbooks for business schools, Miss Cohn said. This summer she plans to teach a course on careers and the environment at N.Y.U.'s School of Continuing Education, relying on expert outsiders as speakers.
She contends that in a generation or so, top business managers -- vice presidents and chief executives -- will need some background in environmental problems to lead companies more effectively. Young M.B.A. candidates getting environmental knowlege now will have an advantage.

HEADLINE: TEHERAN COURTING WESTERN EUROPE

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, May 5

 BODY:
The slogan at Teheran's main airport that was coined by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini proclaims "No East, No West," meaning that revolutionary Iran does not need either. A parade of Western European ministers trooping by it on their way to town these days seems to offer a different message.
Since the Ayatollah's death and the decline of Soviet power, diplomats here say, the less strident Government of President Hashemi Rafsanjani has come to acknowledge that there is no apparent alternative to the West as Iran seeks money and expertise to rebuild after its 1980-88 war with Iraq. 
 Shortly after Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France left here over the weekend, officials began preparing to receive his West German counterpart, Hans-Dietrich Genscher. Britain has restored relations that were broken because of the Ayatollah's death sentence on the author Salman Rushdie.
But there are caveats to the opening. "Iran still does not have a certificate of approval by Western credit agencies," a diplomat said, so investment is hampered.
 
Line Is Drawn With U.S.
 As Iran courts Western Europe, it draws a line at overtures toward the United States, still viewed by revolutionaries and in the official propaganda as the Great Satan. "Down With Israel, Down With U.S.A.," says a slogan at the entrance to the Foreign Ministry.
"They see Western Europe as much less politically sensitive," a Western diplomat said. "They see they have to go to the West for the large-scale investment they need for internal regeneration. They cannot afford to have it from the U.S., so they go to Western Europe and Japan."
Teheran lays the blame for continued hostility at Washington's door.
"The policy of the United States toward us has not changed," Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati said at a news conference on Saturday. "So we do not think there is any different climate in our relations."
"Iran," President Rafsanjani told university students recently, "is not thinking of restoring relations with the United States, which keeps on talking about it and creating problems."
 
Hostage Issue Cited
 The view contrasts with that of the United States and officials of other Western nations, who say Teheran itself is creating the problems by refusing to put pressure on the forces it controls in Lebanon to release American and other Western hostages.
But here, where radical opponents of the Government hold to Ayatollah Khomeini's xenophobic view, the relationship with Washington is infused with complex issues and demands by both sides that seem to preclude rapid improvement.
Teheran sees Washington as fundamentally hostile to the idea of Islamic revolutionary rule, Diplomats and analysts here say the United States maintains its categorization of Iran as a supporter of international terrorism and refuses to press Israel to release Shiite Muslim prisoners.
 
Stand During Gulf War
 The relationship has other shadings, the diplomats and analysts said. "During the gulf war, Iran really wanted the Americans to their dirty work for them by getting rid of Saddam Hussein," one envoy said, speaking on condition of anonymity.
While protesting the foreign military presence in the Persian Gulf region, Iran gave assurances that it would support economic sanctions against Iraq -- and implicitly support the American-led coalition against Baghdad -- while the authorities dismissed calls by Islamic hard-liners for a holy war against the United States and its allies.
Moreover, Washington's huge display of military power and the certainty with which it destroyed Iraq's regional might "produced a different awareness of what America can do," the envoy said.
He said that "the perception changed from the bumbling incompetence" of the failed effort to rescue American hostages during the Carter Administration and the Iran-contra scandal "to something that demanded more respect."
 
Hostage Issue an Obstacle
 The immediate obstacle to any new cordiality is the continued captivity of Western hostages. Iranian officials have made clear that they are not prepared to order the Western hostages released until their Iranian-backed militia captors in Lebanon secure the face-saving freedom of Shiite Muslims held by Israel. In both Iran and Syria -- the two nations with the greatest influence on the hostage-takers -- officials believe that the United States can easily press Israel to release the Shiite prisoners but has not done so.
Iran, Mr. Velayati said, believes "that all hostages should be released from Lebanon or any country."
The significance of the Iranian stance, a Western diplomat said, is that "the price is now established: the Western hostages will get out if there is a properly arranged release" of Shiite Muslims from Israel, which holds them partly in an effort to secure the freedom of Israeli pilots held in Lebanon.
Here and in other parts of the region, officials believe that the release of the hostages would lead to a deal on Iranian assets held by the United States since the 1979 takeover of the American Embassy here and to other steps toward normalization. "It could all happen quickly," an envoy said, "but I wouldn't hold my breath."

HEADLINE: To Cantonese, A Little Graft Is Forgivable

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CANTON

 BODY:
Lei Yu charges into the room, his extraordinary energy a fitting reflection of one of China's fastest-changing cities.
Mr. Lei, the Deputy Mayor of this frenetic and prosperous city, is one of a growing number of sharp and shrewd local officials who shun the Communist bureaucrat's life of long lunches and snoozes. Some people see him as a local hero who bucks the system; others accuse him of glaringly corrupt practices. 
 Guangdong province, of which Canton is the capital, is famous both for bucking the system and for its corruption, so it is not surprising that after being removed from a senior post for violating regulations, Mr. Lei has been able to climb his way back into one of the most powerful and busiest jobs in town.
"Compared with us, the life of New York's Mayor is light and easy," said Mr. Lei, 56 years old, who typically leaves home at 7 A.M. and returns about midnight.
 
Local Booster
 Mr. Lei does not campaign for election, but he lobbies for Canton's needs -- like a new stock market, foreign bank branches, greater efficiency in enterprises, higher exports and more economic restructuring. Leaders like him are rare in China, and he seems highly regarded and popular.
"He's very clearly a reformist, full of ideas of what he wants to do," a foreign analyst here said. "He's someone who is a real activist for getting things done."
It is a tribute to his ability and political skills that Mr. Lei has been able to return to power after being disgraced and dismissed from his post as administrator of Hainan Island in 1985. Mr. Lei and his assistant had taken advantage of the island's special privileges to import foreign cars duty-free and resell them at a high profit on the mainland. They ultimately approved the import of nearly 80,000 cars, in what became one of the biggest scandals of China's reform era.
The scheme was widely denounced as an example of corruption at the time, but Mr. Lei apparently did not benefit personally. On Hainan Island, which has since split away from the rest of Guangdong and been made a province by itself, Mr. Lei is remembered as a folk hero who took advantage of every loophole to buoy the local economy and paid with his job for his dedication to his constituency.
"All men are fallible," Mr. Lei said, dismissing the incident. "I'm not a saint. When I make a mistake, I correct it."
 
A Pragmatic Decision
 But early in 1988, less than three years after the car scandal, the province government decided that Mr. Lei's talent was more important than the tarnish of his recent past. Guangdong, which is not necessarily bothered by an official flouting the rules from the capital, welcomed him back to the fold.
"The mountain is high and the emperor is far away" goes a saying that many people say explains why Guangdong province has been able to shape a freewheeling economy -- it is simply too far from Beijing for the national Government to maintain close scrutiny. Guangdong is already China's economic showcase with growth of about 10 percent last year, twice the national rate.
But Mr. Lei denies that the province's leaders scurry around the guidelines set down by Beijing.
"It is not that we don't respond to the call of the party Central Committee, but that our cadres should not be the kind who blindly obey," Mr. Lei said. "If our cadres are not resourceful and they appear helpless in the face of something, would you call them good cadres? If they can't do anything, would you like to have them? I wouldnot."
Guangdong, however, still has a great deal of catching up to do if it wants to move beyond the level of a developing country. Although per-capita income in Guangdong was more than 40 percent higher than the national figure last year, it was only $430.
 
Progress, Not Perfection
 Not everything here moves as fast as Mr. Lei and his colleagues would like, and many economic changes, for example in prices and housing, have been adopted only slowly in Canton.
Moreover, hard-liners say that negative Western influences, like pornography, prostitution and other crimes, are much more evident in Guangdong than elsewhere in China. Prostitutes linger at the city's best hotels looking for customers, and taxis now have gratings to protect drivers from robbers.
As problems like these irritate local leaders, Canton continues to compete with nearby cities, such as Huizhou, Shenzhen and Zhuhai, for foreign investments. Mr. Lei adds that the entire province is battling with Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines for consumer markets in the United States and other prosperous countries.
"There is a Chinese saying: Sailing against the current, you must forge ahead or be driven back," Mr. Lei said, his eyes dancing about. "The present reality is just like this. Aside from stopping, if you drop your speed, you will fall behind."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Concern on Bush and Rates Helps Send the Dollar Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed lower yesterday after fluctuating in a session driven by concerns about President Bush's health and interest rates.
Analysts said worries about President Bush's weekend hospitalization for an irregular heartbeat after jogging put a damper on the dollar at its opening in Europe and in domestic trading. But after the President returned to the White House yesterday and was reported to be doing well, the currency rebounded. 
 The dollar, seen as a haven in times of international strife, was helped by reports of unrest in the Soviet Union. But concerns about interest rates drove the currency back down.
Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager with Bank of New York, said the German mark started to climb as the market speculated that interest rates in Germany would remain stable while rates in other countries would decline.
Mr. Ryan called the dollar's finish "an overreaction on the downside."
High interest rates lend support to a currency, so rising rates in Germany would be a positive sign for the mark and falling rates elsewhere would undermine other currencies.
The dollar fell to 1.7325 marks in New York, from 1.74825 marks late on Friday.
The financial markets were closed yesterday in Tokyo for a national holiday, but the Japanese yen was traded in the United States and Europe. The dollar fell to 138.19 yen in New York, from 138.85 yen late on Friday, and in European trading, the dollar was quoted at 138.70 yen.
Markets were also closed for a holiday in London. The British pound gained ground in United States and European trading, rising to $1.7100 in New York, from $1.6940 late on Friday. On the Continent, sterling was quoted at $1.6990, compared with $1.6965 in London late on Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Friday, included: 1.4675 Swiss francs, down from 1.4760; 5.8625 Swiss francs, down from 5.9125; 1,282.25 Italian lire, down from 1,294.75, and 1.15055 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15125.

HEADLINE: Big Deal That Poses Little Threat

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

 BODY:
The acquisition of NCR finally seems to give A.T.& T. the chance for success in the computer business that it has long craved. With its huge size, vast telephone network and the technological resources of its Bell Laboratories, A.T.& T. would seem to have the potential to become one of the successful information technology companies of the next century.
But most competitors say they do not fear the phone company's thrusts into computers and see the merger as merely providing a new owner for NCR. 
 Many computer-industry executives and analysts say the $7.4 billion acquisition of the NCR Corporation by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is of more interest for its Wall Street maneuvering.
"It's not a big event," said William N. Joy, a co-founder of Sun Microsystems Inc. "It just means there's one less computer company."
NCR, while profitable, solidly managed and strong in certain areas, is not usually considered one of the companies that shape the industry, like I.B.M., Digital Equipment, Apple Computer and Sun.
NCR, the nation's fifth-largest computer company, could become somewhat stronger with access to A.T.& T.'s financial resources and technology. But many analysts say NCR will be destroyed because the task of merging the two companies will divert its attention from computers and cause its best talent to go elsewhere. The five months that have elapsed since A.T.& T. made its bid may already have scared off potential customers.
"Every single computer executive I talk to that competes with NCR is dying for this to happen," said George Colony, president of Forrester Research, a consulting concern in Cambridge, Mass. "Nobody fears the combined entity at all."
Indeed, electronics industry mergers are notorious for their lack of success. The merger of Burroughs and Sperry into the Unisys Corporation was supposed to create a company with the critical mass to challenge I.B.M. Unisys has lost money.
The Hewlett-Packard Company's acquisition of Apollo gave it the leading market share in engineering work stations -- but only for a year. Hewlett then stumbled while trying to digest Apollo, and Sun retook the lead.
Similarly, the International Business Machines Corporation's acquisition of the Rolm Corporation was supposed to make Big Blue a force in telecommunications. It did not work out; I.B.M. eventually sold Rolm's development and production operations to the German electronics giant Siemens-Nixdorf, though I.B.M. still has an interest in the telecommunications company.
Robert M. Kavner, head of A.T.& T.'s computer operations, and the person behind the NCR acquisition, realizes that history is against him. After a speech at a computer conference in San Francisco in December, he was asked to name some high-technology mergers that have worked. Mr. Kavner acknowledged that he could not name one.
But the merger makes sense for A.T.& T. After losing as much as $3 billion in the last decade in the computer business, the company realized it was not going to succeed in computers on its own.
Buying NCR seems a more acceptable solution than pulling out of the industry altogether. With the acquisition, A.T.& T. obtains a profitable $6 billion computer business with a management team that will be allowed to run the combined computer business after the merger.
In A.T.& T.'s strategic vision, telecommunications and computers are merging, with a few large companies likely to provide complete information systems to large corporations in the next century. If it does not succeed in computers, A.T.& T. fears, it could become a second-rate company.
The computer industry is already undergoing a consolidation, and some analysts predict that it will wind up with only a dozen or so large companies. Despite NCR's protests that it would have been better off on its own, some analysts say the Dayton, Ohio, company might have had to find a partner eventually.
The combination "recognizes the realities of what's going on in the industry," said Ulric Weil of Weil & Associates, a Washington consulting firm. He called the merger positive for both companies.
 
Based on Unix
 A.T.& T. officials also argue that NCR is perhaps the best match for the telephone company. NCR's computer strategy is based on the phone company's Unix operating system, a basic set of commands for controlling computers. NCR also has strong sales overseas, where A.T.& T. has virtually no presence.
And NCR is heavily involved in the type of computer business in which A.T.& T. wants to specialize, one that can take advantage of the phone company's strengths in communications. NCR is a leader in supermarket point-of-sale systems and automated teller machines. Both involve networks of communicating computers.
"They're in the right kind of computer business," said Ian M. Ross, president of Bell Laboratories. "They are not in the standard box business; they are in the transaction business."
Dr. Ross said A.T.& T. could provide technologies for NCR to incorporate into its point-of-sale and automated teller networks, like speech recognition, image manipulation and wireless communications.
 
Successful on Its Own
 NCR has been one of the most successful of the old-line mainframe companies in shifting to the use of computers based on microprocessors and standard software. The company is developing a product line that will range from tiny notebook computers to multimillion-dollar supercomputers, all based on the Intel Corporation's microprocessors.
Executives say this line will give the company a chance to become an even larger force in this decade.
"NCR doesn't need A.T.& T.; it's the other way around," said Morris C. Enfield, a former research manager at NCR.
There is concern that many of NCR's best salesmen and engineers will leave if things go sour. NCR's chief executive, Charles E. Exley Jr., who is credited with much of the company's success, plans to retire after the merger is completed but will stay on as a consultant.
A.T.& T. has had a transition committee planning ways to avoid such disruptions. The company has said that NCR would remain fairly autonomous and that its executives would run the computer business. It is expected that NCR will have a separate board, made up of NCR and A.T.& T. executives.
NCR will be able to take whatever pieces of A.T.& T.'s computer business it wants and jettison the rest. Some A.T.& T. computer division employees have been moved to other parts of the company in preparation for substantial cutbacks. Still, some A.T.& T. managers will be moved into the NCR management team, and some A.T.& T. products are expected to be carried forward by NCR.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A.T.& T. and NCR executives clasped hands yesterday after signing a merger agreement that ended the pursuit of the computer maker that A.T.& T. began some five months ago. From left were: Robert E. Allen, the chairman of A.T.& T.; Charles E. Exley Jr., the chairman of NCR, and Gilbert Williamson, the president of NCR. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Productivity Down, Then Up, as U.S. Errs

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
In one of the most embarrassing statistical mistakes in recent memory, the Labor Department announced late today that American business productivity was up, not down, as it had said in the morning.
Productivity advanced at a 1 percent annual pace in the first quarter of the year, the agency said, instead of dropping nine-tenths of 1 percent as it reported originally. 
 The mistake, which the Labor Department said it could not fully correct until Wednesday, occurred when a single figure was mistransmitted and in effect poisoned much of a detailed 20-page statistical release on the efficiency of the nation's economy.
"This has never happened before," said an analyst at the Bureau of Labor Statistics this evening. "It's caused quite a to-do."
He added that the Bureau of Economic Analysis, a Commerce Department unit that collects the basic data, "gave us the wrong number" in sending it on to the statistics bureau, which makes productivity estimates. However, a statistics bureau spokeswoman, Constance DiCesare, insisted that it was not the fault of the Commerce Department unit.
Although productivity is the ultimate determinant of a nation's standard of living, these figures are not of high importance to Wall Street bond traders, and the statistics bureau's personnel said they had had no complaints about the figures. It was not clear why. The bureau did not formally disclose the error until after the New York markets had closed for the day.
The figures for manufacturing, which cover 20 percent of the economy, were not affected by the error, the statistics bureau said. These showed that productivity in factories generally and in durable goods manufacturing both fell at a pace of nine-tenths of 1 percent and that productivity in factories producing nondurables fell four-tenths.
The fundamental error, a statistics bureau expert said, involved the valuation for owner-occupied housing, an imputation made for purposes of assembling the gross national product that needs to be subtracted out to make productivity calculations. "We pulled out too much" as a result of the mistake, he added.
This expert said he did not know whether the breakdown came in a telephone conversation or by facsimile machine, but he added that "people are already thinking of another level of checks" that might need to be introduced.
At the same time, however, it appeared odd to some economists that overall business activity outside farms could have climbed as much as 1 percent, the revised and assertedly correct figure, when manufacturing was so weak. This implied, one said, that productivity in services had soared when there was no evidence that this had occurred.
 
Statistical Quirk Seen
 The most likely explanation, said H. Erich Heinemann, an economist at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, was a statistical quirk mainly involving the Persian Gulf war combined with a huge $4.3 billion annualized jump in brokerage commissions.
He said that during the war foreign travel to the United States dropped more than overseas travel by Americans, shrinking the nation's net travel surplus at a rate of $3.7 billion. Lower net foreign spending raises consumption of services.
Today's mistake came on the first business day after Janet L. Norwood, Commissioner of Labor Statistics for the last 12 years, told a Congressional panel that she had informed the Bush Administration that she would not accept reappointment to another term.

HEADLINE: Footnote in Dinkins's Plan: $1 Billion Property Tax Rise

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Even as he proposes huge service cuts and tax increases to balance New York City's budget next year, Mayor David N. Dinkins is planning on the financial help of annual property tax increases in the years after that.
The increases total $1 billion in the two fiscal years from July 1992 through June 1994. They are in a footnote of a plan Mr. Dinkins distributed at Gracie Mansion on Saturday, as he met with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, union leaders and state and local officials to head off the most painful measures to balance his budget in the fiscal year that begins on July 1. 
 Business leaders said that the new proposals for tax increases were devastating, coming at the same time as proposals for extraordinary service cuts like turning off one in four street lights, reducing street cleaning and cutting money for libraries.
"They are proposing service cuts and tax increases at the same time they are trying to keep business in the city during a recession," said Ronald K. Shelp, president of the New York City Partnership, a business advisory group. "It is a very mixed message."
 
No Holding the Line
 Mr. Dinkins already plans to raise taxes more than $1 billion this coming fiscal year, including as much as $800 million in property taxes, despite an outcry from the real-estate industry, homeowners, and the leaders of the City Council, which can reject them.
The administration first proposed tax increases in January. After intensive lobbying by business leaders -- including some of Mr. Dinkins's own economic advisers -- he said he would hold the line on taxes next year, despite worsening economic conditions.
But while some of his advisers suggested a moratorium on property tax increases in years after that, the footnote in the financial plan said that the administration's planning assumed a $527 million property tax increase in the fiscal year beginning in July 1992, and another $546 million increase the following year. In 1994, the tax would go up $243 million more.
Carol O'Cleireacain, the city's Finance Director, said that the tax increases were being disclosed now to give businesses a clear picture of the city's finances.
 
'Hope It Doesn't Come to Pass'
 "The business people have used us for some kind of certainty," she said. "Unless the property market turns around, this is the best estimate we can make at this time. We certainly hope it doesn't come to pass."
Mark V. Shaw, the finance director of the City Council, said that each annual increase roughly meant a $100-a-year tax increase on a $220,000 house.
"To talk about tax increases in the out years only sends the wrong message," Mr. Shaw said. He said the Council favored continued "downsizing" of city government.
According to the real-estate industry, the proposed rates of increase would be 7 percent in the year starting July 1992, 6 percent the following year and 2 percent the year after that.
Steven Spinola, the president of the Real Estate Board of New York, said that next year, when assessment increases are combined with rate increases, property taxes would go up between 15 and 25 percent.
Business officials said that nearly $3 billion in city and state taxes had been imposed in the last two years and could cost the city tens of thousands of jobs.
Rather than listing the increases as new taxes, city budget officials counted them as regular tax revenue, and put them in a footnote. This enabled Mr. Dinkins to present a financial plan that showed the city's budget being close to balanced in 1992 and 1993. Previous estimates had showed gaps of more than $1 billion in both those years.
Earlier this year, the administration was widely criticized for including "implicit" property tax increases without fully disclosing them, except in technical support documents. The numbers were included in a footnote this time, after a debate within the administration, one city official said.

HEADLINE: Gorbachev Warns Against Chill in Ties

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 6

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has warned Washington that a new cold war could emerge if the Bush Administration continues to pursue political and economic steps that appear to undermine the Soviet Government, the official press agency Tass reported today.
Mr. Gorbachev also denied reports in the Western press that he was retreating from the far-reaching programs of political and economic change that he initiated when he came to power six years ago. He asked foreign countries to refrain from drawing "hasty conclusions about a 'change of course' " by the Soviet leadership. 
 The Government has been criticized lately both at home and abroad for yielding to pressure from orthodox forces like the army, the K.G.B. and Communist Party bureaucrats. Mr. Gorbachev has been offering steady rebuttals to his critics.
In his latest remarks, during a Kremlin meeting on Sunday with Rupert Murdoch, the Australian-born media executive, Mr. Gorbachev did not specify what actions Washington had taken that signaled, according to Tass, "that the U.S. is readjusting its attitude to the Soviet Union."
 
Feeling Let Down by Bush
 But Western diplomats and Soviet officials said Mr. Gorbachev and his closest advisers were dismayed by President Bush's reluctance to grant a personal request from the Soviet President for the extension of further credits for grain purchases. Mr. Bush cited the Soviet Union's failure to repay its foreign debts.
Moreover, they said, Mr. Bush's plan to meet with the Lithuanian President, Vytautas Landsbergis, in the White House on Wednesday deepens one of Mr. Gorbachev's worst political worries: the campaigns by many Soviet republics to break away from the Soviet Union. And today Mr. Bush met with Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the former Soviet Foreign Minister, who resigned from Mr. Gorbachev's Government while warning of approaching dictatorship.
Commenting on Mr. Gorbachev's remarks, a Western diplomat said: "We don't see this as a threat. We see this as an appeal.
"Let's face it," the diplomat added, "the guy is in a lot of trouble at home. Bush is saying, 'Whoa, not so fast,' when Gorbachev asks for a bigger agricultural loan. He didn't seem to make much headway when he was in Japan convincing those guys that the Soviet Union was a safe investment. And so it's only natural for him to use whatever outlet he has to get across an S.O.S."
In his meeting with Mr. Murdoch, who holds American citizenship, Mr. Gorbachev sought to underscore "the special value of relations" between the United States and the Soviet Union, Tass said. And he appealed to Washington to avoid subjecting the relationship to "unnecessary tests."
Mr. Gorbachev expressed hope that a summit meeting with Mr. Bush would take place as planned this spring in Moscow. "If what has been gained at the end of the term of the previous Administration and under President George Bush is undermined," he warned, "the world will again plunge into a 'cold' or 'semi-cold' war, into an atmosphere of political dampness that will negatively affect the health of international life as a whole."
Mr. Gorbachev implicitly acknowledged that his perestroika program may have slid momentarily backward on its path toward invigorating the moribund Soviet economy. Given the overwhelming nature of the task, he said, it is impossible to predict what pitfalls may yet await the country.
In an apparent response to charges that he has abandoned his original goals, Mr. Gorbachev said his Administration's most pressing need was "to prevent elements of chaos from escalating to catastrophic proportions."
"It is very important for the foreign public, and primarily the mass media, to understand correctly what is really happening and not to draw hasty conclusion about a 'change of course' from any new step taken by the Soviet leadership," he was quoted as saying. "It is hard to predict how many surprises life will spring on us."
But, seeking to offer reassurance, he said, "The general political choice has not changed."

HEADLINE: Shevardnadze Asks U.S. Food Credits

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the former Soviet Foreign Minister, appealed to the Bush Administration today to extend new food credits to the Soviet Union, asserting that the fate of democratic change in Moscow may be at stake.
As Mr. Shevardnadze made his remarks in his first appearance in the United States since resigning his post in December, President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania offered the opposite advice only a few blocks away during the first day of his own visit to Washington. 
 The presence of the two Soviet political figures and their conflicting views underscored a difficult choice the Administration is facing.
The Administration is nearing a decision whether to guarantee $1.5 billion in additional commercial bank loans for Soviet purchases of American grain. Mr. Bush said last week he was not inclined to authorize the guarantees, but officials said Mr. Shevardnadze might have helped sway Mr. Bush during their talks at the White House today.
The new loans would supplement $1 billion in credits guaranteed by the Commodity Credit Corporation last December when the Administration waived the restrictions prohibiting preferential trade treatment with nations that restrict emigration. Moscow has already spent nearly all of the original credits.
 
$1.5 Billion Credits Asked
 Mr. Shevardnadze linked the future of Soviet politics to the uncertain economic situation and the possibilities for increased cooperation with the West. He echoed a request that the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, made in a recent letter to the Agriculture Department for $1.5 billion in new credit guarantees.
"This is a very acute issue with us now," Mr. Shevardnadze said, "and I want to say quite straightforwardly that a decision which will be taken in Washington will to a large extent determine the fate of reform and democracy in the Soviet Union. I want to stress this, that we have very little time."
Mr. Shevardnadze, in an interview after his meeting at the White House with Mr. Bush, said he had consulted with Mr. Gorbachev before visiting Washington, but he insisted that he was not carrying a message from the Soviet leader. Mr. Shevardnadze said Mr. Bush listened attentively to his appeal but did not commit himself one way or the other.
"But I had the impression he understands how acute this question is with us," he added.
But Mr. Landsbergis said he would counsel Mr. Bush against extending new loan guarantees until Moscow liberalizes its policies. "It shouldn't be given to the Soviet Union to prevent it from adopting a path of dictatorship," he said in an interview. "It should only be given after it demonstrates that it is going down the road of democratization."
 
U.S. Recognition Urged
 Mr. Landsbergis said he would tell Mr. Bush when they meet on Wednesday that Lithuania needs Washington's formal diplomatic recognition to prevent another Soviet military crackdown against his breakaway republic. The Soviet Union annexed Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia in 1940 as a result of a secret pact with Nazi Germany.
Prime Ministers Edgar Savisaar of Estonia and Ivars Godmanis of Latvia are also scheduled to meet with Mr. Bush this week, even as American officials began analyzing the meaning of a meeting that Mr. Gorbachev had with Rupert Murdoch, the Australian media executive, in which he upbraided the Administration for pursuing policies that seemed to undercut his authority. Mr. Gorbachev's comments were carried by the Soviet press agency Tass.
A State Department official said: "There is a sensitive, delicate political balance here between supporting Baltic aspirations for independence and keeping our lines open to the Soviet leadership. That's not always easy to do."
Administration officials have said they are undecided on the latest plea for grain credits, expressing concerns that it would be unwise to extend them to Moscow at a time when its creditworthiness is questionable. "We are not helping them by creating another Poland financially," the State Department official said. But he acknowledged that Mr. Shevardnadze's advice could strengthen Mr. Gorbachev's case.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush meeting yesterday with Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the former Soviet Foreign Minister, in the Oval Office. Mr. Shevardnadze appealed to Mr. Bush to extend new food credits to the Soviet Union. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A.I.D. Is Criticized on Population Control

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
The Agency for International Development, a primary force in shaping the world's favorable attitude toward population control, is now in disarray on population matters, a private organization says in a new report.
The group, the Population Crisis Committee, said in a report issued Sunday that "over the past decade the U.S. population assistance program has been battered by ideological controversies and constrained by the creeping bureacratization which now characterizes most U.S. foreign aid efforts." 
 The group said that in four of the last five years, the Reagan and Bush Aadministrations have proposed spending less money on the program than the Congress had appropriated the previous year.
A spokesman for A.I.D., James Kunder, said in response: "Budget priorities limit a lot of worthwhile programs, both domestic and international. As the Population Crisis Committee report itself indicates, the A.I.D. population program is the leader in the world in size, quality and creativity."
The A.I.D. program provides contraceptives, technical training, research and other support for national programs around the world. The report recommended that A.I.D. broaden its approach to include injectable contraceptives, safe abortion services, adolescent education and sex education programs.
The report may be obtained from the Population Crisis Committee at 1120 19th St., N.W., Suite 550, Washington, D.C. 20036

HEADLINE: Iacocca Is Offered, but Rejects, Heinz's Seat

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, May 6

 BODY:
Under pressure to appoint a strong Democrat to replace the late Senator John Heinz, the Governor of Pennsylvania offered the post to Lee A. Iacocca, a political independent. But Mr. Iacocca, who has never held political office and lives in a Detroit suburb, turned it down.
An aide to Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania said today that the offer had been made and that Mr. Iacocca, chairman and chief executive officer of the Chrysler Corporation, "would have been a strong advocate for jobs and economic growth in Pennsylvania." The aide, David M. Stone, the Governor's chief of staff, said Mr. Casey would soon announce an alternative. 
 William J. Green, a former mayor of Philadelphia, is reportedly leading the list of candidates. But Mr. Stone would say only that Mr. Green, now a lobbyist, was on the list to succeed Senator Heinz, who was killed when the small plane in which he was a passenger collided with a helicopter near Philadelphia last month.
The Governor's offer was made earlier last week but it was not made public until today when Mr. Iacocca released a statement in Detroit.
Mr. Iacocca said that Governor Casey, a Democrat, offered him the seven-month interim appointment with the understanding that Mr. Iococca would start campaigning as a Democrat to run in the November special election, which would determine who completes the remaining three years of Senator Heinz's term. In declining the offer, Mr. Iacocca cited his age, family and corporate obligations.
"After 45 years of hard work, my family and I are looking forward to what I'll simply call a more 'normal' life," said the 66-year-old executive.
Governor Casey has been criticized for taking more than a month to make the appointment. But political analysts say he has had a hard time finding a strong candidate to run against the likely Republican contender, Dick Thornburgh, the United States Attorney General who is a former two-term governor of Pennsylvania.
"Who is Governor Casey going to offer the Senate to next? Bob Hope?" said State Senator Robert C. Jubelirer, a Republican.
Mr. Iacocca, who was born in Allentown, Pa., does not have to be a resident of the state to accept an interim appointment, but he would have had to move to Pennsylvania were he to win an election for a full term. He left Pennsylvania more than 35 years ago.
"I am depressed," said State Senator Vincent J. Fumo, a Philadelphia Democrat. "Iacocca has such national prominence I don't think Thornburgh would have dared to run against him."

HEADLINE: Landlords Plan To File Lawsuit On Rent Control

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
New York City's largest landlords' association said it will file a suit today to lift rent controls on the city's most expensive rent-controlled apartments.
The association will attempt to overturn part of the 44-year-old rent-stabilization law on the ground that the city failed to conduct its usual analysis of apartment vacancy rates to justify continued control of rent rates. 
 The rent law, established to prevent landlords from charging excessive rents on scarce housing, was to expire on April 1. The city needed to show a vacancy rate of 5 percent or less to prove that housing was still scarce enough for an emergency to be declared and to extend the law.
But because the city was unable to conduct the analysis of vacancies it usually performs every three years, it submitted the results of a much smaller analysis showing a vacancy rate of 4.2 percent in the first three months of last year.
 
After the April 1 Deadline
 In its complaint, the Rent Stabilization Association, which represents 25,000 landlords, argues that the survey did not cover housing quality, as the law requires, was of doubtful accuracy and was submitted after the April 1 deadline. A copy of the suit was made available by the association.
The landlords' suit also says that later surveys showed a vacancy rate of 5.2 percent for the last six months of last year, and argued that the most recent results should be used.
City housing officials said they had not yet seen the pending suit, and would not comment on it further.
John J. Gilbert 3d, who heads the landlords' group, said that his aim was to create classes of regulated apartments according to rental prices and decontrol only the most expensive ones, where the vacancy rate is already higher than 5 percent. The landlords have generally referred to such apartments as those that rent for $900 a month or more.
 
The Plaintiff of Record
 Mr. Gilbert said that no current occupant of a regulated apartment would be affected, and that no assault on tenant protections, which are also covered in the law, was intended.
The suit is to be filed in State Supreme Court in Queens, Mr. Gilbert said. It names Mayor David N. Dinkins, the City Council and the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which administers the rent law. George Stavroulakis, a Queens landlord, is the plaintiff of record, along with the Rent Stabilization Association.
"The focus of this suit is truly on where the benefit of rent regulations should go, and isn't it time that we re-evaluate the sacred cow called rent control?" Mr. Gilbert said yesterday.
The landlords' suit seeks to take advantage of a jam the city got into last year, when the 1990 Census coincided with the city's Housing and Vacancy Survey, last conducted in 1987. The raw data for the housing survey, which is based on 18,000 rental apartments, is provided by the Census Bureau.
The bureau asked the city to postpone the survey until the census was complete, but when the city asked the State Legislature for permission to do that, the Senate refused.
Felice Michetti, the Housing Commissioner, then asked the Census Bureau to extract the city's rental vacancy rate from information based on just 2,000 apartments. The City Council used that information to certify that a housing emergency still exists in the city, and on April 1, Mayor Dinkins signed a three-year extension of the law.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE A.T.& T.-NCR DEAL
NCR agreed to be acquired by A.T.& T. for $7.4 billion worth of A.T.& T. stock, or $110 a share, after five months of stubborn resistance. A.T.& T. is seeking a solution to its money-losing computer business and a way to expand into new markets. [Page A1.]
The acquisition finally seems to give A.T.& T. the chance for success in the computer business that it has long craved. But rivals are not trembling. [D6.] 
 Gilbert P. Williamson will become NCR's chief executive. His record as a salesman propelled his ascent. [D6.]
The multibillion-dollar acquisition is bringing a welcome stream of tens of millions of dollars in fees to Wall Street. [D6.]
 
COMPANIES
In the effort to avert failure at First Capital Life, talks between Shearson executives and regulators reportedly broke down. [D1.]
USX shareholders approved a plan to separate the company's vast energy business from its steel operations by issuing new common stock linked to its steel business. [D1.]
System 7, the upgrading of Apple's Macintosh operating system, is scheduled to be introduced Monday. [D1.]
Cadillac is putting final touches on a new Seville, G.M.'s latest attempt to win back some star billing in luxury cars. [D1.]
Pan American Satellite tried to buy ad space for a 17-frame comic strip in four newspapers, in pursuit of influence. [D2.]
Occidental Petroleum agreed to sell a half interest in its natural gas liquids business to a Texas investment company. [D4.]
Energy Service vowed a willingness to resolve differences with its partners in Penrod Drilling. [D4.]
Parretti is being forced by a lender to sell a large stake in MGM-Pathe or lose ownership control. [D18.]
Turner Broadcasting said its income fell 11.6 percent because of slightly higher interest expenses. [D19.]
A group of shareholders sought to postpone Sears's annual meeting, accusing it of failing to disclose critical information. [D4.]
Bechtel and Westinghouse hid cost overruns at the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant, the Energy Department said. [A1.]
Lee Iacocca was offered Heinz's Senate seat in Pennsylvania by the Governor, but he turned it down. [A26.]
 
THE ECONOMY
Cathleen Black will leave as publisher of USA Today to head the American Newspaper Publishers Association. [D1.]
Productivity rose at a 1 percent pace, the Labor Dept. said in the afternoon. (The discreet will not mention the figures released in the morning.) [D1.]
Sematech officials said American chip makers faced long delays, or higher prices, in trying to buy advanced equipment from five Japanese companies. [D4.]
 
MARKETS
Stock prices showed little reaction to Bush's heart problem. The Dow ended the day at 2,941.64, up 2.78. [D8.]
Prices of Treasury securities were unchanged to slightly higher in slow trading, as dealers bided their time. [D16.]
Platinum prices rose sharply on fears that unrest in the Soviet Union and South Africa could interrupt supplies. [D17.] The dollar closed lower after fluctuating. [D17.]

All eyes are on home construction as the recession enters its 10th month. Louis Uchitelle: Business Scene. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Reagan Guest Stars Before the California Assembly

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 6

 BODY:
In his first appearance at the Capitol since his terms as California Governor, a nostalgic Ronald Reagan today stepped lightly over the state's budget deficit and instead celebrated the California that "encourages the dreamer in us all."
The 80-year-old former President addressed a rare joint session of the state Legislature, at the invitation of the Democratic leadership of the Assembly, and used the occasion to tell self-deprecating jokes, campaign for the gun-control bill that is before Congress and commiserate without offering advice about the state's $12.6 billion budget deficit. 
 The day had more ceremony than substance for Mr. Reagan, who was accompanied by his wife, Nancy. It was a time for proclamations and plaques, toasts from the lawmakers and small talk with the current Governor, Pete Wilson, who was a cub assemblyman here in 1967 when a former actor took leadership of the nation's most populous state. Mr. Reagan was mellow and platitudinous throughout his 15-minute speech, stumbling from time to time as he read from a printed text, but winning laughs with jokes about his age and current status of unemployment.
In the weeks leading up to the speech, political observers here said, Governor Wilson was concerned that Mr. Reagan would fan the partisan fires in the capital just as budget talks reached a critical juncture.
While Mr. Wilson fretted, some lawmakers here speculated that Mr. Reagan, who began his tenure as Governor with a record $1 billion tax increase, might endorse Mr. Wilson's call for a $6.7 billon rise in taxes. Such a move would offer Mr. Wilson, a moderate Republican, the necessary political cover.
Those hopes were dashed by Mr. Reagan's innocuous reference to the state's budget crisis. First he tweaked Mr. Wilson for the heap of problems he inherited on taking office in January, including "a continuing drought and an exploding deficit."
"What's next, Pete?" he asked. "A swarm of locusts?"
Later, in a more serious vein, Mr. Reagan said that while the state's budget was California's most pressing challenge, "I'm not here to tell either the Governor or the Legislature how to do their work."
Mr. Reagan was more forceful about the gun-control bill named for James S. Brady, his former press secretary who was wounded in an assassination attempt on the President in 1981. Mr. Reagan recently reversed course and endorsed the bill, making it easier for Republican lawmakers to buck the right wing of the party and support it.
Except for endorsing the Brady bill, Mr. Reagan took no stands and stirred no controversy, choosing instead to reminisce about his tenure as Governor, to quote Winston Churchill and to speak fondly of his "friends" Margaret Thatcher and Mikhail Gorbachev.
That, apparently, was what the Assembly leaders had in mind when they invited Mr. Reagan, an invitation that was tendered during a golfing outing with Mike Roos, who recently quit the Assembly to run an education organization in Los Angeles.
"In terms of the institution of state government," Mr. Roos said, "it is a healthy and appropriate courtesy that he revisit the place where he launched his career."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 8, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A headline yesterday about a speech by Ronald Reagan referred incorrectly to his audience. It was a joint session of the California Legislature, not just the Assembly.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Newly Confident Hussein Takes Show on the Road

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 6

 BODY:
After waving silently for several minutes to an enthusiastic but organized crowd in the northern city of Mosul over the weekend, President Saddam Hussein performed his new trick.
In the televised appearance, he suddenly took out his pistol and began firing shots over the heads of the people. The crowd went wild, leaping up and down as they chanted a rhythmic Arabic refrain: "Bush, Bush listen carefully. We all love Saddam Hussein." 
 The shots-in-the-air routine is a recent twist in the President's public relations style. It was noted for the first time on Wednesday when Iraqi television showed him drawing his pistol in the western city of Ramadi and again on Friday when he started shooting on a visit to the town of Baguba.
Iraqis say the shots are a gesture of defiance toward the United States and its allies, a reminder of the President's claim that he has resisted the forces of imperialism and Zionism, a part of the Orwellian rewriting of history under way here as Iraq -- and indeed the world -- comes to terms with the fact that Mr. Hussein has survived the Persian Gulf war and seems almost as firmly in power as ever.
As allied forces continue to occupy parts of the country, newspapers, television and loyal officials present Iraq as the aggrieved rather than the aggressor, never mentioning Kuwait but claiming that the country successfully resisted the American-led attack because Mr. Hussein is still there to prove it. Even the manifest damage Iraq has suffered is presented as a worthwhile price for defending a just cause.
Prime Minister Saadun Hamadi said recently on television, "Iraq has paid a price for a just and noble aim -- resisting imperialism, Zionism and the old system."
 
Atmosphere Grows Heavier
 Middle-class Iraqis are not taken in by such assertions. But as the President recovers his self-confidence and appears more frequently in public, foreigners who have been here since the war say the atmosphere is growing heavy again, with people no longer willing to talk as freely as they did just after the fighting.
Soviet diplomats, who were here throughout the war, say they are not surprised. There was a brief "Baghdad spring" when people voiced dissent openly on the capital's streets, but that is disappearing now after the crushing of the Shiite uprising in the south last month and another rebellion in the Kurdish north.
The President remains firmly in control through his tight family lock on the army and security services, though aided, Soviet diplomats say, by the essentially unpolitical nature of many Iraqis whose primary demand from their leaders is that they provide them with a tolerable life.
And that is clearly the Government's first priority. Nothing did more for Iraqi morale than the lifting of gasoline rationing on the President's birthday last month. Electricity and clean water are returning rapidly. And even the heavily bombed telephone system is starting to work again.
The pace of recovery here is astonishing United Nations relief officials who have been planning assistance on a scale that they now say will probably be unnecessary.
 
Censorship Is Eased
 A major factor, these officials believe, is a Iraq's policy of manufacturing at least part of many sophisticated Western machines it imports. This has allowed it to repair much of the damage done by the allied bombardment without the need to import goods from abroad.
Another sign of a return to normalcy came on Sunday with the lifting of censorship and many other restrictions imposed on visiting journalists during the gulf war.
Yet it is hard to believe the future is going to be quite like the past, for Mr. Hussein's Government clearly faces challenges that were not there before.
The President's three outings last week, his first attempts to mobilize large-scale public support since the war, were all to cities in Iraq's Sunni heartland, his power base. He has yet to try anything similar in the less loyal north and south, although before the war such demonstrations were arranged regularly in those regions.
 
Bush's Call Exploited
 Paradoxically, President Bush may have helped consolidate Mr. Hussein's position, Iraqi officials say, when he called on the Iraqi people to remove their leader. Iran exploited the call by helping to stir up rebellion in the south and the north, which rallied the country's Sunni center to the President's flag.
By moving swiftly to make peace with the rebellious Kurds, as Mr. Hussein did in talks last month that produced the tentative outline of a peace accord, the Iraqi President has shown that he does not want to face insurrection on two fronts again and that he is anxious to get sanctions lifted and start the petro dollars flowing again.
Yet the sudden hesitancy of major Kurdish opposition groups to attend follow-up peace talks is seen by many here as a sign they are in no hurry to strike a deal with a Government that they believe is weaker than it pretends to be.
While sanctions remain, inflation is likely to continue and unemployment seems set to rise. The volume of complaints carried in the Government-controlled press about the pace of price increases suggests that this is the consuming worry of most people.
In a televised pep talk he gave to a group of leading Mosul citizens on Saturday, President Hussein seemed to concede the sensitivity of the issue. Picking up a glass ashtray, he noted that it came from France and had to be paid for in francs. But Iraq has no francs because it cannot sell oil, so it cannot import and shortages develop, pushing prices skyward.
In the past, the President recalled, he and the ruling Baath Party had "interfered" in economic policy. But no more. Inflation, he said, is "a technical matter" that should be left to the relevant technocrats, the Cabinet ministers in charge of the economy.
In effect, President Hussein was excusing himself and his party from any responsibility for economic problems resulting from the crisis precipitated by his forces' occupation of Kuwait.
While inflation is visible and rampant, unemployment looks like a sleeper about the wake up. "Where there were five employees we now have three," a Government clerk said recently. Correspondents flying over northern Iraq last week noted no sign of activity at several large factories untouched by allied bombing.
 
Changing National Interests
 With no oil money to hand out, the Iraqi Government is tacitly admitting past mistakes and offering the people more democracy and better administration instead. A new constitution, a multiparty system, free elections and a free press are all promised for this year.
The few middle-class Iraqis with whom a foreigner is able to speak at length about such matters seem unimpressed, usually saying that they doubt the power structure will change significantly.
This cynicism, while understandable, might just prove exaggerated. Iraq's national interests seem about to change as a result of the difficult terms the United Nations Security Council is imposing in return for lifting sanctions.
In the past, President Hussein presided over a country that was the strongest military power in the region and also one of the richest. But burdened by a continuing military embargo and reparation payments to Kuwait, the Government may find it expedient to strike up some new and more cooperative relationship with its own people as well as with its neighbors.
This is probably what Prime Minister Hamadi had in mind at a recent press conference when he admitted that "a debate" was under way within the leadership about the long-term consequences of the lost Persian Gulf war for Iraq.
