HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Change at Top of Publishers Group

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, May 6

 BODY:
The American Newspaper Publishers Association announced today that Cathleen Black would leave her position as publisher of USA Today to become the association's president and chief executive.
Hard economic times in the newspaper business have turned the annual convention of the association into a call to arms for sweeping change that many publishers say is long overdue. The appointment of Ms. Black, who is 47 years old and considered one of the industry's savviest figures, is emblematic of this new thinking. 
 The job of chief executive is a new position, and the association's top leaders said that when she assumes her duties on June 17 they expect Ms. Black to function as a very visible advocate for the industry and to reflect a new marketing sophistication.
 
New Publisher at USA Today
 Thomas Curley, 42, the chief operating officer of USA Today, will succeed Ms. Black as president and publisher.
John Morton, a newspaper analyst for Lynch, Jones & Ryan in Washington, said USA Today would miss Ms. Black's strong standing on Madison Avenue, which is particularly important because USA Today publishes almost all national advertising in competition with magazines. "Tom does not have that background," Mr. Morton said, "but that doesn't mean he won't do well."
Widespread declines in advertising and earnings at many papers have prompted what many here describe as an unprecedented determination to rethink every aspect of the newspaper business and to come to grips with a new marketplace of very demanding advertisers and increasingly elusive readers. Ms. Black has taken a leading role in this rethinking.
"This recession has been a blessing that forced us to focus on a new world," Lloyd G. Schermer, the association's chairman, said in his keynote speech today at the opening of the publishers convention here.
Mr. Schermer, who is chairman of Lee Enterprises Inc., a newspaper chain based in Davenport, Iowa, added that newspapers could cling to "the old world of our memory" only at their peril.
The association's 1,400 members include most of the daily papers in the United States and Canada.
 
Strengthening Trade Groups
 The appointment of Ms. Black is part of a far-reaching effort by the nation's newspaper publishers to strengthen and integrate the industry's plethora of specialized support and trade organizations.
Traditionally, there have been separate -- and often overlapping -- organizations that served both as fraternal bodies and industry research groups. For instance, the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, the International Newspaper Advertising and Marketing Executives, the International Newspaper Marketing Association and the International Circulation Managers Association are separate organizations, each with membership fees and a specialized agenda.
Many publishers have been critical of the arrangement both because it was expensive and because the organizations tended not to pool their expertise for maximum results.
A study by Booz, Allen & Hamilton, the management consultants, has prompted an effort by the publishers to consolidate all the marketing-related organizations into the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. This group, in turn, would work with the publishers association, which the study said should be headed by a strong chief executive who could speak for the entire industry.
 
Vision of New Role
 Ms. Black, who has spent several years on the board of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, said her new job was "to try to give a sense of energy and vitality and direction" to the industry.
She said her role would range from active lobbying in Congress on behalf of newspapers to pushing for greater representation for women and ethnic minorities in the industry.
Indeed, Ms. Black said she was "totally committed" to diversity. About half the nation's newspapers have no minorities working in newsrooms.
Mr. Morton, the newspaper analyst, said he was somewhat surprised that the association had chosen Ms. Black, most of whose career has been spent in magazine publishing, over James Hoge, who, he added, was her principal competition for the position.
 
Other Candidates Not Named
 The association did not divulge other candidates' names but Mr. Hoge, who is the publisher of The Daily News in New York, is said by people who know him to be interested in taking another position after the 21-week strike by Daily News unions that ended in March with the sale of the paper to Robert Maxwell. Mr. Hoge was previously publisher of The Chicago Sun-Times. Attempts to contact Mr. Hoge, including a phone call to his home, were unsuccessful. A Daily News spokeswoman said at the end of April that he was on a six-week vacation.
Jerry W. Friedheim, who was the association's president for 16 years and is being replaced by Ms. Black, will become a general executive at the Gannett Foundation, a philanthropic organization founded by the Gannett Company that promotes First Amendment values.
Ms. Black began her career with USA Today when it was just starting up. In 1983, when she was publisher of New York magazine, she was hired by Allen H. Neuharth, then chairman of Gannett, to be president of the newspaper. She had been the first woman to be publisher of a weekly consumer magazine.
 
Promoted to Publisher in 1984
 Ms. Black was promoted to publisher of USA Today in 1984 and one year later became a member of the Gannett board, which she will now leave.
Although USA Today has become a popular success, with circulation of 1.8 million, it has never made an annual profit. A USA Today spokesman said advertising pages declined in 1990 by 9 percent, although advertising revenue increased slightly. Ad pages also declined in 1989.
Thomas Curley, Ms. Black's replacement at USA Today, is the brother of John J. Curley, who replaced Mr. Neuharth as chairman in 1989. Ms. Black and Thomas Curley reported separately to John Curley.
Relations between John Curley and Mr. Neuharth, who is now chairman of the Gannett Foundation, have been strained in the last year because of Mr. Neuharth's decision to sell the foundation's 10 percent stake in Gannett to the highest bidder.
In late April, an agreement was announced that subject to Government approval, Gannett itself would acquire the foundation's stock and right to its name for $670 million.
 
Gannett Statement
 In a statement today, John Curley said that the company would miss Ms. Black and that her "intelligence, enthusiasm and vitality are exactly what the newspaper industry needs."
His brother, Thomas Curley, joined USA Today in June 1985 as assistant to the president and became executive vice president and general manager in December 1985. Four months later he became president of the paper and, two years after that, its chief operating officer as well.
He was director of research at Gannett in 1979, when Mr. Neuharth asked him and three other executives to figure out whether a national newspaper was a viable idea. That research project provided the data on newspaper reading habits that formed the cornerstone on which USA Today was based.
 
USA Today's New Structure
 He recently delegated primary responsibility for advertising at USA Today to Carolyn F. Vester, whom he appointed to a new position of senior vice president and associate publisher. But, since Ms. Vester will report to him, Mr. Curley now pretty much runs everything at USA Today but the news room.
To him, that represents the rationalization of a badly fragmented structure. "Finally we are setting up a structure that is normal for a newspaper," Mr. Curley said. "No longer will advertising and circulation people, say, call on the same customers because they are just not communicating."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
More Green For Less Gold

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
AS many a candidate for public office has discovered, green is beautiful: Voters much prefer their air pristine, their water potable and their garbage somewhere else. What elected officials are also discovering is that green can be expensive: According to the Environmental Protection Agency, Americans spend $100 billion annually to comply with Federal environmental rules.
That is why Washington now seems almost as interested in how to clean up as what to clean up -- and why the initial Project 88 report, released on the eve of President Bush's inauguration, caught the political wave. 
 The brainchild of two ambitious Senators, Tim Wirth of Colorado and the late John Heinz of Pennsylvania, Project 88 made a case for market-based incentives as a cheaper, less intrusive alternative to traditional pollution regulation. Round 2 of the project, released this week, offers more specific advice for environmentalists eager to tame the capitalist beast without rendering it lame.
Before the mid-1980's, environmental politics was about us versus them. They were chopping down our rain forests, poisoning our rivers and coating our sea otters in crude oil. Government's job was to stop them.
Now the battle lines are blurred. Companies are scrambling to become greener-than-thou: products once touted as "new and improved" are now "recyclable" or "biodegradable." By the same token, there is greater public recognition that the environmental lunch is not free; sometimes the price of clean is higher taxes and higher prices.
Political momentum for environmental change has not ebbed. But it is dawning on Democrats, as well as Republicans, that the greatest political rewards may well be reaped by those who worry about the costs as well as the benefits.
The first Project 88 report, written by Robert Stavins of the Kennedy School of Public Policy at Harvard, offered ways to think about a laundry list of problems from radon pollution to wetland conservation. The message, that market-linked financial incentives could be a cheap, effective alternative to "command" regulation, was no revelation to economists. But it did impress the target audience, environmental professionals and lawmakers who want the job done with minimal disruption to business, consumers and the Government budget.
One area where the report apparently influenced votes was in the acid-rain provisions in last year's amendments to the Clean Air Act. The "get the bad guys" approach of the original act set standards for sulfur emissions from power plants. Rather than merely tightening those standards, forcing older plants to be rebuilt at great expense, the new law limited total sulfur emissions and gave polluters discretion in how to comply collectively.
Rights to pollute can now be traded, giving polluters an incentive to close exceptionally dirty plants and sell their emissions rights to those who value them more. In some cases, it may even pay utilities to subsidize customer conservation rather than build cleaner plants or buy the right to pollute from someone else. The estimated savings to utility stockholders and electricity consumers will run to about $1 billion a year.
Round 2, again drafted by Mr. Stavins, digs a little deeper than the original report. The chapter on greenhouse warming, drawn largely from the work of Dan Dudek of the Environmental Defense Fund, Lawrence Goulder of Stanford University and Ralph Cavanagh of the Natural Resources Defense Council, is particularly intriguing.
International limits on greenhouse gases, it suggests, would be more cheaply carried out if emissions rights could be traded among nations. This would allow countries to buy rights from others that are prepared, say, to switch to nuclear power or to plant trees. Poor countries might be compensated with a disproportionate share of rights in the initial allocation, giving them the choice of polluting more or raising capital by selling their permits.
The report makes a case for fuel taxes in proportion to the amount of carbon dioxide the fuels put into the air. The revenue, the report suggests, could be used dollar-for-dollar to reduce other taxes, offsetting the regressive nature of carbon taxes and perhaps reducing market distortions that impair economic efficiency.
There is too little detail here to weigh the merits of these policy prescriptions. But it would be a mistake to think of Round 2 as simply a cookbook, to be judged by the completeness of the recipes. Project 88 is a sign of the growing economic savvy of the environmental movement, recognition that there is more to good environmental policy than just saying no.

HEADLINE: Bank Funds and C.D.'s Fall In Yield for the 10th Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts plunged in the week ended yesterday for the 10th consecutive decline.
The size of the weekly declines had been getting smaller until last week, when banks cut their prime rates in response to a cut in the discount rate by the Federal Reserve the week before. 
 Analysts at The Bank Rate Monitor said that consequently only a few banks and savings institutions cut deposit yields. Many did not have an opportunity to change rates between the two cuts, and thus, the sharp drop in yields this week.
 
Plunge in Discount Rate
 At the Treasury Department's weekly auction held Monday, the average discount rate fell sharply, to the lowest levels in three years. The results of these bill auctions often indicate what many banks may eventually pay on money market accounts and certificates of deposit.
The three-month bill fell by 10 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.50 percent, while the six-month bill fell seven basis points, to 5.61 percent.
In The Bank Rate Monitor's weekly survey of New York area banks, declines reported at commercial banks and savings insitutions were moderate to sharper.
The largest yield changes in the New York area this week were recorded at the Banco Popular de Puerto Rico, which cut its money market account by 53 basis points, to 5.39 percent, and the People's Bank in Connecticut, which cut its three-month certificate by 37 basis points, to 5.92 percent, and six-month certificate by 26 basis points, to 6.08 percent.
Commercial banks, which cut their deposit yields deeper than savings institutions, lowered the average money market account by 11 basis points, to 5.27 percent, lowering three-month certificates by 10 basis points, to 5.68 percent, and six-month ceritificates by 11 basis points, to 5.82 percent.
Savings institutions did litle to change money market yields, and left the average unchanged at 5.74 percent. However, they did cut C.D. yields. A three-month certificate fell 9 basis points, to 6.06 percent, while a six-month certificate fell 10 basis points, to 6.28 percent.
At 20 large banks around the country, but outside the New York area, the average money market account yield fell by four basis points, to 5.32 percent, while the average yield for a six-month certificate, dropped by nine basis points, to 5.88 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off Amid Concerns About an Interest Rate Drop

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed lower yesterday, nudged downward by lingering concerns about President Bush's health and a possible decline in interest rates.
Gold prices rose in overseas and domestic trading. In New York, gold picked up $1.10 on the Commodity Exchange, to close at $356.50 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $356.30, up $1.05. 
 Although President Bush's heart rhythm was normal for a second day, traders remained uneasy after the President's weekend hospitalization, said Earl I. Johnson, a vice president with the Harris Trust and Company in Chicago.
Mr. Bush went to Bethesda Naval Hospital on Saturday with an irregular heartbeat, which doctors stabilized on Monday with drugs.
The dollar was also depressed by talk of interest rate increases in Germany that helped lift the German mark, analysts said.
The mark, like all currencies, is supported by higher rates, which make a country's investments more attractive. An increase in German rates would be a positive sign for the mark, and a negative for the dollar and other currencies backed by lower rates.
The dollar fell to 1.7175 marks in New York, from 1.7325 marks late on Monday. In earlier European trading, the dollar slumped to 1.7210 marks from 1.7430 marks.
The dollar was further hurt by the belief that United States rates would continue to fall because of the recession. Although the unemployment rate declined last month to 6.6 percent from 6.8 percent in March, the economy remains weak and traders fear the Federal Reserve will push interest rates lower, Mr. Johnson said.
Traders were waiting for the next economic report on Friday, when the Labor Department will release producer price figures for April.
The dollar fell to 137.80 Japanese yen in New York from late Monday's 138.19. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose to a closing 138.42 Japanese yen, from 137.68 yen at the close Thursday, the last day of trading before a holiday weekend. Later in London, it fell to 137.90 yen.
The British pound gained against the dollar, rising to $1.7275 in New York, from $1.7100 late Monday. In earlier London trading, sterling rose to $1.7205, from $1.6990 at Monday's close in Europe. London markets were closed for a holiday on Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Monday, included: 1.4530 Swiss francs, down from 1.4675; 5.8155 French francs, down from 5.8625; 1,2700.50 Italian lire, down from 1,282.25, and 1.15105 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15055.

HEADLINE: Reynolds Grant to School: A Pilot Program or a Peril?

 BODY:
A proposed North Carolina public school that was hailed recently as a winner in the RJR Nabisco Foundation's Next Century Schools competition for innovative school proposals is now being criticized for its plan to set aside up to 60 percent of its seats for children of employees of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company.
At issue is the Integrated Learning Center, an elementary school that will open in Winston-Salem this fall in an old factory building that Reynolds sold to the county last year. The plan is to have a year-round, 11-hour-a-day school that will serve people who work in a nearby business. Over the next three years the foundation will provide $750,000 and Reynolds Tobacco an additional $250,000 of the school's $3.6 million budget. 
 The foundation is the philanthropic division of RJR Nabisco, the conglomerate that owns Reynolds Tobacco. The foundation's Next Century Schools awards are intended to give substantial grants to public schools that develop innovative "risk-taking" programs. This year, the second for the contest, $9.7 million in grants was distributed to 15 public schools nationwide.
This year the contest drew more than 1,600 entries, and critics questionwhether it is merely coincidence, as the foundation contends, that one of 15 winning proposals will directly benefit its employees.
 
Dangerous Precedent Feared
 More fundamentally, the critics fear that as school districts take up President Bush's call to expand partnerships with business, it may set a dangerous precedent of exchanging benefits for support.
At issue is the concept that public schools should offer equal access and equal opportunity to every student, said James C. Shields, executive director of the North Carolina Civil Liberties Union. "If Reynolds wants to set up its own school, it should go ahead and do that," he said. "It seems to be using a public school to provide an employee benefit."
Colleen O'Connor, a spokeswoman for the American Civil Liberties Union, added that the plan could create inequalities, with the children of employees of major companies receiving a better education than those whose parents work for smaller companies or who are unemployed.
But officials of the Forsyth County School District where the school will be situated scoffed at the idea that the school amounts to a private institution for Reynolds employees. Susan Carson, a spokeswoman for the district, said the school would only serve 360 students, as many as 216 from Reynolds and the rest chosen by lottery from throughout the county.
"Reynolds has 8,000 employees," she said, "so this could actually create problems for them among all those whose children can't get in."
 
Link With Working Parents
 Ms. Carson said a principal aim of the school was to provide a closer connection between students and their working parents. The Integrated Learning Center will be within five blocks of the Reynolds headquarters, and the company has agreed to release employees to attend school functions, meet with teachers or even have lunch with their children.
"This plan would not work if we opened up to all 38,000 children in the district and got very few Reynolds kids," said Ms. Carson.
Noting that from 70 to 80 percent of the mothers in Forsyth County work, Ms. Carson said the new school would be a response to fundamental changes in American society. "The home used to be the center of family life," she said. "But now both parents usually work and so we should begin thinking of building schools near workplaces and assigning kids not based on where they live but where their parents work."
The school will also try to provide a closer link between the classroom and the Reynolds workplace, she said. Reynolds employees are to serve as "coaches" and meet with a group of 15 students once a week. People from the advertising department, for example, can explain how they use writing skills in their work; chemists can discuss practical applications of science, and people from the graphics department can show how they use computers.
"We still have to see if this concept works," Ms. Carson said. "But we fully expect it will and we already have another site in mind where we can replicate it."

HEADLINE: Fed Nominee Discusses Rate Cuts

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
Lawrence Lindsey, nominated to be a Federal Reserve Board governor, suggested to the Senate Banking Committee today that he would have cut interest rates more than the Fed did last fall. But he also endorsed the Fed's most recent rate cuts as adequate for the moment, and he hesitated to say the economy was now in recession.
"Certainly it was in recession in the first quarter," and it "probably" is now, although recovery appears near, Mr. Lindsey said at a two-and-a-half-hour confirmation hearing. 
 Committee members, Republicans and Democrats alike, were not so optimistic. They used the hearing to criticize the Fed for letting a slowdown turn into a recession out of reluctance to lower rates more quickly.
 
Pondering a Vote
 After the hearing, Donald W. Riegle, the Michigan Democrat who is the committee's chairman, said he was not yet persuaded to favor the nomination. "I want to think about what he said," Mr. Riegle said.
Two Republicans, Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico and John W. Warner of Virginia, said they favored the nomination.
Mr. Riegle and Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, also noted that Mr. Lindsey, a Harvard economics professor on leave to serve as an adviser to President Bush, was nominated to the Fed from the Richmond district, although he has lived in Richmond only in the last five years.
"I don't see how you, by any stretch of the imagination, could say that you participated in the economic life of Richmond," Mr. Sarbanes said. Mr. Lindsey, 36 years old, had just acknowledged that his Virginia participation was mainly as a homeowner and payer of property taxes.
Mr. Riegle said the hearing was especially important because of the recession. Indeed, concern over the recession, and what the Fed might have done to provoke it, dominated the hearing.
 
Adjusting Interest Rates
 The Fed deals with inflation by raising interest rates, or holding them steady, to dampen demand and with it economic activity. Only since December has it been pushing rates down sharply to stimulate borrowing and purchases, and reverse the recession that began in July.
"It became obvious to me in the middle of last year that we had a serious problem, and I admonished Greenspan that the danger was a recession, not inflation," said Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, referring to Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman
Mr. Domenici charged that the Fed's governors and regional bank presidents "are like the Germans; they have an almost total fear of inflation."
Mr. Lindsey declined, on several occasions, to say inflation should not be a prime concern of Fed policy makers. He said that in the short term, he would react to such things as growth in the money supply and the growth rate of the overall economy. Weak money supply growth last year would have prompted him to lower rates more than the Fed actually did in the fall, Mr. Lindsey suggested.
 
Examining Past Policy
 "In hindsight," he said, "money growth was too slow in the last three quarters of 1990 and to some extent this problem has been rectified."
But he repeatedly invoked an argument often heard from Mr. Greenspan and other Fed officials: that the Fed must concern itself with long-term growth free of inflation. He talked, as Fed officials often do, of achieving a balance in which growth is not so rapid and inflationary that it drives up long-term interest rates. In the end, he said, long-term rates govern corporate America's willingness to invest in new factories and equipment and make the economy grow.
Mr. Lindsey is an advocate of supply-side economics, which holds among other things that tax cuts stimulate investment and economic growth. His recent book, "The Growth Experiment," argues the supply-side case. Senator Riegle took issue with some of the assertions in the book, declaring that if Mr. Lindsey still believed them, then "I would be inclined to vote against you." One assertion, for example, was that the Reagan tax cuts contributed only "trivially" to the budget deficits of the 1980's.
Mr. Lindsey assured the committee that as a Bush official he operates with an open mind and as a Fed governor he would also be open to many viewpoints.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
3-Year Notes Sell Well, but Rates Go Up

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The first leg of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions was fairly well received yesterday, but Wall Street traders, fearing that coming sales of more speculative securities might not go well, sold outstanding issues of Treasury securities, pushing down prices and raising interest rates.
As expected, demand was good for the $13.5 billion worth of three-year notes auctioned yesterday. The securities were sold at an average yield of 7.09 percent, up from an average yield of 6.98 percent at the last three-year note sale on Feb. 5. 
 The average yield was about what had been expected, but in when-issued trading after the results were announced, yields on the new three-year notes moved a bit higher. By late in the day, the issue was offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.11 percent.
 
'A Sense of Concern'
 "The sheer magnitude of the issue dragged it down," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets. "Once it became clear that the market was going to have some trouble distributing the three-year, that dragged the rest of the market down, and created a sense of concern."
Indeed, credit market participants said the outlook for today's sale of $11.75 billion of new 10-year notes and an auction tomorrow of $11.75 billion of 30-year bonds was far more problematic.
"These rate levels are very attractive," a government bond dealer said. "But the Street will need to see customers show up and buy the 10-year before it feels more comfortable."
However, some money managers said rates would probably have to move a bit higher to attract buyers to the 10-year and 30-year auctions.
"After this auction, I think those securities will have to move a few more basis points higher," one portfolio manager said. "I wouldn't be at all surprised to see the 10-year go at a yield of 8 1/8 percent, and a yield of at least 8.25 percent for the bond."
By late yesterday, the 10-year notes to be sold today were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.05 percent. The 30-year bonds were offered at a price to yield 8.22 percent.
 
Consumer Credit Declines
 A Government report showing that consumer credit outstanding fell by just under $1 billion in March, the fourth straight monthly drop, had no impact on prices in the credit markets.
Despite the lack of a reaction, analysts at Stone & McCarthy noted that it was the first time since the spring of 1980, when President Jimmy Carter imposed credit controls, that consumer credit had declined for four consecutive months. The only other previous period when that occurred was during the recession of 1958, the analysts said.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 95 30/32 late yesterday, down 10/ 32, to yield 8.24 percent, up from 8.21 percent late Monday.
Among note issues, the 7 5/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 26/ 32, down 1/8 point, to yield 7.67 percent. And the 7 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 11/32, down 1/32, to yield 6.81 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose modestly. By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.50 percent, up two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by four basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.63 percent.
 
Offering by Harsco
 In deference to the huge volume of new Treasury debt, only a smattering of investment-grade corporates and municipal debt offerings were priced yesterday.
Among the corporate deals was a $100 million offering of five-year notes for the Harsco Corporation. The 8 3/4 percent notes were priced at $99.92 to yield 8.77 percent, 1.10 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 5/8 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A-minus by Standard & Poor's.
Activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market was highlighted by a competitive sale of $320 million worth of securities issued by the State of Pennsylvania. A bid by an investor group led by Goldman, Sachs won the securities. The issue consists of serial bonds with maturities from 1992 to 2011. The bonds were reoffered with yields from 4.50 percent in 1992 to 6.85 percent in 2011.
Investment bankers involved in the transaction said that as of late yesterday only $66 million of the bonds remained unsold. The securities are rated A-1 by Moody's and AA-minus by Standard & Poor's.
In addition, Paine Webber Inc. acted as lead manager on a negotiated sale of $98.45 million worth of bonds for the Connecticut Housing Authority. The issue consists of serial bonds with maturities from 1996 to 2003, and term bonds maturing in 2008 and 2009.
The serial bonds, which are subject to alternative minimum tax provisions, carry yields from 5.90 percent in 1993 to 6.75 percent in 2003. The term bond maturing in 2008 is also subject to alternative minimum tax provisions. It was priced to yield 7.20 percent. The term bond in 2009, which is not subject to the alternative minimum tax, was priced to yield 7 percent.
The issue is rated AA by Moody's and AA-plus by Standard & Poor's.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues fell by about 1/8 of a point in quiet trading.
Prices of widely quoted tax-exempt municipal securities rose by 1/4 point to 3/8 point, traders said.

HEADLINE: A Union Agrees To a Times Plan To Reduce Staff

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
The New York Times and the Newspaper Guild reached an agreement yesterday in which the company will offer cash incentives to employees who are over age 55 with 15 years' experience and who agree to retire.
Times officials said that 300 employees were eligible under the program but that the company intended to limit the number who accept the incentives, known as buyouts, to 125. They work in departments in the guild's jurisdiction, which covers the newspaper's clerical, commercial, news and editorial staffs. 
 John M. O'Brien, the senior vice president for finance and human resources, said the company had offered the buyouts because poor economic conditions had made it necessary to reduce the newspaper's staff.
 
Layoffs Announced in March
 The agreement comes seven weeks after The Times announced a layoff of 61 employees, all guild members. Times officials said that no reporters or editors were in that group.
Of the 61, Mr. O'Brien said yesterday, four have been rehired for other jobs. The rest, guild officials said, are on a waiting list to be rehired if jobs became available.
The layoffs, which were announced March 21, came after the paper and the guild failed to reach an accord in earlier negotiations aimed at arranging buyouts. At the time the publisher, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, said that if the guild did not reconsider and agree to a buyout program, "additional layoffs will have to be considered."
A sticking point in the March talks was how much the company would contribute in benefits for employees who agreed to buyouts. Yesterday both sides said that the company had agreed to make payments in advance to the health, welfare and pension funds for workers who accept a buyout.
The payments will be based on how much the company would have contributed for each of the employees if they had stayed with the company for five years or until they reached age 65, whichever comes first. The buyout offer provides three weeks' pay for every year's service up to 78 weeks, which means a maximum of one and a half year's salary.
 
Union 'Very Pleased'
 Barry Lipton, president of Local 3 of the Newspaper Guild, said the union had tried and failed to persuade The Times to cancel the 61 layoffs or convert them to buyouts. But he added, "We're very pleased that we'll be able to use this voluntary buyout in an effort to avoid any more involuntary layoffs."
Mr. O'Brien said that if the sign-up exceeded the company's limit, the buyouts would go to employees with the longest service on the paper.
Times officials said they expected that some news department employees would elect to leave under the buyout plan. But the officials said they did not know how many might do so. They said that they had tried to set some limits in specific areas of the newsgathering operation that would let workers who are eligible take a buyout but also insure that the quality of the newsgathering operation would not be affected.
In March, the paper went ahead with a buyout offer to managers and other guild-exempt employees. Mr. O'Brien said yesterday that 80 such workers were eligible. But he added that he would not know how many had decided to accept the buyouts until a sign-up period ends later in the month.
